column2: LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Six Jesuit priests in San Salvador were killed by what one witness described as a group of 30 men dressed in military uniforms. Page A1

LEAD: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved Vaughn R. Walker's nomination as a Federal judge, ending a deadlock that had lasted almost two years because of his membership in a club that excluded blacks and women. The vote was 11 to 2.

LEAD: A reading of a two-character play based on the autobiography of Audrey Wood, the literary agent, will be presented at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, at 8 P.M. Nov. 27. The work, arranged by Max Wilk and performed by Tandy Cronyn and Jeffrey De Munn, is called ''Mr. Williams and Miss Wood'' and deals with the 30-year relationship between the playwright Tennessee Williams and his agent.

LEAD: IF a customer buys a box of corn flakes and finds less than the label promised, a refund can be expected and obtained. But on Wall Street, things are not so easy, and some buyers of new shares in TW Holdings Inc. are furious.
LEAD: The Bush Administration today condemned the killing of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador and said it had asked President Alfredo Cristiani to order a full inquiry.

LEAD: More than one million public-school students and their parents across the state are receiving ''report cards'' this week that for the first time give a measure of the quality of schools and how well they have succeeded in helping children learn.

LEAD: Standing seven-deep in a line that stretched for three blocks, more than 6,000 police officers today mourned one of the two New York City detectives who were shot to death by a prisoner on Monday in Queens.

LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company yesterday reported record first-quarter earnings of $83 million, or 64 cents a share, a sharp contrast to its fiscal 1989 full-year earnings, which were hurt by large restructuring costs.

LEAD: Judging by the jammed parking lot at the Fairfield Inn here, one might think that the budget hotel business is flourishing. But now, with more than 50 such chains in business, the supply of inexpensive rooms is beginning to outstrip even the surging demand for them, and occupancy levels and profits are sliding.

LEAD: Bulgaria's Communists swept out much of their old guard today, leaving no doubt that they wished to break from the hard-line orthodoxy followed for 35 years by Todor I. Zhivkov, their leader who was recently removed.

LEAD: Sydney Drazen, a former president of Tepper Galleries, an auctioneering and appraising concern in Manhattan, died of pneumonia Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 76 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

LEAD: * Ed Des Lauriers has been promoted to senior vice president of Campbell-Mithun-Esty.

LEAD: The Atlanta Falcons have a cornerback, Deion Sanders, whose loose lips are infuriating some of his teammates, a head coach, Marion Campbell, who heard screams for his dismissal this week, and a 3-7 record. There is little hope among the Falcons that they can finish any place but last, once again, in the National Conference West Division.
LEAD: One of three inmates who escaped from the Nassau County jail Tuesday morning was recaptured last night in North Bellmore, L.I., the police said.

LEAD: The Salvadoran Army today stepped up its assault on rebel pockets in civilian neighborhoods along the city's periphery, pounding them with rockets, tanks and mortars. Several fires burned out of control.

LEAD: Prime Minister Li Peng of China said here today that Beijing was watching events in Eastern Europe closely but that the surge of change in East Germany and other Warsaw Pact nations would not weaken China's commitment to Communism.

LEAD: Sporting new uniforms, its traditional man-to man defense and a seldom-used weapon, the 3-point shot, St. John's held off a late rally by North Carolina A. & T. last night and won a first-round game in the Dodge National Invitation Tournament, 64-57, at Alumni Hall.

LEAD: Allegheny International Inc., which had indicated it would not seriously consider a $683.8 million takeover offer from Japonica Partners L.P., has decided to let the New York investment group review its records. ''We're pleased that the board is now apparently cooperating, and we are looking forward to completing a transaction that is in the best interests of creditors and shareholders,'' said Fredric Spar, a Japonica spokesman.

LEAD: In the 14 years since the Roosevelt Island tramway began operating, its admirers say, the twin red cabs have become as much a symbol of New York City as the Brooklyn Bridge and the Staten Island Ferry. And like the ferry, these admirers say, the tram is a bargain; a dollar and a quarter not only gets you from here to there, but also provides a spectacular view.

LEAD: Paramount Pictures said today that it had acquired 49 percent of one of Britain's leading television production companies in a deal that reflects the growing importance of foreign markets to the American entertainment industry.

LEAD: A Queens community board has reversed itself and voted to name a Jamaica street for Edward Byrne, the rookie police officer murdered by drug dealers while guarding a witness in South Jamaica last year.

LEAD: It sounded at first like the wacky plot of a ''Get Smart'' spy spoof: F.B.I. agents whispering into the ears of librarians, urging them to keep an eye peeled for ''hostile intelligence service activities'' among readers. But the story proved true. Last year the F.B.I. admitted that for more than a decade it had tried to recruit librarians as sentries in the cold war, and F.B.I.

LEAD: Lech Walesa brought such pleasure, shared such a sense of pride in a nation's achievement, that it was almost impossible to find room in the mind or heart for anything else -even another piece of history being acted out in the city.

LEAD: The AmSouth Bancorporation, the largest banking company in Alabama, announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be sharply reduced by a special $21 million increase in its reserves to cover possible loan losses on Florida real estate loans.

LEAD: The wave of violent weather that swept across the eastern United States yesterday and Wednesday was the product of the collision of two big storm systems, one carrying unseasonable warmth, the other bone-chilling cold.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Aureole ** (Jan. 6, 1989), 34 East 61st Street, (319-1660) - This airy, cream-and-beige dining room in a converted town house is an attractive spot for a festive Thanksgiving dinner.

LEAD: The police said today that they were banning local distribution of The Asian Wall Street Journal because of an article that they said had insulted the leader of Thailand's predominant Buddhist faith.

LEAD: Kitty Dukakis, the wife of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, is undergoing treatment at a hospital unit specializing in depression and related disorders. Mrs. Dukakis, 52 years old, was hospitalized last week after drinking rubbing alcohol.
LEAD: The nation's trade deficit dropped sharply in September to $7.94 billion, its lowest level since late 1984, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: An insurance company has reimbursed The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette $2 million of what the paper said was the largest libel judgment ever paid by a newspaper, leaving the paper's publishing company to absorb $270,000 of the judgment.

LEAD: Roy Tarpley, the Dallas Mavericks forward with two strikes against him in the eyes of the National Basketball Association for alcohol and drug problems, was suspended from the league indefinitely yesterday by counselors in his after-care program. The ban came one day after he was arrested in Dallas on charges of driving while intoxicated and resisting arrest.

LEAD: As the European Community prepares to meet over the dramatic developments in East Germany, politicians and commentators say that its 12 member countries hope to make clear the importance of their role in fashioning Europe's future before the meeting next month between President Bush and President Mikhail S.

LEAD: ''This is a crime of such repugnance that to say that I condemn or deplore seems inadequate. It is a barbaric act that has brought shame to El Salvador. I have difficulty in imagining what sort of animals would, in cold blood, execute priests, and other innocents.'' - William J. Walker, United States Ambassador to El Salvador.

LEAD: State Department analysts have concluded that Soviet military spending will decline in 1989, to between 14 and 16 percent of gross national product, down from 15 to 17 percent in 1988. While this conclusion is disputed by others in the Government, the evidence is overwhelming.

LEAD: They came on foot, in strollers and on roller skates. They wore straw boaters, baseball caps and, in a nod to gallows humor, life preservers. They carried American flags; they carried flowers; they carried brunch.

LEAD: The artworks auctioned in a 12-day marathon of bidding that ends tomorrow has kept minds reeling with images of paintings and the prices they have realized. Throughout these sales, the artist spoken of most often was Pablo Picasso, whose paintings of the rose period and much later brought some of the highest bids.
LEAD: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. is considering a bid for the MGM/UA Communications Company, a source close to the proposal said yesterday.

LEAD: It was a match that evolved into an ordeal, as the embattled Martina Navratilova, who at this stage of her career finds herself fighting off opponents half her age, held fast against an uninhibited challenge from Monica Seles.

LEAD: It's not as if there were any urgent need, but television has come up with another dramatization of ''A Tale of Two Cities,'' the story of turmoil in the final decades of the 18th century. The Charles Dickens novel has gone through several film adaptations, reaching back to the 1917 version starring William Farnum.

LEAD: After spending his entire career in New York City, John V. LEAD: Lawyers today face a host of problems, from low public esteem to congested courts to the uneven distribution of legal services. But one religious group believes that before the bar can tackle any of this, what it needs most is a theological pep talk, a cosmic shot in the arm.

LEAD: On the sunny, manicured playing fields of an exclusive Australian boys' school, an arrangement is being made. It is ratified by secret, almost imperceptible nods from a couple of older men, and it involves an exceptionally handsome golden-blond student who sits basking in his white athletic uniform.

Bob Blanchard and Jim Krekorian, both of Manhattan, headed a field of 56 pairs who survived yesterday's semifinal play, but world-class players were in close pursuit.

LEAD: Czechoslovakia is like a young man who inherits a fortune from his grandfather and fritters it away, dissipating the capital instead of investing it wisely. Two generations ago, at the time of World War I, this was a rich country, with two-thirds of the industrial capacity of the entire Austro-Hungarian Empire concentrated in Bohemia and Moravia, which make up the western two-thirds of Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: Gloria Simmons, assistant principal of a Brooklyn elementary school, continues to defy her superiors for the sake of a dispute over school authority. If she cared about schoolchildren, education or community peace, she would obey orders and accept a transfer.

LEAD: Dresser Industries said its board had approved a merger agreement with Smith International Inc. of Houston. The company said that Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., which owns about a third of Smith's stock, had also approved the offer. The acquisition, which must be approved by the Justice Department, would give Dresser more than 30 percent of the American drilling tool and service market.

It's amusing, a bit too cute, and the perfect metaphor for John Hancock's mediocre film.

LEAD: N.B.A. Bucks 132, Magic 113: Milwaukee tied a National Basketball Association record last night with 50 points in one quarter and, led by Ricky Pierce's 28 points, routed Orlando in Milwaukee. LEAD: The Los Angeles Times has named Thomas G. Plate, the editor of the editorial pages of New York Newsday, to the same position at The Times. He replaces Anthony Day, who had held the post since 1971.

LEAD: In these days of rising prices and diminishing dissertation topics, the discovery of obscure early works by a great artist can be an especially welcome event. It can also be an exaggerated one. At first glance, ''Franz Kline: Lost Murals,'' now on view at the Baruch College Gallery, falls into the exaggerated category - and perhaps at last glance, too.
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev says the Soviet Union is not ready for private property or competing political parties, but is leaving the door open for both in the future.

LEAD: A young man stares wanly from a hospital bed banked in balloons, flowers and an old straw hat . . . The drawer of a vanity table opens on a row of glass vials, the kind usually used for blood samples . . . A writer rages at ''seeing death coming in from the edges of abstraction where those with the luxury of time have cast it.

LEAD: Foreigners who worry about ''reunification'' as an immediate and ominous consequence of the end of the Berlin wall overlook two things. One is that East and West Germany together only constitute about two-thirds of the pre-war territory of the German Reich. Another is that East and West Germany have gradually been extending and broadening ties of all kinds ever since they established diplomatic relations with each other in 1972.

LEAD: One reason all dogs go to heaven, a character in the film by that name says, is that ''unlike people, dogs are naturally good and loyal and kind.'' That's nice. Another reason, as children watching Don Bluth's new full-length animated feature are sure to surmise, is that all dogs die. Anyone not wishing to discuss this idea and its greater implications on the way home from the theater would be well advised to think twice before taking a small child.

LEAD: Thanks to notation and, to some extent, recordings, music does not depend entirely on uninterrupted tradition, as folk song and poetry did in primitive times when a pupil's ear was art's only conservator. Still, the value of one-on-one transmission from teacher to student - from one Bach to the next, from Haydn to Beethoven, from Liszt to his phalanx of epigones - can hardly be overestimated.
LEAD: Horace W. McCurdy, a maritime construction executive whose company built the Mercer Island floating bridge, died Monday. He was 90 years old and lived in Seattle.

LEAD: Amid the deepening gloom about national resurgence, thousands of ordinary Soviet citizens desperate for state housing have begun taking the solution into their own hands. They are seizing Government land and creating vast new urban squatter settlements, building everything from clay hovels to brick houses for their young families.

LEAD: Dr. Eric A. Blackall, professor emeritus of German literature at Cornell University, died of cardiopulmonary arrest Thursday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Ithaca.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The slowing economy has created opportunities in real estate, as a generally depressed housing market has reduced the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage by more than 1.25 percentage points since March. It is now 9.66 percent, a five-year low. Continued soft spots in the economy, including housing, could push that rate down another half-point by spring, many analysts say.

LEAD: A gas explosion and fire in a coal mine today trapped workers nearly a half-mile underground and about 90 miners were feared dead, the official press agency reported. It reported 73 miners had escaped unharmed. The methane gas explosion and fire started at noon at the Aleksinacki Rudnici mine, 120 miles south of Belgrade, the mine director, Branislav Mandusic, said.

LEAD: A week after becoming Bulgaria's Communist leader, Petar T. Mladenov consolidated his hold on power today while saying he favored free elections and a stronger Parliament that could be ''a democratic alternative'' to the present system.

LEAD: The Rowan Companies, a Houston-based contract drilling company, said today that it had expressed an interest in acquiring the rigs of the Penrod Drilling Corporation, a larger drilling company owned jointly by the Hunt brothers' family estates and a group of banks led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

LEAD: Three Eastern Europeans with long careers as dissidents - a Pole, a Hungarian and a Czechoslovak - were asked in separate interviews what surprised them most about the recent events in East Germany, what they thought might be the next step in Eastern Europe and what they considered the greatest dangers.

LEAD: HARRY Streep has been teaching contemporary dance classes for nearly 10 years. He has taught the young, the old, the fit and the unfit, and until the New Rochelle High School hockey team entered his class a couple of months ago he thought he had seen it all.

LEAD: ELEVEN women ranging in age from the early 20's to the upper 30's gathered recently in Hempstead before an audience made up of judges, probation officers and the women's loved ones. Half a year ago all the women faced various charges - larceny, assault, possession of drugs or drug paraphernalia, or prostitution - and here, now, many of them faced the same judges and probation officers.

LEAD: Most homeless families who seek emergency shelter in New York City have either never had their own apartments or have lost their housing through eviction, and almost all are on public assistance, according to a study released by the city's Human Resources Administration.

LEAD: Five buildings including an 1840 Greek Revival house and its barn are being developed into shops, apartments and offices in the Kings Highway Historic District in Westport, Conn. Called Westport Commons, the $3.5 million project on two acres on Post Road is to be finished next month.

LEAD: RUBEN ZAMORA, who in 1987 returned from seven years of exile, sat in a small office of his leftist party's headquarters here a couple of months ago and deplored the growing political violence in El Salvador. The problem, he said, was that the governing rightist party, the Nationalist Republican Alliance, had come to power before its time.

LEAD: World political leaders may be rushing to broad accord on the urgent need to halt global warming, but since the mid-1980's economists have been worrying about the bill. Their misgivings have been deepened by recent estimates of the cost of limiting emissions of carbon dioxide, which is the primary cause of the problem.

Luciano Pavarotti wore a brocaded cape from the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Rigoletto'' to promenade between the two Roman establishments.

($1 a night) and asked the very British desk clerk to recommend a good place for dinner. She suggested the Shadow, if I could afford it.

LEAD: I lost one of my best friends when her husband retired and took over the house. He dictates who she can see and when, how long she can talk on the phone and questions where she goes.

LEAD: The Baltimore Orioles did not make it to the American League pennant last season, but they came close. If major league baseball offered awards for architecture, however, this team would win hands down. For the design for the Orioles' new 46,000-seat stadium in downtown Baltimore, which will begin contruction this spring and be finished in time for the 1992 season, is the best plan for a major-league baseball park inmore than a generation.
LEAD: A robot spacecraft swinging high over the earth's poles today began a search for the beginning of time.

LEAD: Last month, Ed Koch lost his chance to go down in history as the Mayor who rescued New York's carriage horses from heat exhaustion, chill, long hours and terrifying traffic. He vetoed a bill that would protect them from having to work when it is very hot, very cold, very humid or for more than eight hours at a stretch.
LEAD: A 2-month old baby died in Queens yesterday afternoon in an electrical fire that started in a wall next to his crib, the police said.

LEAD: I HAVE NEVER MUCH LIKED THE WAY I TALK. IN UPSTATE New York, where I was raised, people said things like ''Lemme have a HEE-am SEEN-wich'' and ''You scared the BEE-JEES-us outa me.'' It had no grace. Nowhere in our local speech was there the hint of a drawl, or any majestic New England tones, or even a trace of downstate Brooklynese - which can sound almost poetic if you are in the right mood.

Velasco's final kick hit the crossbar and bounced back onto the field.

LEAD: To the Editor: I recall a letter by a single traveler who complained about exorbitant rates. I concur and think it is high time the travel industry recognized that there are many singles out there, and by charging this ridiculous single supplement they discourage us from traveling. For example, I would like to go to Cancun - the double rate is $475, the single rate $865.
LEAD: Ethiopian rebels say they have captured a small town 85 miles north of the capital of Addis Ababa and halted a Government counterattack.

LEAD: Seven high school students have been arrested and an eighth is being sought in the gang rape of a 19-year-old woman here. The accused are all students at North Miami High School, including seven members of the football team. They are charged with raping the woman Aug. 1 at a North Miami apartment complex.

LEAD: AFTER David N. Dinkins won New York City's Democratic mayoral primary in September, Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center, sent him a congratulatory note. Mr. Leventhal, a former Deputy Mayor in the Koch administration, offered to help in any way he could.

LEAD: The airline industry plans to ask the Federal Aviation Administration to require the manufacturers of child safety seats, which are used mainly in automobiles, to make them smaller so they will fit into airliners' seats as well.

LEAD: If Mr. Fukuyama's perceptions of the world lead him to think that soon to disappear is ''the struggle for recognition, the willingness to risk one's life for a purely abstract goal . . .'', perhaps he needs to take another look.

LEAD: Political unrest, financial collapse and bruised egos - enough to rival the life of the dramatic Eva Peron herself - have marked the tortured path of ''Evita'' from stage toward the screen. Like so many film projects in Hollywood that go on for years without being made, ''Evita'' is an example of the hazards of the high-stakes marriage between art and commerce.
LEAD: The County Health Department and the Elmsford Animal Shelter are at odds over the enforcement of a new provision of the Sanitary Code that is setting new standards for agencies housing animals.

LEAD: IN the 20-odd years since Fairfield County was initiated into the wonderful world of office buildings, it has taken its lumps for overdeveloping and overpricing. But despite a third-quarter vacancy rate of 21.7 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield Realtors of Stamford, the market survives.

But last year, while I was a visiting lecturer in the University of California at Los Angeles Writing Programs, I sat in on Peter Guber's course.

LEAD: The cold war was not a ''worldwide ideological struggle that called forth daring, courage, imagination and idealism''; it was an ad campaign, used primarily to justify the division of the spoils of World War II.

LEAD: IN many homes, attic insulation is placed at floor level, specifically between the joists that support the ceilings of the rooms below. This is effective and economical; however, if the attic entrance is not insulated, substantial energy loss can occur in both winter and summer.

LEAD: After more than a month of debate over whether the University of Illinois' Chief Illiniwek symbol is degrading to American Indians, Chancellor Morton W. Weir announced last week that it wasn't, and that it wouldn't be dropped.

LEAD: Even though drug experts cannot agree on how to define ''treatment on demand'' for addicts, there are widespread complaints that neither President Bush's proposed program nor any existing state approach provides nearly enough capacity to treat drug addicts who want to break the habit.
LEAD: American foreign policy experts interviewed last week differed widely on what steps the United States Government might take to respond to the radical changes under way in Eastern Europe.

LEAD: House supporters of abortion rights have introduced a bill that would write into law the 1973 Supreme Court ruling legalizing abortion.

LEAD: The Rangers, if healthy, can definitely make a run at the end of the year. If the Rangers can keep up their strong play until Carey Wilson returns, they'll be in position to win the Patrick Division and possibly contend for the cup. An injury to either Tomas Sandstrom or Brian Leetch would basically eliminate any legitimate chance they'd have, however, since they lack the depth of Calgary or Montreal.

LEAD: From either inclination or a lack of opportunity, composers who frequent New Music America festivals do not normally write for symphonic forces. Not all the festivals have even offered such extravaganzas. But this year's 10th-anniversary festival gathered itself together Thursday night for a Brooklyn Philharmonic program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater - which has already proven itself a fine acoustical venue for such events.

LEAD: Museums reflect culture and to some measure control it. They collect and exhibit what their curators find instructive or exceptional. In MUSEOLOGY (Aperture, $39.95), the photographer Richard Ross presents the results of a 10-year exploration of art and natural history museums in the United States, France, England, Egypt and Greece.

LEAD: THE latest rush of change in Eastern Europe has left the West in emotional confusion as politicians struggle to interpret events that even the most astute pundits had failed to predict. Delight at the opening of the Berlin wall was followed by fears of a mass exodus of East Germans and then relief when this failed to transpire.

LEAD: Although Thailand's ban on the import and sale of The Asian Wall Street Journal is likely to be temporary, it is certain to diminish the country's reputation for tolerance. The damage has increased as the Government considers a similar ban on the weekly Far Eastern Economic Review.

LEAD: Jacquelyn Hilary Still, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Still of Orange, Conn., was married last evening to Stuart Irwin Romanoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Romanoff of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Peter Weintraub officiated, assisted by Cantor Stephen Merckle, at the Waters Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

LEAD: CHARLIE HALL HAS BEEN A WEATHERMAN at WCSC-TV in Charleston, S.C., since 1953, when the city's first television station went on the air. A silver-haired man with a rich voice, Charlie is a local celebrity, a highly respected figure, and one of the reasons WCSC-TV's local news programming has dominated the ratings.

LEAD: Atlanta, more than any other city in the South, has always looked forward rather than back - interested in the bustle of commerce rather than the history and lore that's so much a part of many Southern cities. Its charms rest partly on the gorgeous wooded setting it began with and partly on the modern city created by the economic juggernaut of the recent past and almost not at all on what came between.

LEAD: BACK in the era of strong home sales and rising prices, which lasted for most of the mid 1980's, it was becoming progressively easier to get a mortgage. Lenders were offering to qualify borrowers at a low introductory rate of interest - often as little as 7 percent - even though this was only a temporary enticement and the rate was certain to rise later.
LEAD: Congress approved legislation early today to support democracy and private enterprise in Poland with a major new program of economic aid over the next three years.

LEAD: Clarkston Hines caught three touchdown passes, raising his own National Collegiate Athletic Association career record to 38, and became only the second player ever with more than 1,000 yards receiving in three straight seasons, as Duke rolled to a 41-0 victory today over North Carolina.

LEAD: Leonard Bernstein apparently felt that if the people in Washington were going to rescind a $10,000 grant to an art show on AIDS, they could keep their National Medal of Arts too. Mr. Bernstein at first refused to comment on why he turned down the chance to be one of 12 recipients of the arts medal this year, but it was generally accepted that he did so in protest of a decision by the National Endowment for the Arts to withdraw support for the AIDS exhibition at the Artists Space gallery in Manhattan.
LEAD: The world's No. 1-ranked player, Ivan Lendl, and second-ranked Boris Becker top the two pairings groups for the $3,135,000 Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden Nov. 28-Dec. 3.

LEAD: As a colleague of Terence M. Hines at Pace University, I would take issue with some of his statements in your Oct. 29 issue Westchester Q&A (''Seeing Is Believing? Not Necessarily''). In answer to the question ''How can we be sure there aren't ghosts?'' he replies ''. . .The burden of proof is always on the proponents to produce something other than vague reports and fuzzy photographs, which are known to have been faked in the past.
LEAD: To the Editor: My husband and I were in Liechtenstein (''What's Doing in Liechtenstein,'' July 23) in June and were very impressed with the country.

LEAD: Jazz has been a familiar guest in the concert hall over the years, dropping in from time to time, stirring things up, then moving on to let musical life resume its more sedate patterns. Recently, though, the guest shows signs of moving in for good. Today's concertgoers pick up programs to find Ellington and Monk in spots previously reserved for Mozart and Brahms.

LEAD: The marriage of Sandra Cornelia Newing to Peter Braestrup took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Sanford Garner officiated. Mrs. Braestrup, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stuart L. Newing of Binghamton, N.Y., graduated from Syracuse University and was, until September, the assistant to the headmaster of St.
LEAD: The financial aftershocks from last month's California earthquake and Hurricane Hugo in September are still being felt.

LEAD: ''BREAKING THE CODE,'' the Hugh Whitemore drama now being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, is about the waste of a natural resource. In this case, that resource was Alan Turing, the English mathematician-cum-British war hero.

LEAD: THREE years ago, when Brian O'Loughlin started an asbestos-removal company, only two people were on the payroll. But business was so brisk that in two years' time the company - New England Asbestos Control of Brewster - had grown to 10 times its original size in sales volume, and last year, Mr. O'Loughlin said, the company doubled in size again.

LEAD: We forgot to think small - at least in television. Recent engineering work has gone mostly into improving the big picture while striving for ever larger screens. Meanwhile, smaller, cheaper sets were bypassed by technical progress.

LEAD: South of Houston Street but east of SoHo, five hours of electronic interactions took place on Wednesday night, with New Music America festival concerts at both the Experimental Intermedia Foundation and the Knitting Factory.
LEAD: A picture caption on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today, with the Stage View column, misidentifies the actor who portrays Maj. Manly Battle in ''Mastergate.'' He is Daniel von Bargen.
LEAD: TWO former New Jersey insurance commissioners say they have come up with a plan to sell automobile insurance at below the current average market rates.

LEAD: The movements in Garth Fagan's dances resemble beads on a string. Such a statement could be made about the creations of many choreographers. What makes Mr. Fagan's works distinctive is the fact that he likes to string together oddly assorted beads of movement. Just as an unconventional necklace might have a round bead next to a square one and a rough bead next to a smooth one, so Mr.

LEAD: As an organized industry, the language translation business is an infant on the verge of growing up. Though a huge global market exists - estimates range from $10 billion to $25 billion a year - it is served largely by thousands of freelancers, agencies of five people or fewer and corporate translation staffs.

LEAD: IN THE GOOD OLD DAYS, IT WAS THE MEN WHO GOT to wear the gorgeous stuff. During the heyday of the Mogul era in India, it was the maharajahs who were laden with ropes of pearls and strands of diamonds. Their rings, brooches, belts and sabers dazzled with emeralds and other gems, while thick tassels of pearls and rubies swung against their brocaded robes.

LEAD: Lynda Brown Leaman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Leaman Jr. of Malvern, Pa., was married yesterday to Kevin Angus Macdonald, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Robert M. Macdonald of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. Stephen K. Jacobson performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

LEAD: Linda Gamble McCausland and William Joseph Davis 3d were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J., by the Rev. Alfred C. Niese, an Episcopal priest, assisted by the Rev. Patrick Brown, a Roman Catholic priest.

LEAD: Peggy and Roger Gerry, who began collecting Japanese ceramics while living in Japan in the 1950's, have amassed holdings covering 4,000 years of the craft: prehistoric earthenware vessels, late medieval ash-glazed storage jars, 17th-century tea-ceremony wares and colorful 18th- and 19th-century porcelains made for export.

LEAD: MY STORY (AND I'M STICKING TO IT). By Alex Hawkins. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $18.95.) The protagonist of Dan Jenkin's highly acclaimed 1972 pro football novel, ''Semi-Tough,''was a hard-drinking, butt-stomping, womanizing country boy named Billy Clyde Puckett, who Mr. Jenkins said was modeled after Alex Hawkins of the Baltimore Colts.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke, fresh from a decisive re-election victory, introduced a county operating budget ''for the 1990's'' last week but quickly learned that he may not be safely out of the 1980's.

LEAD: Lurching toward adjournment, Congress slapped together agreements on politically difficult issues this weekend, from Congressional pay and ethics to the program to protect the elderly from the costs of extended illnesses.
LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins's quest for a police commissioner is to begin in earnest this week with the naming of a search committee.
LEAD: Last weekend I decided it was time to get my snapshots in order. They were in a terrible mess, some sitting in piles, some still in the envelopes in which the processing lab had delivered them.

LEAD: Kahondo Style, an English group making its first New York appearance on Tuesday at the Knitting Factory as part of the New Music America festival, revels in references. Its first tune, ''Werewolf Woman,'' hinted at reggae, and throughout the night the group used bits of jazz, rock, Thai and Eastern European folk music, all informed by an experimentalist's sensibility.
LEAD: A. Joseph Ferolie, founder and retired chairman of the Ferolie Corporation, a food brokerage, died of heart failure Friday at his home in Cresskill, N.J. He was 86 years old.
LEAD: IN ''The Lisbon Traviata,'' now running Off Broadway, a flamboyant homosexual is desperate to get his hands on a pirated recording of the Verdi opera that Maria Callas sang in Portugal in 1958.

LEAD: There are three explanations for Toru Takemitsu's unquestioned status as Japan's best-known composer. First, his music is pretty good, the sonic tip of a deep-probing esthetic and philosophical exploration of the intersections between East and West. Second, he is adept at international composer careerism, which is not so much a cynical dismissal as a dispassionate observation.

LEAD: Martha Jane Brackenridge and Austin Bartholomew Sayre 3d were married yesterday at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y., by the Rev. Theodore Fritsch, a United Church of Christ minister. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Bruce Brackenridge of Bronxville and Bonnieux, France. Mr.
LEAD: In sports, there are always big games. But the World Cup soccer match Sunday is bigger than a big game.

LEAD: Robert Addis uses a facsimile machine and a modem at his translation agency in Menlo Park, Calif., but that is as technically advanced as he gets. Computer translation? ''Alchemy!'' he sniffed. Documents translated by a machine, he said, ''end up needing a complete re-translation.''

LEAD: The Old Pine Street Church in Philadelphia was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Maris Elizabeth Williamson, the daughter of Hannah Clymer Williamson of Philadelphia and the late Robert E. Williamson Jr., and Donald Timothy Pascal, the son of Carol Good Pascal of Stamford, Conn., and the late Donald D.
LEAD: IF THIS WAS HAPPINESS A Biography of Rita Hayworth. By Barbara Leaming. Illustrated. 404 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

LEAD: ''I HAVE found the Fountain of Youth,'' I announced elatedly to the owner of a local cheese store. The statement puzzled him until I explained that I had found a health food store of that name, which had been recommended by his staff. But as I spoke, I realized I might just as easily have been talking about myself.

LEAD: A brief announcement by the American Contract Bridge League in Lancaster, Pa. 10 days ago marked the end of a five-year battle. The League's board of directors did away with simultaneous Men's Pairs and Women's Pairs at future National Championships. ''Instead,'' according to the League, ''there will be an Open Pairs opposite the Women's Pairs.

LEAD: One of the regions of New York State that is undergoing unexpectedly high growth is Greene County south of Albany between the Catskill Mountains and the Hudson River. For a century the county lived up to its fictional reputation as the home of sleepy Rip Van Winkle. Lately, however, it has been emerging as an increasingly attractive area for people working in Albany who want to live in the country and people living in New York

LEAD: The most exciting view in New York City is the vista of the East River, lower Manhattan and the Queens and Brooklyn waterfronts from the Roosevelt Island aerial tramway. It's yours for $1.25. And it's worth working to preserve.

LEAD: Abby Cynthia Schultz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Schultz of Allentown, Pa., and Roy Adam Shulman, a son of Morris Shulman of Lake Worth, Fla., and the late Rita Goldberger Shulman, were married last evening by Rabbi Eugene Wernick at Temple Beth El in Allentown. Mrs. Shulman, a certified public accountant, is a tax manager with the Weissbarth, Altman & Michaelson accounting concern in New York.

LEAD: Poul Anderson has been turning out solid, serviceable science fiction for more than four decades. In THE BOAT OF A MILLION YEARS (Tom Doherty/Tor, $19.95), he aims higher and succeeds admirably.

LEAD: LECH WALESA, the hero of Poland's democratic revolution, asked Congress last week for a Marshall Plan to revive the Polish economy. But Congress and President Bush have already decided how to help Poland, and their vision is much more modest.

LEAD: Dexter Manley, no longer a member of the Washington Redskins, has joined Pete Rose in the limbo of a lifetime ban. Manley is now a three-time loser to the National Football League's substance-abuse policy. Rose accepted his sentence despite his denials that he bet on baseball as the Cincinnati Reds' manager.

LEAD: EVER since Neil Simon tossed off the third semi-autobiolgraphical script in what has come to be known as his ''BB'' plays, one has envisioned the trilogy being presented as a daylong marathon, a sort of long but lightweight day's journey on the road toward making it by nightfall.

LEAD: A fact-finding board of faculty members and students at Washington State University is investigating thefts of more than $5,000 in items from around Pullman that have led to the arrest of 17 fraternity pledges. The pledges became suspects after the police recovered several of the stolen items in the Kappa

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Kiju Kaneko of Yokohama, Japan, have made known plans for a February wedding in Tokyo of their daughter, Megumi Kaneko, and Jonathan Andrew Hill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Hill of Rancho Santa Fe and Carmel, Calif.

LEAD: WITH its white walls, track lights and an array of shiny new items like washing machines and electric mixers, the place looks like a showroom at an upmarket department store. There is, for instance, a neatly dressed guard keeping an eye out for shoplifters; all that's missing is price tags.

LEAD: In a city known for its marriage chapels, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation renewed their vows here last week in a public ceremony, hoping to quash recent speculation of their estrangement over the future course of desktop computing.

LEAD: Hungarians say proudly, and rightly, that they have gone furthest toward political reform in Eastern Europe. There will be truly free elections by spring, without the restrictions Solidarity had to accept in Poland.

LEAD: After 141 years of lobbying on behalf of New York's poor, the Community Service Society is trying a different approach. It is encouraging the city's 2 million low-income residents to become politically active and plead their own cause.

LEAD: Cinderella's glass slipper and Clementine's herring boxes without topses represent the extremes of women's footwear - style versus practicality - but these days most women want both. Lacking any alternative, many women make do by walking to work in clunky-looking athletic shoes and switching to high heels stashed under their desks.

LEAD: LOOKING DEEP. By Terry Bradshaw with Buddy Martin. (Contemporary, $17.95.) As Susan Sontag once remarked, writing well is the best revenge. Revenge is probably not what Terry Bradshaw had in mind when he wrote ''Looking Deep'' with the Denver Post sports columnist Buddy Martin, but that is what he has got: revenge over the scores of sportswriters who called him dumb during his career as a quarterback with the Pittsburg Steelers and who will never write a book about football as good as this one.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ENGINEERS are forever telling visitors to places like Shoreham that nuclear plants make electricity the same way that oil- or gas-fired plants do: by making steam, which is converted into mechanical energy in a turbine, which then turns a generator. Much of this is true. But even the non-nuclear side of a plant like Shoreham has substantial differences from a conventional plant, and those differences may become extremely clear in the next two months or so.

LEAD: In the bitter cold of Penn State's Happy Valley, the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame today extended the nation's longest winning streak with a powerful and cool efficiency that established a record for Nittany Lion futility.

LEAD: Garth Fagan, the founder and director of the Bucket Dance company, has long been praised as a choreographer of great originality. Mr. Fagan has also been seen as a visionary dance director who molded a group of untrained young dancers into a sleek and eloquent company over the last 20 years. But one of the great pleasures in his work, less frequently celebrated, is its bracing and expressive physicality.
LEAD: Government troops said today that they had defeated a new Tamil militia accused of killing 38 Muslim police officers in the eastern Ampara district.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The marriage of Mary Elaine Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Murphy of Trenton, to John Markert Arnold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Arnold of Summit, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Trenton. Msgr. Joseph C. Shenrock officiated.

LEAD: An article in last Sunday's sports pages on the Williams College football victory over Amherst misstated the number of times in a row Williams has won the annual game. It is three straight years, not four.
LEAD: More than a million East Germans surged into West Berlin and West Germany in the bright sunshine today, jamming the streets, stores and markets in towns from Lubeck to Hof.

LEAD: JAY (STONEY) HARRISON is what the police call a career criminal: a suspect in two slayings, he had been in and out of police custody since 1984 for crimes like assault and drug selling. Last week he was in Queens for a lie detector test. As he was being driven back to Rikers Island, the police said, he shot and killed the two detectives escorting him.

LEAD: Self-congratulation is sometimes another form of ignorance, perpetuated by an unaccountable success, such as the case of Francis Fukuyama's Hegelian treatise in the neo-conservative journal The National Interest (''What Is Fukuyama Saying?'' by James Atlas, Oct. 22). Thus, the publisher Irving Kristol wants to think that his arrival in Washington ''has raised the level of discussion.
LEAD: A former head chef at a well-known Brooklyn restaurant who was despondent over his poor health apparently shot his wife and then killed himself in Queens yesterday, the police said.
LEAD: Claire Lang von Arnold, a fashion consultant and retailing executive, died of pneumonia Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old.

LEAD: Freehold $259,000 112 Broad Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 47-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, sun porch, partially finished basement; taxes $2,175. Hamilton $91,500 2330 South Clinton Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $1,080.

LEAD: Paula Lorence Carsky, a daughter of Mildred L. Carsky of Johnstown, N.Y., and the late Alexander J. Carsky, was married yesterday to William David Rosado, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Luis A. Rosado of Brooklyn. The Rev. Michael J. Flannery performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Irvington, N
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Giants placed Raul Allegre, pro football's leading kicker this season, and Mark Bavaro, perhaps the sport's best tight end, on injured reserve today. They activated Bjorn Nittmo, a kicker, from their developmental squad and Steve DeOssie, an inside linebacker, from injured reserve.
LEAD: If you missed Rickey (''read my bat'') Henderson at the World Series, he was the one wielding a billboard, a big black bat with big white letters that made major league officials see red.

LEAD: I retired last February from a very good job (Hers: ''Two of Us Is One Too Many,'' by Helen Bennett, Oct. 22). My wife was apprehensive about it (I was not). My outlook was similar to that of Mrs. Bennett's husband; I planned to work around the house and the garden, do some photography, go back to the lab occasionally (when they asked me to) and whatever else came up.

LEAD: A picture caption on page 25 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies a work in an exhibition at Artists Space, a Manhattan gallery. The cloth sculpture of a couple is Greer Lankton's ''Freddy and Ellen, 1985.'' The picture accompanies an article about a dispute between the gallery and John E.
LEAD: To my way of thinking, which I do not propose as the only way, virtually everything else that's new in town is a relief from ''Orpheus Descending.''

LEAD: When Jeanine Amra was 15 years old, her family left the small Minnesota town where she grew up and moved to the West Bank, taking her away from her high school and her friends to a new life that she feared would be primitive and boring.

LEAD: PEOPLE coming to the Shubert Theater in New Haven to catch ''Les Miserables'' are bringing more than just their show tickets. They are also tucking children's books under their arms to donate to the city's public school libraries.
LEAD: If history, and the Jets' offensive line, repeat, Ken O'Brien will be sacked some time tonight at the Hoosier Dome.
LEAD: Can intelligence officers learn anything from battles fought 125 years ago? Yes, says Walter P. Lang of the Defense Intelligence Agency.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Margaret Ann McKinley and Arthur Ryerson Hyde Clarke Jr. were married yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., by the Rev. Edward Johnston. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. McKinley of Greenwich, Conn. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarke of Springfield, Center, N.Y., and New
LEAD: The Public Schools Athletic League B Division is where the have-nots of New York City play football. And it's easy not to get too comfortable.

LEAD: Two days after he was arrested on charges of drunken driving and resisting arrest, Roy Tarpley, the Dallas Mavericks' forward who was promptly suspended by the team for violating the terms of a drug rehabilitation program, got a glimmer of good news.

LEAD: A player and a team manager from the Muskingum College women's basketball team were killed and five others were injured in an accident today on an icy interstate highway, college and hospital officials said.
LEAD: UNTIL RECENTLY, A CONVERSATION ABOUT dried beans and lentils usually drew a stifled yawn.

LEAD: Tallying its dinosaurs, rabbits and, as of last week, bats, the video industry counts a total of some 30 million new cassettes in the stores. On Billboard's most recent best-seller list ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' stood at No. 2, ''The Land Before Time'' was No. 3, and in anticipation of the new ''Batman'' (15 million fresh cassettes), the old ''Batman, the Movie'' was No.

LEAD: April wedding plans have been announced by Dr. and Mrs. James P. Dunn of Summit, N.J., for their daughter Nancy Ellen Dunn and Steven Bryan Grune, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Grune of Westport, Conn.

LEAD: Responding to the Administration's call for major cuts in military spending, the Air Force has proposed closing 15 bases, stretching out purchase of the Stealth bomber and eliminating five fighter wings, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: IT all started with room service 25 years ago, Ginger Kilbane said. ''I was on business in Italy and stayed at the Excelsior Hotel in Rome,'' she recalled, ''and this chunky little coffee pot was on my breakfast tray every morning. I had to buy that pot.''

LEAD: No one was prepared for the rush of change in East Germany and the abrupt opening of the Berlin wall. So it's not surprising that the good news is being followed by much disquieting conjecture about a feared old topic: German reunification. Even careful Henry Kissinger calls that prospect inevitable.

LEAD: ULTIMATE PRIZES. By Susan Howatch. (Knopf, $18.95.) This third novel in Susan Howatch's ecclesiastical series (the first two were ''Glittering Images'' and ''Glamorous Powers'') demands so insistently to be taken seriously that - though it flies in the face of good sense - one is left with no choice but to do so.
LEAD: The Ivory Coast, whose fast-growing free-market economy was once held up as a model for other developing nations, has fallen on hard times.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/-28 East Germany was ready to shoot protesters in Leipzig when Egon Krenz, then security chief, canceled Erich Honecker's order, party officials say. Page 1

LEAD: BO. By Bo Schlembeckler and Mitch Albom. (Warner, $17.95.) For 20 years, Bo Schembechler has coached the University of Michigan Wolverines, and if success is to be measured by the number of postseason bowl appearances and Big Ten championships a team earns, he has to be judged one of this country's premier college football coaches.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The East German swimmer Kristin Otto, who won six gold medals at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, was quoted yesterday in the Communist youth newspaper Junge Welt as saying she has decided to retire.

LEAD: At an impromptu summit meeting called by France, the European Community pledged aid to East bloc countries that move toward democracy and agreed to set up a bank for low-interest loans to those nations. Page 28.

LEAD: TOWNS around the state are complaining that the General Assembly's recycling plan is still without a system in place to market the materials they are collecting and that without help to process them, the towns will not be able to meet the legal deadline for compliance.

LEAD: Ice skating indoors is a lot like baseball indoors: it's recognizable, but it just doesn't feel like the real thing. Fortunately for city folk and city visitors, there are opportunities to go gliding in the great outdoors.

LEAD: The marriage of Carolyn Leslie-Leonard Bransford and Robert Ian MacDonald took place yesterday at St. Christopher's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Gates Mills, Ohio. The Rev. Mary Starrett Anderson officiated.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Simpson Charles 3d of Short Hills N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Anne Charles, to Francis Patrick Maguire, a son of Mrs. Michael J. Fives of Hauppauge, L.I. A December wedding is planned.
LEAD: A chart in some editions last Sunday about changes in Eastern Europe misstated the new name of the Hungarian Communist Party. It is the Socialist Party, not the Socialist Workers Party.

LEAD: KATHLEEN BROUGH, a certified public accountant who lives in Rutherford, wanted something a little different for her birthday. Her husband, David Isralowitz, a physician, ''wanted to be the first on my block to have a seven-foot bear.''

LEAD: In the largest independent rally in this country's postwar history, about 50,000 Bulgarians filled the broad cobblestoned square of a cathedral here in the capital today to exorcise their repressive past and chart a democratic future.
LEAD: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants that have been reviewed by Bryan Miller in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Andiamo
LEAD: There is one moment in ''Black Rain'' when it is clear that the old film images of Japan are giving way to new ones.

LEAD: The bad news is that in some ways television news is getting worse. The reasons why are laid out on ''Illusions of News,'' this week's offering in the new Bill Moyers series, ''The Public Mind.'' Network correspondents, political operatives and critical observers describe how the imperatives of commercial television are overwhelming and undermining efforts at honest journalism.

LEAD: At an impromptu summit meeting called by France, leaders of the European Community nations tonight pledged to provide all possible economic assistance to East bloc countries that move toward democracy.
LEAD: ELIZABETH COLE By Susan Cheever. 211 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

LEAD: Q. The cold-water faucet in my bathroom sink gives off a loud whistling or humming noise whenever it is turned on. The noise stops when the faucet is turned on all the way. I tried tightening the screw on top of the faucet handle, but this did not help. Can you tell me how to eliminate this noise?

LEAD: A tourist bus on a foggy Golan Heights highway swerved, apparently to avoid a car, and overturned into a ravine today, killing a West German woman and injuring the bus driver, a guide and 48 West German passengers, the police said. Druse villagers, Jewish settlers, military doctors and emergency medical service workers from the nearby town of Qiryat Shemona helped in the rescue operations.
LEAD: The gold rush is on in the new Republic of Hungary, even before the shape of its future government is clear.

LEAD: When the second set of turkey sandwiches is served after Thanksgiving, there are usually sotto voce grumblings. So, the remainder of the turkey is set in the back corner of the refrigerator where it languishes until it begins to develop fuzzy white-and-green spots.

LEAD: To the Editor: A ''Palladian Journey in Vicenza'' (Travel, Aug. 13) would be incomplete without a tour of the city's Olympic Theater. Palladio's evocation of classical Greco-Roman design was commissioned by fellow members of the Olympic Academy, a civic organization founded in 1556 to promote humanistic thought and cultural activities in Renaissance Vicenza.
LEAD: FAMILY PORTRAITS Remembrances by Twenty Distinguished Writers. Edited by Carolyn Anthony. Illustrated. 328 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

LEAD: Norma Terris, who was catapulted to stardom as a lead in the original production of ''Show Boat,'' died Wednesday after a brief illness at her summer home in Lyme, Conn. She was 87 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

LEAD: A chorus from Public School 234 in Manhattan will open an arts and events series at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center with a free performance on Nov. 28 at 6:30 P.M. The concert at the financial center - near Battery Park City between the Hudson River and West Street and Vesey and Liberty Streets - will celebrate the lighting of the Winter
LEAD: Can great literature ever be successfully filmed? Does Dickens, in particular, defy even the wiliest adapter?
LEAD: THINGS just seem to take more time in New York City - like renewing a driver's license, Christmas shopping and, most of all, restoration projects.

LEAD: The Islanders, who gained a rare victory Thursday night, reverted to form tonight. They played just well enough to lose a close game as the Pittsburgh Penguins beat them, 5-3, at the Civic Arena.

LEAD: IF THERE'S A HUB OF THE ANnual whirlwind that is Christmas in New York, it's probably Rockefeller Center - the famous tree, the skating rink, the strolling carolers and brass, not to mention the likelihood that more tourists carrying more gift-wrapped packages toddle through there than any other place on earth.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: JoAnn Rice will conduct the Florilegium Chamber Choir and Orchestra in two German Magnificats by Heinrich Schutz at the German Church, 315 West 22d Street, at 3 o'clock today. The program also includes Bach's Cantata No. 150 and two works by Hugo Distler - a setting of the chorale ''Wachet Auf,'' to be played on the organ by Walter Hilse, and ''Totentanz,'' for chorus and narrator (the Rev.

LEAD: INDIA, in the majestic sweep of its long history, has known glory and famine, empire and invasion. There is nothing unusual about that, but India is unique in one respect. Having invented one of the world's great religions, Buddhism, and exported it to most of Asia, it then proceeded to forget about it.

LEAD: What will they say about 20th-century music when it's dead and gone? By ''they,'' I mean the historians whose duty it will be to shuffle the evidence, weigh tendencies, compute the pluses and minuses and play categories. What plausible description could be applied to a period inhabited by such stylistically variegated composers as Elgar and Webern, Stockhausen and Iggy Pop?
LEAD: A former South African security police captain says he commanded an assassination team created to track down and eliminate opponents of the Government.

LEAD: ''Can somebody tell me,'' the Joker wonders, smashing a bright red boxing glove through a television set to curtail the latest report about Batman, ''what kind of a world we live in where a man dressed up as a bat gets all my press?'' Press, of course, is the operative word when you talk about ''Batman,'' which owes so much of its monstrous success to a public relations and merchandising sideshow.
LEAD: THE HUSTONS By Lawrence Grobel. Illustrated. 812 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: A two-year struggle for control of New Hampshire's largest electric utility apparently ended today when its stockholders and creditors tentatively agreed that Northeast Utilities of Connecticut should take over the bankrupt company.

LEAD: Kathleen Anne Kelly, a psychiatric social-work supervisor at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, and Gary J. Malone, an assistant New York State Attorney General, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York. The Rev. Kevin Madigan performed the ceremony.
LEAD: For a company with such a sweet product, the Nutrasweet Company plays a tough game of corporate hardball.

LEAD: The main suspect in the murder of a Federal drug agent last February was killed in a blaze of bullets fired from a blue van on a Brooklyn street Friday night in what law-enforcement officials said appeared to be an execution by local organized-crime groups.
LEAD: There is much truth in the notion that it is folly to tamper with success, and the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln division has made capital of this idea with its Town Car sedan.
LEAD: Members of the New York City Opera orchestra have ratified a new five-year contract with the company, officials of their union announced yesterday.
LEAD: Iran and Iraq have offered competing proposals for turning their 14-month cease-fire into a lasting peace, but neither side has reported a response from the other.

LEAD: The Joffrey Ballet's devotion to Sir Frederick Ashton's works was evident again Wednesday night at the City Center (131 West 55th Street), in a splendid all-Ashton bill that featured a spate of debuts.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Carl Ross of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Abigail Hale Ross, to Pierce Stewart Sioussat, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Stewart Sioussat of Cooperstown, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

LEAD: This weekend, the most influential filmgoer in your household might just be the one who's mashing Play-Doh on the living-room floor. Children are more eagerly courted by the film industry at Thanksgiving than at any other season. And this year's competition is hotter than ever, bringing three new children's feature films - the Disney version of ''The Little Mermaid,'' Don Bluth's ''All Dogs Go to Heaven'' and the live-action '
LEAD: Some people may see romance in the vision of tumbleweeds rolling along the prairie, but Mayor Darrell Bender of Mobridge sees only horror stories.

LEAD: MY daughter Lisa calls to say she will be coming for Thanksgiving. She works with the poor and it's a time some people (who otherwise forget) remember they exist. She isn't sure if she will get away until early on the holiday morning. It's a seven-hour drive but I can't talk her out of it. She is coming.

LEAD: The actor and former running back at Florida State University, Burt Reynolds, was named the 1989 Walter Camp Football Foundation's Man of the Year yesterday. The award is presented annually to an individual associated with football who has attained a measure of success and been a leader in his chosen profession.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: On page 35, because of a production error, a photograph with the Art View column lacks a credit. It is by Timothy Greenfield-Sanders.

LEAD: NO historical marker, no plaque, tells what once happened at the corner of Western and 63d Streets, on Chicago's South Side. But there are the bullet holes, small craters in the brick and chips in the terra cotta, that mark the spot where a hood named Frank McErlane opened fire one sunny September morning in 1925 with a submachine gun.

LEAD: IN its pursuit of eclecticism, Hartford Stage has been a study in extremes of late. Having opened the season with ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' Oscar Wilde's perfectly escapist Victorian comedy of gentility and absurdity, the theater is now shaking up its subscribers with ''Stand-Up Tragedy,'' a tough and loud dose of contemporary urban reality, replete with street talk, rap music and break dancing.

LEAD: The Franklin D. Roosevelt Library here, the nation's first official Presidential library, will celebrate its 50th anniversary on Sunday with special exhibits, a birthday cake and showings of newsreels of the Roosevelt era.

LEAD: NORTH DALLAS AFTER FORTY. By Peter Gent. (Villard, $19.95.) Talk to a football fan about ''North Dallas Forty'' and the fan smiles. It was a novel about the ribald life of a legendary (and fictitious) Dallas football team. Now the football team has grown up. It is 20 years later and Peter Gent, himself a former Dallas Cowboys flanker and tight end, has given us a sequel, this time concerning the team's reunion.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The marriage of Judy Arlene Katz, the daughter of Robert A. Katz of South Orange, N.J., and Colleen Katz of New York, and Jeffrey Todd Hoffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hoffman of North Brunswick, N.J., took place last evening at Temple Anshe Emeth in New Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Bennett Miller officiated.

LEAD: A current series of film presentations at the Museum of Modern Art, titled ''The Dawn of Sound'' and running through Dec. 4, focuses on what was probably the most decisive period in the development of the movies. During the late l920's, the addition of sound transformed film from a mute mime show into a form of theater with an unequaled range of expressive options.

LEAD: THE hamlet of Centerbrook, near Essex, was put on Connecticut's dining map some years ago by an exemplary French restaurant called Fine Bouche. But now another establishment, 8 Westbrook, provides a second reason for discerning diners to visit town.
LEAD: Collectors seeking a small but expensive collection can turn to the coins of the Aloha State. Hawaii has a limited set of coins, just seven.

LEAD: The Rangers are legitimate contenders for the following reasons: (a) The Patrick Division is no longer dominant, and remaining in first place is a distinct possibility. (b) The combination of strong goaltending and Roger Neilson's defensive system of play is most effective in the playoffs. (c) Strong showings against current N.H.L.
LEAD: Slyvester Stewart, the former lead singer and creator of Sly and the Family Stone, has agreed to return to Los Angeles to face a narcotics possession charge.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Popular culture has always mirrored its times and, as the 1980's draw to a close, efforts are inevitably being made to single out those arts, artifacts and entertainments that perhaps best reflected the spirit and values of the decade. Where was the Reagan Era captured, even if unintentionally, most vividly?

LEAD: Few in the translation industry have made the leap from cottage to corporation, but Berlitz and Alpnet are notable exceptions. Both have gone global, mainly through acquisitions, to become among the world's largest translation companies.

LEAD: There was relief all around when it was learned that Deborah Fahrend and her West German companion and his son had not been kidnapped. But there were still a few unanswered questions. The flap began last week when a news agency received a note, purportedly from a previously unknown group called the Organization of Just Revenge, claiming that the three had been abducted ''because of their activities in Lebanon.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: On Tuesday, the chef Frederic Piepenburg examined his croissant, checked his white-chocolate mousse and black forest cakes, put on a clean chef's jacket and walked out of his pastry shop on York Avenue in Manhattan. The 6 P.M. departure was unusual for a 40-year-old man who says he has not missed a minute of any 16-hour workday since he began work as a baker's apprentice in 1963.

LEAD: For This Week:Tidy up the perennial border by cutting to the ground stalks and stems; add them as a layer on the compost pile. Finish sweeping up driveways, walks and patios and rake leaves once more for compost. Store any summer furniture, still outdoors. Winterizing
LEAD: Francis Fukuyama's ''End of History?'' has all the earmarks of one of those intellectual fads that come along whenever academics need something new to talk about at faculty cocktail parties.

LEAD: For most Americans, the term ''cabaret,'' if it suggests anything at all, probably conjures up movie images of a hyperkinetic Liza Minnelli and an epicene Joel Grey in a squalid Berlin dive on the eve of the Nazi era. In the film ''Cabaret,'' the Minnelli character's invocation of ''divine decadence'' helped stamp the very word ''cabaret'' with intimations of depravity that it unfortunately still carries.
LEAD: Pirates and shippers have long found fame and fortune along Greece's coasts, but a new account of robbery by boat has brought this seafaring nation uncommon diplomatic embarrassment.

LEAD: Early this month, the student senate proposed that the Miss T. U. Pageant be abolished on the grounds that it is sexist and discriminatory. But the student body, to which the proposition was put for a vote last week, doesn't seem to think so. It vetoed the idea 1,050 to 521. There are about 4,000 students at the university.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: As he promised he would, Gov. Robert P. Casey has signed into law the most restrictive state abortion provisions in the nation.

LEAD: LONG ISLANDERS seeking country dining at a quaint atmospheric inn will not be enticed by the Mill River Inn's drab exterior. This ill-lighted, undistinguished gray building situated in a less-than-gentrified section of Oyster Bay will attract few walk-ins.

LEAD: Rose doesn't pick her men very well. In fact, Rose is probably lucky to be alive, given the two psychopaths she is involved with in Glyn Vincent's ''Thin Air,'' a jumble of a play being presented at the Theater for the New City.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: EXHIBITION BASKETBALL

LEAD: Following several weeks of criticism over his decision to keep the University of California campus here open after the Oct. 17 earthquake that rocked the Bay area, Chancellor Ira Michael Heyman has called for the formation of a task force to evaluate the university's emergency preparedness.
LEAD: THE PLEASURES OF THE PAST By David Cannadine. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: Jennifer Ann Lautenbach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Terry R. Lautenbach of Darien, Conn., and Edward Daniel Streeter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Streeter Jr. of Laurel Hollow, L.I., were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Charles Smith.

LEAD: I was married for more than 30 years. During that time, my husband and I raised four sons. I worked part-time and, later, full-time. When our youngest child went off to college, instead of facing retirement and time together, I had to face divorce. I felt ''out of it; diminished in an unexpected way.
LEAD: THREE sentinels stand guard, like faceless robots from a sci-fi film, inside the gallery entrance of the Staller Center for the Arts at the State University in Stony Brook.

LEAD: It's not even Thanksgiving yet, but, as any retailer will happily tell you, it is never too early to think about Christmas. If stereo is on your list, and you worry about the economy - your own economy, that is - it is reassuring that an inviting choice of musically competent components can be had at relatively low cost.

LEAD: RUNNING TOUGH. Memories of a Football Maverick. By Tony Dorsett and Harvey Frommer. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A most intriguing fact in ''Running Tough'' is that Tony Dorsett has accumulated more rushing yardage than anyone in football history save for the recently retired Walter Payton of the Chicago Bears.
LEAD: WHAT if no one called? The possibility fills me with dread as I open the front door. After all, I've been away for more than 24 hours.

LEAD: RESOURCES for medical education and health-care research are tightening. As a result, health-sciences universities nationwide have begun to explore new sources of funds in the form of innovative business arrangements with private industry, including the kinds of public-private partnerships that have proved successful in other fields of governmental responsibility.

LEAD: The United States has paid a high price for the instability of the dollar. A dollar that floats in value against other world currencies confuses markets, distorts supply and demand, and makes it harder for the economy to operate. Long-range investment decisions are clouded by unnecessary short-range uncertainties.
LEAD: The Minnesota Timberwolves are a strange team and it required some strange moves last night by the Knicks to defeat the expansion club, 111-96, at Madison Square Garden.
LEAD: Joseph Boltz, 90 years old, remembers the first time he saw Lehigh play Lafayette in football. It was 1917 and Boltz, a freshman, played the trombone in the Engineers' marching band.

LEAD: In Rye Brook, N. Y., on 27 acres of what once had been a dairy farm, 60 one-family homes are being developed, with construction paced by sales. Six already have been sold for $545,000 to $635,000. Named Hidden Falls, the project off North Ridge Street has a one-acre pond whose outlet flows over a 30-foot high waterfall into Blind

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: WHEN Hurricane Hugo struck inland North Carolina, I was in bed in a snug new motel along I-85 listening to the wind build up and tiny branches strike the window. After one howling burst near dawn, the lights on the highway went out, the restaurant in the parking lot went dark, alarms went off in the motel corridor and
LEAD: Bent Larsen uttered his pronouncement, ''I don't trust long variations,'' many years ago. Yet every once in a while someone gets caught failing to heed the eminent Danish grandmaster's warning.

LEAD: In the spring, a trustee of the University of South Carolina persuaded other trustees to try an experiment this fall. The university would make two of the six predominantly freshman dormitories off limits to members of the opposite sex.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Bohan of Stuart, Fla., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Marguerite Marie Bohan and Dr. James Vincent Bono, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Rudolph F. Bono of Englewood, N.J.

LEAD: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section on Nov. 5 about an instrument built by Harry Partch mis-identified the performer because of incorrect information supplied to The Times. The muscian shown playing the instrument was Jeffrey Peyton.
LEAD: BLUE GLOW SHROUDED THE ROOM FOR AN INSTANT, THEN was gone. In that moment, Louis Slotin knew he had received a lethal dose of radiation from the core of the plutonium bomb he was testing.

LEAD: MARY and Rudy went for a bike ride. Along the way, they got married. As a justice of the peace in the town of Kent, I have been called upon to unite couples in matrimony in a wide variety of circumstances and settings.

LEAD: OUT OF BOUNDS. By Jim Brown with Steve Delshon.) Zebra, $17.95.) For most middle-aged sports fans, Jim Brown is professional football's quintessential fullback, an archetypal strongman in an era when the National Football League was more brutal than it is today. As Mr. Brown observes in ''Out of Bounds'': ''Loose rules.

LEAD: Members of a University of Oklahoma fraternity, long censured by Vietnam veterans, whom they claim to be honoring with an annual party, met less hostility this year than in the past after taking what one veteran called ''concrete steps'' to prove their sincerity.

LEAD: Choi Duk Shin, a former South Korean Foreign Minister and Ambassador to Bonn who moved to North Korea after becoming affiliated with a dissident group that supports the Communist Government, died Thursday. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bert G. Cox of Rye, N.Y., have made known the January wedding plans of their daughter Karen Leslie Cox and John Joseph Mandy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mandy of New Paltz, N.Y. Miss Cox, 24 years old, is an administrative assistant in the investment management group at the Bankers Trust Company in New York.
LEAD: Jane Harris was always interested in tactile things. ''I knitted at 4,'' said the 24-year-old graduate of the Glasgow School of Art.

LEAD: While trying to tear down a goal post and throw it in Lake Washington, celebrating students battled Mace-spraying police today after Washington's 20-9 victory over Washington State. The melee lasted more than 30 minutes after the end of the game at Husky Stadium. Police also were seen hitting students with nightsticks.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: A CONTROVERSY over land use has taken a new turn in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. Its roots are in history but the stakes are a community's future.

LEAD: In 1971, following President Nixon's repudiation of the agreement at Bretton Woods to redeem dollars in gold bullion, I was one of the first economists on Wall Street to warn that Nixon's ''New Economics'' policy would lead to serious economic and financial problems in the 1970's.

LEAD: Marcia Prins-Kemp had given up a career in ballet and was on leave as an airline attendant 10 years ago when she walked down Shattuck Avenue here and saw a sign for a ceramics class starting in an hour.
LEAD: Charles Greenfield, inventor of a dehydration process used in waste disposal, died of pneumonia Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in New Providence, N.J.

LEAD: What makes a contender? A stand-on-his-head goalie, a potent power play and, generally, players with a desire to play above and beyond anyone's expectations. The Rangers might just make celebrating 50 years of futility a forgotten memory in June. JOSEPH PISCOPIA Brooklyn

LEAD: The Nynex Corporation and striking New York Telephone Company workers failed to sign a tentative agreement yesterday that would have ended a 14-week strike that has disrupted service for 10.5 million customers in seven states.

LEAD: The Rev. Dr. Theodore A. Rath, retired president of Bloomfield College and a Presbyterian minister, died Friday after being hit by an automobile outside his home in Lakeland, Fla. He was 85 years old and a former resident of Sussex, N.J.

LEAD: LONDON has at last decided to face the River Thames, after centuries of turning its back on it. The Docklands, an area of eight-and-a-half square miles covering both sides of the river and once a wasteland of industrial dereliction, is being transformed into a city within a city. All along the Thames, old buildings are being gutted and restored, with Georgian warehouses becoming sumptuous apartments, smart offices and shopping malls.
LEAD: THE GREAT UNIVERSAL EMBRACE Arms Summitry - A Skeptic's Account. By Kenneth L. Adelman. 366 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.
LEAD: Fear. It begins in the mind and will always show itself in some physical way.

LEAD: The American Ambassador to Lebanon, John McCarthy, returned here today to present his credentials to the new President of Lebanon, two months after the Ambassador and 29 embassy employees were evacuated from Beirut for security reasons.
LEAD: Charles Greenfield, inventor of a dehydration process used in waste disposal, died of pneumonia Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in New Providence, N.J.
