LEAD: G.E. is moving into Hungary, taking advantage of liberalization in Eastern Europe. General Electric will pay $150 million for control of the Tungsram Company, a light-bulb maker. The deal is the largest American investment in Hungary since World War II. John F. Welch, G.E.'s chairman, said the purchase would help bolster G.E.

LEAD: As if somehow preordained, the top two female players in the world this year, Steffi Graf and Martina Navratilova, will meet in the final today of the last major women's tennis tournament of the year, the Virginia Slims Championships.
LEAD: The article ''Parks Are Becoming Dumping Grounds'' illustrates the many problems the State of New Jersey is facing because of the closing of many municipal landfills.

LEAD: The wedding of Susan Ruth Mankin and Alvaro Bustamante took place yesterday at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del. The Rev. Dr. Adam Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony. Mrs. Bustamante, 27 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hart Tiller Mankin of Wilmington, Del. The bride was until recently a food and beverage manager for Continental Companies in Coconut Grove, Fla.

LEAD: Debra Merril Kimelman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kimelman of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Andrew Weiss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvyn I. Weiss of Muttontown, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Mordechai Waxman officiated at Temple Israel in Great Neck.

LEAD: In 1971, following President Nixon's repudiation of the agreement at Bretton Woods to redeem dollars in gold bullion, I was one of the first economists on Wall Street to warn that Nixon's ''New Economics'' policy would lead to serious economic and financial problems in the 1970's.

LEAD: ''Media about media about media,'' said a voice on tape, summing up the tactics of Negativland, a California group that performed Thursday night at the Knitting Factory as part of New Music America. Negativland dips into the torrent of broadcast words from the likes of preachers, bureaucrats and advertisers, then turns the found messages into collages with noises and occasional songs.

LEAD: YOU have probably read about studies suggesting that a monstrous proportion of repair people are dishonest, incompetent, or both. A perfectly healthy car, for example, is taken to a dozen service stations with a question, and 10 of them recommend expensive, mysterious repairs.

LEAD: FOR many Americans, cranberries are thought of only once a year, as a sauce or condiment to serve alongside turkey. If turkey happens to make it to the dinner table more than once a year, then the cranberries will accompany it on those occasions as well. That does not do justice to the native cranberry.

LEAD: N.H.L. Jets 1, Flyers 0: Doug Smail tapped in Dale Hawerchuk's shot with 3:28 left in overtime yesterday, giving Winnipeg a victory over Philadelphia. Smail fired a 15-foot wrist shot over the glove hand of Ken Wregget for the winning goal.(AP) Golf Mize Retains Lead by a Shot: Larry Mize of the United States held off a challenge from Naomichi Ozaki of Japan yesterday to keep the lead after three rounds of the $1.1 million Dunlop Phoenix Tournament in Miyazaki, Japan.

LEAD: Bristol, Conn. $124,000 36 Batt Place 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; office on lower level, fenced yard; taxes $1,400. Branford, Conn. $127,500 142 Shore Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 41-year-old ranch; walk to beach, expansion potential; taxes $969.

LEAD: An independent Indian politician believed to be working behind the scenes for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has accused the leader of the political opposition, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, of collaborating with the United States Central Intelligence Agency and a private American foundation to obtain a $1 million grant.

LEAD: OAKLAND CEMETERY in Sag Harbor is in a felicitous location, 27 acres of rolling high ground in what was once a forest lush with whispering oaks older than any inhabitants in the place. The rhododendrons and azaleas run riot in the spring, cedars and pines stand straight as sentries. George Balanchine, master of the ballet, although not a resident of Sag Harbor, picked Oakland Cemetery because he ''liked the look of it.

LEAD: Colorado completed its first unbeaten regular season since 1937 and won its first Big Eight Conference championship in 28 years, routing Kansas State, 59-11, today as Darian Hagan became the fifth player ever to run and pass for more than 1,000 yards in a season.

LEAD: WHEN the Shermans moved last week, Dayton Street lost its promising young leader, Jason Sherman, age 8. An ambitious entrepreneur, imaginative game organizer, keeper of the peace and (inadvertently) creator of street-life drama for those of us too old to play, his skills will be hard to replace.

LEAD: CHILI DAWGS ALWAYS BARK AT NIGHT. By Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $17.95.) Unless you happen to be as faithful a Lewis Grizzard fan as, say, my father, you might read his latest collection of Southern-fried columns from The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and find yourself asking: Who is he? What is he?
LEAD: MY TURN The Memoirs of Nancy Reagan. By Nancy Reagan with William Novak. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Random House. $21.95.
LEAD: Roman Hale scored two touchdowns and Temple fought off a 326-yard passing performance by Scott Erney today to beat Rutgers, 36-33. It was Temple's first victory of the season.

LEAD: As a music-theater adaptation of a traditional Korean folk tale, ''The Song of Shim Chung'' is a change of pace for the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, allowing the company's proficient actors to experiment in an area distant from contemporary naturalism. The brief play, which opens the Pan Asian season at Playhouse 46 at St.

LEAD: Dr. Susan Lea Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Cohen of Brooklyn, and James Evan Schwartz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schwartz of Ardsley, N.Y., were married last evening. Rabbi Paul R. Siegel performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in White Plains.

LEAD: A 36-year-old man was fatally shot Friday night by his father's roommate five weeks after the son moved to the city to be reunited with his father, the police said. The father had not seen the son since shortly after he was born. The son, Alonzo Colbert Jr., had been arguing with his father when the roommate, Lawyer Meadows, 55, became alarmed and shot him in the chest, the police said.
LEAD: Six thousand police officers, their gleaming gold badges in sharp contrast to the gray skies, stood along a Queens street yesterday to pay their last respects to Detective Keith L. Williams.

LEAD: Mrs. Walter James Hodges of Washington has announced the engagement of her daughter, Laurie Lee Hodges, to Pierre Fernand Lapeyre Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lapeyre of New Orleans. The prospective bride is also the daughter of the late Mr. Hodges. A March wedding is planned.

LEAD: EVEN BEFORE FREDERIK WILLEM DE KLERK BECAME leader of his party and his country, he laid out four options for South Africa's whites: they could surrender to the black majority, which de Klerk contended the liberals were advocating; they could retain minority control at all costs, which the conservatives wanted; they could find a more acceptable way to hold onto power; or, as he proposed, they could make up their minds to share power with the blacks.

LEAD: In the 10-year-old civil war in El Salvador, 70,000 people have died and about one-tenth of the population has been uprooted. Here is a history of the conflict. 1979: Reform-minded Army officers stage coup in hopes of stemming appeal of guerrillas, but new junta's efforts to call elections are thwarted.

LEAD: The engagement of Wendy L. Davidson and Jeffery A. Krieger, both 1986 graduates of Swarthmore College, has been made known by her mother, Barbara A. Davidson of East Hampton L.I. Mr. Krieger is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry A. Krieger of Claremont, Calif.
LEAD: HENRY ADAMS By Ernest Samuels. 504 pp. Illustrated. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $25.

LEAD: IN the 1960's and 1970's, a small Pentagon office called the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency helped create an explosion of innovation in computer research that has had an immense impact on the American economy. Acting independently and without the bureaucratic strings that often shackle Government organizations, the agency served as a de facto venture capitalist for the American computer industry.

LEAD: Army, which had already lost four key starters for the season with injuries, began today's game against Colgate with the starting quarterback, Bryan McWilliams, sidelined with a foot injury. Then the Cadets lost their outstanding left halfback, Mike Mayweather, who reinjured a groin muscle early in the second quarter.

LEAD: THE irascible Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad, recently caused a stir when he used the word ''scum'' to describe Vietnamese boat people who remain here after Western resettlement countries select those among them who qualify as refugees. ''Why should we be responsible?'' Mr. Mahathir asked.

LEAD: Ignorance is at once the most confining and liberating of intellectual states. Produce ''Parsifal'' today and we know a lot to begin with. Wagner's written wishes for his operas - instruments, tempos, tone, stagecraft - speak sternly and specifically. The way is well marked, allowable deviation made minimal.

LEAD: In a bluntly worded letter two days after six prominent Jesuit priests were slain by uniformed gunmen here, the Attorney General of El Salvador today warned Pope John Paul II of his ''tremendous concern for the fate and fortune'' of Roman Catholic bishops in the country and urged him to withdraw them.

LEAD: From generation to generation, a joyous tradition has brightened the lives of certain women at this time of year. It has nothing to do with Thanksgiving or the Macy's parade or even gargantuan bargains in the stores. These women know better: November triggers the annual migration of fur coats.

LEAD: The Pacific rim is pretty big, and Friday afternoon's New Music America concert at the Guggenheim Museum of music from that rim actually offered only three pieces from California and one from Japan. Still, the arts that appear under that rubric do tend to differ from the characteristic music made in Europe and the Eastern United States.

LEAD: Gail J. Ostrove and Robert A. Kantor are planning a March wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ostrove of Roslyn, L.I., have announced. Mr. Kantor is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Kantor of New York.
LEAD: THE EMPEROR'S NEW MIND Concerning Computers, Minds, and the Laws of Physics. By Roger Penrose. Illustrated. 466 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

LEAD: Until today, the Solidarity founder, Lech Walesa, had been celebrated by officials and business leaders at invitation-only luncheons and cocktail parties during his weeklong visit to the United States. Today it was the turn of hundreds of Polish-Americans who streamed into downtown Chicago in a jubiliant mood to hail him in an outdoor rally.
LEAD: Sixty minutes of hockey, after the remarkable comeback against the Rangers a night earlier, was too much to handle for the Devils tonight.

LEAD: EDUCATION OF A WANDERING MAN. By Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $16.95.) A few days before his class in Jamestown, N.D., graduated from high school, Louis L'Amour (then Louis LaMoore) sat in a Singapore bar with his shipmates. He had decided that ''school was interfering with my education.'' This intellectual autobiography details the path that L'Amour traveled to become admirably, refreshingly self-educated.
LEAD: The main front-page article last Sunday about East Germans visiting West Berlin misstated the former position of Vernon A. Walters. He was Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, not Director.

LEAD: Dexter Manley, the Washington Redskins' star defensive end, was banned indefinitely from the National Football League yesterday for having violated the league's substance-abuse policy for a third time.

LEAD: JULIE D. BELAGA of Westport, a Republican who lost her bid for governor in 1986, has been appointed Region 1 administrator for the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the Government's top environmental post in New England with a staff of 575 people and offices in Boston.

Yet, when the Administration's clean fuels program came before the House Health and Environment Subcommittee last month, the White
LEAD: THE TEMPTING OF AMERICA The Political Seduction of the Law. By Robert H. Bork. 432 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.
LEAD: One of the most original shows in recent years is ''Dancers on a Plane: Cage. Cunningham. Johns,'' which can be seen through Dec. 2 at the Anthony d'Offay Gallery, 23 Dering Street, London.
LEAD: AMONG its celebrity profiles and essays on male angst, the December issue of Esquire magazine offers an added treat for readers: the winner of the Absolut Story Contest.

LEAD: QUICK, WHEN WAS the last time you drank a white Bordeaux? If it was long ago - or never - don't be upset. Most American wine buffs are no different: they may think of red Bordeaux as the king of wines but of white Bordeaux they rarely think at all.

LEAD: Embroiled in a landing-rights dispute with Cyprus, El Al Israel Airlines has closed off a transit route for thousands of Soviet Jews seeking to vacation in Israel, Cypriot and Israeli airline officials say.

LEAD: David Margolick exaggerates the contrast between American and Polish perceptions of Basia Johnson (''Lech's American Angel,'' Oct. 8). He writes that ''to Americans she may always be a chambermaid.'' Why would anyone, besides the stepchildren and their lawyers, consider such a highly educated woman always to be a chambermaid, merely because that was the first job she held in the United States?

LEAD: Russell C. Stanhope, the founder and president of R. C. Stanhope, a manufacturer of steel pilings, died Thursday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 90 years old and also lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

LEAD: The Benetton Group is under attack for a double-barreled advertising campaign that has apparently backfired. Its ''United Colors of Benetton'' campaign is cleverly designed to sell the Italian retailer's colorful line of casual clothes - while at the same time creating valuable good will by promoting unity between people of different races and cultures.
LEAD: Strapped and hoping to build a road from here to Dulles International Airport, Virginia decided to revive a Colonial-era solution: Let private business build the road and profit from the tolls.

LEAD: Saturday night's spectacle at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the finale of the New Music America festival, required a good cardiovascular system to take the willing body from theater to theater. This reviewer managed to ingest five shows in four hours; while the bites were small, the cooking was exceptional.

LEAD: Jon C. Parker spent a recent sunny Saturday morning doing what he does most weekends - breaking the law by handing out clean hypodermic needles to drug abusers, hoping to prevent the spread of AIDS.

LEAD: Last week, Congress acknowledged what President Bush will not: that galloping population growth merits attention. It voted to contribute to the U.N. Fund for Population Activities.

LEAD: Workers at the New England Telephone Company voted late today to accept a new contract and end a 15-week strike. Officials for the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers said about 18,000 electrical workers in New Hampshire, Vermont, Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Maine voted 7 to 1 to accept the contract and would return to work Monday.
LEAD: Tens of thousand of people marched in at least eight East German cities today, continuing to press their demands for free elections and an end to Communist domination.
LEAD: The breaching of the Berlin Wall was a momentous political event and to West Germany's leading news magazine, Stern, it was also a marvelous marketing opportunity.

LEAD: Sir Arthur Sullivan once said he thought history would remember him, if at all, as the composer of religious music like ''Onward Christian Soldiers,'' and had he never met Sir William S. Gilbert that might well have been the case.
LEAD: Paul Shyre, a playwright, director and actor who specialized in character anthologies, died of septisimia, infections linked with AIDS, yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

LEAD: The Green Bay Packers had every chance to fold here this afternoon, every chance to slip or slide or stumble in the manner that most teams do against the Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers: Game on the line. Big-play drive. Joe Montana passing to someone from nowhere. The 49ers win.
LEAD: Three men and a woman on a Manhattan subway train were involved in the fatal stabbing of another rider yesterday afternoon in what appeared to be a revenge killing, the police said.

LEAD: The Foreign Ministry summoned the American Ambassador today to protest as ''brazen and unwarranted'' a resolution passed last week by a Senate panel that focuses on Armenian-Azerbaijani tensions in the Soviet Union. The Soviet officials, who are upset that the resolution criticizes the Kremlin's handling of the ethnic clashes, called the panel's move a ''relapse into the cold war'' and chided the panel for ''interfering'' in a delicate ethnic problem.

LEAD: The rights to the Virginia Slims of Dallas have been sold to a Japanese advertising agency, leaving the city without either a women's or men's professional tennis tour event for the first time in 20 years.

LEAD: Kombi Ltd., a company based in Naugatuck, Conn., uses heating circuitry in its 1990 line of heated gloves and footwear. The system includes a rechargeable battery, measuring three inches by two inches, to produce heat. The warmth passes into the glove through hairlike conductors that are much finer than wire.

LEAD: A week ago the Indiana Pacers, winners of their first four games, were the only undefeated team in the National Basketball Association. Now they are 4-3. Why? A West Coast road trip. With the exception of the Los Angeles Lakers and the Utah Jazz, who have played mostly at home, each of the other 25 teams have at least three losses.

LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of issues this holiday-shortened week is confined to the regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills today. The outstanding three-month bill was bid late Friday at 7.68 percent and the six-month bill was bid at 7.68 percent.

LEAD: Rookie to Legend Q. Among all the players voted rookie of the year in the major leagues, how many have gone on to be voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame? A. A total of 86 players have won rookie-of-the-year honors since the award was instituted in 1947, and so far only 7 have fulfilled their promise enough to be enshrined in Cooperstown.

LEAD: For its finale, New Music America presented ''Night of a Thousand Bands'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night - actually, 11 bands in four hours on four stages, with concertgoers free roam. The lineup was diverse (jazz, rock, Minimalism, African music, Iranian or Cambodian pop and sundry hybrids), and audiences, each member on a self-selected itinerary, were casual but attentive; the offerings made it hard to go wrong.

LEAD: If the Joffrey Ballet's eight-day ''Nutcracker'' run, which begins on Friday, is as superbly danced as its repertory season has been, New Yorkers will be in for more of a company performing at its fervently scaled peak.
LEAD: Voters appeared today to have rejected a measure providing limited autonomy for parts of the southern Philippines, a region rocked by conflict between Christians and Muslim separatists.

LEAD: Engineers repairing three nuclear reactors at the Savannah River Site in South Carolina now believe that the first supplies of a radioactive gas vital to atomic bombs will not be available until July 1991 and full production will not begin until the summer of 1992.

LEAD: Buck Helm, the longshoreman who survived for 90 hours in the wreckage of a freeway that collapsed in the California earthquake last month, died Saturday night. He became 58 years old on Nov. 10.
LEAD: The slow, steady decline in bond yields over the last six months or so has pushed long-term interest rates to within shouting distance of their lowest levels of the 1980's.

LEAD: In the two months United States track and field athletes have been subjected to short-notice drug testing, no athlete has produced a positive test result, although problems continue with the collection process.

LEAD: ''What Is Music?'' asks tonight's offering of ''Nova.'' Although no conclusive answer is forthcoming, the hour, at 8 P.M. on Channels 13 and 49 and at 9 P.M. on Channel 21, touches many strings. It moves from the synthesizing of sound, to the reproduction of violins that are said to approach the quality of the renowned 17th- and 18th-century instruments, to how performers bring their personalities to bear on musical scores, to what happens when the sounds of music creep in our ears.

LEAD: Leonardo Sciascia, an Italian novelist and essayist whose work explored political corruption and crime in his native Sicily, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Palermo. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: More than 200,000 marchers called today for freedom and a change in government in the largest and most vociferous public demonstration since the euphoric Prague Spring that preceded the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: President Bush's nominee to the Agriculture Department's leading environmental post asked the White House today to withdraw his name from consideration after it became clear that he faced insurmountable opposition in the Senate.

LEAD: Players who played in the major leagues in 1985 are being asked to submit claims as their share of the $10.5 million an arbitrator says baseball club owners owe players as redress for collusive acts four years ago.

LEAD: Book publishing, faced with a combination of increasing competition, declining profits and slumping unit sales, is beginning to undergo changes that are likely to alter the shape of the industry in the 1990's, although it may not seem all that different to casual book buyers.

LEAD: CANCER researchers are beginning to make progress in understanding some of their most deadly adversaries, cancer cells that break off from the primary tumor, travel to distant organs and form secondary tumors.

LEAD: The battle of the Classical bands continued on Sunday afternoon as Frans Bruggen and his Orchestra of the 18th Century played Mozart at Avery Fisher Hall, where Christopher Hogwood and the Academy of Ancient Music had played Beethoven just two weeks earlier. This was a far more inspiriting affair, though it raised some of the same disquieting questions about the direction the early-music movement has taken of late.

LEAD: The two teams that played in the 1988 Super Bowl, the Washington Redskins and the Denver Broncos, met tonight, but without their Super Bowl quarterbacks. Doug Williams was on the Washington sideline with a sore back and his Denver counterpart, John Elway, was in the locker room with a stomach virus.

LEAD: Fingernails Q.What causes white spots on the fingernails? And does the half moon at the base of the nail have any function? A.These questions are related, said Dr. Phoebe Rich, a Seattle dermatologist. The commonest cause of the white spots, called punctate leukononychia, is probably mild trauma, such as pushing back the cuticle too hard.

LEAD: A picture caption on Saturday about the dedication of a refurbished halftime room at the Yale Bowl in New Haven misidentified the alumni shown. They were, from the left, Blake Walker, Dick Jenkins and Bob Blanchard.

LEAD: CROSS-COUNTRY Huber Leads Villanova to Victory: Vicki Huber won the individual title and led Villanova to the women's team victory in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships yesterday in Annapolis, Md. Huber, 22 years old, covered the Naval Academy's 5,000-meter course in 15 minutes 59 seconds, a course record.

LEAD: CARBON dioxide, the heat-trapping gas whose concentration in the atmosphere is rising steadily as humans burn more and more coal and oil, has lately captured the attention of a world that is confronting the question of global warming.

LEAD: A severe line of thunderstorms with damaging winds swept through the New York metropolitan area last night, toppling trees, blowing out windows, disrupting some electrical service and causing scattered subway and traffic delays, officials said.

LEAD: It is a wonder that Offenbach's ''Contes d'Hoffmann,'' with its history of textual confusions, ever makes sense on the stage. Despite claims made for competing editions of the score, there still is not - never can be - one unchallengeable version. But come together ''Hoffmann'' generally does, owing to its string of haunting melodies and boisterous ensemble numbers, but also for the possibilities it offers singing actors to portray different characters under one skin.

Wednesday, they left behind a formidable agenda of unfinished business to take up after they reconvene Jan. 23, on issues from child care to the Clean Air Act to the more fundamental deficit reduction that many lawmakers hoped for this year.

LEAD: The former commanding officer of the Nassau County Police Department's personnel bureau has been arraigned on charges that he used police officers for his personal benefit, including driving his daughter to college.
LEAD: It is beginning to dawn on many Republicans that the changing world order and a shifting public sentiment could spell major political problems for their party.

LEAD: In the soaring speeches at the Rumanian Communist Party Congress this week and in the hyperbolic celebration of President Nicolae Ceausescu's first 24 years in power by the local press, there has been no hint of recognition that the totalitarian regimes of Eastern Europe are crumbling.
LEAD: A crime spree by an inmate who walked away from a Florida center where he was living while completing a prison term has led officials to question parts of the state's work-release program.

LEAD: ECONOMIC POLICY Budget: Enacted a $14.7 billion deficit reduction plan that relies heavily on automatic spending cuts and measures viewed as accounting gimmicks to achieve the reduction. Plan also includes a 9-month extension of expiring tax breaks.
LEAD: Suspected Sinhalese radicals killed a South Korean engineer who tried to stop them from buring his company's vehicles, and 10 other people were killed in ethnic violence, officials said today.
LEAD: Rachel Wischnitzer, an authority on synagogue architecture and a professor emeritus at Yeshiva University, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 104 years old.
LEAD: We all remember Kurt Waldheim, don't we?

LEAD: An all-party Government of politicians and technocrats was sworn in here today, putting a formal if temporary end to the political crisis plaguing Greece since its two inconclusive general elections.
LEAD: Barry Sanders has brought a little gladness to an otherwise dismal season for the Detroit Lions.

LEAD: Members of Parliament gathered in a town on the main road to Syria today to prepare for the election of a successor to President Rene Moawad, who was assassinated Wednesday when a bomb blew up his car in Beirut.
LEAD: A citizens group lost another round today in its fight to have last year's toll increase on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway ruled illegal.

LEAD: With the passing of the 1988 Winter Olympics, another generation of figure skaters has faded from world consciousness, except for the lucky few, like Katarina Witt and Brian Boitano, who have won large contracts to dress up in sparkly, glitzy outfits to skate professionally.

LEAD: Ronnie Mutimusekwa, a 34-year-old street vendor who is infected with the AIDS virus, is trying to help educate the public about the disease in Zimbabwe, where people are said to doubt its rapid spread.

LEAD: A Cambodian guerrilla leader is offering $1,000 to $40,000 in gold to Cambodian soldiers who defect with Soviet fighter jets or other military hardware or deliver a Vietnamese soldier wearing a Cambodian Army uniform. The rebel leader, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who commands one of three guerrilla groups fighting the Vietnamese-installed Government, announced the reward offers in a broadcast over the resistance radio Wednesday.

LEAD: Politician Wounded in India An opposition politician was near death after he was shot in a violent first day of voting in the three-day election in India. Page A15. Lebanese Leaders Meet The members of the Lebanese Parliament, meeting in northern Lebanon, are expected to choose a new President today.

LEAD: Catalans have always considered themselves different from other Spaniards - more worldly and sophisticated. They take great pride in their literary, artistic and culinary heritage. Since most Spanish restaurants in New York are oriented toward Castile or Andalusia, the opening of Paradis Barcelona last summer promised an opportunity to sample seaside Catalan cuisine.
LEAD: The state spent more than $3 million to keep police officers at the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation for four months after a gambling raid last summer, officials said.
LEAD: ''It is our view that things here have gone so far that we need profound changes, including those of personnel.'' - Jan Skoda, head of Czechoslovakia's Socialist Party. [ A16:3. ]
LEAD: The East German Government announced a series of measures today that are intended to combat widespread smuggling and speculation with this country's severely battered currency.

LEAD: A service for Tim Wengerd, a choreographer who was formerly a leading dancer in the Martha Graham Dance Company, will be held at 7 P.M. next Friday in the Actor's Chapel at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, 239 West 49th Street. Mr. Wengerd died on Sept. 12 in Albuquerque, N.M.

LEAD: The South African Government today proclaimed the immediate integration of the business district in Boksburg, a Transvaal town where the far-right Conservatives restored whites-only signs and other trappings of so-called petty apartheid last year.

LEAD: The leaders of the flight attendants' union at Eastern Airlines told the members yesterday to return to work, a day after the pilots' union abandoned its nearly nine-month walkout.

LEAD: The State of Connecticut, stepping up its tax battle against mail-order companies, has issued a subpoena against Neiman-Marcus to determine the extent of the company's catalogue business in Connecticut.
LEAD: General Assembly ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

LEAD: Starring Victoria Principal, ''Blind Witness,'' the television movie on ABC this Sunday at 9 P.M., was produced by King-Phoenix Entertainment in association with Victoria Principal Productions. In other words, it is a star vehicle, the kind of showcase contraption that once used to be constructed for a Katherine Cornell or a Helen Hayes.

LEAD: Officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries predicted today that demand for the organization's oil would average 21.5 million barrels a day next year, well under its current level of production.

LEAD: Little girls in scrupulously neat ballerina chignons pass through the backstage lobby at City Center on their way to rehearsal for the Joffrey Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker.'' Their well-scrubbed faces glow with a subdued excitement that belies the attempt at casualness in their voices.

LEAD: Jurors hearing a lawsuit over the supposed merits of a new dog food were recently taken, via three-dimensional computer animation, on a journey inside a Labrador retriever's leg to see how its muscles, bones and joints function.

LEAD: B.A.T. Industries, the British conglomerate fighting a hostile $21 billion bid from Sir James Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd., said today that it had acquired more shares under a plan to buy back up to 10 percent of its stock.

LEAD: Samuel Beckett's ''Krapp's Last Tape'' is to be presented by En Garde Arts beginning Thursday at 8 P.M. at what the group describes as ''an intimate, dirt-strewn space on the Brooklyn waterfront,'' at 1 Main Street, off Water Street between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges. The co-production with the Talking Band will be presented Thursday through Sunday evenings at 8 P.M.

LEAD: Sidney Janis, the doyen of New York art dealers, whose gallery on West 57th Street mounted significant shows of European masters and helped put Abstract Expressionism on the international map, died yesterday after a bout with pneumonia. He was 93 years old and was active in the Sidney Janis Gallery until his 90th birthday.

LEAD: Banks in China will lend $27 billion to state-operated enterprises that need cash, a central bank official said on Wednesday, although the Government's tight credit policy will remain in effect.

LEAD: After the appearance of 28 witnesses over six days, the trial of a Miami police officer accused of manslaughter in the killing of two blacks has concluded one stage, the prosecution, and moves into another, the defense, on Friday.

LEAD: The television program is about a police officer being held hostage by a man with a rifle. The tension builds as the criminal demands the officer's gun. Time seems frozen as the two men glare at each other over their weapons. What is the officer to do?
LEAD: An unmanned barge carrying five million gallons of jet fuel drifted for more than a day near the site of the Exxon Valdez oil spill before a tug snagged the vessel today, the Coast Guard said.

LEAD: Set two people dancing together on stage and after only a few moments they can seem to be either loving or hating each other - or doing both simultaneously. Affections - and the lack of them - can be eloquently expressed in movement. So it is no wonder that choreographers are fond of creating ballets on themes of love.
LEAD: Alexander Dubcek threw his support behind anti-Government protesters in his hometown here this afternoon in a short address to about 70,000 demonstrators.

LEAD: Hank Kuhlmann, who replaced Gene Stallings as coach of the Phoenix Cardinals on Monday, wasted little time making a major change. LEAD: Zoya Zdanovskaya was alone in her cramped Moscow apartment on the night of Dec. 7, 1988, and desperate about her year-old grandson, Kirill. Believing she had ''nothing to lose,'' she wrote a letter to the Voice of America and sent it to Washington.

LEAD: Outside the Moskva Hotel in Belgrade's pre-winter chill, a group of high school students gathered signatures the other day on a petition calling for a free vote to choose the city's next mayor, a post traditionally filled by political fiat.

LEAD: Dakar Group, Solo
LEAD: One man was killed and another injured today in a shootout, the police said. Two men were arrested.
LEAD: On Gorky Street in central Moscow, a stranger watches ravenous shoppers search vainly for something to buy with the ration coupons that have replaced their worthless money.

LEAD: Peter Galenn, a tenor, devoted his Sunday evening program at Weill Recital Hall to works by black American composers. It was an interesting idea, and most of the composers whose music he chose wrote in an idiom so conservative and tuneful that his sequence of song settings and cantata and opera excerpts made for pleasant if not especially surprising or challenging listening.

LEAD: A man hunting deer on Thanksgiving Day was shot to death, the fourth hunter killed in New York this week, the police said.
LEAD: The Japanese Embassy here is modest, quiet and plain. The unadorned three-story building on a tree-lined street does not look like the outpost of an economic superpower.

LEAD: Carl (the Truth) Williams will defend his United States Boxing Association heavyweight title against Tyrell Biggs, an Olympic gold medalist, on Jan. 11 at Atlantic City. Ira Leibowitz, Williams's manager, said the fighter would appear at a hearing at the World Boxing Association Convention in Philadelphia today to ask that his loss July 21 to Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, be ruled no contest.

LEAD: A drug derived from a Chinese tree has proved to be a potent agent against colon cancer in experiments on animals, scientists are reporting in a journal today.

LEAD: Levels of carbon monoxide considered safe by Federal air quality standards can create a potentially dangerous oxygen shortage in the hearts of people with coronary artery disease, a study has shown.

LEAD: Westerners are exhilarated by the drama of Eastern Europe but puzzled about how to help. The West cannot alter the fact that it's Eastern Europe's job to break the chains of centralized control and to wean consumers from subsidized prices and producers from guaranteed sales. But the West can ease this painful process and modestly improve the chances for success.

LEAD: Saatchi & Saatchi said Wednesday that Andrew Woods had resigned as deputy chairman, deputy chairman of its consulting division and a member of its board. The resignation came only one month after the British advertising company appointed Robert Louis-Dreyfus as its new chief executive.
LEAD: Twelve years ago Jerome Andrulonis, a bacteriologist, contracted rabies while conducting a federally supervised experiment in a state laboratory on inoculating wild animals against the disease.

LEAD: Congress has passed a bill allowing Chinese students to stay in the United States after their visas expire. But Administration officials said today that President Bush might veto it at Beijing's request.
LEAD: Barely nine hours after a new casino opened its doors, a 76-year-old customer hit a $4.6 million jackpot.
LEAD: The crumbling of the Berlin wall was also the end of innocence for untold numbers of rabbits.
LEAD: Astronauts on the space shuttle Discovery put a Defense Department spy satellite in orbit today, sources said. But there was no confirmation from the space agency or the Pentagon.

LEAD: Japan's decision to award a lucrative computer chip patent to Texas Instruments Inc. is probably not a sign that the Japanese patent system will be streamlined, patent and trade specialists say. American manufacturers have long contended that Japan's system is rigged against them.
LEAD: The body of a woman was found today in the Genesee River Gorge, where the bodies of three other women who were slain have been found in the last month, the police said.

LEAD: Thousands of travelers in New York and New Jersey were delayed several hours yesterday afternoon when a power failure temporarily shut down service on Amtrak, New Jersey Transit and PATH trains between Manhattan and Newark.

LEAD: A Marine helicopter operating from an aircraft carrier crashed and sank Wednesday in the Mediterranean Sea, killing both crew members. The search for the AH-IT Cobra helicopter and its pilot and co-pilot was called off this morning, said Capt. Elizabeth Kerstens, a Marine Corps spokeswoman. The helicopter was operating from the carrier Iwo Jima off the coast of Spain when the crash occurred.

LEAD: There's a feast of funk available this weekend for anyone with enough stamina and resources. Three longtime exponents of this gritty, syncopated dance music are performing tonight and tomorrow night in Manhattan: a husky-voiced singer who has influenced a generation of soul shouters; a visionary bandleader whose specialty is a solid funk foundation with a psychedelic overlay, and a recently reunited instrumental band that exemplifies the distinctive New Orleans brand of rhythm-and-blues at its finest.
LEAD: The Giants' leader in total offense this year is not a runner or a receiver or a punt returner or a kickoff returner. He is a player who is a combination of all those.

LEAD: An American Airlines flight bound for Toronto from New York City was canceled yesterday morning after the airplane struck a catering truck on the tarmac at La Guardia Airport, officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Never one to shrink from taking credit for famous advertising campaigns, George Lois has now accused an automobile dealer association of passing one of his slogans to a rival agency and giving him neither credit nor compensation.

LEAD: Ethiopian and Eritrean peace negotiators settled two more procedural issues today. A spokeswoman for former President Jimmy Carter, who is mediating the talks, said the two sides agreed on a chairman and co-chairman and a secretariate for further talks aimed at ending their civil war. Mr. Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, treated both seven-member negotiating teams to a traditional American Thanksgiving dinner at a Nairobi hotel after three and a half hours of talks today.
LEAD: A judge fined Avtex Fibers Inc. $6.15 million Wednesday for polluting the Shenandoah River and ordered the company to pay to clean the river of a a chemical suspected of causing cancer.
LEAD: A citizens group seeking the recall of Mayor George J. Otlowski has enough signatures to put the matter on the ballot, but the Mayor plans to fight it.

LEAD: When Venezuela's state-owned oil company announced this month that it would spend $675 million to purchase the 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation that it does not already own, the announcement got the attention of more than the oil industry.

LEAD: Seven people received summonses for disorderly conduct yesterday after they briefly joined the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade with a black balloon shaped like a bomb that read, ''Stop U.S. Bombing of El Salvador'' on one side and ''No Vietnam War in El Salvador'' on the other.

LEAD: P. J. Carlesimo would like to discuss the present and future of Seton Hall basketball, but he cannot escape the recent past. The Pirates took a wonderful journey last spring that stopped in Seattle against Michigan in April, one basket shy of a National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.

LEAD: In a far-reaching effort to stimulate recycling, the Environmental Protection Agency is proposing that incinerator operators around the country be required to reduce the amount of garbage they burn by 25 percent by recycling it instead.

LEAD: Business along the New Jersey shore rebounded sharply last summer after a slump in the previous two years caused by reports of medical waste on bathing beaches and garbage slicks floating offshore, a new study reports.

LEAD: For the eighth time, Patricia Krenwinkel, a member of Charles Manson's ''family,'' has been denied parole for her conviction in the murders of the actress Sharon Tate and six other people. In denying parole on Wednesday, a panel of the Board of Prison Terms cited the brutality of the 1969 murders.

LEAD: Despite nearly two decades of active cultural exchange, Americans are still insufficiently informed about European art, and the P.S. 1 Museum in Queens is doing something about the situation. Its current exhibition -which is really three one-person shows - focuses on three French artists who are all but unknown here: Catherine Beaugrand, Andre Cadere and Raymond Hains.
LEAD: Nearly 600 utility workers in 41 Pennsylvania counties have been organized into a network to tell the police of possible drug laboratories.

LEAD: N.H.L. Bruins 6, Maple Leafs 0: Andy Moog stopped 32 shots in Boston last night for his second shutout. Boston pulled away early with three goals in the first period. Toronto's John Kordic and Boston's Michael Thelven started fighting at 12 minutes 36 seconds of the third period. Before the fight was over, Referee Terry Gregson called 124 minutes in penalties and 10 players were ejected from the game.

LEAD: In a program conceived and directed by Joe Layton, Debbie Shapiro is doing an exercise in self-effacement at Rainbow and Stars, on the 65th floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Her program includes songs introduced by Ruth Etting in the 1920's and a song that Doris Day sang in the film biography of Miss Etting in 1955.

LEAD: Vandals toppled a pole supporting an overhead phone cable and severed the cable yesterday morning, knocking out long-distance service for thousands of Westchester County customers, a New York Telephone spokesman said.

LEAD: Learn how to say ''lawyer'' in Serbo-Croatian or Farsi. Practice at an address like Park Avenue or Wilshire Boulevard, or, if you cannot afford that, at least have a mail drop there. LEAD: East Germans starting new lives on the western side of the Berlin wall joined American soldiers for a mess hall Thanksgiving today, feasting on turkey, cranberry sauce and stuffing. Dozens of recent East German immigrants were bused from the city's Marienfelde reception camp to several United States Army dining halls here.

LEAD: Johnny Moore, a former guard for the San Antonio Spurs, has returned to the team, declaring his bout with Desert Fever to be over and pledging to make the most of any playing time he gets.

LEAD: ''The Paintings of Jakuchu,'' Part II, at the Asia Society, may have an even better chance than Part I of changing Americans' perception of Japanese art. This show, like Part I, is a survey of the career of Ito Jakuchu (1716-1800), the son of a greengrocer from Kyoto who became a Buddhist monk and saw painting as a way of being both fully religious and free.

LEAD: Even as they celebrated the peaceful ending of the hostage crisis at the Hotel Salvador, military experts said the incident reinforced the most striking lesson of the recent rebel offensive here: That large numbers of leftist insurgents can enter and leave the capital at will, even under intense Government scrutiny and bombardment.

LEAD: Thanksgiving crept up on Delisa Holman and Cheryl-Dawn Dyer, East Villagers who came to New York four years ago from La Marque, Tex. As they celebrated early, a night of fried shrimp and white wine in the cozy roadhouse atmosphere of the Gulf Coast on West 12th Street in Manhattan dissolved into the most American of holidays.

LEAD: The out-of-court settlement of an Illinois abortion case on Wednesday did not remove the abortion debate from the Supreme Court's calendar. Two other cases, scheduled for argument before the Justices next Wednesday, provide the Court a chance to clarify or extend its ruling of last July in a Missouri case, a decision that gave the states new latitude to restrict access to abortion.
LEAD: The General Assembly's Office of Fiscal Analysis said today that the state could end the fiscal year with a $51.5 million deficit, mainly because of a sharp drop in sales tax revenues.
LEAD: Fearful of an American reaction to the recent surge of Japanese acquisitions, business and Government leaders here are reassessing their strategy for investing overseas.

LEAD: Faced with the everyday frustrations of urban education, the playwright Bill Cain responds with ''Stand-Up Tragedy,'' as in the apt title of his corrosive new play. First produced at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, it is now running in revised form at Hartford Stage. It is an angry work, filled with bitterness about the impossibility of amelioration.

LEAD: The military wants more land for training and war games in four Western states, land that is more than twice the size of Massachusetts. But hunters, ranchers and environmentalists see the plans as a land grab and a menace to wildlife and farming.

LEAD: FOR much of 1989, it seemed as though the only thing rising more rapidly than art prices was the price of auction house stocks. But in the last two weeks, a downdraft hit the price of Sotheby's shares.

''I had done a great deal of chamber music, but I was probably the only pianist on my block who had not performed the Beethoven 'Appassionata' in public.

LEAD: The powerful bomb that killed Lebanon's President, Rene Moawad, also shattered that country's best hope of peace. The legislators who elected him not three weeks ago speak gamely of choosing a constitutional successor soon. But the long-shot odds of extricating Lebanon from 15 years of deadly civil war have now turned longer still.

LEAD: A growing number of businesses that have found themselves in desperate straits are seeking advice from the Turnaround Management Association. Not many realize that the association has been struggling to sort out a mess of its own.

LEAD: THE Bush Administration's decision to start planning for deeper cuts in military spending has come partly in response to dramatic changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and partly as a result of domestic budgetary and economic pressures.

LEAD: The exhibition at the Spanish Institute of 87 Italian drawings from the Biblioteca Nacional in Madrid should not be missed. For a finer overview of Italian draftsmanship during the 17th and 18th centuries, a trip to Rome would be required.

LEAD: The fullback Rico Tyler scored the winning touchdown on a 1-yard run in the third quarter as 17th-ranked West Virginia capitalized on a turnover and beat Syracuse, 24-17, tonight in a game between bowl-bound teams.

LEAD: A 13-year-old Queens boy was shot in the head and killed at his home Wednesday night, and yesterday morning the police charged a longtime friend with his murder while the two were ''horsing around.''

LEAD: After leading the major leagues in strikeouts at the age of 42 last season, Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers apparently has no desire to be farmed out. LEAD: Paul Moyer, a Seattle Seahawks safety, has a ruptured disk in his neck that will sideline him for the rest of the season and could end his football career, a published report says.
LEAD: This is a city with a dependency problem, one that is destroying livelihoods, forcing people from their homes and contributing to pervasive crime.

LEAD: A Thanksgiving snowstorm, the first in New York City in 51 years, cloaked the metropolitan region in wintry white yesterday, preventing high school football games from being played, horses from running at Aqueduct and Snoopy and Bugs Bunny from making it to the big parade in Manhattan.

LEAD: A national referendum on Sunday to decide on the sequence of the first free Hungarian elections in 42 years has deeply split the opposition and put the largest of the new parties in the same camp as the governing Socialist Party.

LEAD: David N. Dinkins appointed five committees yesterday to look for candidates to head major agencies in New York City, but his transition aides noted that all the jobs will not be filled by the time the Mayor-elect takes office on Jan. 1.
LEAD: The average consumption of hard liquor by Americans has fallen to its lowest level in three decades, Federal health researchers reported today.

LEAD: New York City's Commission on Human Rights yesterday announced the reinstatement of the director of its AIDS discrimination division and his deputy, who had been dismissed from their jobs last month, touching off protests from AIDS and homosexual-rights groups when the two asserted they had been removed because of their homosexuality.

LEAD: BABAR, the dapper king of the elephants, has happily resettled from France to Middletown. Laurent de Brunhoff, the author and illustrator of more than 30 Babar storybooks, now makes his home on the Wesleyan University campus with his companion, Phyllis Rose, an author and English professor.

LEAD: FIFTY years after Hardie Gramatky wrote the now classic ''Little Toot,'' a story beloved by children the world over, the posthumous publication of his sequel, ''Little Toot and the Loch Ness Monster,'' represents for his family a triumph of art and spirit.

LEAD: A FEW months ago Donald R. Byrnes was cautiously optimistic. Even a month ago, he was only ''mildly anxious.'' These days, he is still trying to keep his cool, he says, but it is getting more and more difficult.

LEAD: BESIEGED by crime and eager to attract top-quality officers, New Jersey police agencies are intrigued by a Federal proposal that would offer scholarships to college students willing to wear a badge after graduation. But some law-enforcement officials have expressed skepticism over the proposal.

LEAD: The United States is acting like a poor country when it is not one. Washington sits virtually paralyzed as the world is stunned daily by events in East Europe. Paris called a conference among its European colleagues and West Germany has already announced plans to spend billions of dollars on investment in East Germany.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Kellner of New York and Frankfurt have made known the engagement of Mrs. Kellner's daughter, Audrey Lynn Zissu, to Gerald Austen Hensley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald C. Hensley of Wellington, New Zealand. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: A Havana court sentenced three Cuban human rights advocates to prison after convicting them of giving false information to foreign journalists during a drug trial last summer, the Cuban government press agency reported.

At a cocktail party full of jazzy music, tinkling ice cubes and an aura of boozy flirtation, a French diplomat named Valmont stalks the room, making eyes at women wearing little black dresses. His wife, Juliette, has plotted this event as part of her ambitious campaign to further her husband's career, but her sultry eyes are also on the lookout for desirable men. They are cold-blooded opportunists with a notorious open marriage, these Valmonts, played by Jeanne Moreau and Gerard Philipe in a world-weary manner. But, directed by the less-than-artistic Roger Vadim, this first screen version of ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' was hardly a timeless triumph. In 1959, having earned a bad-boy reputation with ''And God Created Woman,'' Mr. Vadim took up Choderlos de Laclos's classic 1782 novel of sexual manipulation and romantic war games and sent it skittering toward the 60's. Here, when Valmont falls desperately in love with an apparently unattainable woman, she is a ski bunny with hair teased up like Brigitte Bardot's.

LEAD: APPLYING wallpaper is no longer the tricky, messy task it once was. Although stronger paper and slower-drying adhesives have eased the job considerably, achieving smooth-surfaced results still depends on preparing the wall carefully before applying the paper.

LEAD: The Christmas decorations that appeared everywhere last week, the throngs of shoppers, the anticipation of a joyous holiday season - none of this can camouflage the poverty and pain in the metropolitan area.

LEAD: I WANT TO GROW HAIR, I WANT TO GROW UP, I WANT TO GO TO BOISE: Children Surviving Cancer. By Erma Bombeck. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) It's hard to imagine a more well-intentioned book. Erma Bombeck has put her considerable talent as a humorist in the service of changing people's attitudes toward children with cancer.
LEAD: Elizabeth Larkin O'Brien and John Charles Paxton were married yesterday in San Francisco by the Rev. Richard Fowler at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

LEAD: Karel Urbanek, a Communist Party functionary unknown abroad and little known in his own nation before he was surprisingly chosen as Communist Party chief, found himself in his first day in office at the center of swelling criticism. He was forced to go on television to appeal to the Czechoslovak nation for understanding.

LEAD: Bruce Cohen was astonished. Here it was, a week still to go until Thanksgiving, and there he was, that hefty, white-bearded, familiar-looking fellow sporting the red suit, sitting smack in the center of the East Brunswick (N.J.) Mall, surrounded by dancing elves. Dancing elves before Thanksgiving?

LEAD: The 20-story headquarters Carrere & Hastings created in 1912 for the U.S. Rubber Company at 1790 Broadway, at 58th Street, is a building of discreet qualities. It cannot claim any superlatives, and most of the guidebooks omit it, but it has what many better known buildings lack, good manners.

LEAD: Michiyo and Dancers, a New York-based company directed by Michiyo Tanaka, a Japanese-born choreographer, shared a program with the Sapporo Seibi Dance Company, a visiting troupe from Sapporo, Japan, on the evening of Nov. 17 at Gould Hall. Both groups combined jazz with various modern-dance styles.

LEAD: The engagement of Dr. Barbara Anne Kelly and Dr. Gregory Adrian Hack, the son of Cornelius Hack of North Smithfield, R.I., and the late Ann W. Hack, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William M. Kelly of Tenafly, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bernd P. Kuehn of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Westerly, R.I., have announced February wedding plans for their daughter Catherine Elizabeth Kuehn and Malcolm Keith Price, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce E. Price of Ballarat, Victoria, Australia.

LEAD: CLOWNING around is not tolerated in most houses of worship. But at the Shore Christian Center Church here, it is heartily encouraged through a ''clown ministry'' that helps with everything from baby-sitting in church during services to visiting the sick and elderly at hospitals and nursing homes.

LEAD: IN a sense Mikhail S. Gorbachev may be seeking the impossible in his Mediterranean rendezvous with President Bush, trying to project the image of a confident leader as the Communist monolith melts in Eastern Europe.

LEAD: The Aeroflot flights from here to Moscow were serving a younger-than-usual clientele this week, as dozens of Soviet teen-agers slung backpacks over faded denim jackets and bid farewell to the educational, economic and emotional realities of the United States.

LEAD: Advocates for the homeless welcome the Bush Administration's plans for helping homeless people as important and symbolic steps, but they say the proposal is too modest to have much impact on the growing problem.

LEAD: Question: About 12 years ago my husband and his partner, who were both bachelors at the time, bought a co-op apartment. The shares are held in joint tenancy with a right-of-survivorship clause in their contract.

LEAD: Counterfeiters have been around since the birth of coins, faking and debasing currency to make a profit. But the Celts used their skills as metallurgists to produce some of the finest counterfeit coins of pre-Christian Europe. Their counterfeits are all the more interesting because the Celts had little use for money - their economy was based on bartering.
LEAD: Rick Fox scored 23 points, including the 3-pointer that gave North Carolina the lead for good as the Tar Heels beat Villanova, 78-68, in the semifinals of the Maui Classic.

LEAD: Officials of Allegheny County have decided not to set up a Nativity scene this year, even though the Supreme Court of the United States ruled that a display surrounded by reindeer and Santa Claus would be permissible.

LEAD: At the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., Ellen Glaser, a reporter for The Federal Times in Springfield, Va., was married last evening to Scott Rafshoon, a political reporter for The Free Lance-Star in Fredericksburg, Va. Rabbi Jack Stern and Cantor Stephen Merkel officiated.

LEAD: Four 100-year-old buildings that had stood vacant for a decade on the eastern end of the block bounded by Laight, Vestry, Varick and Hudson Streets in TriBeCa have been renovated into a warehouse intended primarily for household goods. Called the New York Security Mini Storage, the six-story facility near the Manhattan end of the Holland Tunnel that incorporates the adjacent buildings will have 28 Laight Street as its address.

LEAD: The fall fashion accessory is often much more than just a scarf, a handbag, a bracelet or a pair of earrings. It can also be the takeoff point for flights of fancy that lift the ordinary, the humdrum, the everyday, into what Rod Serling used to call ''another dimension.''

LEAD: WITH the approach of winter, New York City's hospitals are bracing for what is fast becoming a sorry seasonal ritual: huge numbers of patients, many with preventable illnesses, packed double to a berth or spilling into emergency room hallways, waiting hours for treatment and, when needed, admission to scarce beds.

LEAD: A NEW state law that requires AIDS education in public schools is getting mixed reviews from parents. Some say that such lessons should be taught at home and that the classes should stress abstinence rather than safe sex. Other parents say they are relieved that the schools are offering AIDS classes.

LEAD: A light plane carrying two dozen Soviet-made antiaircraft missiles crashed in eastern El Salvador today on what Government officials said was a mission to resupply leftist guerrillas here with weapons from Nicaragua.
LEAD: BUDGET officials were working late at the Pentagon last week as the Red Army Chorus launched into its program onstage at Kennedy Center, just across the river.

LEAD: The United States will drastically cut funds to the Rome-based United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization if the agency agrees next week to cooperate with the Palestine Liberation Organization on agricultural development in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Administration officials say.

LEAD: Some 2,000 friends and admirers of Virgil Thomson, the composer and critic who died on Sept. 30, gathered yesterday afternoon in Manhattan for a memorial concert in his honor at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Yesterday would have been Mr. Thomson's 93d birthday.

LEAD: The formula is sturdy, no doubt about it. A head of state has been targeted for assassination. Word of the plot leaks out. A small band of Good Guys has less than three days to prevent a murder that could change the course of history. In the 1973 film version of Frederick Forsyth's best-seller ''The Day of the Jackal,'' the villains were out to get Charles de Gaulle of France.

LEAD: The Roman Catholic Bishop of San Diego has denied communion to Lucy Killea, a state Assemblywoman, because as a candidate for California's Senate she strongly advocates the pro-choice position in the abortion debate.

LEAD: ''The Crucible,'' written in 1953 by Arthur Miller, is produced constantly all over the world. On Thursday the play, which links the Salem witch trials of the 1690's to McCarthyism in the 1950's, will open at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, where Arvin Brown will direct a cast that includes John Braden, Charles Cioffi, Frank Converse and Virginia Downing.

LEAD: Series titles are often meant to be only loose indications of the music to be offered. But at the first of this season's Music Today concerts, on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, a listener was struck by the freedom with which the temporal part of the series' title has been stretched. All four of the works on the program were by living composers, but only one of the pieces was written this year - or, for that matter, in the 1980's.

LEAD: New York City will resume its physical examination for prospective firefighters early next month even though the City Health Commissioner has warned that it can cause kidney failure, officials said yesterday.
LEAD: The Sacramento Kings placed Ralph Sampson, acquired just two months ago, on the injured list yesterday so the 7-foot-4-inch center can rehabilitate his weak knees.

LEAD: AS I WAS DRIVING THROUGH Nevada recently, a highway billboard proclaimed ''Winnemucca -If You Don't Visit, Who Will?'' That pessimistic plea did not prepare us for the extraordinary Basque meal we had in a restaurant tucked off the main street of this small town in the northern part of the state.

LEAD: When America - or at least opera-loving America - hunkers down before the family radio console this Saturday afternoon, it will be celebrating more than the advent of yet another national broadcast season of the Metropolitan Opera. LEAD: THANSKGIVING is just behind us but the Christmas musical season has opened in the county. For starters, there are several Nutcrackers; the Tchaikovsky classic receiving four separate productions over the next two weeks.

LEAD: I WAS sitting in the grass high above Long Island Sound. For nearly a week the North Fork area had been intensely humid, with squalls building throughout each day, and striking, usually by night, leaving in their wake immaculate skies that lasted into bright dawns, the air hot but dry.
LEAD: BUSYBODIES By Patrick Anderson. 256 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.
LEAD: Hurray for the Town of Huntington and Kenneth A. Christensen (''Restricting Illegal Apartments,'' Sept. 24), leaders in the legalizing of two-family dwellings.

LEAD: Conrad Jordan has a proprietary interest in the steel drum, which he describes as ''the only musical instrument invented in this century and the only musical instrument invented in the Western Hemisphere.'' For more than 25 years Mr. Jordan has been tuning steel drums and has made a life's work out of studying how the drum - also known as a pan or steel piano - is made.
LEAD: Three children were killed and their mother critically injured in an early-morning fire yesterday that devoured their first-floor apartment in Brooklyn.

LEAD: In the prosperous state of Punjab, homeland of Indian Sikhs, an embittered and divided electorate will choose only 13 of India's 545 members of Parliament. But among those 13 may be the widow of one of Indira Gandhi's assassins and two men now in prison, charged with complicity in her murder.

LEAD: The wreck of the Exxon Valdez eight months ago in Alaska's Prince William Sound caused America's largest oil spill and may yet turn out to be America's most costly environmental disaster. But it has yielded a measure of redemption, jolting Congress into writing credible legislation that would greatly increase the cost of carelessness by shippers and producers of oil.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Steven L. Babits of Cranford, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan N. Babits to Dean M. Vogel, the son of Adelene Hall Vogel of Cranford, N.J., and Grafton, Vt., and Harold A. Vogel Jr. of Bedminster, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: The construction of the tallest office tower in Africa on a sprawling, tree-studded city park here has provoked unusual popular hostility in a country where opposition to official projects is voiced with care.

LEAD: Brett Russ threw for three touchdowns and ran for another today as unbeaten Union College crushed Montclair State, 45-6, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III East Regional final.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Out here in the West where old means almost anything that happened before World War II, Santa Fe is the exception. It was established in 1610 by settlers from New Spain to the south. And although residents like to talk about ''descendants of the conquistadors,'' the folks who came up the Camino Real from Mexico City in the train of Juan de Onate were already two or three generations removed from their Spanish antecedents and their blood was thoroughly mixed with that of the Mexican natives their fathers and grandfathers had conquered.

LEAD: Lawrence A. LEAD: ''We've often said fantasy becomes reality. But fantasy is a dream, it's not real, at least not until today.'' Steve Wynn, on the opening of his Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas, a $630 million casino complex complete with working volcano.

LEAD: In the beginning of the personal computer age, many executives were appalled at the low quality of sales help. Some salespeople could not answer basic questions. Worse, some passed off their wild guesses as expertise. As years went by, salespeople climbed the learning curve along with users, and it became fairly rare to find a dunce selling equipment in the major stores.
