LEAD: Less than one-tenth of New York City's municipal construction projects are completed on schedule, and more than half are not even under construction when they should be finished, according to a report by a private civic group.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Schlesinger of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Joan Schlesinger, to Gary H. Yablon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Yablon of Baldwin, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

LEAD: WHEN the House of Representatives approved a measure to expand the Medicare program to protect older Americans from the high cost of acute extended illness, all 14 members of the New Jersey delegation voted for it. But when the House voted to repeal or curtail the Catastrophic Coverage Act last month, all 14 largely abandoned it.

LEAD: Food manufacturers and diet marketers are seeing to it that the demand for low-calorie foods does not go unsated. The selection of ''light'' foods is limitless: mayonnaise, canned fruit, popcorn and dog food. Even Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., usually a super-rich ice cream, recently announced a new light version.

LEAD: Tracey Brooke Ozer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Ozer of Kings Point, L.I., was married last evening to Scott Michael Schweber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Schweber of Kings Point, at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Robert S. Widom officiated, assisted by Cantor Henry Weintraub.

LEAD: Something strange - not new, but ever more conspicuous - haunts the cultural landscape. Movie makers and television producers have become our most powerful, though perhaps not our most careful, historians. It seems fair to say that more people are getting their history, or what they think is history, from the movies these days than from the standard history books.

LEAD: On a wall of the Kafue Textile factory in Zambia there is a hand-drawn sign that proclaims the local design philosophy. ''Quality always wins,'' it reads. ''Quality is the best policy. Quality strengthens the nation.''

LEAD: POSSIBLY as early as January, or maybe not until July, all New York City employees will come under new ethics rules restricting post-government employment that are stricter than the current rules, or maybe not strict enough.
LEAD: LONG ISLANDERS who opposed the operation of Long Island Lighting Company's nuclear plant at Shoreham have been taken to task several times during the last year in the pages of newspapers.

LEAD: An inmate whose sentence was to have expired today was the first to be charged in connection with two nights of riots last month at Camp Hill State Prison in which 123 guards and inmates were injured, the police said today.

LEAD: Announcement of the engagement of Julia Marie Robertson to Ian M. Kasman has been made by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William S. Robertson of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

LEAD: The marriage of Carol Anne Heher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Heher Jr. of Princeton, N.J., to David Lamborn Peters, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Landon Peters of Princeton, took place yesterday at the Edith Memorial Chapel of the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School. The Rev. Patrick Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.
LEAD: BILL JOHNSON KILLS THE ENGINE OF HIS RUBYRED Mercury Astro and lets the sleek fiberglass bass boat drift along the steep northern shore of the Monongahela River, into the heart of Pittsburgh.

LEAD: The spotlight of the art world is rarely drawn to art that is quiet and discreet. New York is so noisy, so swollen with information, so restless with issues that seem to demand immediate attention, that reticent, self-contained art is easily overlooked or dismissed. There is a general assumption - particularly in New

LEAD: While many American businesses are still trying to figure out how to take advantage of the 12-nation European Community's move to a single market economy in 1992, others are already profiting from it.
LEAD: The mood has lightened in Virginia's coal country.

LEAD: Poland's Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, said today that he had achieved ''complete unanimity'' with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on key issues of European security, but he evidently won no immediate help from the Kremlin in dealing with his economic crisis.
LEAD: Rutgers reached the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament for the second time in its history with a 2-1 overtime victory today over Vermont.

LEAD: Q. Soon after we moved into our new home, a wood toilet paper roller was accidentally flushed down the toilet. All attempts to remove this with a snake have failed. Sometimes the toilet flushes O.K. and other times not. Do you know of anything that would dissolve the roller?

LEAD: Rosalie Cavise of North Syracuse, N.Y., and Naples, Fla., has made known the engagement of her daughter Rosalia Patrice Cavise to Michael Benjamin Levy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Werner Levy of Forest Hills, Queens. A February wedding is planned.

LEAD: Smoke issued from vents, as a kaleidoscope of lights flashed wildly. Two hulking figures brimming with human meanness, with painted faces and Mohawk haircuts and encased in black vests decorated with metal studs, commenced an ominous walk down a black ramp toward the ring. Thumping rock music bounced off the ceiling, and as the pair neared the ring, fireworks exploded over their heads.

LEAD: By the end of 1990, record companies are saying, the vinyl LP will be mostly a memory. Statistics are piling up: According to the Recording Industry Association of America, which monitors the larger companies, in the first half of 1989 LP's accounted for only 4 percent of the value of recordings shipped; in units, LP's were outnumbered 12 to 1 by cassettes and nearly 6 to 1 by CD's.

LEAD: On the very first page of THE TITAN GAME by Niven Busch (Random House, $17.95), it is clear that we are in the presence of a real writer. The topic is weapons. ''Never before in history had there been such a glut of weapons of all kinds: weapons lurking with eyes agleam in the black holes of outer space; weapons that could pop out of the void and kill at ten times the speed of sound; weapons as small as pinheads and as big as cathedrals; .

LEAD: Andre Ware threw two of his four touchdown passes to Manny Hazard and set an National Collegiate Athletic Association record, and Houston turned 5 turnovers by Texas Tech into 27 points on the way to a 40-24 Southwest Conference victory tonight.
LEAD: Frank A. Southard Jr., a former senior official of the International Monetary Fund, died of cancer today at a hospital near his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: Cleaning and dressing up the exteriors of two theaters just west of Broadway in Manhattan's rialto is costing their owner about $900,000. The facade of the Ritz Theater, at 219 West 48th Street, has just been cleaned and renovated for $400,000 and the Virginia Theater, at 245 West 52d Street, is undergoing a more extensive facelift that will also replace the marquee and doors at a total cost of $500,000.
LEAD: Distant Secrets Unraveling the Mysteries of Our Ancient Past By Ronald Schiller Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing Group. 260 pages. $17.95.

LEAD: ARTISTS of the same generation, Isabel Bishop and Reginald Marsh both followed the tradition established by the Ashcan School and both gentrified it. Marsh's female archetype appears to be a floozie but she is essentially a Rubenesque creature, and his crowds, though they lounge on Coney Island, are not far removed from those of Rubens and other
LEAD: A generation ago, the big rivals for the Giants were the Cleveland Browns. After that, the Giants' main rivalries were with the Dallas Cowboys and then the Washington Redskins.

LEAD: On a visit to New York this month, Yan Basely thought about the artists who inspired his decorative designs, paintings that lend themselves to fabric, wallpaper and carpet. ''Watteau was always important,'' he said. Right now he is thinking of Thomas Hart Benton.

LEAD: Dieting is no longer an obsession of women in search of a thinner profile. There is a growing national consensus that being overweight is unhealthy - as well as unattractive. The burgeoning weight-control business is bound to grow fatter.

LEAD: Traveling alone has its pluses: you can go where you want when you want, and you are spared that runaway irritation that comes of suddenly spotting all the little flaws in your companion (who alone seems to be detaining you from perfect enjoyment) and the tension of having to keep that knowledge secret.

LEAD: Michael Harwood, an author and naturalist, died of an embolism Friday at the University of California at San Diego Medical Center, where he had undergone arterial surgery. He was 55 years old and a resident of Washington, Conn.

LEAD: ''Artist Ascending an Airplane,'' an interview drama in 11 scenes. The action takes place over a little more than an hour in Conference Room B in the first-class lounge of British Airways at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York. Scene 1: Nov. 14, 8:30 P.M.
LEAD: Bubba Paris is planning a way for you to become more familiar with the San Francisco 49ers. Paris said that you can soon do this by dialing a 900 number that he will answer.

LEAD: ''I'VE been a reform Communist all my life,'' said a party loyalist in his late 50's a couple of weeks ago. ''They've always told me that it was still too early for my kind of thinking. Now I'm afraid it's too late.''

LEAD: Leonard B. Boudin, a civil liberties lawyer who in more than 50 years of practice defended a number of controversial clients, including Julian Bond, Paul Robeson, Benjamin Spock and Daniel Ellsberg, died at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan late Friday after a heart attack. He was 77 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DeWitt Clinton, behind the strong running of Dan LiSanti, defeated Lincoln yesterday, 25-22, and advanced to the Public Schools Athletic League championship game. LiSanti carried 18 times for 131 yards. Clinton (10-1) will meet

LEAD: A 4-month-old boy was in critical condition last night after he was struck on the head with a metal pipe during an argument between two men in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the police said. The baby was taken to Coney Island Hospital after the argument in an apartment at 3081 Cropsey Avenue.

LEAD: Opposition leaders redoubled their pressure on the tottering Communist regime in Czechoslovakia today, staging an immense protest rally and insisting that the shuffling of the Politburo on Friday night and further resignations this morning had failed to move the nation far enough toward democracy.
LEAD: THE JEWS IN AMERICA Four Centuries of an Uneasy Encounter: A History. By Arthur Hertzberg. 428 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.
LEAD: O.K., EVERYBODY, let's get organized: what are we going to call the get-together of the heads of the two superpowers next weekend?

LEAD: We have learned to cringe from superstar personal appearances, but when Kathleen Battle and Placido Domingo gave a joint operatic concert during the Metropolitan Opera's Tokyo engagement last year, something was going right. Maybe the plan to issue a Deutsche Grammophon recording (427 686; CD and cassette) made it special; maybe the participation of James Levine (appearing for the first time in Japan) added a sense of occasion and pride.
LEAD: THE LONE STAR The Life of John Connally. By James Reston Jr. Illustrated. 691 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $25.
LEAD: I have before me a series of snapshots of a mink trying to yank a pickerel from an angler's hand.

LEAD: Mike McPhee, playing in only his second game since returning from a lengthy injury, scored his first two goals of the season as the Montreal Canadiens ended Boston's unbeaten string at nine games by recording a 5-3 victory over the Bruins tonight.

LEAD: David Baltimore is well known to me and to many other scientists as an eminently honorable man (''Conduct Unbecoming,'' by Philip Weiss, Oct. 29). His scientific work on the enzyme reverse transcriptase is of enormous significance and may be a critical step in our ability ultimately to control AIDS.

LEAD: ALMOST 45 years after Franklin D. Roosevelt returned from the Yalta conference, his heady vision of self-determination in Eastern Europe may finally be coming to pass, though in a manner quite different from the one he foresaw. In the intervening decades, ''Yalta'' has been one of the most charged words in the

LEAD: Elegant evening dresses and the sparkle of jewels brought grace and glitter to a week of charity galas. On Tuesday the New York City Ballet's opening night performance was followed by a supper dance on the promenade of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. Patty Davis Raynes organized the evening.

LEAD: Audrey Lynn Silver, a daughter of William Silver and a stepdaughter of Mrs. Silver of New York, and Henry L. Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Levin of New York, were married in New York last evening. Rabbis Charles Kroloff and Martin Zion officiated at the Pierre.

LEAD: ROBERT GEORGE JAHN HAS A NARROW face, sunken cheeks and a host of eccentricities. His office is crammed with stuffed animals, mainly Princeton tigers, and pictures of a childhood favorite, giraffes. Before heading off to a meeting at one of the half-dozen corporate, foundation and university boards on which he serves, he snaps on his favorite Princeton baseball cap.
LEAD: The holiday season is, of course, a time for shopping - and window shopping.

LEAD: The evidence was clear: Michigan had the better team today against Ohio State. But it took the Wolverines almost forever to prove that and to confirm their reservations for the Tournament of Roses.
LEAD: Joe Ross rushed for 190 yards and two touchdowns as Georgia Southern defeated Villanova, 52-36, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA playoffs.

LEAD: A business and political associate of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos has slipped into the Philippines in a homecoming that took the Government by surprise and raised the hopes of Marcos supporters.

LEAD: LUIS ROLDAN, an 8-year-old third grader from Highland Park, clenched a $10 bill in a fist thrust deep in his pocket. He stood before a blue and white Scrambler Duracycle lying on its side; ''Item No. 44, minimum bid - $2,'' a tag on the handlebars read. Luis was convinced that the bike would soon be his.

LEAD: Part of the estate of Percy H. Johnston, a millionaire banker who died in 1957, is being developed into 21 upscale homes in Montclair, N.J. Mr. Johnston's five-bedroom home, which was built in 1940, was sold earlier this year for $400,000 and the 21 houses are to be built on eight surrounding acres.

LEAD: THE Board of Legislators, seeking what some members said was a much-needed bipartisan spirit, took steps to change its leadership last week as it began work on reducing the county's first $1 billion budget.
LEAD: FOR Cesar Alvarez, a senior at Hastings High School, the pressure was intense.
LEAD: ADVICE to museumgoers: When you visit the exciting new skylighted atriums and expanded gallery space of the renovated Newark Museum, do not miss the two outstanding craft exhibitions.

LEAD: FOR years, the New York City Council has mostly labored in the political shadows, spending a lot of its time dealing with such matters as new names for city streets, parks and ball fields. At the other end of City Hall the Board of Estimate, dominated largely by the mayor, has held the limelight, making many important decisions on municipal affairs.

LEAD: If Bill Cook (''Illegal Apartments: Let's Face Facts,'' Letter, Oct. 22) was really interested in stating statistics, they should be the amount of profits Realtors (like himself) are raking in at the expense of the taxpayer.
LEAD: NANCY Written and illustrated by Karen Barbour. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 8)
LEAD: Everything's coming up roses This time for me for me for me!

LEAD: WHEN Osamu Inoue was an undergraduate majoring in business administration at Kobe University in Japan, he set his sights on a career that would take him beyond the borders of Japan into international markets.

LEAD: As they gathered by the glow of a 40-watt bulb here one evening this week, a group of Afghans opposed to the Soviet-backed Government of President Najibullah found hope in the recent events that have unseated Communist leaders in Eastern Europe. Government officials and Soviet diplomats, however, say the situations are not comparable.

LEAD: IT was Stalin who asked derisively how many divisions the Pope had. Now, a successor who would dismantle Stalin's legacy is about to journey to Rome, recognizing that what the Pope may lack in troop strength he compensates for with a moral and political force that even the Kremlin must respect.
LEAD: ANIMAL ACTS By Cris Mazza. 163 pp. New York: Fiction Collective. Distributed by Sun & Moon Press, Los Angeles. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $8.95.

LEAD: OF SUCH SMALL DIFFERENCES, by Joanne Greenberg. (Signet/New American Library, $4.50.) John Moon, a young poet who is both deaf and blind, falls in love with an actress. As in her earlier book ''I Never Promised You a Rose Garden'' (written under the name Hannah Green), Joanne Greenberg ''calls attention to the slow, painful movement that charts our struggles from isolation toward connectedness,'' Richard Perry said here last year.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: AT 5 A.M. on the William Floyd Parkway in Suffolk, no creatures are stirring, not even a raccoon. It is so dark, so still, you don't know if it's morning or evening, and your body begs not to find out.

LEAD: Swept by the tornado of events in Eastern Europe, the Italian Communist Party, largest in the West, has formally decided to change its name and its identity, down to the hammer-and-sickle emblem.

LEAD: SHOPPERS began lining up very early on Friday outside the B. Altman & Company store in Manhattan. The first day of the Christmas shopping season was also the second day of Altman's going-out-of-business sale. And while the prices may have been beatable - 20 percent was the standard discount -thousands wanted to get in on the last days of the retailer that for 124 years set a high standard for elegance, service and merchandise.

LEAD: The record that gave me the greatest pleasure and demanded the most repeated listening this year was Sir Charles Mackerras's second CD outing with the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, a luminous Mendelssohn ''Italian'' Symphony paired with a light-textured, elfin performance of eight extracts from the ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' incidental music (Virgin VC 7 90725).
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Like Ken Russell, John Schlesinger and John Boorman, Tony Palmer is a graduate of the British Broadcasting Corporation in the 1960's: what has come to be seen, in retrospect, as the Golden Age of British television. But where many of his former colleagues have become movie directors, Mr. Palmer is best known as a maker of musical documentaries (including studies of Maria Callas, Benjamin Britten and William Walton) and feature-length portraits of composers (most recently Shostakovich in ''Testimony'').
LEAD: WHETHER he is helping them find jobs or cutting through red tape to expedite benefits long overdue, Bill Howard says that New Jersey veterans today are in need of extraordinary help.

LEAD: PRESIDENT BUSH and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet each other off the coast of Malta next week at one of those rare moments when you can hear the pages of history turning - a moment when the 40-year-old arrangements of the postwar world are coming to an end and demanding redefinition. But Mr. Bush and Mr.

LEAD: Fresh details of an alleged assassination squad operated by the South African police have emerged from a third man identifying himself as a squad member, and Government critics have continued to call for an independent judicial inquiry into the scandal.

LEAD: IN ''Twice Around the Park,'' two one-act comedies by Murray Schisgal now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, human relationships are not explored so much as they are mugged.

LEAD: It's business as usual at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. and, considering the cutbacks on Wall Street these days, that is pretty remarkable. Take the branch near here in suburban Frontenac. One recent day, as the markets remained lackluster, there was the hum of business in the air. Phones were ringing, brokers were chatting up clients and plans were being made to find desks for people who had just been hired.

LEAD: Men are more likely to join weight-control programs held at their workplace than those that meet in their community. That is what the Diet Workshop branch in Dayton, Ohio, which is considered the fattest state, has discovered. Males account for 33 percent of the 400 people enrolled in its workplace programs, but make up only 9 percent of the 3,200 dieters in its standard program.
LEAD: The crack business, it turns out, is a modern, brutalized version of a 19th-century sweatshop.
LEAD: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.

LEAD: Skiing Schneider Captures Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, the defending World Cup champion, who fell on her first run of the season Friday, turned in two flawless runs to win the women's slalom yesterday at Park City, Utah. Schneider, who won 14 times last year, negotiated the 427-meter course at the Park City Ski Area in 47.77 seconds on her first run and in 46.88 on her second for a total of 1:34.65.
LEAD: IN a world where hyphenated surnames abound, I'm a bit of an anomaly. I'm divorced, and I still have my ex-husband's surname.
LEAD: As the developer of the parcel that was the subject of ''Housing on Aquifer Opposed'' (Oct. 29), I'd like to make the following comments.

LEAD: An arsonist set fire to a bedding display in a crowded Queens department store yesterday, but two off-duty firefighters who were shopping independently with their wives put out the flames before their on-duty comrades got there, the Fire Department said.

LEAD: The engagement of Claudia Elizabeth Shaheen to Jeffrey Sadler Morgan, the son of Mrs. E. Sadler Morgan of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Morgan, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. James William McEnery of Chapel Hill, N.C. A January wedding is planned.
LEAD: Raspberry ale? Is this man serious?

LEAD: Mathias Rust, the West German who flew his single-engine plane to the edge of Red Square in Moscow in 1987, said his aim then was to talk to Mikhail S. Gorbachev about world peace and to dramatize his utopian goals. Last week, Mr. Rust, now 21 years old, may have had a more mundane goal in mind. The authorities said he stabbed a nurse at a Hamburg-area hospital after she resisted when he tried to kiss her.

LEAD: Many a benefactor of mankind would have been content with colorizing ''Casablanca.'' Not Ted Turner. The chairman of the Turner Broadcasting System last week announced a plan to set the world's most vivid imaginations to pondering how, as time goes by, the survival and prosperity of all life on earth can be assured.
LEAD: It's always heartening reading something good on wildlife (Janet Pollak's ''My 7 Visitors and How They Really Love to Eat''), as well as a gustatory risible riot.
LEAD: A chart last Sunday about Vietnamese refugees arriving in three Asian countries was incorrectly labeled. The numbers were in thousands.

LEAD: Roger Norrington's landmark recording of Berlioz's ''Symphonie fantastique'' (Angel CDC-49543) does not obviate every previous performance, nor should it be expected to. Good enough to please even those utterly indifferent to the early-music movement, it owes its distinction to Mr. Norrington's remarkable sensitivity to timbral niceties and to the composer's imagination as shaped by the actual instruments of his day.
LEAD: FESTIVAL OF TREES

LEAD: WHY KIDS LIE: How Parents Can Encourage Truthfulness. By Paul Ekman with Mary Ann Mason Ekman and Tom Ekman. (Scribners, $17.95.) This thoughtful and provocative book is much better than its title suggests. Mr. Ekman, a research psychologist, has spent years studying the phenomenon of truth and its distortion, and he's taken all that he's learned and applied it to young people learning to be adults and to the parents struggling to help them.

LEAD: Hamdi Farraj, who was born in a tent in the Dheisheh refugee camp in 1956, says that his family ''lived for 25 years without electricity, without water.'' Does he realize that for 19 of those 25 years the area was under Jordanian rule? Will he acknowledge that when water and electricity finally were brought to the camp it was under

LEAD: DAVID R. WALLACE of New Haven, a lieutenant colonel in the Army and a Vietnam combat pilot decorated seven times for heroism, has had a new challenge for the past year, as the Army's chief recruiter in Connecticut.

LEAD: A clash between fans who tore down a goal post after a University of Washington football victory and campus police officers who tried to stop them has left the police defending their actions and the university's president calling for a committee to review the incident.
LEAD: The Coast Guard today expanded its air and sea search for five fishermen and their lobster boat, missing in the Atlantic for three days.
LEAD: The caption with a photograph of a home that accompanied an article on Jamaica Estates on Nov. 17 gave an incorrect location for the house. It is on Midland Parkway.
LEAD: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta is aggressively traveling the state these days, buttonholing all who will listen to his plans for a run at the Governor's mansion in 1990.
LEAD: ''To characterize youth,'' Erick Hawkins said recently, ''you must have achieved a certain point of experience.''

LEAD: Retailers of haute couture for the outdoors say the vibrantly colored plush garments made by the nation's largest manufacturers of ski and camping wear have outstripped woolens as the insulation of choice not only on the slopes but also on city sidewalks.

LEAD: There is a new coach, and a new emphasis on halfcourt offense and defense instead of on the press. But the Knicks' homecourt supremacy, which helped them attain their best record since the 1972-73 season last year, continues.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The people who live in the vicinity of Union Square are engaged in heated debate about the future of real estate development in their neighborhood. Some equate development with progress, saying that until the last few years the area was regarded by many as having no future at all; others worry that too much development will ruin its social and architectural diversity.

LEAD: The consumer price index jumped 0.5 percentage points in October, indicating a 5.9 percent annual rate of inflation. The Federal Reserve Board has said it wants to keep inflation low. But with a weakening economy, its ability to stem inflation is limited. Four economists assess inflation and the Federal Reserve's next move.

LEAD: MANY years ago, I inherited my father's pocket watch, a timepiece that had significance well beyond its practical use as a monitor of moments. It was a symbol of passage, an engraved token of termination, awarded 45 years ago by the management of the Soluble Coffee Division of General Foods at the culmination of a lifetime of service.
LEAD: WE have mown down, paved over and smoothed out so much of nature that we now think of the few bits and pieces left as delicate curiosities. We have forgotten nature's function.

LEAD: Medical investigators said today that the Falcons' rookie offensive tackle Ralph Norwood had apparently not taken drugs or alcohol before he was killed in an automobile crash eight miles from the Falcons' training center.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Duffy of Marlborough, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shannon Mary Duffy, to Peter Guyon Weiland Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Weiland of Chappaqua, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College, Miss Duffy teaches English at the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School, where her fiance teaches chemistry.

LEAD: On one frenzied evening in the Orange Bowl, the University of Miami ended Notre Dame's hope for a second consecutive perfect championship season, placed what had been the longest current major-college winning streak into the past and created a new set of contenders for the top of the final football polls.

LEAD: DESPITE the growing national uncertainty over future financing decisions by the National Endowment for the Arts, leaders of county arts organizations have continued to express confidence in the agency's peer-panel grants-making process and said Federal grants for their own programs are not threatened.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

LEAD: For Ping Chong, ''Brightness'' is an experiment in light and sound, a surrealistic canvas of nonserial images. This new work (at La Mama Annex) is a small play of sensory but not intellectual stimulation. As such, it should be considered a sidelight to Mr. Chong's venturesome career as an author and director of conceptual theater.

LEAD: UNDER THE BRILLIANT BLUE ARIZONA SKY, AN air-conditioned GMC Sierra bumps along a weed-choked wagon track near the main road to Kaibito, just south of Many Waters Lake, at the foot of the Peak Where the Wildcats Stretch. In the back seat, Peter MacDonald, the embattled leader of the Navajo nation, peers through the tinted glass window at a distant figure on horseback.

LEAD: The organist plays as if at a respectful recital. The numbers on the scoreboard change only in that they become uglier by the game. Hope is usually gone by the start of the third period, and the crowd almost invariably has followed before the end of it.

LEAD: More than a fib but less than a fraud - that's how one member of Congress describes a postal phenomenon known as ''fright mail.'' These are solicitations sent out by organizations with names like the ''Social Security Protection Bureau'' or the ''Internal Review Service,'' often in official-looking envelopes bearing the notice: ''Official Business.

LEAD: The East German leader, Egon Krenz, made a surprise visit to Leipzig this morning, strolling confidently through the reform movement's stronghold just one day after announcing that the Communist Party wants to surrender its constitutional monopoly on political power.

LEAD: Responding to appeals from the Bush Administration and European nations, Japan has announced that it would provide $150 million in loans to Poland as an initial step to help both Poland and eventually Hungary deal with their financial crises and break loose from the Soviet bloc.

LEAD: Is it possible to make a cream sauce, flavored with cheese, that comes within a country mile of judicious eating?

LEAD: Moral suasion may occasionally move a politician to tears, but it rarely moves a gun control measure toward enactment in the face of gun lobby opposition. Thus an emotional appeal to a Senate panel last week by James Brady, the former White House press secretary, seemed unlikely to win passage of a new gun control measure.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Weinberger of Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sandy Weinberger to Steven Sloane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sloane of Forest Hills, Queens. A spring wedding is planned.

LEAD: A prominent casualty of the war between past, present and future managers of men's tennis, the $3.1 million Nabisco Masters, will be played for the final time this week at Madison Square Garden. It will be the end of an era that spanned a dozen years in New York.

LEAD: I'd like to point out to Janet Pollak (''My 7 Visitors and How They Really Love to Eat,'' Opinion Page, Oct. 22) that one person's raccoon food is another person's decaying garbage. I don't want to be labeled a curmudgeon, so I won't write about the human need for the unconditional love given by pets.

With a rooting interest in the World Cup next year, and the prospect of hosting the event for the first time in 1994, the sleeping giant is about to awake. ROBERT GRABILL Hanover, N.H.

LEAD: ''I try to work in a way so I can always look into people's eyes.'' - Karel Urbanek, the new Communist Party leader in Czechoslovakia. [ 1:5. ]

LEAD: LIVING IN THE MIDDLE of the woods in upstate New York, I am sometimes reminded that a gun can be a useful tool in the normal course of country life. As serene and pastoral as it all appears from the white Adirondack chair - a big house, porches, stream, barn, ducks, dogs, cats, a pickup truck, basketball hoop and seven kids of various sizes and shapes - there is a perilous world beyond the periphery of the lawn, where deer are often seen grazing on the long grasses.
LEAD: As India moves into its fifth decade of regular democratic elections, opinion surveys and the polling of voters are beginning to play bigger roles in political reporting and analysis.

LEAD: GROWING UP WRITING By Arlene Silberman. (Times Books, $18.95.) I wish this book had been available when my son came home from kindergarten last year, eagerly starting stories with the invented spelling he had learned through his school's ''Writing to Read'' program. Despite my professional writing credentials and parental desire to see him enjoy writing as much as I do, in my compulsion to ''correct'' spelling and grammar I reacted like the benighted parents and educators Arlene Silberman indicts in her provocative and important new book.

LEAD: Kristen Coyne still remembers the first time she flew alone, at age 7. Her parents had recently separated, and her mother was sending her from Dallas to Houston to visit her father.

LEAD: The police questioned 10 passengers today about a bomb found on Thursday aboard a Saudi jumbo jet carrying 339 people. The bomb failed to go off, and the plane returned safely to Pakistan.

LEAD: Q. Soon after we moved into our new home, a wood toilet paper roller was accidentally flushed down the toilet. All attempts to remove this with a snake have failed. Sometimes the toilet flushes O.K. and other times not. Do you know of anything that would dissolve the roller?

LEAD: There is another world out there - a recording world of totally unfamilar artists and record labels (and some familiar ones, too), and esoteric and specialized repertory. It is a world beyond what the major international companies generally turn out, a world where almost anything in sound can be found.

LEAD: The real crime capital of the world may be a small town nestled in a rural Virginia forest where bank robberies, kidnappings and deadly extortion plots are running rampant. The town's mayor shrugs it off with a serene smile.

LEAD: I don't understand how Marcia Adams can say that the Apple Cake With Hot Caramel Sauce ''will keep for a week'' (Food: ''Apple Polishing,'' Oct. 8). LEAD: Each morning, hundreds of Vietnamese-born fishermen cast off in refitted wooden boats from piers here and in the harbors of Monterey and Los Angeles to sail far out into the Pacific to cast their nets for kingfish and rock cod.

LEAD: WITH something approaching awe, the rebel looked at the hotel room - a double bed, a carpet, a private bath and a tiled shower. That may be standard in any motel in the United States, but it is unfathomable luxury for most Salvadorans. ''I'm from the countryside,'' the guerrilla said. ''I've never been in San Salvador before.

LEAD: Right now, the American nuclear power industry appears headed for extinction. Every plant of the more than 100 ordered since 1973 has been canceled, and many others are approaching retirement. But reactor manufacturers say that fears of global warming - the greenhouse effect - are giving them a second chance.

LEAD: A dispute over who gave birth to 11-year-old Kimberly Michelle Mays has ended. A point was proved, but nobody won. Mr. Mays, whose wife died of cancer in 1981, broke his silence on the issue last week, saying that when he told Kimberly of the test results, ''She said, 'Daddy, daddy, what does this mean?

LEAD: OFFICIALS in California expect this week to open a new 1,000-bed maximum security prison at Pelican Bay in the northern part of the state and to open another 1,200-bed wing there soon afterward, increasing the capacity of the country's largest state prison system to 49,767 inmates.

LEAD: The former Central Intelligence Agency official whose Iran-contra case was dismissed on Friday by a Federal judge said today that his superiors fully approved of his secret efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.

LEAD: It wasn't until the end of the pianist Don Pullen's last tune of his first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night that it became clear how unusual his compositional ideas are. Launching into a conventional blues piece, he made the previous hour of music seem carefully premeditated. Every tune had its own rhythm from which to work; one piece functioned as a suite, another had a pop-gospel sunniness, while another was essentially a ballad played as piano solo.
LEAD: Bare competence does not harm operas like ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten,'' but the three new singers in the Metropolitan Opera's current production of Strauss's opera hardly did it much good.

LEAD: The reference to Arabs lining up to find day work in '' 'slave markets' in Jerusalem'' is beneath contempt. When longshoremen are picked out to unload ships in the United States, is this a ''slave market''? If Arab contractors pick up laborers, is this a ''slave market''? And at what hour would one expect laborers to line up if they expect to do a full days' work, if not before 8 A.M.?

LEAD: FIFTY years after Freud died in London, Vienna is dutifully paying respect to its famous son. This fall a stream of exhibits and other commemorations has reminded the Viennese of their association with the founder of psychoanalysis, who lived in this city for 78 years. But psychoanalysts here say that behind Vienna's public acknowledgments is a deep ambivalence toward Freud and his ideas.
LEAD: Much of Lebanon shut down today as President Rene Moawad was buried in his hometown in the country's north.

LEAD: THE PARADISE MOTEL. By Eric McCormack. (Viking, $17.95.) Eric McCormack's brilliant and unsettling first novel steeps itself in mystery, horror and suspense to tell a story about the very art of storytelling. Each character in ''The Paradise Motel'' is a teller of tales, which makes them all liars, and no one's words are to be trusted.

LEAD: The Bernese may have a reputation for staidness, but they did noticeably rejoice when a female among the brown Alpine bears that are kept in a pit near the Nydegg Bridge whelped early this year. There had been no cubs in 1988, and the happy event was felt to augur well for Switzerland's capital. The bear is Bern's emblem; the city's name is believed to be derived from the German word for bear.
LEAD: The Rangers squandered an early 2-0 lead and lost, 7-4, to Toronto tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens.
LEAD: Louis Achitoff, a leading expert in aeronautical planning and flight operations, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

LEAD: Israeli warplanes attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base for the second time in three days today, and the Lebanese police said the jets dropped time bombs that exploded as rescuers dug through the rubble.

LEAD: Political changes in Eastern Europe, Soviet arms cuts and improved United States intelligence gathering mean that the Pentagon would now have a month or more of warning before a Soviet attack, intelligence experts believe. They previously expected only 14 days.

In 1947, the British were pulling out of Palestine, leaving the region's Jews, in their struggle to create an independent state of Israel, to fight the Arabs. At the same time, a startling discovery of a group of ancient scrolls was made by a band of Bedouin tribesmen in a cave located in Trans-Jordan, little more than a stone's throw from the Dead Sea.

LEAD: Budapest is a bather's dream city. Nowhere else in the world will you find this combination of a rich cultural life, magnificent architecture and good restaurants with endless possibilities for bathing and swimming in pools fed by thermal springs.

Issues that do not interest the news media are discarded. Mr. Dingell needs to be taken down a peg, but none of the Democratic leadership has had the courage to rein in this modern day McCarthyite.

The deficit problem is simply too daunting and potential Pentagon cuts too gradual to make much short-term difference.

LEAD: More and more airlines are assessing penalties, known as prepay charges, for travelers who book an advance-purchase seat through a travel agent but get the ticket issued at the airport. There is a way to get around the penalty, which is usually about $25, but it requires a bit of planning.

LEAD: TO no one's surprise, An Evening Dinner Theater is at its best with musicals that are tradition-bound, rather than technologically up to the minute or innovative in form. And if ever there was an old-style musical that is worth pondering every now and again, for message as well as music, it is ''Camelot.

LEAD: Few legal principles are as established as the one that holds that when you go to a baseball game you accept the risk of being hit by a foul ball. Courts have held so over and over. But that particular judicial word has not gotten through to a court in Chicago. Last week, a Cook County Circuit Court jury awarded a 16-year-old boy, Delbert Yates Jr., $67,500 of Cubs money for damages suffered when he was hit by a foul ball at Wrigley

LEAD: Yes. Not all sports can be judged popular according to a professional standard. Soccer is a game played by millions of youngsters and adults across America. The United States doesn't need a professional soccer league to make the game popular. All we need are the youths to play the game, a few experienced coaches and a baseball outfield on which to play.

LEAD: It used to be like a fever with me, a compulsion, a madness: to go into a bookstore, head straight for the brand-new books, flip right to the back of the jacket and see if the author was young or old, my age or even - rats! - younger. Envy is a vocational hazard for most writers. It festers in one's mind, distracting one from one's own work, at its most virulent even capable of rousing the sufferer from sleep to brood over another's triumph.

LEAD: ALMOST everyone I know has a driver's license, yet none of my friends have ever shown theirs to me. Perhaps they are as ashamed of the photograph on it as I am of mine. People usually don't show them around, proudly, like baby pictures. Instead, they are carefully hidden in billfolds or handbags, retrieved only when identification is required.

LEAD: Only weeks after she indicated that she was likely to step down in a few years as leader of the Conservative Party, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has announced that she is willing to lead the party into two more general elections.

LEAD: They haven't been built in a day, and at the rate construction has been going on 12 Italian soccer stadiums for the 1990 World Cup, there is some question as to whether they can be built at all, at least in time for the May deadline.

LEAD: I've been thinking a lot lately about what is wrong with the world, and I have finally decided: data overload. Because of the proliferation of computers and of people capable of running them, we are awash in information that nobody needs - or worse, that nobody believes. Gatherers of statistics have great power, but they usually operate quietly.
LEAD: NEWSWEEK recently published an issue on the family of the future. The headline on the first article was, ''What Happened to the Family?'' I guess we have all wondered that from time to time.

LEAD: Until recently, few people made a fuss when a neighbor posted a ''For Sale'' sign on his front lawn, since it usually remained there for a just few weeks. Moreover, the right to do so seemed - like the right to decorate a front yard at Christmas - indisputable. It was, after all, a personal act on private property.

LEAD: Watching the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade - from the comfort of my armchair, thank you - reminded me of the years I used to venture out early in the morning to capture the parade on film. It never snowed, like it did this year, but it always seemed to be either bitterly cold, raining or both.

LEAD: LET'S talk turkey. If you have not had enough of it by now, head straight for Stony Brook. Thanksgiving still lives at the Three Village Inn, where every Sunday a $19.95 turkey dinner with all the trimmings is served (children, $9.95.) Even those who cannot stand to look at turkey after three days of leftovers will find something to like here.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Cold fusion may not have worked in science labs this year, but late-1980's popular music has been happily knocking together genres to release new energy. De La Soul's ''3 Feet High and Rising'' (Tommy Boy 1019) sets three calm, droll rappers amid unexpected borrowings; its loopy playfulness and peace-symbol graphics were quickly dubbed ''hippie-hop.

LEAD: Madeleine Anne Sweeney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Sweeney of Crestwood, N.Y., was married there yesterday at Annunciation Roman Catholic Church to Joseph Edward Carsky, a son of Katherine S. Carsky of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late James B. Carsky. The Rev. James R. Moore performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William McMahon of Roselle, N.J., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter Kathleen Marie McMahon and James Michael Casey, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Casey of the Bronx.

LEAD: Tracy Hedges Shiland was married yesterday to Antoine Claude Kemper Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kemper of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The bride is a daughter of the late William McAlpin Shiland and the late Harriet Manice Shiland.

LEAD: THE FOLLOWING IS THE RECORD OF a recent visit to East Berlin, at a time when the burst of freedom that greeted the opening of the borders to the West on Nov. 9 was still an anxiously held breath; when even the most optimistic could not imagine such a swift and fortunate denouement. The drama, of course, is just beginning.

LEAD: Travel-related gifts clog shop counters and leap off the pages of countless catalogues, especially around Christmas. Finding ones that are worth their weight in your luggage is the trick. Here are a few good ideas for this year, some from exotic sources.
LEAD: The imposing bronze statue of Racho the Blacksmith stands on rocks in the middle of the Yantra River, a somewhat isolated spot for this city's legendary founder.

LEAD: For This Week: If the Thanksgiving Day snow has melted, plant bulbs; they are better in the ground at this late date rather than tossed and forgotten in the back of a garage or toolshed. Be sure the compost pile is securely piled so it does not blow down or away in winter storms. Lightly prune rambler and climbing roses, if their canes are subject to wind damage.

LEAD: WISDOM AND STRENGTH: The Biography of a Renaissance Masterpiece. By Peter Watson. (Doubleday, $21.95.) ''An Allegory of Wisdom and Strength'' was painted by Paolo Veronese in 1576 near Venice and now hangs in the Frick Collection in New York City. In this richly detailed book, Peter Watson traces the painting's remarkable existence through four turbulent centuries and illustrates the major developments in the collecting of old masters since the Renaissance.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about AIDS omitted a word in quoting Dr. Peter C. Welch, senior vice president for medical affairs at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco. He said the hospital's patients had ''not'' included many children with AIDS.
LEAD: A WAKE. Asleep . . . forever. Those images are engraved in my mind as clearly as the words that are etched on her tombstone.

LEAD: If, as Philip Weiss states, Margot O'Toole was ''highly regarded'' as a scientist, why doesn't she get a job in Walter Stewart's or Ned Feder's lab? Or with one of the professors at Rockefeller University who opposed David Baltimore's appointment?

LEAD: If the controversial paper by Dr. Baltimore et al. that appeared in the journal Cell is so important, have any other laboratories tried to repeat their results and publish them? Surely, three years is more than enough time for others to confirm this data. FRANK ULRICH Medfield, Mass.
LEAD: Joseph F. Fernandez says his superiors approved of his secret efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels but remained silent while he took the blame in the Iran-contra affair. Page 31.

LEAD: As a never-ending barrage of movies, television docudramas, and contemporary recordings of pop standards attests, it's easy to re-create the decor of another era but difficult to capture its spirit.

LEAD: Baby boomers may prefer the concept of weight control to the diet, but they still love a good fad. Among the fastest-growing crazes to fight fat is the liquid protein diet, or very-low-calorie diet, as it is also known. Sales of these liquid proteins have grown to $5 billion a year since the late 1970's.
LEAD: Chita Rivera, at age 56, personifies the tough-as-nails show-business trouper determined to stay on the boards as long as she can kick up her heels and play the raucous life of the party.
LEAD: Michael Jordan's 29 points, 14 rebounds and 9 assists led the Chicago Bulls to a 104-91 victory over the Golden State Warriors today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The marriage of Zoe Ann Topsfield and David Raymond Garcia, both New York lawyers, took place yesterday at the Chapel of Gray's Inn, one of the Inns of Court in London. The Rev. Canon Eric James, a minister of the Church of England, officiated. The bride, 30 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.

LEAD: Soccer in the United States will continue to struggle as long as newspapers like The Times continue to give the sport little or no ink. With the United States now qualifying for Italy, and especially with the World Cup being held in this country in 1994, isn't it about time soccer got some expanded coverage?

LEAD: After two loud blasts on the whistle the wood-burning steam locomotive pulls slowly out of the railroad yard, crowded with passengers clad mostly in bathing suits and shorts. But instead of heading for some fancy beach resort, the train is bound for a large pile of rocks in the middle of the Amazon jungle.

LEAD: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. El Salvador Aid: Vote to kill an amendment to a $14.6 billion foreign aid bill that would have placed restrictions on United States aid to El Salvador.

LEAD: For centuries, Carlsbad and Marienbad - the German names for Czechoslovakia's most famous spa towns, Karlovy Vary and Marianske Lazne - drew Europe's most prominent political and artistic figures.

LEAD: THE transformation of ''The Wonderful Wizard of Oz'' into an all-black, jive-talking pop-rock gospel musical was no mere gimmick. ''The Wiz'' still works, and the festive, amiable production at the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport attests its durability.

LEAD: Leslie Ann Simon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Simon of New York, was married yesterday to Marc Bender, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Zel Bender of Cheltenham, Pa. Judge Isabel Cohen of the Van Nuys, Calif., Municipal Court officiated at the Orcutt Ranch, a historic site in Canoga Park, Calif.

LEAD: A FEW hours after audiences leave evening performances at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, trucks arrive to unload meats and produce at the warehouses of the New Haven Food Terminal which surround the theater. By the time the theater's administrative staff returns to work the next day, the trucks are gone.
LEAD: Even before the sun rose this morning, the people of Prague began gathering to celebrate the resignation on Friday of the country's long-entrenched and conservative Communist Party leadership.

LEAD: PORK and beans is one thing, but fish with beans? Now that people are trying to cut down on fat (even in winter, when we crave sustaining food), there is no reason not to serve seafood instead of the usual pork, duck or ham with dried beans and peas.

LEAD: The startling changes sweeping across Eastern Europe have evoked two inconsistent reactions in Washington, an exhilarating sense of historic opportunity and a debilitating sense of the limits of our resources and power.

LEAD: New Yorkers have learned to avert their eyes. There may now be 90,000 homeless people in New York City, and many of them have been on the streets so long they blur into the cityscape, regarded more and more as nuisance rather than tragedy. But their misery endures, and it presents only the most visible dimension of urban degradation.
LEAD: Victoria Marks called it ''Force of Nature.'' But her thought-provoking program of three dances on Monday night at Performance Space 122 could also have been called ''Social Problems.''

LEAD: Joel Brinkley portrays the Intifada as the shebab - as masked young men - who throw stones at Israeli soldiers and settlers (''Inside the Intifada,'' Oct. 29). In April, I was part of a delegation of lawyers and medical professionals who spent two weeks in the West Bank and Gaza. The Intifada is, indeed, stone throwers, but, more significantly, it is the resistance to Israeli occupation.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WITHIN days of the devastation wrought by the California earthquake, the President of the United States urged Americans to contribute to the Red Cross as ''the only organization chartered and authorized by Congress to act at times of great national calamity.''

LEAD: The Navy, under pressure from state officials, has stepped up plans to retrieve live and deactivated explosives accidentally dropped onto public lands outside the service's Nevada bombing ranges.

LEAD: The scale of Canary Wharf is immense: 24 buildings on 71 acres, its centerpiece a 50-story, 800-foot-high skyscraper by Cesar Pelli that when finished will be the tallest building in Britain. This is most assuredly not the London of Christopher Wren or of John Nash. Nor is it the London of Prince Charles, who has made it clear that he expects this huge tower to be a desecration of the city's skyline.

LEAD: OFFICIALLY it is New Jersey State Prison, but more often than not it's called Trenton, the end of the line, the toughest maximum-security prison in New Jersey, a place from which, it is said, there are only two ways out: over the wall or with a toe tag.
LEAD: FOR Mark Salman, a 27-year-old concert pianist from Darien, making his Carnegie Hall debut last month was the easy part of building a career.

LEAD: It makes good sense to reverse the course of a game against the average opponent because the chances are he will either not catch on to the alteration of circumstances or be too slow or timid to react forcefully. But it is a different story if you are up against the world champion.

LEAD: A police officer, a suspect and a passer-by were wounded in Times Square early yesterday in a gunfight that started when the officer spotted a young man with a handgun and told him to drop it, the police said.
LEAD: Eastern Airlines blamed striking machinists for bomb threats against a flight today, claiming that their union was trying to frighten travelers.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: SAPPHO EXHIBITION

LEAD: Two New York City agencies - the Planning Commission and the Public Development Corporation - are preparing blueprints for the brighter future that seems to be in store for Long Island City now that Citicorp has planted a striking Manhattan-style office tower there.

LEAD: No. The American sports mentality simply does not have the patience or attention span for a continuous-play game. Half the fun of football, baseball, basketball, etc., is the time when there is no action. During these breaks we argue over the pros and cons of our team's performance, go to the refrigerator, mull our ineptitude in this week's pool picks, and on and on.

LEAD: Frankly, I find soccer as exciting as watching ice melt. The sport has evolved into a series of 0-0, 1-0, and 2-1 games. Unless the rules and strategy open up to the point where a single goal is not something to riot over, I doubt the sport will ever capture the hearts and imagination of the American sports fan.
LEAD: Falling Into Life

LEAD: Over the past two years, this city has stuggled with a new form of highway robbery: Thieves have ripped out $120,000 worth of underground copper wires from street lights, knocking out the lights and leaving roads dangerously dark.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's chances of remaining in power after this week's national election were set back today when India's Election Commission ordered new polling in 97 stations in Mr. Gandhi's constituency because of rigging and intimidation by his ruling Congress Party.
LEAD: ''The Nutcracker'' is back. This year's first production of the winter holiday classic was that of the Joffrey Ballet, which danced it Friday afternoon and evening at the City Center Theater.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In a comprehensive article about the Jones Beach theater contract [ ''Major Promoters Vying for Jones Beach Shows,'' Nov. 12 ] , an important point about the process by which New York State selects the entertainment for the theater appeared to have escaped your correspondent.

LEAD: Donna Leigh Downing, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Duane Downing of Valparaiso, Ind., was married yesterday to Jonathan Conway, a son of Margaret Mary Conway of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Chester Joseph Conway. The Rev. John Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

LEAD: In Judy Chicurel's thorough article on the people of Le Chambon, France, who saved thousands of Jews during World War II (''Film Recalls 'Conspiracy of Goodness''' Oct. 29) one amplification is necessary if we are to understand why those French villagers took such enormous risks.

LEAD: The name of one of the writers of a letter published Nov. 19 under the subheading ''Northern Bigotry'' did not appear correctly. He is Michael J. Graetz, Justus S. Hotchkiss Professor of Law at Yale University.

LEAD: Japan granted a patent that Texas Instruments Inc. had been seeking since 1960. The patent covers the basic semiconductor chip, which the company's researchers invented in 1958. The Tokyo decision requires all Japanese chip makers to pay royalties to Texas Instruments. Japanese chip makers have about 90 percent of the Japanese chip market and 80 percent of the United States market.

LEAD: SEATTLE'S largest developer, Martin Selig, has come forward with the first major project proposed under new building-size restrictions. Mr. Selig, who has erected more than 6 million square feet, or about a third of the downtown office market, is proposing a $25-million, 10-story building with 268,000 square feet of offices, retail space and restaurants.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's chances of remaining in power after this week's national election were set back today when India's Election Commission ordered new polling in 97 stations in Mr. Gandhi's constituency because of rigging and intimidation by his ruling Congress Party.
LEAD: ''The Nutcracker'' is back. This year's first production of the winter holiday classic was that of the Joffrey Ballet, which danced it Friday afternoon and evening at the City Center Theater.

LEAD: In a comprehensive article about the Jones Beach theater contract [ ''Major Promoters Vying for Jones Beach Shows,'' Nov. 12 ] , an important point about the process by which New York State selects the entertainment for the theater appeared to have escaped your correspondent.

LEAD: Donna Leigh Downing, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Duane Downing of Valparaiso, Ind., was married yesterday to Jonathan Conway, a son of Margaret Mary Conway of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Chester Joseph Conway. The Rev. John Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.
