The Tokyo decision requires all Japanese chip makers to pay royalties to Texas Instruments. Japanese chip makers have about 90 percent of the Japanese chip market and 80 percent of the United States market.

LEAD: SEATTLE'S largest developer, Martin Selig, has come forward with the first major project proposed under new building-size restrictions. Mr. Selig, who has erected more than 6 million square feet, or about a third of the downtown office market, is proposing a $25-million, 10-story building with 268,000 square feet of offices, retail space and restaurants.

LEAD: AMELIA EARHART A Biography. By Doris L. Rich. Illustrated. 322 pp. Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press. $19.95. THE SOUND OF WINGS The Life of Amelia Earhart. By Mary S. Lovell. Illustrated. 420 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $22.95.
LEAD: Union-management relations in football are the worst among the professional team sports. The two sides barely exchange civilities, much less negotiate issues.
LEAD: Falling Into Life

LEAD: THE RESTORATION OF THE CITY of Babylon is likely the most long overdue project in history. It is the desire of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to restore from 2,000-year-old rubble (above, lower right) the glory of the city at its most glorious. The was during the reign of Nebuchadnezzar, Babylonia's ruler from 605 to 562 B

LEAD: Lawyers for the tanker captain accused of allowing the nation's worst oil spill to occur will seek to have his case thrown out of court on claims of immunity, a flawed sobriety test and other grounds, in a hearing that begins Monday.

LEAD: I'd like to answer the question that Linda Martin asked in her excellent ''From an Empty Nest, the Voice of the Turtle'' (Nov. 5). That is, ''What to do with pets when their owners leave for college.'' As the adoption chairperson for the New York Turtle and Tortoise Society, I have had to find numerous homes for turtles like Ms.

LEAD: A week after he was banned from the National Football League for a third violation of the league's substance-abuse policy, Dexter Manley owned up to his lapse yesterday. At a news conference in Washington, the 30-year-old Redskin defensive end admitted he had used cocaine, accepted his punishment and said he would do everything in his power to work for reinstatement when he becomes eligible to apply next November.

LEAD: Maria Daniel Lambros, a violist with the Ridge String Quartet in New York, and Michael Steven Kannen, a cellist in New York, were married last evening at Bargemusic in Brooklyn by the Rev. James Grant, a Unitarian minister.

LEAD: The Prospects column last Sunday about the New Yorker magazine misidentified the magazine's purchaser and misstated its purchase price. Advance Publications Inc. acquired the magazine for $168 million.

LEAD: Experts at American universities say anxiety about the prospect of German reunification is widespread in Europe and the United States despite declarations by Western leaders that they are unconcerned and that the issue should be resolved by the Germans themselves.

LEAD: Holiday shoes for men and women are ornate yet practical this season. Women's shoes are lavishly embellished, but designed with low heels and high vamps. For men, the fussy dance pump with its round toe and grosgrain bow is supplemented with daytime styles - lace-up or slip-on - made in elegant materials like faille, satin or gleaming patent leather.
LEAD: It's not that everything's coming up roses these days for Stephen Sondheim. It's that everything's coming up roses and daffodils. And sunshine and Santa Claus.

LEAD: In last week's rush to adjourn, Congress took a bold step forward and a giant leap backward on medical insurance for the elderly. The step forward was a system to control total physician billings. The leap backward was repeal of catastrophic health insurance - which protected the elderly against bankrupting medical bills.

LEAD: Eyebrows were raised last week when Fred Lebow, the president of the New York Road Runners Club and the director of the New York City Marathon, emerged as the key figure in a drive to upgrade the nine-year old Moscow Marathon into a premier event.
LEAD: A 12-year-old boy was found dead Saturday on top of an elevator where had been playing in a Harlem building, the Housing Authority police said.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney encouraged the Kremlin today to go beyond the cuts in conventional arms that it has already agreed to in talks in Vienna, suggesting that the United States would reciprocate with further reductions in its forces in Europe.

LEAD: In the 50 years that J. R. D. Tata has led the sprawling industrial giant that bears his name, he has molded it into India's most diverse and respected industrial empire under the slogan ''growth with ethics.''
LEAD: An obituary in some editions Saturday about John Kaplan, a law professor and author, omitted the name of a survivor. He is a brother, Benjamin, of Brooklyn.
LEAD: A state judge has approved the sale of Sir Rudolf Bing's assets to pay for his nursing home care.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party appear to have lost their majority in the Indian Parliament and will be out of power unless they form a coalition government, according to early results in the country's most violent national election, which ended on Sunday.
LEAD: Willie Anderson set a National Football League record for single-game receiving with 336 yards as the Los Angeles Rams beat the New Orleans Saints, 20-17, in overtime tonight.
LEAD: A putter that was designed as a golf training device is being marketed for tournament play as well.

LEAD: Out of sight does not mean out of mind for contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Though the books were closed on last year's campaign on Feb. 28, and articles about it stopped appearing in March, donors continued to send contributions throughout the year.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Alison Granger considers herself a generous, even selfless person. But lately the 31-year-old mother has caught herself hoarding something very dear: the names of her favorite baby sitters.
LEAD: Debt
LEAD: High winds in the California desert today delayed the return of the space shuttle Discovery from its classified military mission until Monday.

LEAD: Faced with a growing clamor from Communist Party conservatives, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev published a manifesto today insisting that Marxism will be revived in the Soviet Union, and under the leadership of the Communist Party.

LEAD: Douglas Wilder, the apparent winner of Virginia's gubernatorial election, has taken descriptions of his ''razor-thin'' victory margin at face value, shaving off his mustache while he awaits official vote totals on Monday.

LEAD: The new President of Lebanon, Elias Hrawi, threatened today to use military force against Gen. Michel Aoun, the Christian Army commander who claims to be President and controls a sizable armed force based in and around East Beirut.

LEAD: New York's Offtrack Betting authorities know full well that gambling can be a devastating addiction. Their current subway advertising cautions, in the lower-left corner: ''Bet with your head . . . not over it.'' But the type is so tiny that only the most searching straphanger can read it.

LEAD: The prime lending rate, which most commercial banks have held at 10.5 percent since late July, is likely to be lowered by half a percentage point this week, some credit market analysts and economists said.

LEAD: Judith Rose Spett, a product manager for the Dreyfus Corporation in New York, was married yesterday to James Philip Ruskin, a securities analyst at Dreyfus. Rabbi Fabian Schonfeld performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.
LEAD: For four decades, Miami Beach has been known as much for its Jewish flavor as for its sun and sand. As recently as seven years ago, three-quarters of its population was Jewish.

LEAD: Japan's ancient art of sumo wrestling rumbled and shook today when a 490-pound 25-year-old Hawaiian named Konishiki, easily the most instantly recognizable American in the Japanese islands, pushed, slapped and shoved his way to the country's most coveted sports prize, the Emperor's Cup.
LEAD: Americas Watch, a New York-based human rights organization, has accused the Bush Administration of trying to cover up abuses by the Salvadoran Army during this month's offensive by guerrillas.

LEAD: In format, Handel's ''Acis and Galatea'' resembles ''Friedenstag,'' the Richard Strauss antiwar polemic that surfaced at Carnegie Hall last week. Both occupy a halfway house between the theater and the concert stage. Both tell a story in music that might be acted out onstage but is just as well apprehended with closed eyes.
LEAD: HIDDEN in the heart of Manhattan is a new recreational amenity: an indoor wall used by amateur rock and mountain climbers to simulate outdoor conditions and practice their hobby.

LEAD: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday Automobile Sales ... Mid-Nov. Tuesday Merchandise Trade ... 3d Qtr. Wednesday G.N.P. (Revised) ... 3d Qtr. Corporate Profits (Rev.) ... 3d Qtr. Thursday Personal Income ... Oct.

LEAD: One of Latin America's most deeply rooted democracies went to the polls today, and a middle-of-the-road lawyer appeared on the way to becoming its next president. Voters opted for a leftist coalition to run the Montevideo city government.
LEAD: Surgeons at the University of Chicago are to perform the nation's first liver transplant from a living donor today, ushering in what is widely expected to be a new era in transplantation.

LEAD: After four days of talks here, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continues to scramble for an agreement on new production quotas. But the dispute among its 13 members is not expected to have a significant effect on world oil prices.
LEAD: The Navy has reassigned the skipper of a destroyer based here following a collision two weeks ago off Malaysia that killed one sailor and injured five others.

LEAD: IT may go down as the case of the gullible banker. Just days after the Securities and Exchange Commission halted trading in shares of Lifeline Healthcare Group Inc. last summer and expressed concern about the accuracy of the company's accounting, company executives managed to arrange a $1.5 million loan from the Bank of New

LEAD: When the Bush Administration charged Japan with unfair restrictions on imports from America last spring, it also wisely proposed that the two governments sit down and air complaints about each other's economic systems. That opened the way for Japan to pick at America's faults, instead of just taking it on the chin from Washington.

LEAD: * Slater Hanft Martin has accepted an assignment to create public service advertising for the National Foundation for Ileitis and Colitis. The foundation has designated the 1990's the ''Decade of the Cure'' for the chronic intestinal illnesses.

LEAD: Members of Congress who deal with military policy say the Pentagon is scrambling to propose cuts in troops and weapons for budget reasons without thinking through the altered strategic needs dictated by political upheaval in Eastern Europe.

LEAD: Johanna M. Hopkins, who was a schools superindendent in the northwest Bronx from 1942 to 1964 and the first woman to hold such a post in New York City, died Thursday in the Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. She was 94 years old and lived in Kings Park, L.I.

LEAD: Within hours after a Federal Bankruptcy Court released the books of several dozen small publishers last summer from a Connecticut warehouse, where they had been impounded after their distributor filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, the first of a dozen moving vans began streaming toward this one-time mill town between Baltimore and Washington.

LEAD: Despite strong objections by President Bush, British Government officials said today that they planned to go ahead with the forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong, probably starting within the next few months.

LEAD: Maryland's largest bank awarded its advertising account last week to W. B. Doner, a Baltimore agency. Maryland National Bank said the switch had come after its recent merger with Equitable Bank and an extensive agency search. Doner would not disclose the budget of the account, which has been reported by the advertising trade press as being $5 million to $7 million.

LEAD: Golf Strange Is Big Winner: Curtis Strange chipped in with a 9-iron from 35 feet on the 13th hole for a $135,000 prize and capped the Skins Game with a $70,000 putt on the final hole yesterday in La Quinta, Calif. Strange, shut out of money winnings in his first Skins Game appearance last year, emerged as the big winner this time, collecting $265,000 from the total purse of $450,000.
LEAD: International

LEAD: The coaches, as coaches like to do, call it just another game. But when the Giants and the 49ers meet Monday night before a sellout crowd at Candlestick Park and a national television audience, it will be something special, as at least one person involved was willing to admit.
LEAD: * Stanislaus M. Shibinsky has been named senior vice president and executive creative director of BBDO Detroit.

LEAD: It hardly comes as a surprise that the house Ivan Lendl lives in is made of stone, great slabs of gray and beige stone, and is protected from the rest of the world by two fences: a natural baffle of hemlocks backed up by a no-nonsense span of chain link. Protecting himself - on the job with a dentist's drill of a forehand, at leisure with a battery of sarcasm that passes for cocktail-hour banter, at home with a meticulously trained quartet of brainy

LEAD: When Nina Rubinstein fled Nazi Germany 56 years ago, she escaped to France with few possessions except her books and the doctoral dissertation that she had just completed - on political emigres. She never had a chance to defend her thesis before faculty members or to receive a degree.

LEAD: Sometimes there are advantages to getting older or even approaching middle age. This past weekend age was a prerequisite to getting into the Ingalls Rink in New Haven to see the Yale Hockey Classic, a tournament involving Yale, Air Force, Colgate and Northeastern.
LEAD: Marxism will be revived in the Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said, responding to conservatives.

LEAD: The Communists built the hulking Lenin Steelworks here in the 1950's as a monument to their industrial ambitions for Poland, but today the sprawling mill symbolizes another set of yearnings and challenges: to transform the fossilized hulks of a burdensome Communist economy to more efficient market-oriented enterprises.

LEAD: GTG Entertainment, the production company formed by Grant A. Tinker and the Gannett Company almost three years ago, has yet to come up with a hit program, although it has taken several hits itself.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Delbert W. Yocam, who held several key posts as Apple Computer Inc. rose from a perky startup concern to a multibillion-dollar computer vendor, left the company Friday after 10 years.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from addresses by the caretaker Prime Minister, Ladislav Adamec, and the dissident playwright Vaclav Havel at an opposition rally here today, as translated by The Associated Press: Remarks by Adamec

LEAD: Orders for American machine tools dropped 32.3 percent in October from the September level, largely because the auto industry cut back its orders, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said in a monthly report released today.

LEAD: By giving all of New Jersey's public schools ''report cards'' recently, state education officials had hoped to create a dialogue between parents and educators that would, over time, make schools more accountable and improve education.
LEAD: THE founders of Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein seem like talented Broadway understudies waiting in the wings for the parts that will finally make them stars.
LEAD: The news of Larry Bird's return was trumpeted in every National Basketball Association city and beyond in the days leading up to the start of the 1989-90 season.
LEAD: A 28-year-old man was shot and killed in a Times Square convenience store early yesterday, and a man who said he was the killer surrendered soon afterward, the police said.

LEAD: Robert F. Wagner was the last New York City Mayor without a telephone in his official car. Mr. Wagner didn't want one, he recalled, because ''anything I had to say could wait until I got there.''

LEAD: Richard Pfizenmaier, a developer of international operations of the pharmaceutical house of Smith Kline and French Laboratories, died of blood cancer Thursday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 69 years old.
LEAD: Public hearings or final votes on proposed increases of 11.5 percent or more in the cost of commuting by train, riding a subway or taking a taxi will be held this week.

LEAD: THE usual visitor to Quebec's remote Anticosti Island goes there in quest of deer or Atlantic salmon. But an effort has been started to attract summer tourists: hikers, campers, bird-watchers, fossil hunters and part-time anglers who would enjoy an offbeat sojourn in a wild and lovely spot.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: * Six Flags Great Adventure theme park to Bozell, with a budget of $3 million to $4 million.

LEAD: Lawyers for John Z. De Lorean, whose Belfast-based car company went bankrupt in 1982, won a High Court order on Friday setting aside an earlier court order against him for more than $51 million.

LEAD: With neither the Congress Party of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi nor the opposition heading for a clear majority in Parliament, attention turned today to President Ramaswamy Venkataraman, a former Gandhi aide who now apparently has the power to tap either side to form a coalition Government.
LEAD: Kurdish guerrillas killed 21 people, 6 of them women and 13 of them children, in a reprisal raid on a pro-Turkish Kurdish village near the Iraqi border, officials said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: It seems almost tempting to pity Helmut Kohl these days. With history being made all around him, the limelight seems to be everywhere but on the West German Chancellor.

LEAD: As the bleak skies turned into sunshine at Giants Stadium this afternoon, so did the Jets' fortunes turn for the better. Jet receivers began clutching passes. Jet backs began breaking tackles. Jet kickers began clicking. Jet defenders became stout.
LEAD: A 4-month-old boy was killed in Brooklyn on Saturday night when a pipe-wielding man struck another man who had grabbed the infant and claimed to be his father, the police said.
LEAD: Ricky Hammond, his eyes opened wide, lips sealed tightly, sat courtside yesterday in a gymnasium at the Essex County Community College in Newark.
LEAD: Jerome Harmon scored 21 points tonight and Louisville staved off a Villanova rally for an 83-69 victory and third place in the Maui Classic.

LEAD: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.
LEAD: Numbed by a long night of drinking, Carlos Williams seemed hardly fazed early Saturday by the knife slash opening up the left side of his face.

LEAD: Jim Kelly threw three touchdown passes as Buffalo took advantage of both physical and mental mistakes for a 24-7 victory today over Cincinnati, the team that beat the Bills out of a Super Bowl trip last season.
LEAD: William C. Murphy, an uncle of Vice President Dan Quayle and a former executive of Eli Lilly and Company, died Wednesday. He had been hospitalized for a heart ailment and he was 67 years old.
LEAD: David Ridgway kicked a 35-yard field goal with 2 seconds left to give the Saskatchewan Roughriders a 43-40 victory over the Hamilton Tiger-Cats in the Grey Cup game tonight at the Skydome.
LEAD: The publisher of the monthly Cable Guide plans to challenge the 30-year dominance of TV Guide and local newspapers in providing a weekly roadmap to the ever-expanding landscape of television.

LEAD: A Threat in Lebanon The nation's new President, Elias Hrawi, threatened to use military force against Gen. Michael Aoun, the hard-line Christian military commander, who disputes the presidency and controls sizable forces. Page A14. LEAD: The underground press is thriving in Prague these days. The rare clandestine documents of previous generations have given way to a flood of homemade handbills and posters that adorn the city's walls and windows, subway cars and stations.

LEAD: For the last 18 years, the score reads: Strikes 4, Lockouts 2. Beginning tomorrow, labor representatives of baseball's club owners and players will try to avoid adding to that score on either side.

LEAD: The sign on the wall said ''Old Play, New Cast,'' reflecting the dissatisfaction of most people here with the pace of political change, even as all semblance of unity within the Communist Party vanished in a welter of resignations, demands, concessions and emergency meetings.

LEAD: East Germany's national youth organization, the training ground of the country's elite, severed its formal ties to the Communist Party over the weekend and endorsed democratic change.
LEAD: The violinist Eugene Fodor gave a benefit performance on Saturday across the street from the courthouse where he was sentenced last month on a drug-related charge.
LEAD: In the first free national vote in 42 years, Hungarians went to the polls today for a referendum on when a presidential election will be held.

LEAD: The growth of the performing arts in the Bay Area, from the days of the gold rush to the present, is documented in a collection of memorabilia that is soon to be open to the public for the first time. The 50-year-old collection, once known as the San Francisco Dance Archives, will make its debut Friday as the San Francisco Performing Arts Library and Museum in new quarters on Grove Street, near the Performing Arts Center.

LEAD: ''America's Century,'' Lewis H. Lapham's dour and dire view of the decline of American power and confidence over the last 100 years, comes to its gloomy conclusion tonight with a litany of events that have shaken the nation's sense of itself.
LEAD: The Fair Trade Commission of Japan said Friday that two Japanese computer manufacturers might have engaged in unfair trade practices by bidding one yen on local government projects.
LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, tomorrow's sale of two-year notes and Wednesday's sale of five-year notes.

LEAD: Tens of thousands of Ukrainians demonstrated in three cities in the vast southern republic today to demand the legalization of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, banned since the rule of Stalin, campaigners for religious rights reported.

LEAD: Yuri Vladimirovich Dubinin calls himself ''a popularizer of perestroika,'' a salesman of the new Soviet thinking that brings Red Army watches to Bloomingdale's and blasts holes in the Berlin Wall.

LEAD: Maria C. Sanchez, a Connecticut State Representative who built a political base from a small convenience store in Hartford, died on Saturday at her home there. She was 63 years old and died of natural causes, said Robert Clark, director of the DeLeon Funeral Home in Hartford.

LEAD: Shortly before 9 A.M. on Nov. 15, New York City traffic officials got a nightmare phone call: a truck had struck a pedestrian bridge in the Bronx, knocking it onto the Bruckner Expressway. It was the sort of accident that could have gummed up traffic for days.

And there are pictures in such glorious profusion that to Alice they would have offered new Wonderlands to dream in.

LEAD: Say what one might about the Kronos Quartet's deficiencies in ensemble polish and tone - and there is much to be said on those matters - it must be granted that few quartets offer programs as inventive, varied and exotic as the Kronos consistently does. On Saturday evening, in the first of its three concerts this season at Alice Tully Hall, the group gave premieres of works by Ugandan, Sudanese, Cuban, American and Argentine composers.

LEAD: Representatives from 20 South Pacific nations on Friday endorsed a pact aimed at banning the use by fishermen of the 60-mile-long drift nets that environmentalists say are robbing the ocean of marine life.
LEAD: In a modest frame house on Main Street, Joyce and Lester L. Cruzan quietly wait for their appointment with history.

LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady will undergo elective surgery to replace his hip on Dec. 14 and will be out of the office for three to six weeks, the Department of the Treasury said today. While he is recuperating, Deputy Secretary John E. Robson will be in charge of the department. Mr. Brady, 59 years old, has suffered from arthritis in his right hip for years, and has recently walked with a pronounced limp.

LEAD: THE first call was from a physician in Sante Fe, N.M., puzzled about a 39-year-old woman with mouth ulcers, severe muscle pain, liver problems and extraordinarily high numbers of a type of white cell in her blood.
LEAD: Three civic organizations said yesterday that they opposed any delay in new ethics rules that are to go into effect for New York City municipal employees on Jan. 1.

LEAD: The opposition presidential candidate in Honduras, Rafael Leonardo Callejas, an American-trained economist, claimed victory today in elections held on Sunday. Official returns were incomplete.

LEAD: The failing Miller & Rhoads department store chain abandoned a plan to reorganize under Federal bankruptcy law and said it would seek to sell its assets. The reversal came just four months after the century-old regional department store sought Chapter 11 protection from creditors and sought to reorganize as a smaller company.

LEAD: When Civic Forum, the umbrella group mounting Czechoslovakia's opposition to Communist rule, was formed eight days ago, the Government authorities tried to dismiss it as a group of feckless, isolated intellectuals.

LEAD: What most distinguishes a democracy is the people's right to reject those in power. In India, the world's largest democracy and the third world's most durable, voters have done just that, denying a majority to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party. They gave no clear mandate to any single political force but everywhere vented their anger at incumbents for corruption, inequality, religious discord and a variety of local failures.

LEAD: BENNETT S. LEBOW seemed to be Western Union's savior when he swooped in, with backing from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., to put fresh money in the ailing telex company in December 1987. But now Western Union has new troubles.
LEAD: A SMALL office building that has just opened on Columbus Circle seems to belie the prevalent mind-set that bigger is better in Manhattan real estate development.
LEAD: The Giants wanted to keep Joe Montana from making the big play Monday night, and they did. They did not want to fall behind early and be forced to pass, but they did.
LEAD: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing above 2,700, after languishing in a slightly higher range throughout most of the session.
LEAD: ABC's ''Roseanne'' returned to first place in the network ratings race last week, and ABC had 6 of the top 10 shows. But NBC still won the week easily. ABC was second and CBS third.
LEAD: Van Sinderen Lindsley Jr., a retired advertising executive, died Sunday at a nursing home in Suffern, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.
LEAD: Four free throws by John Lucas helped the Houston Rockets stop a late Los Angeles rally tonight and gain a 110-104 victory that ended the Lakers' winning streak at nine games.

LEAD: A growing number of Roman Catholic universities are debating whether advocacy of abortion rights and the distribution of condoms on campus are compatible with their identity as Catholic institutions.

LEAD: HOLIDAYS reinforce links to the past, and not necessarily one's own. As December rolls around, the bygone era most often dusted off is the 19th century, especially as it unfolded in Victorian England. This season the image seems more pervasive than ever.
LEAD: The Supreme Court has refused to let public schools cut off educational help to severely handicapped children even though they may not be able to benefit from such services.

LEAD: John C. Whitehead, former Deputy Secretary of State, is becoming a limited partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the firm announced yesterday. As a limited partner, Mr. Whitehead's personal investments will be managed by the firm, but he will have no operational or administrative responsibility, a spokesman said.
LEAD: Sweet-Tooth Specials
LEAD: * Biocontrol Technology Inc., Indiana, Pa., a biotechnology concern, named T. J. Feola vice president and director of marketing and sales.

LEAD: Hydro-Quebec, the electric utility owned by the Province of Quebec, is offering $500 million, up from $400 million, in debentures due in 2029 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: One of the many things I have never been able to get interested in is what's going on in my arteries, which may explain why my attention always wanders when the conversation turns to cholesterol.

LEAD: For four days last month, the State of Alaska refused to allow an oil tanker to discharge her cargo at a refinery 100 miles south of here in Kenai. In a state that owes its prosperity and indeed its existence in large part to oil, the event was a jarring one.

LEAD: David N. Dinkins's committee to seek nominees for police commissioner decided yesterday to interview 11 candidates, including the incumbent, Richard J. Condon, and to report back to Mr. Dinkins by Dec. 11, people close to the search said.
LEAD: Gov. Buddy Roemer denied clemency today for a retarded man scheduled to go to the electric chair on Thursday for killing a state trooper, a crime committed at the age of 17.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Following are excerpts from statements issued by the Czechoslovak Government and by Civic Forum and the Public Against Violence, two leading Czechoslovak opposition groups, after Prime Minister Ladislav Adamec met with the opposition groups today. The Government statement was translated by The New York Times; the opposition issued an official translation.
LEAD: The Supreme Soviet today restored Azerbaijan's control over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, the center of a prolonged and violent dispute with neighboring Armenia.

LEAD: As New Yorkers are well aware, the most challenging job in the city is about to change hands. In the bridge community the same switch has already occurred; on Oct. 5 Richard Reisig took over from Tom Snow as secretary of the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan. He will administer the world's most famous bridge club, whose members include many world champions and whose activities include the annual Invitational Charity
LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is examining the possibility of bringing in an outside investor to put additional capital into the troubled brokerage firm, people close to the plan said yesterday.

LEAD: Hoping to head off more Government restrictions and to rebuild public trust in their industry, editors of 20 national newspapers in Britain have agreed to an ethics code and a system to deal with complaints.

LEAD: Interest rates declined yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, capping a month of up-and-down swings. The bank holding company sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.1855 percent, down from 8.2181 percent last week. Citicorp said it also sold $50 million in 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.8648 percent, down from 7.8822 percent.

LEAD: Working in a factory alongside his father was an option that Luis Rivera of Passaic always had but never wanted. His dream was to go to college, learn all he could about computers, work for a big corporation and, someday, own the business.
LEAD: DEAR DIARY:

LEAD: The crew of a Navy frigate named for a Vietnam War hero, Lieut. Comdr. Wilmer Paul Cook, performed a solemn mission Monday, scattering the commander's ashes at sea 22 years after he died in battle.
LEAD: Leslie Combs Bruce, a retired financier, died Saturday at the Doylestown (Pa.) Nursing Facility. He was 91 years old and had lived in Greenwich, Conn., before moving to Doylestown in 1984.

LEAD: The Government has abandoned a two-year effort costing $500 million to plan the nation's only dump for highly radioactive nuclear waste because it lacks confidence in its work thus far, officials said last night. It has decided to start over.

LEAD: On the same day they officially announced the departure of their longtime chief labor lawyer, representatives of baseball's club owners opened talks with the players' bargaining team yesterday calling for an end to the hostility that has raged between them.

LEAD: Don Morton, who managed only six victories in his three seasons, was dismissed yesterday as coach at the Wisconsin. The school's Athletic Board voted, 10-0, with one abstention to remove Morton, who has two years left on his five-year contract.
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about Police Commissioner Richard J. Condon referred incorrectly in some copies to the other man shown. He was Joseph Borrelli, the Chief of Detectives.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Prague's Communist Government all but surrendered to its opposition by pledging to yield its 41-year monopoly on political power and to allow non-Communist ministers into a cabinet to be named by Sunday. Page A1

LEAD: John MacLean's 13th goal of the season, 3 minutes 30 seconds into overtime, gave the Devils a 3-2 victory over the Islanders tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena and saved the home team an embarrassment.

LEAD: One-ring circuses from the United States, France, Switzerland and Canada are the subject of a photography show that will be on view through Jan. 27 at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.
LEAD: A limited partnership that includes Gordon P. Getty said today that it had increased its stake in Avon Products Inc. to 8 percent.

LEAD: The Soviet Legislature granted an unconditional amnesty today to all former servicemen who committed crimes while serving in Afghanistan, including more than 2,000 prisoners serving time on charges ranging from petty theft to premeditated murder.

LEAD: Members of the anti-nuclear protest group Greenpeace will try to halt the launching of a Trident 2 missile from a submarine off the Florida coast, a spokeswoman said today. The spokeswoman, Shannon Fagan, said the launching was set for Friday, but the Navy declined to confirm or deny it. Greenpeace was successful in stopping a Trident 2 test from a submarine last July, maneuvering small rafts close enough to the vessel to attach protest banners to its hull and mast.
LEAD: These days Jose Ruiz eyes his neighbor across the street, an aging recreational complex sprawled over 15 acres of Brooklyn's Brighton Beach waterfront, and can hardly wait for it to die.

LEAD: It had been at least six months since the last of the five women had moved out of this large house that was their home after their lives became living hells. And now, on a sunny morning, they had returned. There were hugs and laughter and chatter about how fast children grow up. The women cooed over a set of twins not yet born when they lived together.

LEAD: Frank Fools Crow, a Sioux Indian spiritual leader who helped to negotiate the end of a 68-day insurrection at Wounded Knee, S.D., in 1973, died Monday at the home of his grandchildren. Mr. Fools Crow, whose exact age was not known, was believed to be 99 years old.
LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk announced today that he was scrapping a system that gave the army and the police a dominant role in regional and local government.

LEAD: Fred Kreig, who plays Santa for handicapped and poor children, lost a mock reindeer to a hunter last week. Mr. Kreig runs Santa's Cottage, a Chenango County farm that gives tours and holiday events. A hunter shot one of the 12 European fallow deer posing as reindeer after it had escaped from its pen.
LEAD: Baseball
LEAD: A former New York State Senator has emerged as the leading contender for the nation's top civil rights enforcement job, Administration officials and New York Republicans said today.
LEAD: Hector Camacho never met a spotlight he didn't like.

LEAD: The Southwest Bank of St. Louis, which three weeks ago was the first to announce a cut in its prime lending rate to 10 percent, said yesterday that it was raising the rate back to 10 1/2 percent ''at least on a temporary basis.''

LEAD: Perhaps it was during those many mornings he spent with his face buried in The Wall Street Journal that John Ogrodnick mastered the expressionless stare. Ogrodnick, the veteran left wing for the Rangers, won't say how heavily he was into the stock market a couple of years ago. Suffice it to say, he was an active trader and thus an inveterate worrier.
LEAD: Saying he had turned up new evidence, the Attorney General has reinstated a murder charge against a man in the 1976 car-bomb slaying of a newspaper reporter. Don Bolles.

LEAD: The ceiling on the size of single-family home loans purchased by the nation's largest secondary mortgage-market agency is declining by $150, to $187,450 next year, the first drop in at least a decade, the agency said today.

LEAD: Braniff Inc. officials told creditors the airline was operating as a ''limited charter carrier'' while seeking a buyer and was continuing to run up expenses under bankruptcy proceedings. Howard T. Glassman, a Braniff lawyer, told the creditors in one of a series of meetings conducted by the bankruptcy trustee that there was no clear picture of the airline's future.

LEAD: ''The Nutcracker'' is a holiday classic that offers the opportunity for dancers to move into new roles, often with the eagerness with which the battalions of mice take over the stage in the dream of toys and a candy paradise that is at the heart of the ballet. And on Sunday afternoon at City Center, Meg Gurin and Pascal Benichou danced the roles of the Sugar Plum Fairy and the Nutcracker Prince in the Joffrey Ballet's cosy, pretty production of ''The Nutcracker.

LEAD: George Sawyer Pettee, a research analyst, educator and author who wrote extensively on national security issues, died of Parkinson's disease on Nov. 17 at the Kensington Gardens Nursing Home in Maryland. He was 85 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.
LEAD: THE generous of heart who entertain have a recurring fantasy. ''One opens one's refrigerator and inside is Zabar's,'' as Nora Ephron puts it.

LEAD: All over Czechoslovakia, intellectuals who have spent two decades assigned to such demeaning jobs as window washer, bathroom attendant and coal stoker for their involvement in the liberal experiments of the Prague Spring 21 years ago are wondering whether their fortunes and positions may improve.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Colombian jetliner lost cabin pressure before it was destroyed by an explosion on Monday and the 107 people aboard had time to don oxygen masks before they were killed, investigators said today.

LEAD: Worried that full public review might seriously delay or even derail their plan to build two large civic buildings in lower Manhattan, the Federal Government and New York City have agreed to sidestep that process.

LEAD: Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood's contention that he is immune from prosecution for sailing the Exxon Valdez onto the rocks of Prince William Sound last March is being fought out in a state court here, two months before his trial is to start.

LEAD: President Bush today signed legislation renaming the Maryland and Washington parts of the George Washington Memorial Parkway the Clara Barton Parkway. The name change is intended both to honor the Civil War nurse who organized the American Red Cross in 1881 and to help motorists who confused the Maryland-District stretch of the parkway with the longer, better known portion of the George Washington Memorial Parkway on the Virginia side of the Potomac River.

LEAD: Dismissal of the indictment against Joseph Fernandez, a former C.I.A. station chief in Costa Rica, sets back the pursuit of those culpable for illicit U.S. aid to the contras in Nicaragua. The special prosecutor has good reason to ask higher courts to reinstate charges of lying to investigators.
LEAD: Eliana Martinez, an AIDS patient whose mother successfully fought a court ruling that the child be in a glass cage in school classes, died of the disease on Monday. She was 8 years old.
LEAD: For the second night in a row, Coast Guard searchers spotted a flare tonight in their search for five crew members from a lobster boat that disappeared a week ago off Massachusetts.

LEAD: THE upheaval in Eastern Europe, with its greater openness to the West, means to many Americans that the United States no longer needs a huge military establishment. The Bush Administration, in fact, is beginning to shrink the $300 billion military budget. But if billions of dollars are diverted from military spending over the next decade, how should the money be spent?

LEAD: In the aftermath of a weekend attack on Kabul that killed at least 38 people and wounded more than 100, the Soviet-backed Government here has renewed demands that the United States stop supplying Muslim rebel groups with Egyptian-made rockets that have become their primary weapon in attacks on Afghan cities.

LEAD: Edith S. Stevens, a volunteer for Planned Parenthood of Union County, N.J., died of a stroke on Nov. 22 at her home in Plainfield, N.J. She was 90 years old.
LEAD: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a former manager of the Water Club restaurant in Manhattan embezzled at least $485,000 while he ran the restaurant from 1983 to 1986.

LEAD: The Great Western Financial Corporation said today that it would add $200 million to a reserve against possible losses on bad real estate loans. The savings and loan company said the move would reduce its after-tax earnings in the fourth quarter by as much as $150 million, causing a loss for the period of about $75 million.

LEAD: The Nikon Corporation said this morning that it was not in negotiations with the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, although it acknowledged for the first time that it had held such talks several months ago about acquiring the American company's semiconductor equipment operations.

LEAD: Dozens of Syrian tanks, supporting President Elias Hrawi, moved within easy striking distance today of the military stronghold of Gen. Michel Aoun, who has refused to recognize the new President and has said he expects a Syrian attack.
LEAD: Yields offered on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week that ended yesterday.
LEAD: Consumer food prices will rise at a much slower pace in 1990 as farmers continue to expand their crop production, a senior Agriculture Department economist predicted today.

LEAD: Hungary's Minister of Trade predicted today that the United States' recent decision to grant most-favored-nation tariff treatment to Hungary would contribute to a doubling of two-way trade, to $1 billion a year, by the early 1990's.

LEAD: rrUsing an advanced computer technology like RISC to power a cellular telephone or a compact disk player sounds a bit like using a supercomputer to balance a checkbook. But Microchip Technology Inc. says it has found a way to make the chips inexpensive enough for such uses.

LEAD: ABC's ''World News Tonight'' has taken over as the top-rated network evening newscast, displacing the CBS ''Evening News'' in the most tightly contested continuing ratings race in the television industry.

LEAD: President Bush declared today that he does not intend to strike a deal that would sharply reduce troop levels in Europe when he meets this weekend with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President.
LEAD: Barbara Bush learned today after two hours of tests at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., that her thyroid disease is not improving, although it has not worsened, her spokeswoman said.

LEAD: The State Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that armed state officials who were trying to stop illegal and rowdy conduct on the popular Saco River in southern Maine had no right to set up a ''riverblock'' last year to stop and search canoeists there.

LEAD: Lance Parrish was declared a free agent yesterday by the arbitrator George Nicolau and has until Jan. 8 to negotiate with all clubs. But the California Angels, his team this past season, said they were seeking to retain the veteran catcher.

LEAD: For centuries, Mediterranean powers bartered, seized or bullied this little archipelago because it sat at the center of what was long the world's most vital sea route. LEAD: Howard (Pappy) Mason, described by the authorities as a drug boss, refused to attend his Federal racketeering trial yesterday as a jury heard testimony that he ordered, from jail, the murder of a New York City police officer because he felt the police had shown him ''disrespect.''

LEAD: In the interminable first act of Joe Sutton's new drama, ''Black Market,'' JoAnn (Elaine Rinehart) and Hatch (Bruce McCarty), an absurdly naive young married couple who have recently moved to Manhattan, sit around their tenement and dream of being rich and famous.
LEAD: Gunnar Hedlund, the longtime leader of the Swedish Center Party and a former Interior Minister, died on Sunday after a long illness. He was 89 years old. The cause of death was not made public.

LEAD: DR. JEAN MAYER has been the president of Tufts University for 13 years, but he is still well known as a nutritionist. He secured his place in the nutrition hall of fame when he was chairman of the first White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health in 1969. At the time, the French-born, much-decorated World War II artillery officer with the Free French forces was a professor of nutrition at Harvard University.
LEAD: Clyde F. Kohn, a geographer and author, died of multiple myeloma on Wednesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 78 years old.
LEAD: A booming market in nostalgia is turning yesterday - when all our troubles seemed so far away - into the latest craze in the communications and consumer products industries.

LEAD: The Afghan rebels were a lot more popular in Washington when they were winners. Theirs was a classic geopolitical battle: bearded, turbaned ''freedom fighters'' with their divine mission and American-made weapons against the well-trained, heavily armed Red Army.

LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Alva R. Fitch, a survivor of the Bataan ''death march'' in the Philippines in 1942 who later became a deputy director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, died of a kidney ailment on Friday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 82 years old and lived in Williamsburg, Va.

LEAD: When Col. Lansana Conte seized power in Guinea five years ago, he vowed to restore law and order to a nation that had endured nearly three decades of nightmarish repression, purges and bloodshed.

LEAD: Carlos Arias Navarro, the last Prime Minister appointed under Franco, died of a heart attack on Monday, his family said today. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: Soviet and American partners, led by Combustion Engineering Inc. of Stamford, Conn., signed an agreement today to build and operate a $2 billion petrochemical complex in western Siberia. The first phase is to be finished by 1993.

LEAD: Handel's ''Messiah,'' in the version for men's and boys' voices in which it was originally performed more than 200 years ago, will be given two performances by the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys on Dec. 12 and 14 at 7:30 P.M. at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53d Street. Tickets are $20 and $50 for reserved seats; $10 for students and the elderly.

LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation said it was developing electronic medical imaging equipment for hospitals. The company said the products, which are to be available in 1991, would record images from electronic diagnostic tools, quickly giving doctors pictures of internal organs and other body parts.

At his New York debut recital, on Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection, he demonstrated that the recordings are faithful representations of his work.

LEAD: N.H.L. Flyers 6, Penguins 3: Ilkka Sinisalo and Mark Howe scored twice and Mike Bullard had his 300th goal as Philadelphia won at Pittsburgh last night. The Flyers scored four goals on 17 shots in the first period to chase Wendell Young, the Penguin goalie. Mario Lemieux had two assists for Pittsburgh, extending his point-scoring streak to 13 games.
LEAD: Reggie Hanson scored 24 points tonight to lead Kentucky past Ohio University, 76-73, giving Rick Pitino a victory in his debut as coach of the Wildcats after leaving the Knicks.

LEAD: Ralph S. Purdum, an acxtor who ap-peared in many plays, television programs and commercials, died of pancreatic cancer on Monday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 63 years old and lived in Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y.

LEAD: M/A-Com Inc., facing uncertain times as a maker of electronic components for the military market, yesterday named Thomas A. Vanderslice, 57, as chairman and chief executive to succeed Thomas F. Burke, 60, who suffered fatal injuries in an auto accident in September.

LEAD: Christine Lahti, Debbie Shapiro, Liliane Montevecchi, George Hearn, Ruth Brown and Victor Garber are among the artists scheduled to take part in a benefit performance for the homeless on Dec. 11 at 8 P.M. at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Proceeds are to benefit the Partnership for the Homeless.
LEAD: If proof is needed that the pen is mightier than the sword, then Vaclav Havel is a veritable smoking gun.

LEAD: * Ambrit Inc., St. Petersburg, Fla., a novelty products maker, agreed to a new exchange ratio in its proposed merger with Empire of Carolina Inc., Tarboro, N.C., a toy maker. Each Ambrit share will be exchanged for three-tenths of an Empire share.

LEAD: Western European defense ministers asked the Bush Administration today not to reach any understandings about American and Soviet troop cuts when President Bush meets this weekend with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
LEAD: Five months ago, the Kentucky Supreme Court broke new ground in education when it declared the state's entire public school system unconstitutional.
LEAD: Having succeeded with its theme parks and movie making, the Walt Disney Company wants to see if its golden touch extends to the recording industry.

LEAD: Birago Diop, a Senegalese poet, novelist and diplomat and a founder of the Negritude movement in the 1930's, died on Saturday in Dakar, according to an announcement on national television in Senegal. No cause of death was given. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: This is a tale of two rooms, and one city. The rooms are the latest works of Sir John Soane -the latest to be seen by the public, that is, not the latest to be designed, since Soane, the genius known for his brilliant contortions of neo-classical space, died in 1837. At his death Soane left a rich array of buildings, including two unquestioned masterworks: the headquarters of the Bank of England, which was altered beyond recognition by Sir Herbert Baker in 1925, and his own house and office at 13 Lincoln's Inn Fields, which remains essentially as he left it, open to the public as Sir John
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl presented an outline to Parliament today for creating a German federation that would eventually lead to the reunification of the two German states.

LEAD: It is an idle school-day afternoon on the rugged East Side of Cleveland. Groups of children hang out on the street corner, while a couple of dozen others gather around a swimming coach in an inner-city gymnasium and plot their path to the big time.

LEAD: Friends and associates of Jennifer Jean Casolo depict her as an idealistic and deeply religious woman who thought she could help end the decade-old civil war in El Salvador by bringing people to see the horror of the conflict first hand.

LEAD: Hundreds of philosophy students crammed into the second floor at Charles University today to discuss with their deans and professors how the department's curriculum could be changed to make it less doctrinaire.
LEAD: Harvey Hart, a Canadian film and television director, died of a heart attack on Nov. 21 in Toronto. He was 61 years old.

LEAD: The end of history? The remarkable uprisings in Eastern Europe are more like a resumption of history. As Hungarians plan their first free elections since World War II, demonstrators in Czechoslovakia quote Thomas Jefferson and chant the name of Alexander Dubcek, who failed heroically in 1968 to bring reform.

LEAD: Bill Parcells expects Lawrence Taylor's sprained right ankle to prevent the Giants' All-Pro linebacker from playing Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles.

LEAD: Dr. Marcus David Kogel, the founding dean of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University and a former Commissioner of Hospitals in New York City, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at his daughter's home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

LEAD: The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press reached a tentative agreement with five unions today, preventing a strike in the first week of the newspapers' long-delayed business merger. The agreement came after more than 11 hours of talks that began Monday.

LEAD: McCann-Erickson Worldwide yesterday became the first international agency to open a branch in Yugoslavia -underscoring the industry's growing conviction that there is opportunity in the political and economic tumult of Eastern Europe. The agency, called Jadran

LEAD: With almost half of the 500,000 public employees in New Jersey spending time in front of video-display terminals, the State Health Department today issued guidelines intended to eliminate hazards that can cause injury and stress.

LEAD: A 21-month-old girl was doing well today after receiving the nation's first liver transplant from a living donor on Monday and undergoing surgery this morning to stop bleeding from the transplanted organ.
LEAD: FEW dishes are more satisfying in late fall than poached chicken with vegetables. This one-pot meal can be prepared quickly and is excellent as a leftover.

LEAD: It seemed somehow appropriate that when the old regime in Czechoslovakia formally agreed to cede its monopoly on power, the deed was done between a caretaker Prime Minister and an opposition lacking even a formal headquarters.

LEAD: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign for 1989-1990 opened on Sunday, and $1,303,381.21 has been collected. That is a substantial increase over the $1,168,040 that had been collected by the same time last year.

LEAD: The quarterback couldn't take a deep breath without wincing. The linebacker couldn't walk without crutches. Joe Montana was wearing a towel as he stood at his locker in the 49ers' dressing room. Lawrence Taylor was wearing a scowl as he hobbled on crutches to the bus that would take the Giants to the airport Monday night after a 34-24 loss in the essence of the National Football

LEAD: The Communist Government, with the approval of party leaders, all but surrendered to its opposition today by pledging to give up its 41-year monopoly on political power and to allow non-Communist ministers into a new Cabinet to be named by Sunday.

LEAD: The United States has warned that it may pull out of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization if the agency extends any new measure of recognition to the Palestine Liberation Organization.
LEAD: Priscilla Robertson, an author, a historian and a teacher, died of a stroke on Sunday at Humana Hospital-Suburban in Louisville, Ky. She was 79 years old.

LEAD: In ''Kate's Diary'' by Kathleen Tolan, characters comment on the deficiencies of a play in progress, indicating that it is melodramatic or self-indulgent or that it causes ''the audience's presumed discomfort.'' The comments are intended to be disarming, but one ends with the belief that the playwright has been astute in her self-criticism.

LEAD: In youth-orchestra programming, hard experience has taught, discretion is the prime virtue. Samuel Wong's valiant program for the first concert of his second season as music director of the New York Youth Symphony on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall seemed, therefore, to carry the likelihood of failure and the potential for disaster.
LEAD: A New England Airline commuter plane with eight people aboard was feared missing in the Atlantic Ocean after it vanished tonight on a night flight from Block Island, the authorities said.
LEAD: A high school football star was sentenced today to 40 years in prison for his part in the beating death of a gay man from Wethersfield.
LEAD: Kris Beck is a political science major at the University of Chicago who plans to become President of the United States. That's why he signed up for Natural Science 104.

LEAD: When Morgan Hughes, an amusement park concessionaire, came to Westchester County in 1982 to negotiate leasing rides at the county-owned Playland Amusement Park in Rye, his lawyer took him directly to Republican Party headquarters.

LEAD: The script for this year's subway fare increase was written here in the state capital three years ago, and, in a departure from the usual plot, no fight scene was planned for the final act. But now it turns out that the drama will end much as it always has -with a boisterous battle at the close.

LEAD: Baseball's spiraling salary structure reached a new plateau yesterday when Rickey Henderson, traded by the Yankees to his hometown Oakland Athletics last June 21, agreed to a four-year contract with the A's worth $12 million.
LEAD: Claudio Teehankee, the representative of the Philippines at the United Nations and former Chief Justice of the nation's Supreme Court, died of cancer Monday in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: Max M. Low, a founder of the IPCO Hospital Supply Corporation, died of heart failure Monday at Albert Einstein Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

LEAD: IF you suspect that some generous admirer is planning to give you a case or two of 1985 Chateau Margaux this Christmas, hint around to your less affluent friends that you'd like a copy of Jancis Robinson's ''Vintage Timecharts'' to go with the wine.

LEAD: Francis X. Smith, once one of the most powerful judges in New York City, walked yesterday into one of the courthouses he used to supervise, escorted by his son, his lawyer and a friend. When he left, he was escorted to jail.

LEAD: Nearly 600 arts institutions throughout the United States plan to observe ''A Day Without Art'' on Friday to draw attention to the effects of AIDS on the arts community.

LEAD: In a kinder world, New York's present $1 bus and subway fare would stay right there. But that's neither realistic nor prudent. The cost of living has gone up 22 percent since the last fare increase, in 1986, and so has the cost of operating the transit system. That means fares or government transit subsidies must go up.
LEAD: AN early peek into this year's Christmas sack of kitchen equipment reveals few innovative products. Instead, one sees familiar tools that have been considerably improved.

LEAD: A day after two researchers at the University of California at San Francisco received the Nobel Prize for the discovery of normal genes that can cause cancer when they go awry, a tiny New York biotechnology company received the first Food and Drug Administration approval for a diagnostic test based on such genes.

LEAD: The Thinking Machines Corporation said today that it had received a $12 million contract from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency to develop the first supercomputer capable of speeds of a trillion operations a second, the level of computer performance researchers believe will be necessary to solve the most difficult scientific problems.
LEAD: The former Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, one of this country's most prominent right-wing politicians, was shot to death today outside a fast-food restaurant here.

LEAD: Jerry Claiborne, whose 6-5 record this season capped a 41-46-3 record in eight years as Kentucky's head coach, resigned unexpectedly yesterday, saying his heart was no longer into recruiting players.

LEAD: With the help of former Navy colleagues and a direct mail specialist, John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser facing trial in the Iran-contra affair, is making an unusual public appeal for money to help pay his mounting legal bills.

LEAD: Niatross, one of the greatest harness racing horses, fetched $1.35 million in a United States Bankruptcy Court auction. Niatross was owned by Saratoga Standardbreds, which filed for bankruptcy last year.

LEAD: Chinese leaders, quick to complain when foreigners question their conduct of internal affairs, have now presumptuously interfered in the American legislative process. LEAD: The Knicks yesterday flew to the West Coast, where they will open a four-game trip tonight against the Golden State Warriors in Oakland, Calif. LEAD: The Tennessee Valley Authority paid $172,700 to fly a top manager between his home in Virginia and his office in Tennessee over a one-year period, a Congressional report says.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday as dealers placed bids at an auction of $10 billion worth of two-year notes.

LEAD: Michael Chang looked across the net last night and saw, in addition to the No. 1 player in the world, a giant of a man with an ax to grind and just the weapon to do it.

LEAD: SKIING Italian Wins Slalom: Alberto Tomba of Italy won the second slalom of the World Cup season yesterday by 1.73 seconds in Waterville Valley, N.H. Tomba easily won both heats in times of 57.96 and 58.28 for a total of 1 minute 56.24 seconds. His closest challenger in each test was Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, who was more than one second behind after a first run of 59.15 seconds.(AP)

LEAD: Dr. John F. Grady, a retired surgeon, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 87 years old. He practiced in Manhattan from 1933 to 1974, when he retired. He had been an attending surgeon at the French Hospital in Manhattan and a director of the French Polyclinic Hospital.

LEAD: The Communist leadership of East Germany reacted coolly today to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's proposal on Tuesday for a ''confederative structure'' joining the Bonn and East Berlin Governments. But it did not reject the Kohl plan out of hand.

LEAD: Sales in the early part of the Christmas shopping season ''have been pretty good but nothing exceptional,'' with a mixed pattern and regional differences, Rosalind Wells, chief economist of the National Retail Merchants Association, said at a news conference yesterday.

LEAD: Much has been made of the $2 billion that it will cost taxpayers to bail out Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. But for the people who were persuaded to invest their life savings in now-worthless securities, the cost is emotional as well as financial.

LEAD: Test-driving a pair of skis before laying out $300 to $500 would seem to be a sensible idea, but most skiers base their buying decisions on such superficial things as color, price or a friend's recommendation. Equipment manufacturers have for several years been trying to counter this method by providing skis for free tests.

LEAD: A new study has found a statistically significant link between cancer and human exposure to electromagnetic fields from the network of electrical wires that crisscross the nation.

LEAD: Paul Mellon, the president and chairman of the National Gallery of Art, has received this year's Benjamin Franklin Award for public service from the American Philosophical Society in Philadelphia.

LEAD: Halfway through Peter Parnell's new play, ''Hyde in Hollywood,'' a malevolent 1930's gossip columnist named Harry Babylon tells the audience his nightmare. Harry has dreamed of a phantasmagoric movie premiere at which the stars he helped make famous are all scrambled: Gary Cooper sounds like Marlene Dietrich, Adolphe Menjou is made up like Rita Hayworth, and Deanna Durbin sings ''My Bill'' to Helen Morgan, who is dressed like Hattie MacDaniel in ''Gone With the Wind.

LEAD: What's an anchorman? The term, also rendered as the gender-neutral anchor, has won dictionary recognition; it refers to a television personality who coordinates all the reports on a news broadcast. But even as the word wins formal acceptance, events are draining away its meaning. This has become the era of floating anchors.
LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that Robert B. Gill, a vice chairman, would become chief operating officer of Penney stores and the company's catalogue division on March 1.

LEAD: At least seven parties have expressed interest in buying a large part of the American Express Company's stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as part of a deal to inject capital into the investment house, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

LEAD: Insect infestation was found in 6 of 17 samples of imported food products bought in New York City stores, City Council President Andrew J. Stein said yesterday.

LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. acknowledged yesterday that it planned to raise several million dollars of equity capital by requiring that its best-paid employees take a portion of their year-end bonuses in Drexel stock rather than in cash.

LEAD: If the walls of 273 Water Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10004 could talk, the dainty would have to block their ears. LEAD: Mother Teresa, who sustained a heart attack in September, will receive a pacemaker in an operation on Friday, her doctor said. Mother Teresa fell ill Wednesday.

LEAD: The upheaval in Eastern Europe has left Americans optimistic and ready for even greater change in the region. Two out of three say East and West Germany should be reunited, and an equal number predict that Eastern Europe will be largely out of Soviet control a year from now.

LEAD: Wry wit and arresting visual images distinguished 22 print ads that won Athena awards for excellence in newspaper advertising yesterday. LEAD: Despite objections from some of its rivals, the American Stock Exchange is moving to put into effect a plan that allows stock options to be traded on more than one exchange.

LEAD: While the United States and other countries intensify their war on drugs, two European countries, Switzerland and the Netherlands, are adhering to a much more liberal approach to their drug problems.

LEAD: When President Bush meets President Gorbachev tomorrow, it will be with the best of intentions for improving Soviet-American relations. But it's still not clear that he has a clear and compelling strategy for doing so.

LEAD: Roy M. Huffington of Houston said today that he intends to sell his Huffington Corporation, a holding company with oil, gas and real estate interests that he started in 1958. He did not name an asking price, but analysts said it could fetch close to $1 billion.

LEAD: Cox Landey & Partners has named David Mandelbaum as a management partner and Jay Wolf a creative partner. The appointments came a week after Bob Cox, the former top creative executive of Hal Riney & Partners/New York, joined Shaw & Landey, which changed its name to Cox Landey & Partners.

LEAD: Consumer spending fell in October to its lowest level in nearly three years, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts said continued sluggishness in personal consumption is likely to be a ''major drag'' on the economy in the fourth quarter.

LEAD: Dr. Pearl Ma, who was chief of microbiology at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Manhattan, died of cancer Wednesday in Hong Kong, according to word received at the hospital here. Dr. Ma was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan until she returned recently to her native Hong Kong.

LEAD: On the eve of an encounter with Pope John Paul II, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said tonight that the Soviet Union had erred in long rejecting religion and now needed its moral force to help make his plans for a restructured society work.

LEAD: * Young & Rubicam has acquired a majority interest in a Turkish agency, Reklamevi, based in Istanbul. The agency will change its name to Young & Rubicam Turkey.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has said he is not yet a candidate for a third term next year, but his friends say they raised nearly $2 million for a third-term campaign last night.

LEAD: Rise in New York Cab Fares An 11.5 percent increase in yellow-cab fares was approved. Fare rises for subways, buses and commuter railroads are expected to follow shortly. Page B1. LEAD: ''Mastergate,'' a comedy by Larry Gelbart about Government cover-ups, will close after the matinee on Dec. 10 at the Criterion Theater, Broadway and 45th Street. The play, directed by Michael Engler, will have run for 24 previews and 68 regular performances.

LEAD: In the work of Alfred Pinkham Ryder (1847-1917) there are images that, once seen, form part of a collective American folk-memory. One such is ''The Race Track,'' now in the Cleveland Museum, in which a pale rider on a pale horse races round and round an empty racecourse for all eternity. Another is ''Jonah'' in the National Museum of American Art in Washington, in which the sea that surrounds Jonah's boat is so convulsive we almost think he will be more comfortable inside the belly of the whale.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Britain still intends to send a Bangkok-based diplomat on an aid-related visit to Cambodia despite an American request that it lay the plan aside, Western diplomats here said today.

LEAD: A sign-painter was putting the last touches on the company logo in the lobby as guests arrived early Tuesday evening for the opening of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation's new headquarters at 211 West 61st Street, just west of Lincoln Center.

LEAD: President Bush today killed legislation that would have allowed Chinese students to stay in the United States after their visas expired. He said he was taking administrative action to give equivalent protection to the students.

LEAD: The prices farmers received for raw products rose by 1.4 percent in November over the previous month, primarily because of higher prices for strawberries, milk, eggs and celery, the Agriculture Department said today.

LEAD: SKIING Swiss Wins Giant Slalom: Urs Kaelin of Switzerland won the giant slalom yesterday at Waterville Valley, N.H., for his first World Cup victory. Kaelin overcame Lars-Boerje Eriksson of Sweden to win in a combined time of 2 minutes 38.49 seconds through 54 gates over hard-packed snow. Eriksson, 15th after the first run, moved up with the fastest clocking of the second run, 1:20.91, for an overall time of 2:38.75.

LEAD: The former head librarian at the University of Texas Medical Branch has been charged with stealing five rare medical books from the school. The accused, Emil Frey, 62 years old, surrendered to Galveston County sheriff's officials Wednesday and was later released on $23,000 bond. An indictment charges him with stealing five of 80 books missing from the school's Moody Medical Library.

LEAD: Joe Barry Carroll, the Nets' backup center, will be out for two to five weeks with a sprained left ankle. LEAD: For more than 50 years, Lloyd Wescott ran a dairy farm in Hunterdon County about 30 miles west of here, on the Delaware River. Two years ago he sold it. At the age of 80, he was growing old for farming, and the dairy business simply was not making it.

LEAD: A Philadelphia school district program that gave preference to minority contractors has been struck down by a Federal district judge, who says it failed to meet a new test established by the Supreme Court.

LEAD: Czechoslovakia announced today that it would begin immediately to dismantle fortifications along some sections of its 240-mile border with Austria, and remove virtually all restrictions on travel to the West.

LEAD: The California Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating reports of illegal drug use among workers at a construction job where a crane collapse killed five people.

LEAD: Two sinkholes, one more than 25 feet deep, opened here today, forcing the temporary evacuation of at least six homes, the police said.

LEAD: Eduardo Chillida is very much a European modernist. His abstract sculpture in metal and clay is intense yet measured, freest when it is most self-contained. Its edge depends upon its ability to communicate a sense that it is both aware of its limits and entirely at ease with its identity, and yet driven to push those limits and see, feel and know more.

LEAD: Frantisek Kucera, the general manager of the century-old Tos Hostivar Machinery Company, is one of those who lost out in the bargain that the hard-line Communist Government made to keep itself in power - cutting back on crucial investments to keep workers docile by providing them oranges, automobiles and homes.

LEAD: In what could be an important test case of the boundaries of the Federal law banning insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused a typesetting supervisor of illegally trading on confidential information from advance copies of Business Week magazine.
LEAD: Francis J. McCaffrey, a lawyer and former Democratic State Senator from the Bronx, died of a stroke Wednesday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: Xavier McDaniel scored 37 points, including 20 in the fourth quarter, leading the Seattle Supersonics past the Knicks, 127-122, tonight.

LEAD: Stanford Olsen, the tenor who won the 1989 Naumburg Vocal Competition, will sing Schubert's ''Schone Mullerin'' at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening at 8. The pianist will be Phillip Farris. Tickets are $10. Information: 874-6770.

LEAD: Edward Lee Howard, the former Central Intelligence Agency agent who was said to have passed important secrets to Moscow before defecting to the Soviet Union, has been permanently expelled from Hungary, Administration officials say.

LEAD: Stock of the Chevron Corporation, which has been pushed up in recent days on speculation that it is a takeover candidate, was the most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Almost 3.4 million shares changed hands, including a one-million-share block. The San Francisco-based oil company closed at $68.625, up 25 cents.

LEAD: In his first public comments since his killing of two unarmed blacks set off three days of rioting here 10 months ago, a Hispanic police officer testified today that he fired the fatal shot because ''I feared for my life - I thought I was going to be killed.''

LEAD: Under mandate of the Legislature, legal scholars here are polishing a new state law that they detest and believe to be unconstitutional. Their task is to mesh the new law with the complex state civil code.

LEAD: The tragedy of the growing violence here is that it is fortifying the extremes and seems to have all but ended any chance of a political solution to the decade-old civil war for the foreseeable future.

LEAD: When Chevy Chase finds a good way to hurt himself in ''National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation,'' he generally tries it more than once. The board that whacks him in the chin is liable to strike again. Floors will collapse, ladders fall, Christmas trees come hurtling through windows. The film's penchant for breakage jokes is rivaled only by its taste for gross-out humor, and for the kinds of double-entendres best appreciated by 7-year-old boys.

LEAD: Grace Billotti Spinelli, a retired social worker who directed programs at Young Women's Christian Associations in Orange and Passaic Counties in New Jersey, died Saturday at Warren Hospital in Phillipsburg, N.J. She was 83 years old and lived in Jersey City for 53 years before moving to East Orange about 10 years ago.
LEAD: Producers, theater owners and unions are discussing a plan to cut costs and prices so that some serious plays would have a better chance to succeed on Broadway.
LEAD: Tony Tubbs has been suspended indefinitely after having tested positive for cocaine last week after beating Orlin Norris in a North American Boxing Federation heavyweight championship bout.
LEAD: A Treasury of Yiddish Stories Edited by Irving Howe and Eliezer Greenberg With drawings by Ben Shahn. 676 pages. Viking. $29.95.

LEAD: The Gerber Products Company said it will close its Niagara Falls, Ontario, plant by April, terminating about 150 jobs. The world's largest maker of baby food is consolidating production in its three United States plants: in Fremont, Mich.; Fort Smith, Ark., and Asheville, N.C.
LEAD: Rutgers has been trying to make a national name for itself with its football and basketball teams, but national acclaim has come to the school this fall from its soccer team.

LEAD: The French Baroque remains opera's last frontier, largely unknown to the world's major companies. That has left a vast area to be scouted out by ensembles that specialize in reconstructing the performing practices of bygone eras. One such group, James Richman's Concert Royal, explored Rameau's first extant opera, ''Hippolyte et Aricie,'' at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday and Thursday evenings.

LEAD: Lynn Bari, an actress who appeared in nearly 50 movies, most of them in the 1930's and 40's, died of a heart attack on Nov. 20 in a Santa Barbara, Calif., hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in the Santa Barbara suburb of Goleta.

LEAD: The Omnicom Group said yesterday that it had sold a subsidiary, Franklin Spier Inc., to the agency's senior management and a group of investors. Omnicom did not disclose the terms of the deal. Alix Nelson, the chairman of Franklin Spier, which specializes in advertising for publishing houses, said Omnicom's emphasis on global marketing services did not suit its local focus and client list.
LEAD: One of Czechoslovakia's best-known balladeers looked out at the people packed into an auditorium here tonight, nodded his head and smiled.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the economy misstated the third-quarter change in two price indexes.

LEAD: President Bush made a timely and sensible call when he sent American warplanes on ''combat air patrol'' in the Philippines yesterday. The mission served as a deterrent, helping President Corazon Aquino's democratic Government fight off a dangerous military rebellion while conforming to principled American policy.
LEAD: Pacificorp, rebuffed in its effort to acquire a utility owned by the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, offered today to buy all of Pinnacle West.
LEAD: The Lear Jet Corporation is scouting for potential buyers again after the Chrysler Corporation decided against acquiring the manufacturer of business jets.

LEAD: The New Orleans Traditional Jazz Conservation Band, a sextet that plays the music of Jelly Roll Morton, Louis Armstrong, Kid Ory and other early New Orleans jazz musicians, opened a three-week engagement this week at Michael's Pub, playing Tuesdays through Saturdays.
