LEAD: Of the 35 million cut trees that will be sold this Christmas, slightly more than a third will be Scotch pines, the National Christmas Tree Association says. Next in popularity are Douglas firs, followed by two other top sellers: balsam firs and white pines.

LEAD: Lo Yuk-Sui, a Hong Kong real estate owner and developer, said yesterday that he had abandoned his plan to acquire the L. J. Hooker Corporation, the Australian developer with large retailing interests in the United States.

LEAD: Many people in their 50's and 60's - and a few even younger - would do well to begin orderly withdrawals from their I.R.A.'s and other qualified retirement plans before the end of the year. The accounts can provide needed cash for those who have taken early retirement, for example, and withdrawals can lower the long-term tax bite for those who have accumulated substantial sums.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's savings and loan institutions continued to shrink significantly in September in preparation for tough financial standards that take effect next week, the Government said today.
LEAD: Probing the nucleus of human cells, two scientists in Massachusetts have patented a technology they believe makes it easier to diagnose cancer.

LEAD: Dr. Patricia Aisemberg and Martin Varsavsky were married last evening at their New York home by Justice Carmen Ciparick of State Supreme Court in New York. The bride, 29 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Manuel Aisemberg of Buenos Aires. Her husband, also 29, is the son of Silvia Waisman of Buenos Aires and the late Dr.
LEAD: Alfred J. Green, a women's apparel manufacturer and an owner and breeder of thoroughbred horses, died of prostate cancer Thursday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: William P. Hoffman, a stockbroker who from 1917 to 1965 was a member of the New York Curb Exchange and its successor, the American Stock Exchange, died on Nov. 18, 10 days before his 101st birthday, at his home in Menlo Park, Calif.

LEAD: Two Taiwanese inventors have patented a wallet containing a pickpocket alarm. The wallet features electrical contacts on each side, both of which are connected to a small battery and alarm circuit. If a pickpocket gets hold of the wallet on each side, his fingers close the circuit and trigger the alarm.
LEAD: The Coast Guard ended its search today for the five-member crew of a lobster boat that has been missing for 11 days.
LEAD: Stock prices registered their biggest gain in weeks yesterday, buoyed by heavy foreign and institutional buying.

LEAD: The official inquiry into the beating of student demonstrators two weeks ago has run into difficulty since those who were witnesses are not eager to tell what they saw to those who are doing the investigating.
LEAD: Billy Owens and Stephen Thompson scored 21 points each tonight as Syracuse used an early 21-4 run to rout Virginia Commonwealth, 100-73, and move into the final of the Carrier Classic.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: President Bush took the unusual step of ordering American aircraft into action against Philippine rebel forces after he was advised that President Corazon C. Aquino was in danger of being overthrown, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: So that Reggie Williams would not have to miss a practice for tomorrow's key game with the Cleveland Browns, the Cincinnati Bengals staged a City Council swearing-in ceremony at their training site yesterday. The veteran linebacker was sworn in as an elected member of the Council in a conference room at the Bengals' field because he could not spare the time to attend the official swearing-in at City Hall with the eight other council members.
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about kitchen equipment gave incorrect dimensions for Le Smoker. It is 11 inches high, 13 inches wide and 23 inches long.

LEAD: The semifinalists in the final four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament, who will play Saturday at Rutgers Stadium, have combined for 45 shutouts this season. Santa Clara (19-0-2), the only unbeaten team in the tournament, has 14 shutouts. The team's goalie, Eric Yamamoto, has 13 of those and has allowed only 7 goals in 21 games.

LEAD: James D. Watkins, the Secretary of Energy, expressed concern today about plutonium that had escaped and collected in the ventilation ducts at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant in Colorado, and said the plant would not reopen until conditions there had been proved safe.

LEAD: Joseph A. Fernandez, who will become New York City's schools chancellor next month, yesterday faced an audience that, in the end, will be the measure of his success here: the schoolchildren of New York.

LEAD: About half the Soviet Union's 286 million people profess a religious affiliation. In addition to the groups cited below, there are 40 million to 50 million Muslims, 1.8 million to 2 million Jews and 665,000 Buddhists. Figures for adherents are Western estimates. RUSSIAN ORTHODOX: 50-60 million adherents
LEAD: All five eastbound lanes of Interstate 78 that were severely damaged by a garbage fire in August were reopened for tonight's rush hour, officials said.

LEAD: The stock of the UAL Corporation rose $12.50 yesterday, to $174 a share, on reports that the company would soon begin talks with its unions and employees about putting together a new employee stock ownwership plan. In a memo to employees, Paul George, senior vice president of human resources for the company, warned that putting together a new plan involved many ''uncertainties which may affect our ability to complete a new ESOP successfully.

LEAD: By encouraging independence in Eastern Europe and withholding Soviet support for Tiananmen-style crackdowns, Mikhail Gorbachev gives preliminary shape to the political and economic arrangements he has in mind for a ''common European home.'' His ideas for the military arrangements -which he might discuss this weekend with President

LEAD: The minutes remaining in the third period were evaporating, and with it the Rangers' lead atop the Patrick Division was on the verge of shrinking to a single point. Enter John Ogrodnick. The left wing for the Rangers, who has salvaged his career with a stunningly productive season at age 30, rescued the Rangers tonight.
LEAD: The summit meeting, whose goal is lasting peace, began, naturally, with a display of war power.

LEAD: Through much of the 20th century, Catholicism and Communism have appeared as titanic forces locked in combat, rival world faiths whose leaders in the Kremlin and the Vatican had no message for each other except mutual condemnation.

LEAD: Congress has been in high dudgeon all year over political favoritism and influence-peddling in the Department of Housing and Urban Development. But the H.U.D. appropriations bill suggests that lawmakers were upset less with the practice than with the practitioners. Passing out pork, it seems, is their prerogative.

LEAD: Arab members of the United Nations agreed today to postpone until Monday a General Assembly vote on a resolution prepared by the Palestine Liberation Organization that would recognize the existence of a state of Palestine in the Israeli-occupied territories.

LEAD: Ransom Harris Skeen, a retired executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank and Chase International Corporation, died of an aneurysm Thursday at Winter Park (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 88 years old and had lived in Bronxville, N.Y., for many years before moving to Winter Park in 1987.

LEAD: The company operating a crane that killed five people when it fell 16 stories in San Francisco on Tuesday had such a poor safety record that its own employees complained to state labor officials here about workplace hazards.
LEAD: In another sign of a slackening economy, the Government's main forecasting index fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the fifth decline so far this year.

LEAD: The chief of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that he was recommending a $1 toll increase on all six of its bridges and tunnels and a 25-cent fare rise on PATH, the underground commuter rail system.

LEAD: Dominick P. Felitti, a retired government official who worked at the city, state and Federal levels, died Wednesday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Markets

LEAD: Singing opera 50 years ago was a friendlier experience than it is today, and the scenery didn't upstage the singers, say the six divas who are to take part in the Met Marathon on radio this afternoon.

LEAD: Three days after she stole across a closed border into Hungary, Nadia Comaneci, the Rumanian gymnast who captivated the world with a series of perfect performances at the 1976 Olympics, arrived in New York yesterday and explained why she had risked arrest to leave her homeland and come to the United States.

LEAD: Winter is generally the busiest time of the year for animal shelters. People often decide to adopt pets during the holiday season, only to discover later that they cannot cope with the responsibilities of pet ownership.

LEAD: Two members of Congress have asked President Bush to invoke a law that they co-sponsored to block the sale of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation's semiconductor division to a Japanese company on the ground that it would jeopardize national security.

LEAD: Franz Beckenbauer will quit as manager of the West German national team after the World Cup in Italy next year, the head of the West German soccer federation, Hermann Neuberger, said yesterday in Frankfurt. Neuberger said Beckenbauer, who coached the team to a runner-up finish in the 1986 World Cup, would become a marketing executive for the federation.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh proposed regulations today that would allow the Government to impose civil fines of up to $10,000 for possessing small amounts of marijuana and other illegal drugs for personal use.

LEAD: A drug dealer charged with the murder last year of an undercover New York City narcotics officer on the Upper West Side was convicted of the slaying yesterday by a jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In the ever-escalating world of baseball economics, Mark Langston is the latest highest-paid player in the game's history.

LEAD: A dancing midget named Emoro brought a touch of novelty to the Zairian soukous of Pepe Kalle on Thursday night at Kilimanjaro, 531 West 19th Street, where they are appearing through tonight. Mr. Emoro shared the band's dance routines, swiveled his hips and even danced while standing on his head, stepping to the beat with his legs in midair.
LEAD: The new Politburo of the Czechoslovak Communist Party declared today that the Soviet-led invasion that choked the Prague Spring of 1968 was wrong.
LEAD: The night she first saw the television newscasts showing hundreds of thousands of people demonstrating for freedom in Czechoslovakia, Vera Hudak cried.
LEAD: Security and fire-safety deficiencies at a state Division for Youth center in Columbia County threaten the juvenile offenders who live there, Comptroller Edward Regan said today.

LEAD: A chronology on Wednesday under the headline ''An Outline of German History'' gave pivotal dates in the growth of German nationalism and the efforts toward unification since the early 19th century. It amplified a report about the vision of reunification offered by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.

LEAD: For Samuel Granirer, a 48-year-old management consultant accused of extortion and bribery, yesterday was not the first time that his activities with his local school board in Queens had thrust him into the limelight.

LEAD: Although pirated copies of Metropolitan Opera broadcasts, with wildly varying sound, have been available for many years, the company has begun a series of official releases of broadcasts of special distinction, high-priced as a fund-raising device.
LEAD: The city's public housing agency is planning a midnight basketball league in the hope of attracting gang members and of easing tension in some tough neighborhoods.
LEAD: The Parliament amended the Constitution to eliminate the Communist Party's monopoly on power. Page 9.

LEAD: A 30-year-old drug dealer who ran one of the largest and most violent drug rings in Brooklyn and was responsible for 6 murders, 17 assaults, a kidnapping, a maiming and other crimes, was sentenced yesterday to seven consecutive life terms in Federal prison.

LEAD: In a move to cut its administrative expenses, Fidelity Investments, one of the nation's largest mutual fund firms, is raising the minimum investment in its funds to $2,500, from $1,000. The firm will also raise the minimum amount that current investors must maintain in these accounts to $1,000, from $500.

LEAD: Representative Jack Brooks of Texas, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, was released from the Bethesda Naval Medical Center today, where he had been treated there since Oct. 22 for inflammation of the pancreas, his office announced. The 66-year-old Congressman is expected to return to a full schedule, his staff said.

LEAD: To the Editor: I am deeply grateful to Brendan Gill for detailing in public what many of us at Sarah Lawrence College privately knew all along about Joseph Campbell. Because Campbell has been proposed as a sage for our times, it is particularly important for those of us who have a different estimate of the man and his work to speak up.
LEAD: New Leader for India
LEAD: With an agreement to begin official relations and a pledge of expanded religious freedom for Soviet citizens, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev joined hands today with Pope John Paul II.
LEAD: After three agonizing weeks without winning, the Nets found nothing wrong tonight with their 101-77 victory over the Miami Heat.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new insider-trading case, brought against an employee of a contractor for Business Week magazine, misstated the penalty given S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman, former Business Week broadcast editor. He was sentenced to six months in jail and fined $5,000 on two criminal counts, and agreed to pay an additional $41,000 in civil fines and restitution.

LEAD: Hassan Fathy, an Egyptian architect who championed the use of indigenous construction techniques to build housing for the world's poor, died Thursday in Cairo, the Associated Press reported. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: For his first recital at Carnegie Hall, on Tuesday night, the pianist Yefim Bronfman seemed to be staking a claim to the sort of sober, serious Germanic repertory long championed by Rudolf Serkin and, before him, Artur Schnabel. But curiously, after a deft opening Haydn sonata, his most successful outing came at the end, with Stravinsky's Three Movements from ''Petrushka.

LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday named James M. Taylor its chief staff official, the executive director for operations, replacing Victor Stello Jr., who has been nominated to head the bomb program at the Energy Department.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors said today that they would not retry three people they called dangerous underground militants, ending the case more than three years and millions of dollars after it started.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: The bombing that killed Alfred Herrhausen, the head of West Germany's largest commercial bank, was a complicated attack, planned weeks in advance and executed with precision, the police said today.
LEAD: Frank Cardi, a former president of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association, died on Thursday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 56 years old.
LEAD: To the Editors:

LEAD: Dorothy E. Rowe, former senior vice president of the American Research and Development Corporation, died Thursday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. She was 72 years old and lived in Boston.

LEAD: The staff of the New York City Transit Authority has revised a plan on subway and bus fares and is now proposing that the agency raise the price of a token to $1.15 from $1, but without offering discounts on bulk sales, a spokesman said last night.

LEAD: Two tables yesterday showing arms levels in Eastern and Western Europe, part of a page of charts giving background to the summit meeting in Malta, were described incompletely. The left-hand table labeled ''Conventional Arms'' gave the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's estimate and the Warsaw Pact's estimate of European military strength in NATO countries.

LEAD: Charity giving, a year-end tradition, has become a high-pressure sweepstakes. And as the competition for donations grows, some organizations are increasingly turning to telephone marketing and even some deceptive strategies to raise funds.

LEAD: Intercollegiate competition is showing welcome signs of revival in New York City. A five-team event was played on Sept. 27 at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, and two City College teams tied for first place.

LEAD: The HomeFed Corporation, parent company of the HomeFed Bank, said it will add $115 million to its loan-loss provisions in the fourth quarter. ''These general allowances will provide HomeFed greater flexibility to reduce its level of nonperforming assets and restructure its loan and real estate portfolios,'' said Kim Fletcher, chairman of the San Diego-based savings and loan association.

LEAD: A report in the Weekender Guide column of Weekend yesterday about a benefit on Sunday for the Madison Avenue Christmas for Children Fund gave the information phone number incorrectly. It is 988-4001.

LEAD: In a move that industry experts say could lead to significant changes on Wall Street, the directors of the Securities Industry Association voted today to drop the group's longstanding opposition to allowing banks to enter the securities business.

LEAD: The Giants' Lawrence Taylor has a broken right ankle, two sources with the team disclosed today. At the same time, in what seemed to be a contradiction, Coach Bill Parcells upgraded the linebacker's availability from out to doubtful for the game here Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles.
LEAD: As the invading Soviet tanks rumbled through the streets of Prague early on Aug. 21, 1968, local youths honked their car horns in raucous, unavailing protest.
LEAD: Despite more reports suggesting that the economy has weakened, prices of Treasury securities rose only modestly in light trading yesterday.

LEAD: The young woman who was raped, beaten and left for dead this spring in Central Park is known to most New Yorkers only as ''the jogger.'' For a rape victim to want to remain anonymous, and for the media to keep her so, is not unusual. Rape, even today, stigmatizes.

LEAD: To the Editor: You state in ''Caveats on Ordering by Phone'' (Consumer's World page, Nov. 4) that ''Nationwide, mail and phone orders make up for the greatest number of complaints received by Better Business Bureaus.''
LEAD: East Germany's Parliament amended the country's Constitution today, eliminating the clause that assigned the leading political role to the Communist Party.

LEAD: Ahmadou Ahidjo, who served as President of the West African nation of Cameroon for 22 years after it won independence from France in 1960, then fled into exile in 1983, died on Thursday in Dakar, Senegal, according to a French radio report quoted by the Reuters news agency.

LEAD: In December 1939, Alfred I. Jaffe paid $2 for a license to marry Mimi Muschat. ''Several years ago, I decided to make my annual contribution a tribute to my wife on our anniversary,'' Mr. Jaffe, who now lives in Somers, N.Y., wrote to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''I donated $2 for every year we were married, the $2 representing the original cost of our license.

LEAD: Jim Nolan is a teacher who was assigned to Intermediate School 74 in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx 15 years ago. The landscape is one of vacant lots and shattered dreams, but Mr. Nolan saw reason to stay.

LEAD: Game birds, extremely lean and low in fat, are becoming increasingly popular, especially for holiday meals. Those sold at retail or served in restaurants are raised on farms or ranches and do not have a strong, ''gamey'' flavor. It's illegal to sell domestically hunted game, but a small amount of shot game is coming in from Scotland, particularly grouse and pheasant.

LEAD: ''Our meeting today will hardly fail to have a powerful impact on world opinion. Not only is it something new and unusual. LEAD: Because of the Christmas for Children Fair, Madison Avenue will be closed tomorrow between 66th and 72d Streets from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.

LEAD: Officials in the Ukraine have announced that they will register congregations of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, which was forcibly dissolved 43 years ago, church members said today.

LEAD: The Golden State Warriors have requested waivers on Marques Johnson, the forward who was attempting an N.B.A. comeback after a layoff caused by a neck injury in November 1986, while he was with the Los Angeles Clippers.

LEAD: A public-television documentary examining Israeli perspectives on the uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories was financed with help from the Israeli consul general in New York, an executive producer of the film said yesterday.
LEAD: M. Hughes Miller, former president of Bobbs Merrill Company, the book publisher, died of cancer Tuesday at St. Joseph Medical Center. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: A twin-engine Army cargo plane with four crew members and a civilian on board crashed into a river this morning as it was approaching the Patuxent Naval Air Station near this southern Maryland community. No survivors were found.

LEAD: The holidays are a time for family gatherings, and for many families with elderly relatives, it might also be a good time to discuss what can be a difficult subject: health care in the home. Planning ahead can prevent a desperate search for medical or custodial care for a person who could need such care in a hurry.

LEAD: V. P. Singh won the unanimous backing of the victorious political opposition today and will be sworn in as the eighth Prime Minister of India at noon on Saturday, the office of the President said tonight.

LEAD: Dr. Chandler McCuskey Brooks, an educator and a physiologist who researched the functions of the brain and heart, died on Wednesday when an automobile struck him outside his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: The twin superpowers of men's tennis, Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, flicked away short-lived challenges from Stefan Edberg and John McEnroe last night to advance to the semifinals of the Masters with matching 3-0 records. They completed the week with their egos in matching form as well.

LEAD: The son of Peter MacDonald, the suspended Navajo chairman, pleaded not guilty to two counts of conspiracy today in a tribal court at which he had failed to appear for two arraignments last month.
LEAD: Throughout the fighting in the most serious armed challenge to the presidency of Corazon C. Aquino, no group or figure stepped forward to claim leadership of the rebellion.

LEAD: GOLF Four Teams Share Lead: Kenny Perry and Sherri Turner shot an eight-under-par 64 to share the lead with three other teams yesterday after the second round of the J. C. Penney Golf Classic in Largo, Fla. Also tied for first at 10-under 134 were Bill Britton and Donna White, Andy Bean and Laura Davies and Mike Hulbert and Val Skinner.(AP)

LEAD: Robert L. Heilbroner, the chairman of the nonfiction panel for this year's National Book Awards, evoked scattered murmurs and hisses at the awards ceremony on Wednesday when he said he had not read most of the 190 books submitted for the prize. Instead, he said, he narrowed his selections with such shortcuts as reading the first and last pages of some books, looking at blurbs and examining the index and table of contents.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Forces loyal to President Corazon C. Aquino appeared to be turning back an army rebellion today after seizing rebel-held military camps and television stations with the aid of American warplanes.

LEAD: The economy, hurt by declines in production, new orders and employment, continued to deteriorate in November for the seventh consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday as it released its monthly index of economic activity.
LEAD: Engineers at Bendix/King Air Transport Avionics, a division of Allied-Signal Inc., have obtained a patent for the heart of a new onboard aircraft collision avoidance system.

LEAD: In what organizers called ''the largest event that's ever happened to focus on the AIDS crisis,'' some 600 museums, galleries and other arts institutions across the United States observed ''A Day Without Art'' yesterday.

LEAD: Robert William McLaughlin, emeritus professor of architecture at Princeton University's School of Architecture, died Thursday at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 89 years old and lived in Princeton.
LEAD: These should have been heady days for F. Kenneth Iverson, chairman of the Nucor Corporation and a man celebrated for teaching Big Steel a thing or two about operating mills more efficiently.
LEAD: His face had not appeared on state television since 1968, and when his name was mentioned it was to denounce him.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The owner of a much-picketed birthing center here that also does abortions has invited anti-abortion leaders to come inside to talk with his patients in counseling sessions rather than scream slogans at them outside.

LEAD: Bolstered by the first gain in single-family home building in nine months, construction spending climbed modestly in October, and analysts said the improvement suggested lower interest rates were helping end a construction slump.
LEAD: Alan Bowne, a playwright and author, died of AIDS on Sunday at his home outside Petaluma, Calif. He was 44 years old.
LEAD: ''My life does not begin and end with football victories, but coaching is my profession and we all dream of perfect seasons,'' said Bill Curry of Alabama.

LEAD: Shares of Pacific Telesis Group, a major partner in a consortium bidding for West Germany's first private mobile telephone network, surged yesterday after press reports said the group would be awarded the multi-billion-dollar deal. Pactel shares jumped $2.25 to close at $48.125 in active New York Stock Exchange trading.
LEAD: President Alfredo Cristiani said today that leftist guerrillas had begun to use sophisticated antiaircraft missiles against Government warplanes for the first time in their 10-year civil war.

LEAD: The State Treasurer, Catherine Baker Knoll, sees Pennsylvania as a state with a fragile economy and a public pension fund that is bulging with $25 billion. After taking a medical degree and practicing for a time as a surgeon and psychiatrist, the Italian polymath earned a reputation as an avant-garde composer. He turned to the serious study of conducting in the early 1970's.

LEAD: Network news people say the biggest good-news story of the modern age, which is the story of Communism's falling dominoes, is box-office poison. TV ratings depict Americans tuning out in droves despite television's wonderfully moving pictures of freedom sweeping everything before it.

LEAD: Nancy Cruzan, once a spirited, vital young woman, lies unconscious in a Missouri hospital. It rejected her family's plea to let her die by removing her feeding tube.

LEAD: The trumpeter Tom Harrell's first set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night began in earnest halfway through. With Joe Lovano on soprano saxophone and Mr. Harrell on fluegelhorn, the band picked up some speed and finally began playing as an ensemble. Using arrangements by Mr. Harrell - he makes careful use of repeating patterns for the rhythm section - the band began abstracting the basic material of the tunes, using it as fuel for improvisation.

LEAD: SIXTEEN MONTHS AGO, I BECAME the first American to open and run an ice cream parlor in Seoul. In some ways, it didn't make much sense. The South Korean Government was notorious for its unwillingness to open markets to foreigners. Moreover, Koreans traditionally have no taste for dairy products or sweet desserts.

LEAD: Retailing is frequency marketing's next frontier. The Limited is rumored to be considering such a program. And several department stores, including Sears Roebuck and Montgomery Ward, have considered or tested the concept.

Membership is limited to 50 people chosen by their peers from the 250 members of the academy's parent body, the National Institute of Arts and Letters, Broadway and 155th Street.

LEAD: AS President Bush moves to fill the Administration's top civil rights jobs, policy makers in and outside the Administration are pointing to a subtle rethinking of what ''civil rights'' means.

LEAD: Sales have opened on apartments in Liberty View, a condominium tower under construction in Battery Park City at the southern tip of Manhattan, in advance of its completion, scheduled for early 1991. LEAD: Calling his move a protest over methods used to test two of his horses for drugs, the Aga Khan, one of the world's leading race-horse owners, has resigned from Britain's Jockey Club. On Friday, the Jockey Club disqualified Rifada, one of the Aga Khan's horses, from victory last July in a meeting at Warwick, England, after a muscle-relaxing substance was discovered in its system.

LEAD: Public school students in New York City will have an opportunity to view ways to change Times Square for the better through a 30-minute film that examines the history of the neighborhood and proposals for its redevelopment. Starting next month and continuing through the school term, the documentary ''Changing Times in Times Square'' is to be presented at 296 high schools and junior high schools in all boroughs.

LEAD: THE recent introduction of two new telephone services has touched off a debate over whether they are an invasion of privacy. LEAD: ONE annoyance frequently found in older homes, and sometimes even in homes that are not so old, is the lack of shut-off valves beneath plumbing fixtures. Shut-off valves permit turning off the water supply to individual fixtures like sinks, tubs and toilets without having to shut off the main water supply or large sections of household plumbing.

LEAD: ONE OF THE MOST UBIQUITOUS PRESENCES ON THE current art scene is a 39-year-old maverick named Jenny Holzer, a tricky impresario of language who makes words into visual spectaculars. A writer who doesn't think the printed page is ''enough of a forum,'' Holzer hatches messages that range from deadpanned aphorisms to dark meditations about the human condition, embosses them on plaques, engraves them on marble or granite benches and sarcophagus lids and - with skilled technological choreography - sets them prancing in dazzles of colored light.

LEAD: Does a city really need a museum with a permanent collection featuring 15 typewriters, 13 calculators, dozens of cameras, and glass showcases filled with telephones, dishes, glassware and stereo equipment? No, it doesn't, and visitors are to be excused if they think they have mistakenly stepped into the electronics and housewares departments of Harrods.
LEAD: Not many retired basketball professionals get a chance to return to the court to begin a new season at the age of 41, but Neal Walk, who did just that yesterday, is hardly an ordinary player.

LEAD: As of a week or two ago, it has been possible that Berlin will one day become again what it was in the past - the de facto capital of central Europe. This notion is a nightmare to many, in that between 1933 and 1945 the name of Berlin was fouled almost beyond redemption. The very idea that it should ever again be a place of power and pre-eminence was abhorrent.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Linda Brantley Bell and Ronald Louis Blackburn were married yesterday by the Rev. George H. White at the Central Brick Presbyterian Church in East Orange, N.J. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. John Jordan and Edward Brantley Salaam, both of Roselle, N.J. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lemuel H.

LEAD: Despite bitter cold and an occasional snow flurry, more than 1,000 people turned out for two rallies and a march in Manhattan yesterday to protest United States Government support for the Government of El Salvador in its war with guerrillas.

LEAD: Around late morning on Thursdays, things begin to slow here. Offices empty, traffic builds on homebound routes, the city's athletic clubs begin to fill and strollers take to the streets. Weekend is near.

LEAD: This is the season to lose oneself in a good oratorio, to inhabit a distant realm where the frescoes of Giotto and Michelangelo spring to life, where prophets, saints and seraphim lift their voices to the accompaniment of massed choirs and where the sound of the orchestra has the sheen of sustained organ harmony.
LEAD: TWO men walked out of the restaurant and onto the sidewalk in front of me. They were deep in conversation having something to do with adoption.

LEAD: The Greek notion of the Golden Mean is having a rough time these days. Our immoderate age, fascinated with the pursuit of outer limits, often takes a condescending view of the middle. But at least in audio, the idea of intelligent moderation persists in the middle price range which, as a group, offers the best dollar value in stereo equipment.

LEAD: Mike Taranto, the quarterback for Susan Wagner, didn't get much sleep on Friday night. In his mind, he kept going over certain plays he would use if given the opportunity when his team met DeWitt Clinton yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League championship game at Midwood Field in Brooklyn.

LEAD: William Draper Carter, a former director of the Department of International Exchanges at Unesco, died of kidney failure and pneumonia Friday at Huntington Hospital on Long Island. He was 80 years old and had lived in Huntington since 1965.

LEAD: Nancy Beth Levinbook, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin S. Levinbook of York, Pa., was married there last evening at Temple Beth Israel to Dr. David Michael Widlus, the son of Martha Widlus of Columbus, Ohio. Rabbi Irwin Goldenberg officiated.

LEAD: Pro football is one of two sports (boxing is the other) where physical destruction of your opponents pays such big dividends that bounty hunters will soon be replaced by body counters. Who orders it? We do. Every time we boo our losses. Who pays it? We do. Every time we buy from television sponsors.

LEAD: As the challenge of an undefeated Alabama football team finally arrived here - here, for the first time in 54 meetings over 97 years - the football players from Auburn University set out late this morning on their Tiger Walk.

LEAD: Difficult Choices in Prague
LEAD: WHAT DO DIRECTORS do?'' That was the question put to Walter B. Wriston at a meeting of the Council of Institutional Investors held in Manhattan last month.
LEAD: FROM Montville to Mahwah, the final 19-mile link of Interstate 287 is slowly taking shape amid the crumbling rock and pristine riverbanks of some of New Jersey's most desirable real estate.

LEAD: SNIPPETS OF SKIN PEEKING OUT HERE, EXPOSED LIMBS ON VIEW there. Flashes of barely veiled bosoms and expanses of flesh everywhere. When the showings of the spring 1990 collections ended a month ago, the nude message -- though by no means the only news -- was certainly clear. Even the most pronounced color palette emulated skin tones, ranging from deep browns to rosy peaches and palest alabasters.

LEAD: THE new Prime Minister of India, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, who was sworn in yesterday, is embarking on an ideological balancing act that will test his substantial skills as a builder of consensus.
LEAD: Where has Sally Friedman been for the last 20 years? Her Opinion page article (''A Honeymoon for One,'' Oct. 29) left me wondering why someone as talented as she is chose to write it.

LEAD: Before Tom Pollock, the chairman of Universal Pictures, could slide into his booth for breakfast at the posh Bel Air Hotel one morning last week, he was showered with attention from others in the dining room. The film producer Lee Rich congratulated him on the opening of ''Back To the Future, Part II,'' which had a recordbox-office gross of $43 million for the five-day Thanksgiving period and has become one of the Christmas season's major hits.
LEAD: Two top officials in the Bush Administration today strongly urged changes to address what they said are fundamental and structural problems underlying the nation's financial markets.

LEAD: Roger Neilson sat lost briefly in thought on the team's flight here, poring over charts and sifting through his briefcase for further data on the 4-3 victory the Rangers had magically manufactured in Vancouver barely an hour earlier.

LEAD: Eric Hawkins has come to seem a choreographer of primarily luminous pure dance pieces with delicate traces of symbolism woven through. But he is a storyteller, too, as a performance of ''God the Reveler'' suggested on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 18th Street, where the Erick Hawkins Dance Company appears through

LEAD: I was in charge of the United States Consulate in Cochabamba, Bolivia, in the 1960's (where Vargas Llosa spent some of his childhood). I found Gerald Marzorati's article excellent. I was particularly impressed by his mention of the informales, ''the street vendors and bus-van operators and the owners of tiny factories,'' who are pervasive in South

LEAD: WHAT is a ''nontraditional'' family? Should people who consider themselves members of such families have a right to succeed to a rent-stabilized apartment when the tenant named on the lease dies or moves out?

LEAD: Presented below are definitions of words and phrases drawn from ''Managerial Literacy: What Today's Managers Must Know to Succeed,'' which is discussed on page 8. The definitions have been prepared by the authors of the book, Gary Shaw and Jack Weber.

LEAD: IN the North Sea on the Flanders coast, Belgium's gray shrimp are caught beneath an almost perpetually gray sky. The bulk of them are harvested by boat, but at Oostduinkerke, shrimp fishermen on horseback still drag their nets at low tide to scoop up these tiny glistening delicacies. A basketful of gray shrimp can be a comically monstrous sight; each shrimp is less than an inch long and, before they are cleaned, all appear weirdly mustached.
LEAD: In an effort to end turmoil in New York City's Human Rights Commission, its chairman reversed himself on Friday and reinstated the top two officials in the AIDS Discrimination Division.

LEAD: Victoria V. Baron, a daughter of Pamela Stearns Baron of New York and Richard W. Baron of New York and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey R. Lauterbach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Lauterbach of Pittsburgh. The Rev. William Pindar officiated at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An Australian select team will play a four-game exhibition tour against Major Indoor Soccer League teams in January. The Australians will play in Tacoma, Wash., on Jan. 22; in Wichita, Kan., on Jan. 23; in Dallas onJan. 25, and in Kansas City on Jan. 30.

LEAD: Short films are so pitilessly noncommercial that they become havens of freedom; film makers might as well give up any idea of reaching a large audience and do the most wildly inventive work they can. The exception to this rule occurs in film schools, where fledgling producers, directors, writers and cinematographers put together brief films commonly known as ''calling cards'' to the industry, meant to show agents and producers that these students have become professionals.

LEAD: WHEN he became Secretary of Energy, James D. Watkins promised a new era in which the American nuclear weapons industry would no longer be allowed to invoke national security as a reason to cover up safety and management problems.
LEAD: A BOOM in walking vacations sounds like an oxymoron: anything that is booming must be loud and fast, and walking is quiet and closer to two miles an hour. So call it a soft boom.

LEAD: ACCORDING TO GEORGES Duboeuf, perhaps the bestknown of the Beaujolais shippers, the two greatest vintages in modern Beaujolais history were 1945 and 1976. In a business built on hyperbole, Mr. Duboeuf comes off as almost laconic. So when he says, as he has been since September, that 1989 could be better than both those years, there just may be something to it.

LEAD: So now decaffeinated coffee is in hot water. A study found that drinking decaffeinated coffee raises levels of the so-called bad cholesterol in the blood. People like Stanley Rubin, who weaned themselves from real coffee to decaf in the belief that it was healthier, are feeling betrayed.
LEAD: Last Sunday was one of those days when the only ingredients that looked appealing in the supermarket required little or no work to be turned into a meal.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Arthur Miller should be ashamed of himself for saying that A. R. Gurney is a perfectly good playwright even though he has never written a character like Willy Loman (''Laughter, Tears and the Perfect Martini,'' by Alex Witchel, Nov. 12). Willy Loman was a great deal more than an interesting character.

LEAD: Thousands of needy New Yorkers could be warmer this winter thanks to a welcome initiative to recycle coats. Civic groups, led by a volunteer organization called New York Cares, seek donations of wearable parkas and overcoats. A similar campaign in Denver has collected and distributed more than 100,000 secondhand coats since 1981.

LEAD: For This Week: If old flower stalks of perennials are still standing, cut them to near ground level. Don't forget to move hoses inside and shut off outdoor faucets for winter. Also, the power tools should be cleaned and stored, especially mowers. Apply anti-desiccant sprays any time this month to conifers, rosebushes and broadleaved evergreens to cut down on drying out; the colorless material wears off in a few months and may need to be re-applied in February.
LEAD: M.C.I. Rent Increases

LEAD: Long Islanders may well be proud of the extraordinary bequest of Wedgwood to the Sands Point Museum in Port Washington. The North Shore of Long Island is fortunate to have so many museums and cultural centers for the enrichment of its residents who find travel to New York City for the lively arts increasingly more expensive, frustrating and not a little hazardous.
LEAD: Entries for the 114th annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club, scheduled for Madison Square Garden on Feb. 12 and 13, have closed with 2,903 dogs representing 141 breeds or varieties.

LEAD: Cheshire, Conn. $260,000 7 Worden Circle 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old saltbox; cherry-stained floors, breakfast area, 1.1 acres; taxes $3,603. North Haven, Conn. $162,500 18 Temple Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; wraparound deck, cathedral ceiling in family room, wood stove; taxes $1,580.

LEAD: Stacey Robin Kaplan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Kaplan of Bay Shore, L.I., was married last evening to Gary Evan Schreiber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Schreiber of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbis Martin S. Rosenberg and Gershon Schwartz officiated at Temple Beth Shalom in Smithtown, L.I.

LEAD: AFTER repeated instances of harassment, disturbing phone calls and a bomb threat, Susan K. Blair, a native of the South Shore of Long Island, has gone into hiding to protect her family and to await this month's release of the book she feels some people do not want to see published.

LEAD: Just outside a dilapidated storeroom, a balding plantation owner crouches down, staring intently at the ground. ''There's a boy out here says I owe him some money,'' he growls to a shabbily attired employee standing on the porch. The wizened figure picks up some pecans scattered amid the fallen leaves as he barks out questions: ''Where is Nancy?
LEAD: THE Week in Review asked three European journalists to assess how the continent's security needs can be met as the cold war recedes.

LEAD: Leading lights of the New York art and social worlds and whirls are sponsoring an auction of donated works this Wednesday, with proceeds to go toward helping fight construction of Trump City, a proposed 7,600-apartment development on the Upper West Side.

LEAD: In midafternoon on Aug. 3, Randal Swanson, a 29-year-old baker from West Caldwell, N.J., steered his black Toyota along West 162d Street in Manhattan, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, looking to buy cocaine.

LEAD: HARD as it is to remember today, only a year ago many countries of Eastern Europe remained the essence of gray Communist orthodoxy. But the rigid foundations of party dictatorship were already being eroded by deepening economic malaise and the reformist policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In a startling shift, the Soviet leader made it clear that Soviet tanks would not enforce the old order as they had so often in the past and that, in the satellite countries at least, an end to the

LEAD: In a project designed to benefit both the body and soul of Goddard College and of its students, undergraduates are restoring the school's historic buildings and grounds. Already, three porches of the 80-year-old Martin Manor, the campus focal point, have been cleaned, repaired and, where necessary, recreated in accordance with the historical record.

LEAD: Government scientists examining the carcasses of laboratory monkeys imported from the Philippines say they have discovered three with the ebola virus, which before the discovery of AIDS was considered the world's deadliest virus to humans.

LEAD: The marriage of Alice Frances Collopy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Collopy of Morris Plains, N.J., to Michael Anthony Carlucci, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emilio Carlucci of Dumbarton, N.J., took place yesterday at the Estherwood mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. A. William Sabatino, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: SOUTH KOREA'S centuries-old kilns, out of operation for more than 50 years, are going full blast again. Shut down during the Japanese occupation (1910-1945) and throughout the Korean War, the pottery centers reopened one by one after the war ended in 1953, as the country undertook rebuilding and reclaiming its 5,000-year-old culture.

LEAD: The article ''Broader Membership Is Giving Teachers' Union New Influence'' (Oct. 8) correctly judged that the inclusion in teacher bargaining units of such support staff members as school secretaries, instructional and noninstructional assistants, custodians and bus drivers has enhanced the bargaining power of the New Jersey Education Association and its affiliates.

LEAD: Leslie Joy Weingarten, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Weingarten of New York and New Milford, Conn., was married last evening at the Hotel Westbury in New York to Scott Ryan Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Singer of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Rabbi Stanley Davids officiated.

LEAD: THE HOLIDAYS ADvance inexorably; trite phrases like 'tis the season and Yuletide cheer come out of the attic along with the old tinsel, and readers of this column demand specific advice on language books to prevent those on their gift lists from facing the Nifty Nineties at a loss for words.

LEAD: Tournament competitors were more wary years ago in the early rounds. It was as though each one wanted to hold back on playing sharp opening variations until the others exposed their secret innovations and prepared analysis. There were a lot of tentative Reti and English openings and you would not get a look at open games until about the fifth round.

LEAD: Dr. Joseph Murphy, who will step down next year as chancellor of the City University of New York, has a lot in common with many CUNY students: he's a son of working-class parents who sought to better himself through academic training.

LEAD: The official East German press agency today made public the existence of a previously secret arms-exporting company that it said sent weapons to the Middle East, Latin America and Africa to earn currency for the Communist Party.

LEAD: In the last 18 months, I have turned down two all-expenses-paid trips to drug-company symposiums in Bermuda and in Vancouver, B.C. (spouse invited, too), and countless free dinners at the finest restaurants in town. I did attend a free seminar entitled ''Performance Under Pressure,'' which included two medical talks, a buffet lunch, a talk by former Knick's great Dave DeBusschere and tickets to the 1989 N.C.A.A.

LEAD: New York City can be such a delight in the holiday season. Children can often be found lined up outside Radio City Music Hall for the Christmas show or gazing wide-eyed at the tree in Rockefeller Center. Grandmothers bake gingerbread in their kitchens. Parents hustle to grant the wishes of their children.

LEAD: The test of Malta will be whether George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev have taken advantage of the sudden new reality in East-West relations. That is the fact that, in profound ways, the interests of the United States and the Soviet Union now coincide.

LEAD: WE ARE CHARGING what the market will bear. London is a more popular point,'' says a British Airways spokesman sounding not the least bit apologetic about the $3,606 one-way Concorde fare between New York and London. Air France charges $952 less, flying its Concordes on a route to Paris that is 186 miles longer.

LEAD: As many times as I have read the instruction to ''brown the meat well,'' I never understood even so simple a requirement until one day I got the chance to watch a real cook do it. Then I caught on: browning it well meant browning it well - not just giving up in relief as the poorly aged, watery meat finally turned from gray to a sort of beige.

LEAD: WHEN Emil Davidson retired 20 years ago, after selling the multimillion dollar plastics-molding company he founded in Elmsford, he found the quiet life in his Scarsdale neighborhood frustrating. ''Here I knew all this stuff,'' he said, ''but nobody asked me any questions.''

LEAD: Jewelry exhibitions on view and soon to open at New York's museums and galleries are rich in glitter or glorious fun. Most are also provocative or historical, and they present the widest range of such ornaments seen here at one time in many years.
LEAD: Over the last six days, in nearly 150 scheduled meetings, delegates to The Athletics Congress's annual convention addressed almost every conceivable issue in contemporary track and field.

LEAD: THE WAKE-UP CALL HAS sounded. Things are really perking these days for the coffee traders on the eighth floor of 4 World Trade Center, where one of the nation's sleepier commodity markets has come to life.

LEAD: New York City's role as host to the United Nations adds $830 million a year to the local economy, according to a study by Gillian Martin Sorensen, the New York City Commissioner for the United Nations and Consular Corps.

LEAD: CAN A NOVELIST SAVE PERU? pretends to answer the question of whether Mario Vargas Llosa can ''save'' Peru (as if the days of one-man rescue missions still existed!). He focuses on the dilemma of a novelist-turned-politician who can no longer use his imagination, because ''in politics you have no use for the imagination'' (something I hope is vigorously contested).

LEAD: Bernard S. Cox of Akron, Ohio, and Mrs. Charles G. Lake of San Diego have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Caroline Cox, to David Stuart Prall, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart E. Prall of Hewlett, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Philip Kanter of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Dana Kanter, to Michael Harris Sonnabend, a son of Katherine Sonnabend of Livingston, N.J., and Henry Sonnabend of Dallas. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: EARLY BIRDS are an acquired taste that you should cultivate if you're visiting your folks in Florida this winter. Though not indigenous to this locale, Early Bird Discount Dinners (a k a Sunset Specials) are so cheap and plentiful in Florida restaurants, they are a staple of your folks' diet. As an Official Guest, you'll eat Early Birds, too, so start training now, before heading south.

LEAD: The entire 2,400-member faculty of the University of Wisconsin-Madison will meet tomorrow, for the first time since 1970, to take a vote that could help decide the fate of the campus's Reserved Officers Training Corps. Professors and students alike say the vote will put the spotlight on an issue that has been debated on campus for more than two years: should the military bar homosexuals.

LEAD: A RECENT MONDAY MORNING at Shane Longman, a mid-sized merchant bank in the City of London. Phones ring, Reuters monitor screens flicker and, as a jittery bond market awaits the latest United States trade figures, Declan McConnochie, a senior bond trader, is especially jumpy. Some doggy Japanese debt he's holding as a favor to another trader is blotting his performance record.

LEAD: Q. A roof leak caused the latex-painted walls in my home to blister and created yellow stains on the wallpaper. Is there any way to remove the stains, and can the blisters on the dry wall be removed?

LEAD: LAST summer, my mother sat down to dinner with us at our old pine kitchen table that had come, as she had, from Ireland. The table, she said, she hoped would be with us for a very long time, but this visit, she told us, would be her last.

Barrett of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Randal Jay Martin, a son of Judith Martin of Columbus, Ohio, and William Martin of Wintersville, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Thomas A. Hughart officiated.

LEAD: When Tadeusz Mazowiecki became Poland's first postwar non-Communist Prime Minister on Aug. 24, the euphoria at home and abroad was extraordinary. LEAD: Tuesday evening was a festive night at two Manhattan cathedrals - and the events weren't just church suppers. At the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Gothic Romanesque Byzantine interior was illuminated by 4,000 candles for the first black-tie dinner dance in the nave. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the cathedral, presented the Spirit of the City award to Stephen C.

LEAD: Gone now are the striped prison fatigues, the sunken cheeks and the shaved head; but even so, Willem Dafoe cannot banish the ghosts of Auschwitz. ''Imagine living in a house where a terrible crime had happened,'' he says. ''Now magnify that millions of times. How did it feel to be there? I expected to identify with the horror, to break down, but that would have been obscene.

LEAD: TRAVELERS through southern Germany in the 18th century - in general no tourists but, rather, serious researchers in various fields - returned full of praise for the treasures they had come upon in the libraries of remote monasteries. Today's visitor is likely to find more interest in the exuberant Baroque and rococo architecture of these libraries than in whatever volumes can be found within them.

LEAD: The man who heads the Institute for Forecasting at the Academy of Sciences, a research bureau devoted to discerning Czechoslovakia's economic and social future, has decided to take a hand in shaping it, stopping just short of publicly declaring that he wants to be Prime Minister.
LEAD: Oh yes, Andre Ware also had a game today.

LEAD: Ronald Merrick, the chill Army officer at the center of ''The Raj Quartet,'' Paul Scott's compelling novels of British India, compared Subhas Chandra Bose to Hitler. Democratic India has honored Bose with three commemorative stamps. What is the truth about this man? Buried in a few catalogues is a list of 21 stamps inscribed Azad Hind or Free India.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: SOOTHSAYING HAS A long and checkered history, and the year-end predictions of economic soothsayers generally fare no better than the rest. How much more chancy is the task of the end-of-decade forecaster! Yet there is one clue to the proper approach, provided by the astounding record of the last 10 years: think boldly.
LEAD: THE barrage of holiday concerts has arrived, but music lovers with carols and cantatas have plenty of attractive alternatives.

Clutz of Williamstown, Mass., were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. Margaret B. Gunness performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev.

A master of the Celtic harp, Ms. Wayne also accompanies herself on dulcimer, the bodran frame drum, limberjack and sundry other folk instruments, her free family concert at the Greenburgh Town Hall devoted to songs, stories and harp solos for Hanukkah, Christmas and the New
LEAD: Virginia and Santa Clara used different means to reach the same end today as they advanced to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament for the first time.

LEAD: IT MIGHT JUSTIFIABLY BE called a cable car, but it is equally fitting that the device supporting the workmen who are replacing 177,000 feet of steel cable on the Brooklyn Bridge is known as a spider. Unlike, say, the Williamsburg Bridge, just up the East River, which is supported by vertical cables, or other spans, which employ a system of diagonal stays, the Brooklyn Bridge has both.

LEAD: Maltese officials warned American and Soviet summit planners several times that they should make contingency plans in case stormy weather made meeting aboard ship too difficult, an official in the Prime Minister's office said today.

Our address is Fox Bluff, Box 5070, Madison, Wis., and our phone number is 608-836-1631. KATHI CLAGGETT Communications and Marketing, St.

LEAD: Shooting accidents have been markedly reduced throughout the country in the last decade, and much of this can be attributed to the hunter-education courses now required of first-time license holders in most states.

LEAD: Coffetable books - scorned though they often are - can make glorious gifts. The trick is in matching the gift to a passion. The Book Review sought out reviewers known for their particular passions to look at some of the season's most tempting offerings. BALENCIAGA. By Marie-Andree Jouve and Jacqueline Demornex.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Two months ago, Guy Willoughby shed the natty suit that he has frequently worn in Kabul, dropped to his hands and knees off a highway north of here, and worked his way through a Soviet minefield.

LEAD: Patrick Baynes, celebrating his 23d birthday with his first start at quarterback in nearly two years, rushed for a career-high 131 yards and two touchdowns as Furman beat Youngstown State, 42-23, today in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-AA playoffs.

LEAD: The aluminum-shafted elevator slowly makes its 196-foot climb from the floor of the Duomo to the base of the 16-level scaffolding that rings the interior of Filippo Brunelleschi's cupola. The scaffolding has been in place for nearly 10 years, its green and gray safety netting concealing the 10,500-square-foot surface of frescoes by Giorgio Vasari and Federico Zuccari.

LEAD: Former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. gave a $350,000 development grant to a longtime friend even though other officials at the Department of Housing and Urban Development had rejected the award, H.U.D. documents and interviews show.

LEAD: On Nov. 17 in Bangkok, Thailand, the Rev. Jon Sobrino, an internationally known theologian from El Salvador, was giving a lecture about Jesus to Asians interested in Latin American liberation theology.
LEAD: CHIC SAVAGES By John Fairchild. Illustrated. 222 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

LEAD: Garbage time came extra early yesterday at Alumni Hall as St. John's easily defeated the University of San Diego, 74-59, in the opening round of the 15th annual Joe Lapchick Memorial Tournament.
LEAD: HOW do you make a small fortune in automobile racing? Start out with a big fortune, goes the old joke among racers who have found that money goes fast when going fast.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: We spent part of last summer in Montana's Glacier National Park and Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, Canada. As magnificent as the scenery was, we were equally impressed with the friendliness of Montana's residents, in particular, Don and Carol Young, the hosts of the bed-and-breakfast where we stayed in Kalispell, and felt that our find was too good to keep to ourselves.

LEAD: Thanks to the Federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, some 700,000 migrant workers in California's $16.6 billion agricultural industry have applied for legal residency in the United States. But the stamp of impending legitimacy has yielded a mixed harvest for workers.
LEAD: After eight years of archeological digs and four years of research, the public can now view the finds from City of David excavations dating to the 10th century B.C.

LEAD: The Mobil Oil Corporation has pleaded no contest to misdemeanor charges stemming from two pipeline ruptures that poured more than 130,000 gallons of crude oil into the Los Angeles River and the city's sewers last year.

LEAD: SIGNS of taxpayer resistance to Westchester's proposed $1 billion 1990 budget, with record increases of 18 percent to 52 percent in county property taxes, surfaced last week at two public hearings of the County Board of Legislators and in individual expressions of anger.

LEAD: Lebanon's warring factions backed off from a head-on military confrontation today to allow time for mediators to break a political deadlock that has threatened to plunge the country into another round of violence.

LEAD: The New York Symphonic Ensemble, a chamber orchestra founded in 1979, offered a program of popular Baroque and Classical works on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall. LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ENCHANTED DRAWINGS The History of Animation. By Charles Solomon. Illustrated. 322 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $75.

LEAD: For Dr. Jeffrey A. Scolnick, moving a 300-pound, six-foot-long fish tank into his 12th-floor studio apartment was only the first obstacle to overcome before he could have a coral reef beside his bed.

LEAD: In the early days of contract bridge, it was not unusual for a player to win a major national title at a first attempt. LEAD: J. KENNETH LEAP says he still gets goose bumps when he recalls the first time he saw the stained-glass windows at the Chartres Cathedral in France. Even though he had studied details of the cathedral at the Rhode Island School of Design, from which he had just graduated, he said he was stunned by what he saw.

LEAD: PATRICIA FRENCH, THE founder and president of Gazelle International, a black-cosmetics company, makes no secret of her ambitions. As for her publicist's claim that French will be ''the next Estee Lauder,'' the 33-year-old former model and makeup consultant smiles and says, ''We all have to have a goal and a dream.

LEAD: Lincoln Kirstein, Jerome Robbins and Suzanne Farrell have all announced their retirement or resignation - depending on their individual choice of words - from their positions in the New York City Ballet this autumn. Patricia McBride retired from the company in July.

LEAD: FALL is the time when college-bound seniors are making their final trips to look at universities and colleges, filling out application forms, being interviewed. And so, in some instances, are their grandparents - not applying for college but for the appropriate retirement homes.

LEAD: ONCE promoted as a possible cancer cure, interferon fell into disrepute in the early 1980's when the optimistic predictions failed to pan out. But in the last year the drug has found its niche as a treatment for hepatitis and perhaps AIDS and other diseases.

LEAD: ACT I: It is Dec. 23. 10 P.M. A car is snowbound. Stranded, a married couple, Diane and Alex, take refuge in an abandoned inn. Its once grand party room, where Christmas extravaganzas were staged, now contains a ladder, some chairs, a table, a trunk - and a piano.

Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Armed with a new flexibility and immense reservoirs of foreign exchange, Taiwan is struggling for a seat at the international table, and in the process new tensions are surfacing between the rival Governments in Taipei and Beijing.

LEAD: Just because your average suit comes with a jacket and skirt doesn't mean the two pieces always have to be worn at the same time, does it? Of course not, and if it's not your average suit to begin with, there is probably more reason than ever to break up the combo.

LEAD: FOR THOSE WHO SEE THEMSELVES AS larger-than-life heroes, nothing seems impossible. Consider Joe Weider, the king of the body builders, head of a multimillion-dollar international empire that encompasses muscle magazines, muscle-training equipment and food supplements. A few months ago, Weider was sifting through a pile of photos in the Hollywood studio of photographer Ken Marcus, trying to put together the next cover of Muscle & Fitness, the flagship publication of Weider Health and Fitness.

LEAD: AT 10 O'CLOCK ON THE MORNING OF OCT. 17, CARL E. REICHARDT, the chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo & Company, presided over a meeting of the board of directors in the Sheraton Grand Hotel in Los Angeles. He had nothing but good news to report for the third quarter. Net income would be strong (the final figures showed it at $153.7 million, a 17-percent rise over the 1988 figure) and costs, one of the chairman's obsessions, were well in hand.

LEAD: BIDS are to be opened this month for the first phase of the $156 million replacement of the Raymond E. Baldwin Bridge on Interstate 95, which connects Old Lyme and Old Saybrook over the Connecticut River and on which traffic is often backed up for miles on weekends.

LEAD: Uptown or downtown, the newest hats combine warmth with whimsical historical flourishes, preferably those of old England. Men and boys are topped off as royalty or rapscallions, women and girls as Shakespearean serving girls or Dickensian dowagers. This season the two authors are muses millinery as well as literary.

LEAD: SOME of America's most cherished scenic vistas are gradually disappearing behind a curtain of air pollution. A growing number of the country's national parks, from Sequoia and Kings Canyon in California to Acadia in Maine, are at times so afflicted with air pollution that views are often obscured and health is sometimes threatened.
LEAD: LESS than a decade ago, the interesting places to eat in Stamford could be counted on one hand. Now, it is possible to dine out well nightly at a different place for the better part of a month.

Matthews of Honolulu, was married yesterday to William Angus Douglass 3d, the son of Mrs. Robert P. DeVecchi of New York and William A. Douglass of Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England.

LEAD: The engagement of Diana Dale Wiesenthal and James A. Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold A. Singer of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Melvin L. Wiesenthal of Harrison, N.Y. A January wedding is planned.

LEAD: The executive director of the United States Gymnastics Federation said today that he understood that Nadia Comaneci, the former Olympic champion, would leave New York before the day was out and go to Miami, where she would stay in a Rumanian immigrant neighborhood.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: American attitudes toward the Soviet Union are now as favorable as they were at the end of World War II, when the two countries were allies and Churchill had not yet declared the descent of an Iron Curtain, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.

LEAD: Elaborate, large-format - which is to say expensive - architecture books this year seem to fall into two categories: monographs on the work of a particular architect, of which there are fewer than in recent years, and generic books on particular styles or types of buildings, of which there are many more.
LEAD: The chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging is renewing his attack on a Federal rule that prohibits pilots from flying jetliners after they turn 60 years old.

LEAD: The frequency-marketing craze is spawning a host of partnerships. The drive by sponsors of these programs to offer their members a diverse mix of products to buy with their bonus points has pushed them to negotiate formal ventures with companies with alluring services and wares.

LEAD: Just when it seemed that America was being consumed by despair of ever again doing anything better than the Japanese, there arrived 490 pounds of hope named Konishiki. The 25-year-old Hawaiian, who was born Salevaa Atisnoe, last week rocked the tradition-bound world of sumo wrestling by becoming the first foreigner in 17 years to win the Emperor's Cup, Japan's most coveted sports prize.

LEAD: I feel intimidated by these tales of people who find the experience of having cancer to be a source of inspiration and personal growth. I suspect that most ordinary mortals would fall short of this ideal. I suspect that this presentation of critical illness as a path to growth through adversity gives a patient unreasonable models and is likely to encourage friends and family to react unsympathetically when one fails to measure up.

LEAD: ON THE PARAMOUNT STUDIO LOT EARLY IN THE fall, there is a screening party given by the producers of ''Black Rain.'' As the credits appear, the crowd bursts into applause. ''Produced by Jaffe-Lansing, in association with Michael Douglas.'' Within the industry, this partnership has magical associations.

LEAD: President Bush offered an array of more than a dozen economic and arms proposals to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today as they began their summit meeting, including an end to cold war trade restrictions.

LEAD: IN A JANUARY NIGHT IN 1973, ALAN R. FRASER lugged a cardboard carton through customs and stepped into the crowded arrivals hall of Manila International Airport. The New Zealand entrepreneur was desperate. Fraser needed a company with the equipment and the low-cost data-entry typists to convert his box of paper into computer files.

LEAD: EVERY 10 years, when property values in Connecticut's 169 towns are reassessed, some people's tax bills rise steeply. This year, after a decade of zooming land prices, shock waves from revaluations are being felt almost everywhere.

LEAD: I WAS divorced on a stormy day. The radio blared flood alerts and warnings. I had tossed about the bed during a mostly sleepless night. I missed her so. I used to get up an hour earlier than she did. I would drive to the country store to pick up the newspaper and return, have it read, my cereal and banana eaten, and my huge cup of coffee drunk when she would stagger up the stairs to my study.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Leland Miles of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Marie Miles, to John J. Kelliher, a son of Mrs. Francis Kelliher of Albany and the late Mr. Kelliher. A May wedding is planned. Miss Miles, formerly the director of the Fraunces Tavern Museum in New York and the museum art gallery at the South Street Seaport Museum, is the director of the Albany Institute of History and Art.

LEAD: In the sudden surge of films about America's Vietnam experience, 84 CHARLIE MOPIC, newly released on cassette (1989, RCA/Columbia Home Video, $89.95), stands out for the originality of its cinematic devices. The writer-director Patrick Duncan imagines that a six-man patrol, sent into the jungle to pinpoint the location of enemy troops, is accompanied by an Army cameraman - known as 84 Charlie in Army lingo - assigned to make a training documentary.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Hally Peter Wall of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Batterson Wall to Daryl G. Nelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Nelson of Naples, Fla. A January wedding is planned.

LEAD: Carla Beth Freedman, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and Neil Evan Ross, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, were married in Syracuse last evening. Rabbis Charles Sherman and Daniel Jezer officiated at Temple Adath Yeshurun.

LEAD: This list of paperbacks is a selection from the New & Noteworthy column since the December 1988 Christmas issue. It includes novels, poetry, stories, biography, memoirs, letters, history, essays and science. ADAM, EVE, AND THE SERPENT, by Elaine Pagels. (Vintage, $8.95.) The author of ''The Gnostic Gospels'' shows how politics might have helped transform the cryptic Garden of Eden myth from a celebration of freedom to a condemnation of original sin.

LEAD: Television commercials for children are not kid stuff. About $500 million a year is spent promoting toys, games, foods and other goodies to young consumers. There may be two sides to the question of whether any advertising is appropriate on programs aimed at grade-schoolers and under, but nobody is likely to take public exception to the principle that youngsters should not be fooled by adults.

LEAD: WHILE most people know that it is wise to keep records connected with owning a home, it is not so clear which documents, invoices, receipts, canceled checks and other items need to be kept and which can be discarded. It also helps to know the kind of system that makes for easier record-keeping.

LEAD: Driven by internal political pressures, France has taken the lead among several nations in warning Syria against using force in an attempt to remove the Lebanese Christian military commander, Gen. Michel Aoun, from the presidential palace where he has been headquartered.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S voters approved new procedures governing the landmarking of church properties last month, but a new political fight between church leaders and preservationists is shaping up and promises to become a contentious issue in the new mayoral administration of David N. Dinkins.

LEAD: CHRISTIAN LUGINBUHL tracks leatherbacks - giant, elusive sea turtles with tough, leathery backs. ''They're very difficult to track; scientists know where their nesting beaches are, but we're trying to find out where they go,'' Mr. Luginbuhl said.

LEAD: I recognized Anatole Broyard's experience. I had it, too, on learning that I had cancer. I think it comes from a sense of deliverance from the banal. One can move on to a higher plane with a free conscience. And though Mr. Broyard's friends rally 'round, they do not really understand. One feels impatient, as at a railroad station when one is about to start on a unique adventure and people come to see you off with the conversation of a cocktail party.

LEAD: Peru's coca problem and the rise of the Sendero Luminoso guerrilla movement are rooted in the fact that the central Government in Lima has not dealt seriously with the agricultural sector of the country. LEAD: A EUROPE WHERE THE TRAVELER'S electric shaver can be plugged in and works regardless of country, where road signs are uniform and frontiers can be crossed without tiresome formality. A Europe with a common currency and similar working conditions in each country - indeed, similar workers. A Europe no longer of disparate, strange, even feuding countries, but one happy family of nations living in harmony and sharing a common culture.

LEAD: This is the year of the sesquicentennial of photography's entry into the world, and to mark the occasion a number of shows were mounted. These in turn led to the publication of several books-cum-catalogues that offer quick courses in the history of photography. Foremost among them are ''On the Art of Fixing a Shadow'' (discussed below), ''The Art of Photography 1839-1989'' (Yale University), ''Decade by Decade: Twentieth-Century American Photography'' (Bulfinch/Little, Brown) and, in a vanguard vein, ''The Photography of Invention: American Pictures of the 1980s'' (MIT).

LEAD: Waste no pity on pearls, they are more popular than ever. First Lady Barbara Bush's penchant for wearing the fake variety and the renewed interest in Chanel accessories have made them best sellers. Now, even many of the fashion critics, the women who sit on the sidelines passing judgment on the styles that parade down the runways, have taken to donning them.

LEAD: Two Southern Pacific freight trains collided today, causing eight cars to be knocked into a swamp and forcing the evacuation of more than 50 people for fear that hazardous cargo was leaking. When it was determined there was no leak, everyone was allowed to return home, said a sheriff's spokesman.

Under the proposal, American Express, which owns 62 percent of Shearson, would sell some of its shares. Wall Street sources said seven potential bidders have expressed interest in buying a large percentage of Shearson's stock.

LEAD: The Solar Max spacecraft, a victim of the very forces of nature it investigated for almost a decade, came crashing back to Earth yesterday, breaking into flaming pieces in the upper atmosphere but causing no known damage.

LEAD: The Ecco Trio found a perfect balance of the familiar and the unusual in its Weill Recital Hall program on Wednesday evening. Of the three works the ensemble played, only the Schubert Trio in B flat (Op. 99), which took up the second half of the concert, was drawn from the standard literature. Before the intermission, the group offered two tonal, melodic and traditionally structured 20th-century works, both of which would make worthy additions to any piano trio's repertory.

LEAD: The spiritual leader of Ukrainian Roman Catholics said today that he considers his long-banned church to be fully legal again as a result of new Soviet statements and the meeting on Friday between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Pope John Paul II.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your section had an article about a 5-year old child who went to Paris with his parents (''Child's Play in Paris,'' Travel, Oct. 15). Is this really an amazing thing? I'm 10 years old and when I was 6 I traveled around France and England with my parents and my 9-year-old brother. I don't see what the big deal about this kid is.

LEAD: The price of books on art has been rising steadily, though by no means as fast as the price of some kinds of art at auction. What $20 would have bought not so long ago may cost close to $100 today. Sometimes it's worth it (always provided that we have the money). Year after year, the catalogues of major exhibitions are the definitive studies of the works in question.

LEAD: ''A specter is haunting Europe -the specter of Communism,'' wrote Karl Marx in January 1848. It took a century for that red specter to become iron gray reality in Eastern Europe. Gods, shamans, peasants and chorus girls populate the works at the Margaret Mead Film Festival, which begins today and runs through Thursday at the American Museum of Natural History. The annual festival, named for the influential anthropologist, may suggest endless accounts of Samoan initiation rites. But the 48 nonfiction films to be shown are eclectic enough to include Hindu pilgrims, rangers at Yosemite National Park and a Chinese-American bubble dancer. A sampling of the films (most of which run about an hour) suggests that several are models of innovative documentary film making, while in many others flabbergasting images fight with the sort of droning voice-overs that give documentaries a bad name.
