LEAD: No Heisman for Brown Q. Before Jim Brown became a great running back for the Cleveland Browns, he was a star at Syracuse, but he was never voted the Heisman Trophy as the country's outstanding college player. How close did he get? A. Not close enough to call for a measurement. In 1956, Brown's senior year at Syracuse, he barely cracked the top five among Heisman finishers, earning a little more than half the point total accumulated by the winner, Paul Hornung, quarterback at Notre Dame.

LEAD: The technology that has given national magazines the ability to split their circulation into hundreds of editions is also beginning to give city and regional magazines anxiety about a possible loss of advertising.

LEAD: The 1985 Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law was supposed to eliminate Federal deficits by next October. It won't. Worse, the law distorts budget decisions, encourages deceit and risks turning recession into disaster.

Many teams have tried this season and he is averaging 29.2 points a game, second best in the National Basketball Association behind Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls.
LEAD: A showdown between three Pentecostal ministers and a prosecutor over the confidentiality of a burglary suspect's confession in church ended today when the man pleaded guilty to grand larceny.

LEAD: New York's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, announcing plans to sell $40 million in bonds to clean up hazardous waste, said yesterday that at least 600 sites need work, When state voters passed the $1.2 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act in 1986, the department set a goal of cleaning up 500 sites by the year 2000.
LEAD: The publisher Robert Maxwell said today that his new newspaper, The European, will begin publishing next May 11, a year later than originally planned.

LEAD: Just before leaving for Malta, President Bush took hostile action against the Legal Services Corporation, one of the nation's worthiest justice programs. He issued recess appointments to fill two vacancies on its board, thereby continuing a destructive standoff initiated by President Reagan.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 The West should help out Moscow, particularly with economic concessions, President Bush said. But he would not endorse President Gorbachev's comment that the cold war epoch was over. Page A1
LEAD: A Federal appeals court today upheld San Francisco's agreement to hire and promote women and members of minority groups in the Fire Department.

LEAD: John Williams, the Washington Bullet forward, will be sidelined for at least three months following arthroscopic surgery to repair torn ligaments in his right knee. Williams was hurt in last Saturday's loss to Utah. Williams had played in 255 consecutive games since November 1986. (AP)
LEAD: The McMartin Preschool molestation case produced the longest and perhaps the most complex criminal trial in American history. Now the jury deliberations are proving just as difficult.

LEAD: Thomas Jackson Oakley Rhinelander, a real-estate broker and a member of a prominent family in New York, died of complications of Parkinson's disease on Saturday at the Oakwood Healthcare Center in Newport, R.I. He was 69 years old and lived in Newport.
LEAD: President Bush said today that the West should help out President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to show support for the changes taking place in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

LEAD: ''Dances in Junihitoe: Old and New,'' which Saeko Ichinohe and Company presented Saturday afternoon at the Asia Society, was simultaneously peculiar and gorgeous. What made the program so was the remarkable garment that inspired it.

LEAD: Arnold Arnstein, a music copyist who worked with Gian Carlo Menotti, Samuel Barber and other composers, died of respiratory failure on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said today that further arrests would be made soon in the assassinations of two prominent white opponents of apartheid this year.

LEAD: The retaliatory spirit (you strike us, we bomb you) that has long prevailed in the Middle East seems to have infected public television. Hardly has the commotion begun to subside over the broadcast of a pro-Palestinian documentary about the uprising on the West Bank than a pro-Israeli documentary is upon us.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in very light trading yesterday, as market participants pointed to the release of November employment data on Friday.

LEAD: With politicians nationwide eyeing pension fund surpluses as a way to finance new roads, bridges and other such projects, a group representing 60 state and union pension funds has struck back. It issued a broadside yesterday against those who would like to see more pension fund money channeled into local economies.

LEAD: * Alco Standard Corp., Wayne, Pa., a distributor of paper, steel and glass products, said its Paper Corp. of America unit would acquire Distribix Inc., St. Louis, a distributor of paper and paper products, with annual revenue of about $200 million. Terms were not disclosed.
LEAD: Stock prices extended their gains yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 5.98 points, to 2,753.63.

LEAD: ''Isaac Asimov writes new lyrics for 'Pinafore'! William S. Gilbert turns in his grave!'' screamed the advance publicity for the Village Light Opera Group's production of ''U.S.S. Pinafore,'' which opened over the weekend at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

LEAD: Jerry Bailey was elected yesterday to fill the unexpired term of Willie Shoemaker as president of the Jockeys' Guild. The election was held at the annual guild meeting in Las Vegas, Nev. Bailey, 32, takes over on Feb. 5 and will serve until next year's board meeting.(AP)

LEAD: The news magazine Mladina, whose name means youth, decided recently to do away with a Communist politician, symbolically at least, by printing spoof photographs of him, first with an assassin's pistol at his head and then in his coffin.
LEAD: Norman Abner Adler, a lawyer and former CBS executive, died of complications of emphysema Saturday at Mission Bay Hospital near his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: If men's tennis, which last week closed out the decade with the final staging of the Nabisco Masters in New York City, can be briefly considered an apple cart, then unassuming Stefan Edberg of Sweden surely upset it on Sunday with his four-set elimination of Boris Becker, the defending champion.

LEAD: More than half of the country's dealers in all-terrain vehicles continued to recommend dangerously large vehicles for children under the age of 16 despite an agreement to prevent such sales, a Federal inquiry has found.

LEAD: Bone-chilling cold, heatless apartments, subway shutdowns and a midtown gridlock alert formed a coalition of misery in New York City yesterday for thousands of homeless people, transit riders, motorists and others unwarmed by holiday cheer.
LEAD: Gerald H. Carson, a social historian of the American scene, died of a heart attack early Monday at St. Mary Hospital in Langhorne, Pa. He was 90 years old and lived in nearby Newtown.
LEAD: The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that it had named D. Kenneth Richardson president and chief operating officer, succeeding Donald H. White, who retired Dec. 1. Mr. Richardson reports to

LEAD: Tens of thousands of marchers were back on the streets of Leipzig tonight for their weekly demonstration, but this time many of their banners demanded German reunification and the death of the foundering Communist Party.

LEAD: President Bush called President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines tonight to express concern for the safety of some 200 United States citizens trapped in Manila hotels occupied by rebel soldiers, a White House official said.

LEAD: Edward W. Lang, a chemist who developed the formula for Head & Shoulders shampoo for the Procter & Gamble Company, died Nov. 27 while visiting in Cincinnati. He was 65 years old and lived in retirement in Naples, Fla.

LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, said recently that Moscow ''feels immeasurably more comfortable in the international arena than ever before.'' After last weekend's meeting at Malta between George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev, Soviet leaders are entitled to relax still further: Soviet

LEAD: May Swenson, a poet known for her cerebral, playful verse, and a recipient two years ago of a MacArthur Foundation Fellowship, died yesterday in Ocean View, Del. She was 76 years old and had been suffering from chronic asthma.

LEAD: Soviet military personnel in East Germany detained a team of American military officers for seven and a half hours on the eve of President Bush's meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Pentagon said today.
LEAD: New Yorkers be forewarned. The end of the telephone strike will reduce - but not eliminate - the maddening wait for new service.

LEAD: For many years there was little competition in the convenience store industry. ''You could open a store almost anywhere and succeed,'' said Charles Nirenberg, who has been in the industry all his career.

LEAD: Biologists from Harvard Medical School who compared a gene that is present in people, chimpanzees and gorillas have concluded that the chimpanzee and gorilla are the closest cousins. That means that neither is the clear direct ancestor of humans.

LEAD: An overheated wood stove caused a house fire on Sunday night that killed a mother and two daughters, the authorities said. The dead were identified as Patricia A. Risley, 27 years old, and her daughters, Michelle, 5, and Danielle, 3. Mrs. Risley had sent two sons, John, 2, and Joshua, 1, out of the house and had gone back for the girls, the authorities said.

LEAD: The two main prosecutors in the upcoming trial of John M. Poindexter took the witness stand today to deny defense accusations that they were tainted by exposure to Mr. Poindexter's testimony in the Iran-contra hearings in Congress.
LEAD: George Mc Grath, a certified public accountant, died of a stroke on Friday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 99 years old.

LEAD: A state judicial panel has cleared Francis T. Murphy Jr., one of New York State's most powerful judges, of improperly interfering in disciplinary proceedings against several prominent lawyers, officials close to the case said yesterday.

LEAD: IT can be frustrating to shop for holiday gifts for the kind of people who read this column. What they really need is new socks and cologne, but what they really want is 4 megs worth of 100-nanosecond, 4-megabit RAM chips or an accelerator board.

LEAD: Fifteen Soviet-built jetliners once reserved for use by top East German Communist officials will be put into passenger service, the Government press agency A.D.N. said today. Klaus Henkes, the general director of the national airline Interflug, was quoted as saying about half the planes were ready for immediate use on charter flights and the rest would be converted for regular passenger flights.

LEAD: When Deion Sanders, a.k.a. Neon Sanders, intercepted a pass and ran it back a long way for the Altanta Falcons on Sunday, he proceeded to engage in a whoop of exultation that, on the street, would have brought a screaming ambulance carrying men with a white coat to the scene.

LEAD: Precious metals prices tumbled yesterday, and dealers said the decline came in part because the weekend summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev raised promises of reduced global tensions.

LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins reported yesterday that he had ended his campaign with an $810,000 surplus, which he is now trying to reduce to avoid having to return substantial public financing to the city treasury.

LEAD: The Yankees swung the first trade of baseball's winter meetings today when they sent Don Slaught to the Pittsburgh Pirates for two relief pitchers, Jeff Robinson and a minor leaguer, Willie Smith. But they said that they were still pursuing their No. 1 goal of landing a quality starting pitcher.

LEAD: About five years ago, with the supertanker business in the doldrums, the Loews Corporation bought seven large tankers for about $5 million each - basically, their scrap value. Now those ships are carrying crude oil between the Middle East and the Gulf Coast for up to $3 million for just one voyage, operating at considerable profit.
LEAD: Prime Minister Zeid bin Shaker resigned today and was replaced by Mudar Badran, who has held the office twice before and is sympathetic to Islamic fundamentalists.
LEAD: Goran Jarvefelt, a Swedish opera director, died of cancer on Thursday. He was 42 years old.
LEAD: Adm. Carlisle Albert Herman Trost would never make it as the hero of a Tom Clancy adventure novel. ''Who would be interested in me?'' he asks. ''I'm a character that wouldn't sell books.''
LEAD: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. yesterday asked a Federal District Court in Manhattan to order the Government to allow ABC Sports to televise the 1991 Pan American Games from Havana.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the crane collapse that killed five people in San Francisco misidentified the manufacturer of the equipment. The crane was made by Peiner A.G. in West Germany, not the American Pecco Corporation. The crane was owned by American Pecco and leased to a subcontractor.

LEAD: It has been a surprisingly cheerful month for the merchants of Santa Cruz. Selling from big tents because the Oct. 17 earthquake leveled their downtown shopping mall, many say that the day after Thanksgiving this year was their best ever and that sales have remained strong since.

LEAD: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has changed its opening program, tomorrow at City Center, in commemoration of Mr. Ailey, who died on Friday. The program will consist of ''Revelations'' and excerpts from six of Mr. Ailey's dances. The previously scheduled revival of ''Come and Get the Beauty of It Hot'' will be performed on Friday, and ''Sarong Paramaribo'' will be presented on Dec.

LEAD: The ''no surprises'' summit meeting was surprising in its lack of ''new thinking'' about the new world unfolding. This summit smacked of summits of the 1970's, with arms control once again raising the highest expectations.

LEAD: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants seldom criticizes his players publicly. But today, disappointed and irritated by Sunday's 24-17 home-field loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, Parcells seemed plainly upset with the performances of Phil Simms and Dave Meggett.
LEAD: From her bedroom window, Blue Collins can look across Lake Champlain to see the white cloud rising from the International Paper Company mill in Ticonderoga, N.Y.
LEAD: The world's largest maker of slot machines filed suit today against a Japanese company, contending that three of its patents are being infringed.

LEAD: WHEN word spread in September that Helayne Spivak -the brassy, funny and very New Yorkish copywriter for Ammirati & Puris - would take charge of Hal Riney & Partners' New York creative department, the acclamation followed quickly. At last, said advertising's creative critics, Riney/ New York would have an executive creative director capable of weaning it from the emotional and mid-American style that had been identified with the gravel-voiced Mr.

LEAD: There is more to the savings and loan mess than M. Danny Wall, who resigned yesterday as chairman of the Office of Thrift Supervision. But he protests that he is a scapegoat, and he ought not to become one: too many others need to answer for their roles in this scandalous episode.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 23 about a guerrilla takeover at a hotel in San Salvador referred incorrectly to 12 American Green Berets trapped there for a day.

LEAD: A statement urging church and synagogue members to work actively for greater government involvement in AIDS prevention and care was adopted here today by an interfaith group of religious leaders.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Despite the recent vote by Congress to repeal the expanded Medicare coverage, the Government will continue to collect premiums from the nation's 33 million beneficiaries after the program is expected to end on Jan. 1.
LEAD: Touche Ross completed their merger in the United States on Saturday, amid signs that increasing numbers of foreign affiliates of the accounting firms had rejected the merger.

LEAD: Because of a computer transmission error, the television program listings yesterday omitted entries for the Cinemax channel (MAX) for 7 P.M. to midnight. The entries that appeared were for the Madison Square Garden channel (MSG).
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A man from Suffolk County, charged in the first indictment relating to a fireworks death on Long Island, pleaded not guilty to the charge today.

LEAD: Civic Forum, the two-week-old opposition movement in Czechoslovakia, took its boldest step yet by announcing today that it would endorse candidates when the country holds its first free elections since the postwar Communist takeover.

LEAD: The normally elegant Westin Philippine Plaza Hotel had the look of a refugee camp this morning as residents of the villages around Makati, the Manila business district paralyzed by rebel forces of the Philippine military, heeded their embassies' call to evacuate their homes.

LEAD: Steven S. Schwarzchild, professor of philosophy and Judaic studies at Washington University, St. Louis, died of an aneurysm Friday at the Jewish Hospital in St. Louis, where he lived. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. has raised the commissions it charges individual customers by about 3 percent, a spokesman for the firm said yesterday. The move was viewed by industry analysts as a reflection of the continued pressure on retail brokerages' profits. Prudential-Bache has also informed its 6,500 retail brokers that it was reducing the amount of commission revenue it shares with its lowest-producing brokers.
LEAD: John Rosenberg resigned yesterday as the head football coach at Brown after two consecutive losing seasons.
LEAD: As the Palestinian uprising enters its third year, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin acknowledges that the Israeli Army has not succeeded in bringing the revolt under control.

LEAD: Shandwick P.L.C., the British public relations conglomerate, yesterday took a step toward unifying its diverse agencies by appointing Dermot McNulty, formerly of Burson-Marsteller, its first executive vice president of marketing for North America.
LEAD: UNUSUAL cancer patterns among transplant patients are providing startling insights into the body's natural immunity against the disease.

LEAD: In ''Up Against It,'' his unproduced screenplay for the Beatles, Joe Orton tried to combine the irreverent spirit of ''A Hard Day's Night'' and ''Help!'' with his own far more mordant sensibility. Since the playwright's death, the screenplay has remained a tantalizing footnote to Orton's career. Although the film script is not in the same class as his plays, the published version exists for reading and imagining, raising the question of what the movie would have been like.

LEAD: Dec. 24, 1988: A group including McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said it planned to ask for regulatory approval to increase it stake in Lin Broadcasting Corporation. June 6, 1989: McCaw said it would begin a cash tender offer of $120 a share, or $6.5 billion, for Lin. McCaw already owned 9.8 percent of Lin.
LEAD: The owner of a pit bull dog went on trial today in the death of a toddler who was mauled after wandering close to the animal, which prosecutors contend was guarding 243 marijuana plants.

LEAD: No doubt many Americans do not yet believe ''the cold war is over,'' just because Presidents Bush and Gorbachev say it is. But even skeptics must concede that both sides have come a long way from the depths of dangerous hostility reached in the 50's, at the time of the Cuban missile crisis or in the early years of the Reagan

LEAD: Eugene Newton Greenblatt, a pharmacologist who specialized in anti-depressant drugs, died of heart disease Saturday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived in Chestnut Ridge, N.Y.
LEAD: WHEN the Department of Energy said last week that it had lost confidence in its latest effort to find a safe place to bury nuclear waste, a gnawing question resurfaced: is the task possible?

LEAD: The Queens Symphony Orchestra was founded in 1953 by David Katz, who shepherded the group from amateur to professional status during his 34-year tenure. When he died in 1987, the organization faced the task of finding a conductor for the first time.

LEAD: The injury to Vyacheslav Fetisov's left knee that kept him out of the last five games includes slight cartilage damage, the Devils said yesterday. Dave Freed, a team spokesman, said, however, that the damage was so limited that the Soviet defenseman might not need an arthroscopy. He said that Fetisov may return to action before the weekend.

LEAD: Each year about 18,000 letters addressed to Santa Claus arrive in Manhattan's General Post Office, and you can read them like a script for New York itself: tales of need and greed and shining expectation, of entitlement or estrangement, of a chance to get something for nothing, or even, at times, to gain nothing at all but the chance to give to someone else.

LEAD: N.B.A. Trail Blazers 121, Magic 95: Sparked by its defense, Portland pulled away in the second half last night to defeat Orlando in Florida. The Trail Blazers outscored Orlando, 66-44, in the second half to push their record to 13-4, second best in the league behind the Lakers. Jerome Kersey scored 22 points and Kevin Duckworth had 19 for Portland.

LEAD: Experts on Central America said today that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, would have difficulty stopping the flow of arms through Cuba and Nicaragua to Salvadoran guerrillas even if he made assiduous efforts, as President Bush has demanded.
LEAD: Richie Adubato, who last week was appointed interim coach of the Dallas Mavericks, yesterday accepted the coaching job through the rest of the season.
LEAD: THE world's population of whooping cranes, on the brink of extinction just 50 years ago, has nearly doubled this decade and now appears on the brink of a remarkable comeback.

LEAD: Andy McCarroll, a Vanderbilt linebacker from Memphis, was asked to stand and express his feelings about being one of the 11 scholar-athletes chosen this year by the National Football Foundation for academic and football achievements.

The Marxist government seized the bakery. ''I could not work after Castro took it,'' Mr. Corrales said. ''He took everything.

LEAD: Every baby born in New York State will be tested for syphilis at birth, starting tomorrow, because of a sharp surge in the disease among newborns in recent years, the State Health Department said yesterday.
LEAD: Exxon has spent $1.9 billion cleaning up last spring's Alaskan oil spill, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said today.
LEAD: As the Zairian diplomat poured sparkling wine for a visitor, he made no effort to hide the label, which proclaimed, ''Product of South Africa.''
LEAD: The Coast Guard began a formal investigation yesterday into a boating accident in the Ambrose Channel on Saturday that killed two people. Ships were advised to avoid the area.

LEAD: The State Education Commissioner announced today the appointment of 13 Jersey City residents to a 15-member advisory Board of Education that will operate in the shadow of the state's all-powerful Superintendent in managing the public schools here.

LEAD: Dr. George L. Nardi, a surgeon who was an expert on diseases of the pancreas, died of cancer yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 66 years old. Dr. Nardi, who lived in Boston, received his medical degree from the University of Chicago in 1944, when he was 21. Except for service as a medical officer in the Navy, he spent his entire medical career at Massachusetts General.

LEAD: Two months after police units began beating East Germans arrested in Dresden, Leipzig and East Berlin for demonstrating against the Government of Erich Honecker, there is still no official acknowledgment that many were severely wounded.
LEAD: A woman arrested for failing to answer a court summons on charges that she had seven overdue library books is suing the county and its solicitor.
LEAD: Sales of domestically produced cars and trucks fell in late November and were down sharply at the Big Three. Japan's auto makers, however, continued to show relative strength.

LEAD: Some names attached to contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are recognizable. Most are not. But the spirit of gratification derived from giving seems to be the same, regardless of celebrity.

LEAD: As the military coup attempt against President Corazon C. Aquino continued for a sixth day, rebel troops in the city's business and financial district and the Philippine Government reached a cease-fire today long enough to begin evacuation of hundreds of foreigners trapped in their hotels by the fighting.
LEAD: INDEX arbitrage trading - the form of program trading that has been most criticized - appears to have slumped dramatically.
LEAD: Lord Elwyn-Jones, a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war-crimes trials and Britain's chief legal officer under the last Labor Party Government, died of cancer on Monday at the age of 80.

LEAD: The City Council yesterday postponed until April putting new conflict-of-interest rules into effect for many New York City employees. The vote was 26 to 8. The postponement, from Jan. 1, is intended to encourage some officials to continue in their jobs during the transition between administrations.

LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino may yet find a neat way to finish off the most serious coup attempt of her four years in office, but her ability to deal with widespread complaints about her administration has been severely undermined.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''Every mayor-elect has a certain anxiety, a certain fear about whether or not they're up to the job. The people decided you were, and that's all that's required.'' - Mayor Edward I. Koch, to Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins. [ B1:5. ]

LEAD: A Congressional subcommittee is investigating the $170 million contract that a Japanese-owned rail car manufacturer in Yonkers won earlier this year to build subway cars for a new mass transit system in Taipei, Taiwan.

LEAD: Four months after President Bush signed legislation to bail out and change the savings and loan industry, most savings institutions have taken major steps toward meeting strict new rules intended to make them safer and more conservative.

LEAD: Though President Bush announced in September that he was sending several hundred million dollars to fight drugs in South America, no new funds have reached Peru and Bolivia, the world's two main growers of coca.

LEAD: * American City Business Journals Inc., Kansas City, Mo., acquired The San Francisco Business Times, previously managed by American City, and sold its interest as manager of The Business Press, a Fort Worth business publication. Terms of the deals were not disclosed.

LEAD: The National Endowment for the Arts has announced that the International Business Machines Corporation and Nynex Business Centers have donated computers, software and technical support to 50 arts organizations around the country. Each organization also received a one-time $1,000 grant from Nynex. The arts organizations will use the donation to improve their business operations.

LEAD: ''Bronx Views,'' an exhibition of paintings depicting landscapes in the Bronx, will open a new art gallery today at the Kingsbridge Center of the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, 100 West Kingsbridge Road, in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. The exhibition, co-sponsored by the Bronx Museum of the Arts, features 30 works by 6 artists who live in the Bronx: Rikki Asher, Garin Baker, William Behnken, Dina Bursztyn, Daniel Hauben and Leslie Lowinger.

LEAD: The Knick fans in the crowd cheered loudly last night at the pregame announcement that Charles Barkley was suffering from a viral infection and would not play for Philadelphia.

The Sanson family owns 30 percent of Gelati Sanson, an ice cream company based in Italy, and TLC Beatrice controls the rest.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities again traded in a very narrow range yesterday on extremely light volume. For the second straight session, market participants chose to ignore news developments that at other times would normally have had a beneficial effect.

LEAD: A smoky fire in a nine-story building used by garment makers sent panicky workers scurrying today down fire truck rescue ladders and up to the roof, where Fire Department helicopters plucked 15 people to safety.
LEAD: THE old cliche that the essence of real estate is location is coming under increasing challenge in Manhattan's midtown leasing market.

LEAD: THE 1989 holiday season brings an exceptional bounty of books for cooks and food lovers, handsome picture books for gift-giving, thoughtful books for thinking and those rare, treasured volumes that both tantalize the eye and palate with clearly presented recipes and provoke thoughtful discourse or at least good dinner-table conversation.
LEAD: The sign said the white tigers would not be on display in their casino habitat this night. But at the new Mirage hotel there were other sights to see.

LEAD: Full service on some IND lines in Manhattan may be restored by Friday, if repairs go smoothly, the Transit Authority said yesterday. The lines were inundated on Saturday morning when a water main broke at 135th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, spilling 18 million gallons.
LEAD: * Abreu Advertising in Speonk, L.I., has changed its name to Abreu/ Mitchell Advertising, in recognition of Kim Mitchell, who has joined the agency as a partner.
LEAD: One of three drug suspects was shot and wounded last night during a buy and bust operation conducted in Upper Manhattan by Federal drug enforcement agents, officials said.
LEAD: Bulgaria's new Communist leader indicated today that his party's leading role in Government will be an open question as he initiates reforms.

LEAD: As Kirby Puckett, Rickey Henderson and Mark Langston escalated baseball salaries to record heights in the last two weeks, Don Mattingly watched with more than a passing interest. But Mattingly did not start counting the days - 321 from today - until he could become a free agent and see what barriers he could break.
LEAD: In a policy shift, President Bush has proposed that the United States sponsor an international conference in Washington next fall to begin negotiating a treaty on global warming.

LEAD: Mexico and its creditor banks have nearly completed negotiations for refinancing the nation's $48 billion in medium- and long-term debt, according to Jose Angel Guerria, Mexico's leading negotiator with the banks.

LEAD: On recent mornings, Prof. Wangari Maathai has postponed reading the newspapers until she arrives at the office, where she braces herself over a cup of hot tea for the daily fulminations against her.

LEAD: ''Die Schone Mullerin,'' Schubert's first great song cycle, shares the thwarted-love theme of his last. But it is ''Die Winterreise'' - that final searing metaphor for the dying composer - that has preoccupied our imaginations ever since.

LEAD: The Boeing Company maintained a secret library of classified documents through much of the 1970's at a marketing office in Kent, Wash., a retired employee of the aerospace giant testified today.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury today indicted two associates of Jim Bakker for lying during the PTL fraud investigation.

LEAD: The AIDS drug AZT has been found to cause cancer in laboratory animals, the drug's manufacturer said today. But doctors emphasized that AIDS patients should continue to take the drug because the risk is still only theoretical.

New Savings Industry Rules Most savings institutions have taken steps to become more conservative and safer, but 800 of them will not meet Federal regulations that take effect tomorrow.

LEAD: In a study that traced the path of $28.5 million in 1988 campaign contributions, a nonpartisan research group today provided new evidence of how wealthy donors were able to skirt Federal laws regulating contributions to Presidential campaigns.

LEAD: Sir John Pritchard, the music director of the San Francisco Opera and, until early this year, of the BBC Symphony and the Cologne Opera, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Seton Medical Center in Daly City, Calif. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: Charles A. Corry, the chairman of the USX Corporation, said that his company's strategy would not be altered as a result of the holdings of Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor who owns a substantial stake in the energy and steel company.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: The Soviet Union today issued a sharp critique of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's plan for German reunification, describing it as ''fraught with dangerous consequences'' and ''bordering on outright diktat.''

LEAD: When the H. J. Heinz Company introduced a squeezable plastic bottle for its ketchup in 1983, the consumer-products industry hailed it as a major advance. The diner could gently squeeze out ketchup with far more accuracy than the conventional glass bottle allowed, yet the ketchup could last without spoiling almost as long as that in a glass bottle.

LEAD: The faculty of the University of Wisconsin at Madison has recommended that the Board of Regents sever contracts with the Reserve Officers Training Corps by May 1993 if the programs do not change their policies regarding homosexuals.
LEAD: In a major concession to the opposition, the Communist leadership agreed today to accept a minority role in one of the country's two principal regional governments.

LEAD: One of Mozart's experiments with the clarinet hit upon a combination so potent that composers since the 18th century have followed it enthusiastically. The instruments in question are the clarinet, the viola and the piano - the subject of his great Trio in E flat and also of the two less familiar works played by the American Chamber Players at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon.

LEAD: In a discussion of Soviet domestic problems with President Bush in Malta, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called his campaign to end consumer shortages in the Soviet Union ''the ultimate test'' of his leadership, senior Administration officials said today. The Soviet leader reportedly left some American officials with the impression that he was at a loss over how to solve his economic problems.
LEAD: The mark continued to dominate foreign exchange trading yesterday, with traders focusing on West Germany's potential for trade with its eastern neighbors, dealers said.
LEAD: TThe Texas Rangers yesterday gave their second baseman, Julio Franco, a three-year contract extension worth $7.8 million.
LEAD: Stock prices were broadly lower yesterday amid continued uncertainty over the economic outlook. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.95 points, to 2,741.68.

LEAD: Civic Forum, which in scarcely two weeks has assumed the mantle of Czechoslovakia's political opposition, is a mass movement whose members simply declare themselves by shouting for freedom at demonstrations and whose leaders serve by acclamation.
LEAD: Reports of the stunning ignorance being created by the American educational system make it hard to write for a mass audience.

LEAD: In what amounted to a political valedictory, Mayor Edward I. Koch offered yesterday an ardent summation of his 12-year tenure, advised his successor to ''be not afraid'' and strongly criticized the Federal Government as being unfair to the city.

LEAD: Peace here talks between Sudanese rebels and the Khartoum Government collapsed today in a disagreement over the country's Islamic legal code and other issues that have kept them at war for nearly seven years.

LEAD: Lawyers for New York City and 32,000 retired female city workers told a Federal judge yesterday that they had settled a 14-year-old discrimination suit against the largest of the municipal pension systems.

LEAD: To investors in the Taiwan stock market, ''research'' often means talking to a fortune teller, and ''long-term investments'' tend to be measured in weeks instead of years. But what the Taiwan Stock Exchange lacks in pinstripes and gravity, it makes up for in size and performance.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Davey Johnson, manager of the Mets, ended two months of silence on the tumult that swamped the team at the end of last season and said today that he had been so troubled by his loss of authority, he thought about quitting.

LEAD: The first charity bridge event in the New York metropolitan area to designate AIDS patients as its beneficiaries was played Sept. 24 at the Grand Bridge Studio, Franklin Square, L.I., and will be repeated next year. Most of the top-ranked Long Island players took part in a partly Pro-Am format, and since the playing space was donated and the directors were volunteers, virtually all the income of $3,500 went to the People with AIDS Coalition of Long Island.

LEAD: A gallon of gasoline cost about a half-cent less at the nation's pumps in the last two weeks because of the traditional fall-winter decline in driving, an industry analyst said. The average service-station price, including taxes, was $1.0697 a gallon as of Friday, a survey of 13,000 stations by the analyst, Trilby Lundberg, found.
LEAD: There may be only one thing that educators, business leaders, governors and President Bush agree on: America's schools are in trouble.

LEAD: * The Foundation for Religious Retirement, an organization devoted to the care of retired women employees of the Archdiocese of Milwaukee, has begun a $1 million fund-raising campaign with advertising support from Cramer-Krasselt Advertising, Milwaukee.
LEAD: I HAVE long enjoyed beer-leavened batters for fried seafood and poultry, and shrimp is particularly good prepared this way. The batters must be well seasoned so flavors integrate with the food.

LEAD: A case before the United States Supreme Court that challenges the confidentiality accorded scholars who evaluate colleagues for tenure is being watched by universities around the country. Many of them agree with David Reisman, the Harvard University sociologist, who calls it ''a case of absolutely crucial importance to the academic life of the country.
LEAD: SLATER HANFT MARTIN is a small advertising agency that is every large agency's nightmare.

LEAD: About 6,500 policemen used large steel cages and an armored box suspended from cranes today in an effort to dislodge a dozen protesters armed with slingshots and bows who were opposing an addition to Japan's principal international airport.

LEAD: Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Inc., is in talks about investing hundreds of millions of dollars in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in exchange for a large stake in the brokerage, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

LEAD: Baba Goya, the title character and earth mother in the 1973 play by Steve Tesich now being revived at the Second Stage Theater, starts the morning with an Italian love song and a cup of strong Turkish coffee. As long as her household is full of warm bodies, Goya is undaunted by all of the messy problems they can pose.

LEAD: After months of delay and frustration, Ammirati & Puris appears close to concluding its buyback from the Omnicom Group, which acquired the creatively renowned New York agency when it bought its parent company, the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership of Britain, in May.
LEAD: An American religious worker who was arrested after the police found ammunition and explosives buried in her backyard was charged with terrorism by Salvadoran authorities late today.

LEAD: Leo McKern first appeared 11 years ago as Horace Rumpole, the roguish, lovable barrister. Since then, the actor has regularly insisted that he is through with the role. He would rather be remembered, evidently, for his often acclaimed interpretations of Shakespeare. But Mr. McKern and the grumbling husband of She Who Must Be Obeyed are by now inseparable, and the author John Mortimer, himself a former barrister, shows no sign of running out of ''Rumpole of the Bailey'' stories.

LEAD: A judge today delayed a requirement that the actress Zsa Zsa Gabor spend 72 hours in jail and pay fines totaling $2,937 until after appeal of her misdemeanor conviction for slapping a police officer. But the judge, Charles G. Rubin of Municipal Court, refused to delay the 120 hours of community service that was also a part of the sentence.

LEAD: The American Medical Association's top executive, whose approval of two financial deals that lost money led to a dispute in the organization, has announced that he will retire when his current contract ends.

LEAD: Paul Brown, who coached championship teams in high school, college and the pros, and the former Notre Dame athletic director Ed (Moose) Krause were honored last night by the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
LEAD: * Southern Progress, a division of Time Warner Inc., to Slaughter Hanson Advertising, Birmingham, Ala., for Cooking Light magazine.

LEAD: The United States is coming under pressure from some of its NATO allies to drop its rigid opposition to including naval forces in arms reduction talks with the Soviet Union, diplomats and other Government officials in several European capitals say.

LEAD: N.B.A. Celtics 114, Hornets 101: Larry Bird had 13 rebounds, 11 assists and 11 points last night as Boston beat the Hornets at Charlotte, N.C., and improved its record to 7-0 against the Hornets. Bird was 4 for 13 from the field. But after the Hornets closed to 66-59 with 6:09 left in the the third quarter, he made two jumpers that capped a 13-4 run.

LEAD: Liv Ullmann had hoped that as the final witness yesterday in the GAF stock manipulation trial she could tell the jurors details about the character of the main defendant in the case, a senior GAF executive. But like her two books and many of her films, her testimony was limited mostly to her own character.

LEAD: New York Bus Service and its striking drivers reached tentative agreement yesterday on a three-year contract. It will allow service to resume this morning for 13,000 express bus riders from the north Bronx.

LEAD: IN a Bordeaux restaurant a few weeks ago, a prominent American wine importer ordered a 1982 Chateau La Grave Trigant de Boisset, from a little-known property in Pomerol. His guests, all professionally involved with wine, found it pleasant.

LEAD: CLOTHING for fat children, in the not too distant past, was sold in the ''chubby'' department. Stores are no longer so insensitive that they call attention to obese children in this way. But the children's peers have no such qualms: fat children are still subject to cruel taunts.
LEAD: The Vermont Supreme Court has blocked the construction of a vacation-home development on the ground that it would deprive about 20 whitetail deer of a vital winter habitat.
LEAD: Israeli troops killed five heavily armed Arab guerrillas today after the gunmen crossed into Israel from Egypt through the Sinai, the army said.
LEAD: Finally wrestle steering wheel into going to ball park. Can't put it off any longer. Have to see for myself how the old boys are doing in the Senior Professional Baseball Association.

LEAD: THIS time of year, the height of the entertaining season, calls for more lavish, richer food than usual. That does not mean there is no role for the microwave oven. It can speed preparation of dishes like potato gratin to gild the simplest meat or fish for company.

LEAD: COMPANIES I.B.M. will reduce its domestic work force by more than 10,000 and take a $2.3 billion charge against earnings in the fourth quarter. It said it hoped to reduce its costs by $1 billion a year. But some critics said I.B.M. had not gone far enough to address its problems in a difficult and highly competitive market.

LEAD: Cabot Advertising in Boston makes its national, pro-bono television advertising debut on Dec. 15 with a new and unusual campaign for the American Red Cross urging people to give blood. In an appealingly languorous style that diverges from the dire mood of much public service advertising, the all-text spot tells people, ''When you give blood, you give another birthday party, another wedding anniversary, another day at the beach, another night under the stars, another talk with a friend, another laugh, another hug, another chance.

LEAD: In his first broad move to put his stamp on City Hall, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins has chosen four deputy mayors, a corporation counsel and a press secretary to serve at the center of his administration, members of his transition team said yesterday.
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration refused yesterday to allow a private company to become the first to take control of a public commercial airport, Albany County's.

LEAD: Faced with voters who threaten them with political and even physical harm, Massachusetts legislators are trying again this week to figure out how to go about the distasteful business of raising taxes.

LEAD: The New York State Health Commissioner has accepted a panel's recommendation that administrative charges be dropped against two doctors who treated 18-year-old Libby Zion in the hours before her death in 1984.

LEAD: Some call it ''the Versailles of sewage treatment,'' and for good reason. The majestic North River Water Pollution Control Plant on Harlem's western waterfront is a delight to behold. Its sweeping arches, graceful lines and breathtaking vistas engage the eye and the imagination.

LEAD: For the second straight year in spring training, the Yankees and Mets will play a series of games against each other, culminating in two meetings in New York on the weekend before the beginning of regular-season play.

LEAD: The repertory the Saturday Brass Quintet presented in its First Annual Contemporary Music Concert at Washington Square Church on Friday evening, consisting almost entirely of premieres and first New York performances, ranged from high pretense to low humor, and it was sometimes difficult to tell the difference.
LEAD: Percy Snow of Michigan State, who calls himself mean on the field and a nice guy off it, was named yesterday as the winner of the Dick Butkus award as the top linebacker in college football.
LEAD: When business executives take up the cause of public education, they usually end up doing things like volunteer tutoring or picking up the tab to send the senior class to Washington.
LEAD: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law Page on Friday gave an outdated name for a Boston law firm.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the collection of premiums under the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act included an incorrect assertion by a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services about refunds to be made because of repeal of the program last month. The spokesman said Medicare beneficiaries would receive no refunds of either monthly premiums or the surtax paid this year for the expanded health insurance.

LEAD: The battered bride at the center of Deborah Pryor's ''Briar Patch'' stands in the Virginia moonlight and dreams about floating away into outer space. Confined in the tangled brambles of Ms. Pryor's dreary play (opening the season at the Ensemble Studio Theater), theatergoers may feel similarly in need of liberation.

LEAD: Ethics is the issue that will not die on Capitol Hill. Even as the House passed an ethics bill last month, culminating a year of political agony for that chamber, a crisis was building in the Senate.
LEAD: Pope John Paul II warned today that the world was caught in an ecological crisis that violates human rights and ''lays bare the depth of man's moral crisis.''

LEAD: The National Football League is expected to announce before Friday its findings on the so-called bounty-hunting incident involving the Eagles and the Dallas Cowboys, who meet again Sunday in Philadelphia.

LEAD: In the first stage of a process intended to combat mismanagement and abuse, the Office of Management and Budget has identified areas of high risk in the way the Government handles its business, especially in contracting, credit and insurance programs and financial accounting systems.

LEAD: In states with container-deposit laws, people can insert their used cans or bottles in a ''reverse vending machine'' and get back their nickel or dime deposit. LEAD: A judge has cleared Joseph Pikul's name because the former Wall Street securities analyst died before an appeal of his conviction on charges of murdering his wife was decided, a lawyer said today.

LEAD: Presidential Airways Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection five weeks ago, discontinued all of its flights effective Monday. It had been operating 24 flights a day to and from six cities. Presidential, which began four years ago, had provided feeder service for United Airlines at Washington Dulles International Airport here since January 1988.
LEAD: Scientists studying the effect of sonic booms on Los Angeles buildings have determined that skyscrapers may be more vulnerable to earthquakes than previously believed.
LEAD: * Bryan Birch and Ed Cole have joined Foote, Cone & Belding/Southern California as senior vice presidents and co-creative directors.

LEAD: The former Olympic gold medalist Nadia Comaneci repeatedly shunned questions about her personal plans, but made it clear at a news conference today that she had no immediate plans to become involved with gymnastics in the United States.

LEAD: Pergament Home Centers, a chain that sells home-improvement products, said yesterday that Michael H. Lurie had been named president and chief operating officer to fill one of the posts held by Murray Pergament, the longtime president, chairman and chief executive.
LEAD: John Brunetti, the owner of Hialeah Park, wants to close the historic race track as soon as possible because he is losing an expensive battle for bettors with nearby Calder Race Course.
LEAD: Rebuffed in his effort to use campaign funds for inaugural expenses, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins will ask big contributors for up to $250,000 for an inaugural party for 6,000 to 8,000 people.

LEAD: A dispute about liability insurance that kept a $1 million state-of-the-art bomb detector sitting in a crate at Miami International Airport has been resolved, with the manufacturer agreeing to absorb the cost.

LEAD: Erich Honecker and top members of his fallen leadership were placed under house arrest by the authorities today as a furious and impatient public increasingly took the hunt for corrupt and repressive former officials into its own hands.

LEAD: The more affluent Medicare beneficiaries who paid a surtax of up to $800 this year for coverage under the Catastrophic Coverage Act will get that money back under the measure Congress passed last month repealing the program.

LEAD: Venus Lacy and Sheila Ethridge each scored 18 points tonight night to lead second-ranked Louisiana Tech to an 87-49 victory over Northeast Louisiana.

LEAD: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, the credit-rating company, told clients yesterday that it was no longer advising them to ship goods to the Campeau Corporation's department stores because of the delay in finding bidders for the company's Bloomingdale's stores, financial and manufacturing executives said.
LEAD: John Tudor, a pitcher, and the outfielder John Shelby were among five free-agent players who were offered salary arbitration by the Dodgers yesterday.
LEAD: Early this year Wendy Kopp, then a student at Princeton, wrote her senior thesis on a plan to entice some of the best college graduates into teaching in public schools.

LEAD: The jurors in the McMartin Preschool molestation case turned in the second of a potential total of 65 verdicts today and rejected a suggestion that they cancel their two-week Christmas vacation.

LEAD: In the Pul-i-Baghmi bazaar, down by the muddy waters of the Kabul River, the old trader smiled. Although there were no customers on hand, his sacks of flour, rice and other grains were overflowing. With food prices edging up every week, the trader could see little ahead but profit.

LEAD: In a dramatic reflection of its inability to find the right combination of products to meet its goals for growth, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would reduce its domestic work force by more than 10,000 and take a $2.3 billion charge against earnings in the fourth quarter.
LEAD: Maintaining its drum roll of bad news, the Cuomo administration predicted today that tax revenues for the current fiscal year would be even worse than it had estimated just last month.
LEAD: Tony Campbell scored 26 points, including 9 straight late in the fourth quarter tonight, as the Minnesota Timberwolves held off the Nets, 92-90, to gain their first two-game winning streak.

LEAD: Henry A. Simons, former vice president and creative director of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau in Manhattan, died of a heart attack on Monday at White Plains Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: One man was killed and another was critically wounded in a Queens parking lot Monday night by two men whom they had arranged to meet to settle a drug deal, the police said.

LEAD: Despite an entire life lived here in car country, in Southern California, I only very recently succumbed to full-blown car lust. For a month and a half I lurched, with my husband along, from showroom to showroom, sizing up the new cars and trying to decide which one to buy, which one was really me.

LEAD: The National Academy of Design, the school, museum and society of artists on upper Fifth Avenue, abruptly dismissed about one-fourth of its 40-member staff yesterday and said it planned to cut its educational programs and the hours for its exhibition galleries because of financial problems.

LEAD: After testimony by 59 witnesses in 13 days, the trial of a Miami police officer for the killing of two unarmed black men went to the jury tonight. Jurors will begin formal deliberation in the morning.
LEAD: Former State Representative Joseph Walkovich pleaded guilty yesterday to failing to file a Federal tax return for 1985.

LEAD: The 1990 spring season of the American Music Theater Festival in Philadelphia will include the first performances of a cabaret theater piece, ''Casino Paradise,'' by William Bolcom and Arnold Weinstein, as well as a reconstruction of the 1948 musical ''Love Life,'' by Kurt Weill and Alan Jay Lerner.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from remarks by E. D. Hirsch Jr., author of ''Cultural Literacy: What Every American Needs to Know,'' and Henry Louis Gates Jr., W. E. B. DuBois Professor of Literature at Cornell University. They spoke yesterday in New York at a forum on literacy in America, sponsored by The New York Times.

LEAD: Dave Dravecky, who battled back from cancer to pitch for San Francisco this season, will have surgery in January because of a recurrence of a tumor in his left arm. Dravecky, 33, will undergo the procedure at the Sloan-Kettering Memorial Cancer Center in New York on Jan. 4.

LEAD: After President Bush's meeting with Western European leaders in Brussels on Monday, it has become apparent that the rapid pace of change in Eastern Europe is creating political and personal strains within the European Community and the Western alliance, officials and diplomats here say.

LEAD: Angelo Ruggiero, a longtime friend and close associate of John Gotti, died of cancer Monday at his home in Howard Beach, Queens. Mr. Ruggiero, who was 49 years old, had four major cases against him pending in Federal and New York State courts and was free on $1 million bail when he died.
LEAD: John Hill Tyner, a retired antiques dealer, took his own life Monday at his home in Chatham, Mass. He was 69 years old and had suffered from depression for 20 years, a family member said.

LEAD: Carriage drivers have obtained a temporary restraining order while they prepare a court challenge to a city law restricting the use of the horse-drawn taxis in midtown Manhattan. The law, which was sought by animal rights organizations and approved by the City Council over Mayor Koch's veto, bars the carriages from midtown for most of the day.

LEAD: Investigators have concluded that a bomb destroyed a Colombian jetliner that crashed last month and killed all 107 people aboard, and they say they believe that the bomb was hidden under a seat, an official said today.

LEAD: A memorial service for Dr. Howard A. Rusk, founder of the Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine, will be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. at Alumni Hall of the New York University School of Medicine, at First Avenue at 30th Street. Dr. Rusk died of a stroke on Nov. 4 at the age of 88.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed eliminating tactical nuclear weapons from the American and Soviet Navies at his Malta summit meeting with President Bush, Administration officials disclosed.

LEAD: When the Greenwich Board of Education went shopping for a new superintendent this year, its members knew that it would be difficult to offer a package of pay and perquisites large enough to enable an out-of-town administrator to buy a home here. After all, the average price of a four-bedroom colonial on one and a half acres is $837,000.

LEAD: Corning Inc. will receive $25 million from Sumitomo Electric Industries in an out-of-court settlement of a suit that accused the Japanese company of violating two Corning patents for optical fibers, Corning said today.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today expanded the scope of one of the most important Federal civil rights laws, ruling that state and local governments can be sued for damages if they intervene improperly in labor negotiations.

LEAD: The Government was forced to agree today to a recount in an important local race. The recount was ordered after the election victory over the weekend by the Nationalist Party, which set off accusations of fraud and led to a clash between the police and supporters of the opposition.

LEAD: Art is still commanding breathtaking sums in the auction houses. Pablo Picasso's ''Pierrette's Wedding'' was bought last week by a Japanese real-estate developer for $51.3 million, the second highest price ever paid for a painting. But indications are that the feverish buying of recent years is beginning to cool down and that buyers are becoming more selective.

LEAD: Redwood Protection Q.I have redwood patio furniture and am interested in the best way to protect it from the weather. Is applying a redwood stain enough? LEAD: Like so many other singers who have made their professional impact principally on the opera stage, Faith Esham appears to look longingly at recitals. Here one tests a different set of skills. Nimbleness replaces brute strength, and the voice alone creates the sense of theater.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation will not be able to sell some models in Vermont in 1992 because of the state's air pollution law, a company official said today.
