LEAD: With the virtual collapse of the East German Communist Party, the leading moral authority in this part of Germany is once again what it has been for most of the time since the Reformation, the Lutheran Church.

LEAD: West Germany is expected to announce today that it has awarded a license to build its first private cellular telephone system to a consortium that includes the Pacific Telesis Group, the regional Bell telephone company based in San Francisco.

LEAD: JILLIAN ROLAND sat outside for nearly an hour before working up enough courage to go in. Finally, she took a deep breath, clenched her pocketbook and her father's hand and took a step into adulthood.
LEAD: A defense lawyer summed up his case today by calling his client ''a monster in nurse's whites'' who may well have killed four hospital patients but should not be convicted of murder.

LEAD: The Campeau Corporation yesterday sharply criticized Dun & Bradstreet Inc., the credit-rating company, for advising its clients against further merchandise shipments to its stores because of a delay in the proposed sale of its Bloomingdale's department store chain.
LEAD: Calls are mounting in the Soviet Union for the repeal of Article 6 of the Constitution, which insures Communist Party dominance. Here is the text of the article.

LEAD: Prices of Teasury notes and bonds slipped in light trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities after a report from regional Federal Reserve banks showed that the economy remained a bit stronger than anticipated.

LEAD: John Craig Barker, a clarinetist from Mississippi who is a student at the Juilliard School, made his New York recital debut on Sunday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. His program was devoted mostly to 20th century works, the one 19th-century holdover being Schumann's ''Fantasiestucke'' (Op. 73).

LEAD: A tradition of father-son banquets honoring the high school football team was canceled after the quarterback said he wouldn't go if his mother couldn't. ''A lot of people supporting us through hard times were mothers,'' said Owa Brandstein, quarterback for the Mohawk Trail Regional High School team.
LEAD: A young man with a rifle killed 14 women and wounded 12 other people today in a shooting rampage at the University of Montreal engineering school, then shot himself to death, the police said.
LEAD: * Allen Group Inc., Melville, L.I., a manufacturer of automotive products, named Robert G. Paul president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: The price of The New York Times delivered directly by The Times in the metropolitan area will increase to $4.50 a week on Jan. 1, William L. Pollak, the vice president for circulation, announced yesterday. Most customers now pay $4.25 a week. The increase will not affect suggested newsstand prices or direct home-delivery rates outside the New York area.

LEAD: The importance of human rights in American foreign policy has just been powerfully demonstrated. As change sweeps through Eastern Europe, we can feel that we played a part by pressing over many years for democratic values: free elections, the right to travel, freedom of speech and press.

LEAD: The Soviet Union received some free economic advice from American officials during the Malta summit meeting on how Moscow could put a chicken in every pot - or least some soap in every washroom.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Lin Broadcasting Corporation's acceptance of a takeover offer from McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. misstated terms for the disposition of the stock and options held by Lin's chairman, Donald A. Pels.
LEAD: For the Giants, it looks like a case of going from one frying pan into another and another and another.

LEAD: President Virgilio Barco Vargas said on Wednesday that drug traffickers were responsible for a truck bombing that killed 52 people in the capital and pledged not to allow Colombian democracy to succumb to their ''bloody tyranny.''

LEAD: Virginia Xanthos Faggi, coordinator for special projects at Columbia University, died of a heart attack Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Sections of southern New Jersey's pygmy forest, where decades-old pitch pines and blackjack oaks reach only four to six feet in height, have been owned by the state for years, but environmentalists feared they still were not adequately protected.

LEAD: ''Dear Samuel Beckett,'' a wild-haired, whiny-voiced, starving young dramatist writes to his idol. In view of the ''uncanny kinship'' between ''Waiting for Godot'' and ''Despair,'' the young man's own play about life and death (''Life, life, life, death, death, death,'' chants a black-robed chorus), perhaps the two men might collaborate on a future project?

LEAD: A production by the director Peter Sellars of Wagner's ''Tannhauser,'' announced for June at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has been canceled, the academy's president, Harvey Lichtenstein, said yesterday.

LEAD: Barbara and Oliver Rose (Kathleen Turner and Michael Douglas) started out as young lovebirds, ready to scrimp and save and struggle their way toward a rosy future. But by the time that future arrived, bringing with it two kids, two pets, two cars and a big house with a lighted, glassed-in shoe closet, they hated each another like poison.
LEAD: Grant Tinker and the Gannett Company said yesterday that they had agreed to end their partnership in the GTG television production company.

LEAD: Luis Zendejas, the Dallas Cowboys' place-kicker, has told The Dallas Times-Herald that a Philadelphia Eagles assistant coach pleaded with him not to tell the National Football League that he had warned Zendejas about attempts to knock him out of the Thanksgiving game between the teams.

LEAD: Direct negotiations between Viacom Inc. and Time Warner Inc. to settle Viacom's $2.5 billion suit against Time Warner finally began this week. In the suit Viacom charged that Home Box Office has used anti-competitive practices in its dealings with Showtime, Viacom's pay television service.

LEAD: The White House, concerned about conservative dissatisfaction with President Bush's warm praise for Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Malta summit, has given Vice President Dan Quayle free rein to criticize the Soviet President and his policies, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: Americans took out $3.34 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in October, resulting in the biggest increase in net consumer debt in five months.

LEAD: Frances Bavier, who played Aunt Bee on ''The Andy Griffith Show'' on television in the 1960's, died at her home here on Wednesday. She was 86 years old and had been released Monday from a hospital, where she had been in the coronary-care unit.

LEAD: A music review on Monday about cast changes in ''Rigoletto'' at the Metropolitan Opera referred incorrectly to a radio broadcast celebrating the company's 50th season. The program, heard on Saturday, was a mixture of live interviews and excerpts from previous years' broadcasts, not a recording of Richard Strauss's ''Frau Ohne Schatten.

LEAD: Ladislav Adamec resigned today as Czechoslovakia's Communist Prime Minister and was replaced by his relatively unknown 43-year-old deputy. Mr. Adamec reportedly felt that the new leader would find it easier to put together a cabinet acceptable to the opposition led by Civic Forum.
LEAD: The Zanuck Company

LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, joined by almost every other member of the New York City Board of Estimate, voted yesterday to overturn the landmark status of a 113-year-old building on the Avenue of the Americas that was designated in October as ''a forerunner of the skyscraper type.''
LEAD: Governor-elect James J. Florio stayed with experience today by naming for his first cabinet appointment Robert J. Del Tufo, a former United States Attorney for New Jersey, as attorney general.

LEAD: Harold T. Miller, who helped rally prominent authors to fight an attempted takeover of Houghton Mifflin Inc. in 1979, announced yesterday that he would retire in April as chairman and chief executive of the Boston-based publishing company.

LEAD: Constance K. Kaiser, an executive, philanthropist and former publisher of telephone directories for Westchester and Connecticut communities, died of cancer on Wednesday at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 56 years old.
LEAD: In a defeat for organized labor, a Federal district judge today upheld a Labor Department regulation that allows people to work at home in five apparel-related industries.
LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation today named A. Thomas Young, the company's executive vice president, to the posts of president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: As Philippine rebel troops returned to their barracks in an uneasy truce, officials here said today that the top military and political leadership of the country was nearly toppled a week ago at the height of the military rebellion against President Corazon C. Aquino.

LEAD: To almost everyone in Louisiana politics, he is the most overpublicized man in American politics, a freshman state legislator without a substantive achievement who has nevertheless become a national figure.
LEAD: The Gold Ball By Hanne Marie Svendsen Translated by Jorgen Schiott. 245 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.
LEAD: Verdi Letters

LEAD: The stock of the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation climbed 90.7 percent today, after the Phoenix-based financial services company said it had agreed to settle a dispute with Federal regulators by injecting capital into its insolvent savings subsidiary, Merabank.
LEAD: The First Interstate Bancorp, plagued by troubles in the Southwest, moved to clean up its money-losing Texas operation today by adding $400 million to reserves before selling problem assets.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought 410,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in 1989-90, the seventh year of a long-term grain supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today.

LEAD: California sea lions that prey on steelhead and salmon at a fish ladder here could be caught and sent back to breeding grounds off Southern California ahead of time this winter under new government recommendations.
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's political foes asserted today that the Government's tentative plans to reduce its military forces by nearly a fifth do not go far enough.

LEAD: A Long Island planning agency recommended today that almost 5,000 houses and businesses on Fire Island and in other shore resort areas threatened by erosion be gradually eliminated and that the barrier islands they stand on be returned to nature.
LEAD: Lithuania became the first Soviet republic to abolish the Communist Party's guaranteed monopoly on power when its parliament voted overwhelmingly today to legalize rival political parties.

LEAD: Mexican federal police have shot down four drug-laden planes in the past three months and will continue to fire at suspicious planes that do not respond to warnings, a senior Mexican official has announced.

LEAD: As a self-proclaimed ''tax therapist,'' Joyce Rebhun has helped thousands of late filers who have special emotional problems. Her job here is to get them penalty fee waivers from the Internal Revenue Service.

LEAD: A gunman who killed 14 women and wounded 13 other people before killing himself Wednesday was described by the police tonight as a 25-year-old loner who was repeatedly frustrated in what one investigator called ''relationships of the heart.''
LEAD: John Payne, an all-around actor who starred in nearly 50 films, mostly in the 1940's and 50's, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 77 years old.

LEAD: The Miami financier Victor Posner said today that he had granted to American International Group Inc. the option to buy his controlling interest in the Fischbach Corporation, the nation's largest electrical contractor.
LEAD: A picture caption on Nov. 6 about accusations of anti-Semitism against the mythologist Joseph Campbell reversed two identities. He was at the center; the author Brendan Gill was at the right.
LEAD: Mon Cher Ton Ton (French Room)

LEAD: Although the Jets' pass rush had its most productive day of the season in last Sunday's victory over the Chargers in San Diego with five sacks, there is a feeling that things could be different Sunday against the Pittsburgh Steelers at Giants Stadium.

LEAD: In the first public follow-up to the national ''education summit'' in September, a committee of governors and White House aides heard advice today about what the United States should expect from its schools and decided to focus for now on goals, not on how to achieve them or pay for them.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL Western European governments are expected to create an enlarged European common market of 18 nations, not just the 12 in the European Community. [ Page A1. ] President Mitterrand of France is eager to extract a new commitment from the European Community to proceed with rapid economic integration.
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. reported today that its profits jumped 23 percent in the year ended Sept. 30, with higher revenue from its food, beverage and retailing operations.

LEAD: A thousand people gathered at two sites today to remember the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor that killed 2,403 soldiers, sailors and civilians and propelled the United States into World War II. Simultaneous ceremonies on the 48th anniversary of the attack were held by the Navy aboard the U.S.S. Arizona Memorial, which spans the hull of the sunken battleship that serves as the final resting place for 1,102 Navy officers and enlisted men, and onshore at the Arizona Memorial Visitors Center.

LEAD: In the most hopeful experimental finding yet on the question of whether scientists will be able make an AIDS vaccine, researchers in Louisiana today reported that they protected eight of nine monkeys against simian AIDS with a vaccine.

LEAD: After more than two and a half years of extensive repair work, all three northbound lanes of the F.D.R. Drive will be open again, beginning today at 3 P.M., the City Transportation Department announced yesterday.

LEAD: ''We,'' that pronoun of commonality and cooperation, runs wild as weeds through the conversation of Mahir Babayev, shifting its meaning as the Soviet legal expert describes his odyssey through American corporate law, the contacts made, the deals now brewing and the deals already done.

LEAD: THE complex job of rebuilding the international economic order in the wake of the upheaval in the Communist world and the apparent end of the cold war will require dedicated and brilliant leaders like those who created the Marshall Plan after World War II. The late chief executive of West Germany's biggest bank, the Deutsche Bank, Alfred Herrhausen, who was murdered by a terrorist bomb near Frankfurt last week, was such a leader.
LEAD: A 42-year-old art teacher at Public School 59 in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with sexually abusing three students, the police said.

LEAD: In what is considered a major advance in biotechnology, a team of California scientists have devised a new method of creating monoclonal antibodies, which are widely used in medical diagnosis, experimental cancer treatments and basic research in immunology and disease.
LEAD: In a surprising decision, England has been seeded sixth for the 1990 World Cup soccer championships, ahead of Spain.

LEAD: Western European governments plan to announce an agreement later this month to establish a free-trade zone that includes the 12 nations of the European Community and 6 others, diplomats and community officials said in recent days.

LEAD: Robert Craft, the conductor and critic, will lead the 20th-Century Classics Ensemble and the Gregg Smith Singers at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening at 8. The program includes Edgard Varese's ''Ionisation''; Elliott Carter's Double Concerto for Harpsichord, Piano and Two Chamber Orchestras; Arnold Schoenberg's ''Herzgewachse'' (Op.
LEAD: Barbara Watson began working for the Department of Parks and Recreation in this Fairfield County town of 27,000 about 15 years ago.
LEAD: An American communications company today announced a joint venture to wire Poland for cable television and provide it with an array of Western programming.

LEAD: Everyone talks about how magical New York is for children at Christmas, but coping with the city at holiday time is never easy. Here and on page C22 are suggestions from seven New York Times critics on how to give children the best of New York in every realm, from architecture to theater to restaurants.
LEAD: C. L. Dellums, a labor and civil rights leader, died yesterday of cardiac arrest in Oakland, Calif., where he lived for the last 66 years. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: The Renaissance scholar at the center of a dispute about a plaster statue he has said was the model for Michelangelo's David has won $:7,500 (around $12,000) in damages in an English High Court in a libel case against The Independent newspaper.

LEAD: Lynda Ashley was released from jail today after serving 10 days for illegally raising 18 pet chickens. Mrs. Ashley was jailed on Nov. 25 for violating a village ordinance prohibiting raising poultry without a permit. ''The chickens can wait,'' Mrs. Ashley said upon her release. ''I just want to be with my family and have a nice hot cup of tea.

LEAD: Many beneficiaries of a Social Security program for poor people who are aged, blind or disabled have been mistakenly dropped from the rolls because a reduced staff cannot handle the workload, an agency study says.

LEAD: The television film ''Money, Power, Murder,'' on CBS at 9 P.M. Sunday, offers as its hero Peter Finley, an Irish-American cable-channel reporter who was obviously weaned on early James Cagney movies.
LEAD: The board of trustees of the Long Island Power Authority voted yesterday to hire three consulting companies to study whether the Shoreham power plant can be converted to burn non-nuclear fuel.
LEAD: If you have a yen to improve your skills in either fly tying or fly fishing, you might wish to sign up for the classes being offered by the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited.

LEAD: Soccer's governing body yesterday upheld its decision to ban the Chilean goalie Roberto Rojas from international play for life. Rojas was banned for feigning an injury in a World Cup qualifying match with Brazil. Rojas spoke for a half-hour before the appeals section of the Federation Internationale de Football Association in

LEAD: Junge Welt has still not published a photo of a bare-breasted woman, as was done in mid-November by the People's Army paper. But in the past month of political upheaval, this newspaper of the Communist Party youth organization has been transformed into East Germany's most sensationalistic publication at a time when all of the country's once uniformly conformist Communist

LEAD: Daniel Gaisford will be the soloist with the Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra in Dvorak's Cello Concerto in B minor (Op. 104) tomorrow at 2 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The program, which is to be conducted by Andrew Massey, also includes Delius's ''Walk to the Paradise Garden'' and Strauss's ''Metamorphosen.

LEAD: Children at the theater are at once the most open-minded audience and the toughest critics. Or such has been my experience with the children I have taken to the theater most often - boys between the ages of 4 and 10. I have watched a 6-year-old who didn't know Dickens from Seuss eat up seven hours of ''Nicholas Nickleby'' (as well as a dinner-break pizza), held spellbound by the teeming action and the poignant figure of Smike.

LEAD: When I was a typical wide-eyed youngster coming to New York City from rural New Jersey with my mother to see the holiday sights, fine dining was not exactly high on my shopping list. Sitting in a hushed dining room for an hour would have been as torturous as being shackled to the sofa on Christmas morning and watching my sister tear open all my presents.

LEAD: The Federal Government's decision to abandon its current development of the Yucca Mountain Nuclear Waste Depository in Nevada, and to start again on a new plan for the same site, repeats an old, discouraging story: a ballyhooed ''solution'' to the radioactive waste problem that turns out to be just one more flop.

LEAD: In his first official trip out of the capital since becoming Prime Minister of India, V. P. Singh went to Amritsar today to pray at the holiest shrine of the Sikhs, promising to heal ''the heavy, bleeding heart'' of Punjab state. Thousands have died in confrontations there in the last five years.

LEAD: Sheldon A. Vogel, a former partner in the Manhattan law firm of Thacher Proffitt & Wood, died of respiratory failure on Wednesday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan and Coronado, Calif.
LEAD: ''Our success is unambiguous proof that a vaccine for AIDS is possible.'' - Dr. Michael Murphy-Corb of Tulane University. [ A1:1. ]

LEAD: The last of the great private estates that helped give Greenwich, Conn., its patrician character - a 169-acre wilderness area in the town's northwest corner - has been sold and the first phase of subdividing it has been approved.
LEAD: Despite presidential promises to rein in security forces, the armed forces have intensified a crackdown on international relief groups, church workers and opposition groups.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE pain on Wall Street is spreading to a business whose very existence is known to few customers - the practice of over-the-counter market makers paying retail brokerage firms for orders.

LEAD: The free agents kept marching through the marketplace of baseball with soaring contracts today, and the march was led by Keith Hernandez, the former co-captain of the Mets, who signed a two-year contract with the Cleveland Indians for $3.5 million and said: ''I'm not ready for the bench yet.''

LEAD: The cold war between the Association of Tennis Professionals, which will administer the men's tour in 1990, and the International Tennis Federation, which will administer the four Grand Slam tournaments and the new Grand Slam Cup, failed to thaw despite frequent meetings between the two groups as the final Nabisco Masters was played out in New

LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk tonight rejected requests that he appoint an independent judicial commission of inquiry to investigate allegations that the police operated assassination squads to eliminate opponents of apartheid.
LEAD: The war was a bore.
LEAD: A car bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army exploded in a suburban shopping district today, wounded 21 people and heavily damaging surrounding stores, the police said.

LEAD: U S West Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to lead a corporation formed by the Soviet Union and seven other international telephone companies that plans to lay a fiber-optic communications cable across the Soviet Union, linking Japan and Europe.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped again in light trading yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for this morning's release of November employment data.

LEAD: Two brothers who were crewmen aboard a ship that rammed a fragile coral reef in October have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of operating the vessel recklessly and while intoxicated.
LEAD: An inmate was shot to death and six guards were hurt Wednesday in a night-long riot at the Hudson County Jail, the authorities said today.

LEAD: The difference between Saturday's Army-Navy game and the 89 that preceded it is the location: Giants Stadium in New Jersey's Meadowlands. This is a one-time-only arrangement and also a subtle message to the city of Philadelphia, where 67 of the games have been played.

LEAD: Balletomanes sometimes bemoan the presence of children at performances of ''The Nutcracker.'' Aside from occasional candy-wrapper fidgeting that adults do even better, children make an ideal theater audience. But what is good children's theater? Some theater that bills itself as that is pretty awful and bores the kids as well, condescending to its audience by talking down and skimping on imagination and production elements.

LEAD: The 6-year-old boy whose crushed right leg had to be amputated in the wreckage of the Nimitz Freeway after an earthquake struck on Oct. 17 has been fitted with an artificial leg and is in high spirits, a physical therapist says.
LEAD: Eight telephone companies, led by U S West, agreed to form a corporation with the Soviet Government to link Europe and Japan with a fiber-optic cable. Page D1.
LEAD: Vaclav Havel, the playwright and opposition leader, declared his readiness tonight to become President.

LEAD: The presence of a Russian hockey team in the United States may no longer be news, but the upcoming tour of Sokol-Kiev, an elite team, is different. The squad will play five games against college teams and then a two-game series against the USA Selects, the latter an All-Star team of current college players.

LEAD: There's a psychotic killer loose in Coxsackie, N.Y., the setting for the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's new production of ''Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.'' The killer, a formerly mild-mannered librarian, has dismembered 16 1/2 bodies. Dr. Henry Jekyll of the Coxsackie Medical Institute believes this is no ordinary criminal.

LEAD: The National Hockey League's Board of Governors decided yesterday to move the goal lines an extra foot from the goal line to the boards behind the net. Effective next season, the line will be 11 feet from the boards instead of 10.

LEAD: The intensity that John Thompson prefers to develop in his basketball laboratory on the campus of Georgetown University was revealed tonight for the sake of college basketball's latest profit-making venture.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Philippine military rebellion gave an incorrect date in some copies for Corazon C. Aquino's election as President. It was February 1986, not August 1986.

LEAD: American ships carrying food aid began arriving in Poland last week. But they will deliver less food than they could, critics say, with correspondingly fewer benefits to American farmers, because of a law that results in higher shipping costs.

LEAD: West Germany today awarded the license to build and operate a private cellular telephone system to a four-nation consortium led by Mannesmann A.G. The group also includes the Pacific Telesis Group of the United States, Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain, Lyonnaise des Eaux of France and Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank, a West German bank.
LEAD: Holiday pageants, plays, musicals and puppet shows are enchanting young audiences throughout the New York City area. Although geared to children, many ought to appeal to adults as well.
LEAD: In a town 20 miles east of here there is fear that a copycat killer is on the loose. Another venerable tree has been poisoned.

LEAD: The end is a new beginning, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater proclaimed eloquently on Wednesday night at the City Center. The company's members, hardly low on energy at any time, danced their hearts out as never before - in tribute to their founder and artistic director.

LEAD: N.H.L. Flyers 4, Sabres 3: Ron Sutter scored 1 minute 24 seconds into overtime last night in Philadelphia, beating the goalie, Darren Puppa, with a backhander from the goal mouth after Buffalo had forced overtime by rallying from a 3-1 deficit on a goal by Mike Foligno with 11 seconds left in regulation.

LEAD: The L. J. Hooker Corporation said it would seek approval of a Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to retain Financo Inc. to sell its Bonwit Teller and Sakowitz Inc. specialty stores. Financo is a New York investment banker specializing in mergers and acquisitions. Sanford C. Sigoloff, Hooker's chief executive, said Bonwit Teller continued to show improvement, but ''Hooker management felt that the best way to maximize returns was through a sale.

LEAD: Close Call for Aquino Philippine officials said President Corazon C. Aquino's Government was nearly toppled at the height of the military revolt a week ago. Page A8. Gain in Biotechnology A new method has been developed to produce monoclonal antibodies, substances that have become critical in diagnosis and research.

LEAD: The Pennzoil Company said today that it had spent $2.1 billion in the last two months to buy an 8.8 percent stake in the Chevron Corporation, the nation's third-largest oil company, and indicated that it might increase the stake by another $500 million, or to about 11 percent.
LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk announced today that military conscription of whites would be cut from two years to one year as part of a broader reduction of the South African armed forces.

LEAD: Anyone with children has the opportunity for hands-on expertise in taking them to concerts; anyone else is a mere critic. My own experience in these matters extends to a 14-month-old, which means I have not yet really confronted the issue of which concerts my own child might enjoy. That doesn't mean she doesn't like music, if dancing in front of a loudspeaker counts (sometimes before it's even warmed up and actually emitting sound), or clambering up on the piano bench to make tone clusters.
LEAD: An obituary on Saturday about Alan Bowne, a playwright and author, misstated the date of his death. It was Nov. 24.

LEAD: A Hispanic police officer was found guilty of manslaughter today in the killings of two unarmed black men that set off rioting in the mostly black Overtown section of Miami. The killings, which occurred in January, have come to symbolize the ethnic tensions of this troubled city.

LEAD: In recent years, more and more New Yorkers have been waltzing and two-stepping to genuine Gulf Coast zydeco, the infectious Cajun-Creole dance music created by French-speaking blacks in and around Louisiana. Now the music may well be on the verge of a local breakthrough as one of its acknowledged masters, the accordionist and singer known as Rockin' Dopsie, begins an eight-night stand tonight at Tramps.

LEAD: Egypt's qualified acceptance of the American plan for Palestinian-Israeli peace talks received a cautious welcome today from the Israeli Government, which said its Foreign Minister was ready to attend the first meeting as early as next month.

LEAD: ''Bloodhounds of Broadway'' attempts to rediscover the slangy, exuberant life embedded in Damon Runyon's sentimental fables of long ago. At its heart are more or less the same Broadway characters apotheosized in Frank Loesser's classic ''Guys and Dolls.''
LEAD: About 300 Yonkers firefighters and their families marched on City Hall today, as their union leader accused the Fire Commissioner of neglecting them.

LEAD: Watching Meryl Streep at work in Susan Seidelman's ''She-Devil'' is to behold a magnificent illusionist at work. Miss Streep dives into this thimble-sized comedy and makes one believe - at least, while she is on the screen - that it is an Olympic-sized swimming pool of wit.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday named Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, to head a panel on program trading and market volatility.
LEAD: Lenny Pickett, a saxophonist and composer, is to perform new pieces on Sunday at 9 P.M. at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street in TriBeCa (219-8242). Tickets are $6.

LEAD: There is plenty to see, and plenty to think about, in the small-scale retrospective of paintings by Philip Evergood (1901-1973) at the Terry Dintenfass Gallery. In histories of 20th-century American art, Evergood has a way of falling through the cracks. He was a moralist when moralizing was not thought to be one of a serious painter's options.

LEAD: Five Palestinians living on the Egyptian side of a refugee district divided in half by the Israeli border have crossed into the Gaza Strip, the first of more than 5,000 Arabs who are to be reunited with their families here over the next five years.

LEAD: Just in time to enliven Albany's dreary year-end political scene, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the state's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, today began their annual squabble over the state judiciary budget.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Percy Snow, a Michigan State linebacker, earned his second honor of the week last night when he was presented the Lombardi Award as the nation's top lineman. Snow, a senior who holds the school record of 164 tackles in a season, won the Butkus Award on Tuesday as the nation's top linebacker. The 6-foot-3-inch, 240-pound Snow has 163 tackles this season, one short of the school record he set last year.(

LEAD: After spending three years in the shadow of another United States Attorney, Andrew J. Maloney is now the pivotal prosecutor in New York City's most politically sensitive inquiry: an investigation of Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: ONE of the few, unintended benefits of the Congressional outrage against Andres Serrano is that it has brought widespread attention to a good artist. His photographs are indeed provocative. They are also serious art. There are 14 of them at the Stux Gallery, including the reviled and dreaded one from 1987, with its 13-inch plastic-and-wood crucifix upright in a Plexiglas tank filled with the artist's urine.

LEAD: With his new paintings, Julian Schnabel should get some credit for showing up where he is least expected. The master of conspicuous pictorial consumption - famous for painting on surfaces made of broken plates or pot shards, fatigued tarpaulin or Kabuki theater backdrops - is now making paintings that criticize such consumption.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.
LEAD: The migration of millions of Mexican workers into the United States in search of jobs has brought a new influx: Mexican politicians and leaders in search of their influence, money and votes.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh assigned 400 additional prosecutors and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today to investigate savings and loan fraud. Money for the appointments was provided in a $48.5 million appropriation in the savings and loan rescue law enacted in August.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today formally censured S. B. Lewis & Company, the brokerage firm controlled by Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, for its role in Mr. Lewis's manipulation of the stock price of the Fireman's Fund Corporation in May 1986.
LEAD: FRIDAY JAM SESSION IN DAYLIGHT

LEAD: The East German Communist Party leadership moved up the opening of its critical party congress to Friday because of growing fear that the country would fall into chaos if it waited seven more days, senior officials said today.
LEAD: Donald B. Rice, the Secretary of the Air Force, said today that he was considering a slowdown in production of the B-2 Stealth bomber as military spending declines.
LEAD: A Florida company is recalling a nonprescription eyewash because of bacterial contamination that could cause serious infection, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.

LEAD: The captain of the Bronx Queen testified yesterday that he felt a thump at the stern just before the charter-fishing boat began to sink near the entrance to New York Harbor on Saturday. But neither the captain nor a diver who inspected the submerged ship could determine the cause of the accident.

LEAD: The Advertising column of Business Day yesterday, about the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, misidentified the period in which the company earned $:22.9 million in pretax profits. It was the first half of this year, not the second half of last year.
LEAD: * Beatrice Co., Chicago, said it had received almost $165 million from the Internal Revenue Service in connection with a 1980 transaction related to the disposition of Transocean Oil Inc.

LEAD: Fiat Auto S.p.A. said today that it planned to buy nearly half of Maserati to take advantage of some of Maserati's unused production capacity in Milan, Italy.

LEAD: Washington is embarking on another drug-of-the-month war, the third since 1986. Even the bellicose political rhetoric is misleading, for drugs come to

LEAD: * Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., the entertainment production company that was recently acqquired by Sony Corp., promoted Joe E. Stevens to senior vice president and controller, television.

LEAD: Robert J. Stephens, a principal in the New Rochelle, N.Y., school system who directed one of the nation's first elementary-school magnet programs focusing on the humanities, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 51 years old.

LEAD: Cinucen Tanrikorur, an oud (lute) player and singer, is to perform Turkish music on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Admission is $10, or $7 for students and the elderly. Information: 206-1050.
LEAD: A Southampton, L.I., doctor convicted of prostitution for soliciting college students to have sex with his wife was found dead yesterday, apparently a suicide victim.
LEAD: A motorcycle factory in eastern China has become the first state-owned enterprise to go bankrupt in the country's 40 years of Communist rule, the official press agency reported Wednesday.

LEAD: With the future of the European Community suddenly clouded by events in Eastern Europe, President Francois Mitterrand is anxious to extract a firm new commitment to rapid economic integration when leaders of the 12-nation bloc meet here on Friday.
LEAD: A man who said drugs and alcohol had led him to a life of crime was put to death by injection early today for the murder of a woman in a robbery.

LEAD: Nearly two-thirds of the advisory and fund-raising board for the National Academy of Design resigned yesterday during an emergency meeting called to discuss the academy's growing financial problems and a dispute over the institution's policies.
LEAD: A 22-year-old man was convicted of murder yesterday in the beating death of a 93-year-old Bronx woman during a robbery in her home, the Bronx District Attorney's office said.

LEAD: Benjamin J. Lucarelli, a contractor whose company built some of New Jersey's best-known apartment and hotel complexes, died yesterday at his home in Spring Lake, N.J. He was 82 years old and had lived in Jersey City and Sea Girt, N.J.
LEAD: East Germany's new and old political groupings held their first ''round table'' discussions today and agreed to call for the adoption of a new constitution and for free elections by May 6.
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has upheld a 1987 ruling that Boston University must pay $215,000 in damages and grant tenure to a female professor who sued the university for sex discrimination.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Lawrence Milberg, a lawyer and senior partner in the Manhattan-based firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad Specthrie & Lerach, died on Wednesday after suffering a heart attack while playing tennis near his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: The fossil, along with other lizard specimens, is kept in a cabinet in the American Museum of Natural History. LEAD: NBC News said yesterday that it would broadcast on the ''Today'' show this morning a report about a Federal investigation of the aerospace industry that includes information critical of the General Electric Company, which owns NBC.
LEAD: A Federal court jury convicted a former Boeing Company marketing executive today on 39 counts arising from his possession of secret Pentagon budget documents.
LEAD: In this city where glitter and glitz are dirty words, residents are trying to sort out how redevelopment has lit up their skyline with a hotel only Liberace could love.

LEAD: Just before Mark Jackson went to the free-throw line for a second time in 47 seconds Wednesday night in the Knicks' 113-98 loss to the Boston Celtics, Paul Silas, an assistant coach, yelled over the din of the Boston Garden crowd, ''Confidence, Mark! Confidence, Mark!''
LEAD: Stocks moved broadly lower yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.99 points, to 2,720.78.

LEAD: The battleship U.S.S. Iowa, its No. 2 turret still sealed after an April explosion that killed 47 sailors, arrived today to cheers from the crew's family and friends after a six-month deployment in the Mediterranean. The crew lined the rail as the Iowa docked at its home port. About 1,000 family members and friends, who greeted the sight of the ship with cheers, waited patiently for her to dock.

LEAD: Dan Alexander, the Jets' right guard, whose 13 years of seniority is surpassed only by the 16 years of Pat Leahy, the place-kicker, and equaled only by Wesley Walker, a receiver, announced his retirement at the end of the season.
LEAD: Government lawyers went to court today to defend the Federal takeover last April of the financially troubled Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

LEAD: A former Federal agent, tried twice for espionage and now free on bail while awaiting a third trial, said today that he had been ''stupid'' for forming the romantic relationship with a young Soviet woman that resulted in the charges against him. But he again asserted his innocence.
LEAD: The British Government yesterday confirmed the appointment of Robert Paul Reid as chairman of the British Railways Board.

LEAD: The flutist Paula Robison is to give the world premiere of Roy Harris's ''Lyric Study'' at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8. The program also includes Aaron Copland's Duo, Robert Beaser's Variations, Samuel Barber's Canzone and ''Melodies Passageres,'' and the New York premiere of Lowell Liebermann's Sonata (Op.
LEAD: Cleaning up the IND subway after a water-main break on Saturday in Harlem may cost $20 million, a transit official said yesterday.
LEAD: The designation of 22 Broadway theaters as landmarks and a companion law that restricts their demolition were upheld yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: As predominantly Muslim areas of Lebanon observed a one-day general strike to show solidarity against Michel Aoun, the rebellious Christian general, rival Shiite militiamen fought today with rocket-propelled grenades and heavy machine guns on the streets of West Beirut.

LEAD: Hank Jones, a pianist, is leading a trio tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow. There is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and $10 admission at the bar.

LEAD: When a visitor rings the doorbell at the apartment of Bishop Jan Korec, there is no sound inside, but a small light goes on in the kitchen. He would not want frequent ringing to be heard by the neighbors upstairs, who for the last eight years have been assigned to keep tabs on Bishop Korec, the leader of the underground church in

LEAD: A landmark of sorts was reached yesterday at the Corroon & Black Corporation when Robert F. Corroon stepped down as chairman and the New York-based insurance brokerage found itself for the first time without a member of the founding Corroon family in top management.

LEAD: Pervis Ellison, the No. 1 choice in this year's National Basketball Association draft, may be unable to play for the Sacramento Kings until mid-March because of tendinitis in his right big toe. Team officials believe the tendinitis developed after Ellison underwent foot and ankle surgery on Sept. 27 and changed his running gait to compensate for soreness in his foot.(

LEAD: An oddly revealing sight in Prague is the Museum of Czech Literature in the ancient Strahov Library. Here visitors are shown the books and authors that supposedly formed the consciousness of a nation - yet Thomas Masaryk is absent, which is like blotting Jefferson from American literature.
LEAD: Soldiers used tear gas and clubs today to disperse 1,000 high school students protesting a coup in which the island nation's president was killed, witnesses said.
LEAD: Only weeks after Oktoberfest, church steeples here have cause for celebration again: the breach in the Berlin wall.

LEAD: Soldiers at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba, fired two shots today at Cuban sentry posts, the official news agency Prensa Latina said. It said the shots broke glass but caused no injuries.

LEAD: The Solidarity-led Government said today that it will not tolerate more demonstrations at a monument to Lenin where anti-Soviet protesters trying to destroy the statue have twice clashed with the police. Protesters hurled paint, gasoline and explosives at the monument and fueled the fire with park benches in a demonstration that lasted until midnight Wednesday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The head of a newly formed advocacy group for people wrongfully convicted has been arrested on Federal drug and conspiracy charges after a Federal agent recognized him in newspaper photographs taken at a fund-raising event.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Iraq was reported to have said today that it has tested a large rocket capable of carrying satellites into space. Such a move would step up the Middle East arms race because missiles that can carry satellites could also be used to carry warheads.

LEAD: The president of the Alabama chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People began serving a four-year jail term here Wednesday on Federal bribery charges. Thomas Reed, 61 years old, was ousted from his seat in the Alabama Legislature after he was convicted in September 1988 of accepting $10,000 as a bribe.

LEAD: Robert T. Schwaegerle, 66, of Westport, Conn., was killed Wednesday and his wife, Beverly, seriously injured as a tire fell off a truck and struck the roof of their car on Interstate 80 in Clearfield County. The car hurtled over an embankment and stopped in a ditch. The tire apparently came from an 18-wheel tractor-trailer, and the truckman might not have been aware what had happened, the State Police said.
LEAD: Robert E. Wallace, a retired insurance executive, died of heart disease on Wednesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived in Summit.
LEAD: What world are they living in, our elected leaders in Washington, our bureaucrats and so many of our academics and journalists?
LEAD: A banner on the outskirts of this Bohemian village says, ''With Soviet Union Forever,'' but the people here want to sell their 20-foot statue of Stalin for Western currency.

LEAD: In the hours before Leonard-Duran III, one of boxing's best fights was developing. But the participants were wearing tuxedos instead of trunks. And the new kid on the block was jabbing two old bullies.
LEAD: The number of New York City households that recycle trash reached one million yesterday in a program that is intended to cover all of the city's three million households by 1992.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the United Nations debate on the Palestine Liberation Organization characterized the Finnish delegation's statement incorrectly. The Finns did not speak on behalf of the Scandinavian countries.
LEAD: The Roman Catholic Church is warily preparing to test its hold on the hearts, the minds and, more to the point, the pocketbooks of Italian taxpayers.
LEAD: The Houston Rockets yesterday waived Lewis Lloyd, who was making a comeback after treatment for cocaine addiction.

LEAD: A search committee of the board of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has reportedly recommended the appointment of James D. Wolfensohn, chairman of Carnegie Hall, as the new chairman of the center.

LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it had completed its purchase of 5 percent of the 3Com Corporation. The move is part of an alliance between the computer companies. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it had acquired its 1.45 million shares for an average of $18.89 each.
LEAD: Research suggests that people who take anabolic steroids to promote muscle growth may become addicted to the drugs, scientists at Yale University have found.

LEAD: The Portland City Council has approved a law that allows the police to seize the automobiles of people who drive while their licenses are suspended because of convictions for drunken driving or those who use their autos for prostitution.

LEAD: Not that anybody expected baseball's labor negotiations to proceed smoothly and quickly, but with the two sides talking on two different planes, the owners and the players will very likely take a long time to get nowhere.

LEAD: Paul Lustig Dunkel will conduct the American Composers Orchestra in the world premiere of Michelle Ekizian's ''Beyond the Reach of Wind and Fire'' and the New York premiere of Frank Ticheli's ''Images of a Storm'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The program also includes Wallingford Riegger's Variations for Piano and Orchestra, with Ruth Laredo as the soloist, and George Rochberg's Symphony No.

LEAD: Although ''Triumph of the Spirit'' is not especially graphic or brutal, it depicts aspects of the concentration-camp experience that are not ordinarily seen on film. And it serves as a reminder of why the tattoos being inflicted, the prisoners being marched to the showers, the release of the poison gas and the bodies on their way to the crematorium are not usually shown.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $431.4 million, to $367.14 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 144 institutional funds decreased by $714.9 million, to $88.58 billion. The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up by $319.6 million, to $119.53 billion.

LEAD: Parents who plan to take children to the movies often find themselves asking what Laurence Olivier asked in ''Marathon Man'': ''Is it safe?'' Seeking out children's films that are diverting and fun is only half the game. The other half is making sure that you aren't awake at 3 in the morning explaining that even though the tree in ''The Wizard of Oz'' got angry at Dorothy for taking an apple, the tree on your front lawn isn't mad at you.
LEAD: MGM Grand Inc. today named Clifford S. Perlman, a former chairman of Caesars World Inc., to head its planned casino and theme park in Las Vegas, Nev.

LEAD: ''As I see so many homeless people on the street, it would give me great satisfaction if these people could be in safe shelters or, better still, homes,'' Eleanore B. Saidenberg of Manhattan wrote in the short note she enclosed this week with her $150 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases

LEAD: Nordstrom Inc., the Seattle-based fashion retailer, will take over the B. Altman store site in White Plains and open its first Westchester County store in 1993, the company said yesterday. Nordstrom, which has been held up as a paragon in emphasizing customer service, will build a new 250,000-square-foot store on the site of the present Altman store of 220,000 square feet in the so-called Million Dollar Mile shopping complex in White Plains.
LEAD: A year after a grand jury declined to indict him, a second grand jury in Bangor today charged a deer hunter with manslaughter in the accidental killing of a 37-year-old woman in her backyard.
LEAD: Surgeons completed the nation's second liver transplant from a living donor tonight, removing part of the liver of a 20-year-old Tennessee man and implanting it in his 15-month-old daughter.
LEAD: ''Our next election is not until 1992. Those who want to be president will have to wait until then.'' - President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines. [ 3:3. ]

LEAD: Overriding strong objections from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, leaders of the European Community took an important step today toward creating a central bank and a common currency for the 12-nation region.

LEAD: East Germany's National People's Army said today that there were no mob attacks on its depots this week. The denial was issued after Radio D.D.R. reported that that such attacks had taken place. A spokesman said that groups showed signs of wanting to attack the depots, perhaps to obtain weapons, but that they did not carry out the attacks.
LEAD: A Soviet research institute is negotiating to become a part owner of a Silicon Valley high-technology company.

LEAD: Because Ken O'Brien, the Jets' quarterback, suffered two concussions and a jammed shoulder and had to be relieved in the team's last three games, Coach Joe Walton has been leaning toward starting Pat Ryan against the Pittsburgh Steelers on Sunday in Giants Stadium. The start would be Ryan's first of the season.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: By almost everyone's reckoning, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has stumbled badly in his initial efforts to rebuild the Soviet economy from the ruins of Stalinist central planning. The 64-billion-ruble question is whether Mr. Gorbachev can succeed in his mission to find an alternative to capitalism that does not clash with the peculiarly Russian sense of order and economic justice.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Delaware County Domestic Relations Court here has devised a new way to find people who fail to pay child support and elude arrest: the court advertises their names on a ''Most Wanted'' list 300 times a week on cable television and once a month in full-page newspaper advertisements.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the dropping of administrative charges against two doctors at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, Luise M. Weinstein and Gregg W. Stone, misstated conclusions of a grand jury that examined the death of 18-year-old Libby Zion after treatment at that hospital. The jury, which issued no indictment, said ''a definitive cause of death cannot be established.
LEAD: Air traffic delays are up dramatically at the New York region's three major airports, even as an increase in air traffic has leveled off.
LEAD: Federal regulators seized New Jersey's largest savings association today after the institution recorded large losses from real estate ventures in New Jersey, Florida and Texas.

LEAD: The Mercury Bay Boating Club, the New Zealand club that lost last year's America's Cup competition to the San Diego Yacht Club, will file its appeal next week before New York state's highest court, club representatives said today.

LEAD: When Norman Steisel became New York City's Sanitation Commissioner in 1978, he inherited a department in chaos. Half the equipment was out of service, the work force was demoralized, there were no long-range plans to cope with a looming garbage crisis, and city streets from Riverdale to Far Rockaway were filthy.

LEAD: The architect Fay Jones has been chosen as the 48th recipient of architecture's highest award, the American Institute of Architects Gold Medal, the A.I.A. announced yesterday. The 58-year-old Mr. Jones, who was Frank Lloyd Wright's apprentice in the 1950's, is to receive the medal on Feb. 22 as part of the Accent on Architecture awards gala at the National Building Museum in Washington.

LEAD: A teen-age drifter who ran away from a Louisiana psychiatric hospital three months ago was arrested yesterday and accused of the fatal stabbing of an advertising executive on the Lower East Side, the police said.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Baseball's players are continuing to indicate that they will reject the owners' plan for a pay-for-performance salary scale, although the players also continue to say they do not yet have enough information to make a judgment on the issue.

LEAD: Researchers at Applied Biosystems of Foster City, Calif., a manufacturer of biotechnology laboratory equipment, have patented what officials call a more accurate method for investigating genetically based illness.

LEAD: In an unusually blunt shoot-out at the top, the Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that Kay R. Whitmore, the company's president, will succeed Colby H. Chandler as chief executive next year and that his chief rival for Mr. Chandler's job, J. Phillip Samper, will retire as vice chairman by the end of the year at the age of 55.

LEAD: An editorial last Saturday mistakenly asserted that Mackinac Island was in the district of Representative Bob Traxler, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee for the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. Traxler bought property on Mackinac and championed a H.U.D.

LEAD: In recent weeks, 10 New York City public school students have been shot, eight fatally. On Halloween, nearly half of New York's high school students stayed home, fearing violence. Since then, store owners, pedestrians and subway riders have been terrorized by ''posses,'' disorderly gangs of youths bent on rowdiness, assault and robbery.

LEAD: A gunman armed with a shotgun and handgun broke into the home of his former wife early today and killed her, their two daughters and her new husband before killing himself, the authorities said.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: C. L. Dellums, a labor and civil rights leader, died of cardiac arrest Thursday in Oakland, Calif., where he had lived for the last 66 years. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: As a child, she says, she was extremely shy, and to this day her mother says, ''Sally never bothered anyone.'' This may surprise those who have worked for and with Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, New York City's Commissioner of Financial Services, who was named yesterday to be deputy mayor for finance and economic development.
LEAD: Israel Unterman, a professor of management at San Diego State University, died Dec. 1 from congestive heart failure at his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 68 years old.
LEAD: As if this proud commercial city didn't have enough problems, word got out recently that Godzilla would be rampaging through town.

LEAD: Midcontinent Airlines Inc., a regional carrier that had been scaled down since Braniff Inc.'s bankruptcy filing, has ceased operations indefinitely. About 35 Midcontinent employees in Kansas City have been laid off, the carrier's chairman, Steve Gillette, said. The carrier had nearly 50 workers in its system, he said.

LEAD: The Federal Government issued a proposal today that creates new obstacles for New York City and other urban areas that seek to correct the 1990 census to make up for undercounting minorities and the poor.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: India's new Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, turned his attention today to New Delhi's most pressing foreign-policy problem: the restoration of good relations with Sri Lanka, where 25,000 Indian troops are stationed against the wishes of the Sri Lankan Government.

LEAD: Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party daily, said yesterday that any article of the Soviet Constitution ''may be reassessed or updated, even to the point of elimination.'' Pravda specifically mentioned Article 6, which insures Communist Party dominanc e. Here is the tex t of Article 6.

LEAD: In Hitler's Shadow West German Historians and the Attempt to Escape From the Nazi Past By Richard J. Evans 196 pages. Pantheon Books. Hard cover, $18.95; paperback, $8.95. Double Indemnity A Memoir By Zofia S. Kubar 208 pages. Hill & Wang. $17.95.

LEAD: The former chairman of a brokerage firm that collapsed after the market crash in October 1987 was convicted yesterday by a Federal jury in Manhattan of participating in a conspiracy to manipulate the prices of three over-the-counter stocks.

LEAD: Albert Scardino, a New York Times reporter who has been named press secretary to Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, was reported yesterday to have met with Mr. Dinkins and campaign aides in the summer to give advice about the campaign.

LEAD: The holiday season is tipping time, and often it is hard to know what is fair or wanted. There are no hard, fast rules for tipping. If someone has been serving you all year and you tip regularly, your gift should reflect that fact as well as the quality of the service. How much you tip also depends on where you live.

LEAD: American and Soviet negotiators ended a 10-week round of arms talks here today with agreement on two joint verification exercises that are to begin well before a strategic arms reduction treaty is signed.

LEAD: For investors considering what year-end moves to make in their portfolios, the watchword from Wall Street experts is prudence. ''Nineteen-ninety may well be a year to sow rather than to reap,'' said Robert J. Farrell, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. ''Rates of return on stocks could well be below average, in general, after 10 years of far above-average returns in the 1980's.

LEAD: Inmates rioted at four prisons today after lawmakers rejected a proposed amnesty for repeat offenders, the authorities said. At least three prisoners died, the Government said, but the circumstances of the deaths were not clear.

LEAD: President Bush still hopes to go to Colombia in February for a regional meeting on narcotics trafficking, but some aides have expressed concern about safety and the Administration is taking another look at security at the proposed site in Cartagena, officials said today.
LEAD: East Germany's writers are not writing much in these turbulent days.
LEAD: Barbara Joelson Fife is a classic case of civic leader become political leader.

LEAD: When Martin Keino, a 17-year-old senior at Fork Union Military Academy in Virginia, suddenly emerged this fall as one of the country's top high school distance runners, there was a logical explanation.

LEAD: Two brothers have patented a new bottle for people who buy soft drinks in economical two-liter containers and want to drink them over time without losing the fizz. Working in their kitchen in Cherry Hill, N.J., Stephen and Robert Tullman have fashioned a bottle that they say keeps 68 percent of its carbonation several hours after being drained half empty, compared with about 19 percent for a conventional bottle.
LEAD: A music review on Wednesday about a concert by the American Chamber Players at the Frick Collection on Sunday misidentified the ensemble's violinist. She is Elisabeth Adkins.

LEAD: An unusual double bill took place here this week: the opening of ''L.A. Art 89,'' the fourth annual Los Angeles art fair, and ''Art Fairs: Plans and Process,'' a two-day symposium convened to discuss the increasing effect of such fairs as they spread throughout the world.

LEAD: The long-running inquiry into Pentagon fraud edged closer to former senior Defense Department officials today when a New York military contracting company admitted in court that it had illegally obtained inside purchasing information from the Navy and Air Force.

LEAD: The executive committee of FIFA, soccer's international governing body, announced today that it would not approve the television contract arranged between the United States Soccer Federation and NBC for the 1994 World Cup tournament, which will be held in the United States.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: President Bush announced today that he would nominate David W. Mullins Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, to be a Federal Reserve Board governor.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins surprised no one when he said yesterday that he would reappoint Mary Schmidt Campbell as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. It was Mr. Dinkins who recommended Ms. Campbell for the job to Mayor Edward I. Koch in the fall of 1987.

LEAD: These days, nurses from Tri-County Home Healthcare Services Inc. in Coral Springs, Fla., sometimes find more than a sick patient when they visit a home. Just-delivered boxes of complex home medical equipment may also clutter the doorstep of the ill.

LEAD: Fodor's 1989 guide to this city says it is a place of ''audacious uniqueness'' where the Declaration of Independence was signed, where people shout ''Yo!'' in greetings and where ''the city's first black Mayor, W. Wilson Goode, made a perverse kind of history by approving the bombing of a neighborhood.

LEAD: Former New York State Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut, the Brooklyn Democrat who was a longtime power in state politics, died early yesterday at the Tisch-University Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: In his bluntest public rejection yet of the profound political and economic changes now sweeping the rest of the Soviet bloc, President Fidel Castro of Cuba has vowed to resist all such reforms even if it means a parting of the ways with his allies.

LEAD: An outside investigator has concluded that conflicts within the Nuclear Regulatory Commission led the agency to pursue a highly unusual investigation of a staff member last year. The conclusion contradicts an assertion by Victor Stello Jr., formerly the commission's chief of staff, that the reason for the inquiry was suspicion of wrongdoing that could affect safety.

LEAD: A response in the Q&A column of Science Times on Tuesday about time zones at the North and South Poles misstated the time difference at the international date line. East of the line, the time is a day earlier, not later.

LEAD: There have been Allens in this Cortland County town since 1817, and Allens on Allen Hill for more than 130 years. For nine generations their sweat and blood have mingled with the town's history, as doctors, carpenters and, for the last six generations, farmers.

LEAD: Whatever else they were saying at a party congress tonight, the East German Communists had really gathered to bury the remnants of a party that had ruled with an iron hand for 40 years, in the hope that something new could still sprout in its place.

LEAD: A state board has decided not to take disciplinary action against four psychologists who were quoted in a newspaper article that speculated about the possible reasons for Kitty Dukakis's depression and alcohol abuse.

LEAD: A theater review on Nov. 15 about the Roundabout Theater Company's production of Shakespeare's ''Tempest'' misinterpreted a gesture. The actors' intent was to portray 18th-century gentlemen taking snuff, not cocaine.

LEAD: As the deadline for initial proposals to purchase Bloomingdale's expired yesterday, the Campeau Corporation said it had received expressions of interest from a number of parties seeking to acquire the chain of 17 stores. A definitive announcement on the sale is expected to be made in February, Campeau added.
LEAD: The Boeing Company said today that its commercial aircraft division would begin offering airlines a new twin-engine jet of a size between the existing 767-300 and 747-400.

LEAD: Republicans can't believe their luck. Gorbachev happened on their watch, yet it makes them nervous. They should be joyous, because in politics you get the credit for good things that happen on your watch and the blame for disasters.

LEAD: CBS's effort to hire Marcy Carsey, one of the producers of ''The Cosby Show'' and two other top-rated television series, as its new president of entertainment ended yesterday when the complicated deal could not be worked out in time to meet a deadline imposed by Laurence Tisch, CBS's chief executive officer.

LEAD: As dusk fell today, Vladimir Sraier, an advertising agent in a gray windbreaker, stood in a large crowd, a lighted candle in hand, at a tawny stuccoed wall in the part of Prague called the Lesser Side.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Black Jack, one of three mules used as mascots at the United States Military Academy, died of stomach cancer on Thursday, just two days before the Army-Navy football game at Giants Stadium. He was 10 years old.
LEAD: In the darkness of the desert night, the new Mirage casino offered an elaborate fireworks display Thursday night as a prelude to its main event.

LEAD: The need to find a nursing home often comes suddenly, requiring quick decisions. Although only 5 percent of the nation's elderly are in nursing homes at any time, about 20 to 30 percent of the population can expect to enter a home during their lifetime.
LEAD: Two Essex County investigators were convicted by a Federal jury today of protecting a drug dealer, who is an admitted killer, in exchange for cocaine, cash and valuables.
LEAD: Col. Bob Denard was cheered as a hero in the Comoro Islands after he pulled off a bold coup in 1978 that returned Ahmed Abdallah Abderemane to the presidency of the Indian Ocean island nation.
LEAD: James D. Squires, editor of The Chicago Tribune since 1981, resigned yesterday and the paper's executive editor, Jack Fuller, was selected to replace him.

LEAD: Susan E. Shepard, who was named yesterday to head the Department of Investigation, may soon find herself in the awkward position of inheriting an investigation of the man who hired her, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins.

LEAD: Jamelle Holieway, former Oklahoma University quarterback, has denied charges that he and Charles Thomas, another Oklahoma quarterback, received cash payments during their collegiate careers, payments originating from a football booster who lived in Tulsa.

LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins named eight appointees to his administration yesterday, including an experienced Federal prosecutor to head the New York City Department of Investigation, with responsibility for uncovering corruption in government.

LEAD: Humans seemed tiny in the huge vaulted space that is St. Ignatius Loyola Church at Park Avenue and 84th Street. The organ droned. The flowers were beautiful. ''Tragic, tragic, tragic,'' said a woman, talking to herself and sobbing.

LEAD: The Communist Party expelled more of the old guard from its leadership today, leaving the ruling Politburo with only three members who were there when Todor Zhivkov was dismissed as party chief on Nov. 10.

LEAD: The Intel Corporation, which has been shifting production to newer factories in other states, said it would phase out its last chip plant in Silicon Valley. Intel, Silicon Valley's largest chip maker, said it would stop building microcircuits at its nine-year-old plant here in the next 18 months and switch the building to other uses.

LEAD: Arrivals and departure delays over 15 minutes have grown sharply at New york area airports this year, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. LaGuardia has one of the worst records in the country. Article, page 27.

LEAD: Pictures of protesters in Prague's Wenceslas Square evoke memories of September 1948, when I last saw crowds massed in that same historic center of the Czech capital. At that time the human flood was held back by an apparently impenetrable chain of armed militiamen.
LEAD: Those stubborn price tags that stick tenaciously to holiday gifts can generally be removed with a little patience and the right remedy.

LEAD: International 3-10 Forming a Czechoslovak cabinet in which half the members do not belong to political parties is the goal of the Acting Prime Minister, he said. This would in effect mean a government in which the Communist Party would be a minority. Page 1 Portrait of top Czech Communists hit by change
LEAD: Helped by early strength in the bond market, stock prices rose modestly yesterday.

LEAD: Domino's Pizza Inc.'s owner, Tom Monaghan, said the company had retained Goldman, Sachs & Company and J. P. Morgan & Company to study the feasibility of an employee stock ownership plan. He said he would decide whether to put an ESOP into effect on completion of the study and would remain as chairman of Domino's if one was adopted.
LEAD: Despite a surge in layoffs and the eighth straight monthly decline in factory jobs, the economy continued to generate jobs in November, the Labor Department reported today.
LEAD: Cynthia Hughes, co-editor and publisher of The Grenada Newsletter, died on Wednesday after a short illness. She was 72 years old, and the cause of death was not made public.

LEAD: In a year in which he peaked in Paris in May, Michael Chang hit a valley in Florida yesterday. Chang, the first American man to win the French Open in 34 years, learned he would be sidelined 6 to 12 weeks after fracturing a hip joint Wednesday in practice for a tournament in Palm Coast this weekend.

LEAD: The president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., called yesterday for a radical overhaul of New York City's decentralized school government, saying the new Schools Chancellor would need ''some basic structural reforms'' to succeed.
LEAD: Bill Lynch may be the only politician in New York City who has gone from chief of a crew of migrant laborers on eastern Long Island to deputy mayor at City Hall.
LEAD: The one thing the Devils need right now, Coach John Cunniff said tonight after his team absorbed its fourth consecutive loss, is patience.

LEAD: This afternoon's Texaco broadcast of Richard Strauss' ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten'' is a milestone for the Metropolitan Opera, opera in America and corporate support for the arts. It begins the 50th season of Saturday matinee grand opera on radio, live from the Metropolitan stage. And it marks the longest continuous sponsorship of any program by one company.

LEAD: The wife of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel laureate who was accused of treason, stripped of his Soviet citizenship and forcibly exiled from his homeland 15 years ago, said today that it was pointless to discuss Soviet offers to restore the author's citizenship because he has no plans to return to the Soviet

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York, Vicky-Anne Faraggi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Faraggi of Montreal, was married yesterday to Andrew Leopold Laszlo Lorant, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Laszlo Lorant of Paris. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Barbara Shay Curran and Norman Thomas MacDonald were married yesterday at the bride's home in Scarsdale, N.Y., by Justice Thomas J. Lowery Jr. of State Supreme Court in Syracuse. Mrs. MacDonald is a daughter of Helen Butler Shay of New Haven and the late Dr. Francis L. Shay. Mr. MacDonald is a son of the late Mr.

LEAD: In what some analysts said was a surprisingly fast rush to the barricades, the Chevron Corporation said today that it had asked a Federal court to force the Pennzoil Company to sell its 8.8 percent stake in Chevron and to block Pennzoil from buying more shares.

LEAD: Some letters in The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund mailbag stand apart because they come from recognizable names, others because they come from unexpected places, still others because they offer a flash of humor in a sea of sympathetic thoughts.

LEAD: Although Canada has witnessed mass killings over the years, none have involved so many deaths, or so profoundly shaken the national psyche, as the rampage this week at the University of Montreal.

LEAD: Kiki Vandeweghe, the Knick forward who has been bothered by back problems and by tendinitis in his left foot, returned to New York from California on Thursday and worked out yesterday at the Knicks' practice center in Purchase, N.Y.
LEAD: Stuart Novins, a CBS news correspondent for 35 years, died of respiratory failure Thursday at Porter Medical Center in Middlebury, Vt. He was 75 years old and lived in Middlebury.
LEAD: A movie producer was arrested yesterday and accused of picking up teen-age boys in New York City housing projects and taking them to New Jersey motels for sex, the police said.

LEAD: At her husband's trial in Yugoslavia's most troubled region recently, Nadira Vlasi compared the hearings to a political style that much of Eastern Europe has given up with bewildering speed in recent months.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities rebounded and yields tumbled yesterday.
