LEAD: Senior army and police officials say a rebel gunrunner has told them that a woman seized last month in a raid on her property knew that a cache of weapons was buried there. The woman, who is being held without bond in a Salvadoran prison, has denied knowing of the arms cache.
LEAD: Artists and intellectuals testified this week in behalf of the first film in Britain to be banned for blasphemy.

LEAD: It was a complete coincidence that I happened to be reading Freud's ''Jokes and Their Relation to the Unconscious'' the day I was summoned to West Germany, not long ago. It was just prior to the eruption of nationalistic feeling, the mutual embrace of the two Germanys, the breach in the wall. Before I left, people kept asking why

LEAD: Seeking to expand trade with the West and bolster its economic efficiency, Hungary has moved to have its trade with the Soviet Union settled in dollars instead of rubles, State Department officials said today.
LEAD: A headline in some copies yesterday on the obituary of a labor and civil rights leader misidentified him.

LEAD: The Cleveland Indians picked up more infield experience yesterday, signing Tom Brookens, a free agent, to a one-year contract. Brookens, 36 years old, spent nine years with the Detroit Tigers and went to the Yankees last March 23 for the pitcher Charles Hudson. He has played third base, shortstop and second, and has a career batting average of .245.

LEAD: Usually, if not always, it is the major rather than the minor artist who acknowledges the existence of mentors. Alvin Ailey, typically, never tired of crediting those who inspired him in the late 1940's to become a professional dancer. These figures were Lester Horton, the modern-dance visionary in Los Angeles who recruited him into his company, and Katherine
LEAD: Stormy weather today forced the postponement of the launching of a Titan 3 rocket with British and Japanese communications satellites.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Vaslav Nijinsky's strange and haunting ballet ''L'Apres-midi d'un Faune,'' created in 1912 for Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, has enjoyed new popularity in recent years. But is the popular version entirely authentic? Ann Hutchinson Guest, the founder and former director of the Dance Notation Bureau in New York, says it is not.

LEAD: In all the years since Cain and Abel threw boxing's first punches, Sugar Ray Leonard will be the first to reign as a champion on the last day of a decade after having reigned as a champion on the first day of the same decade. With his agile artistry again deflating Roberto Duran, in a unanimous 12-round decision, he will enter 1990 as the World Boxing
LEAD: South Korea and the Soviet Union today announced an unusual form of consular relations that many analysts consider a significant step toward establishing full diplomatic relations.

LEAD: He occupies a luxurious office as head of a major Czechoslovak Communist Party institution and is driven around in a black Tatra, a limited-production automobile assigned as a perk to the leaders of the nation.

LEAD: Government lawyers, trying to justify a Federal takeover last April of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, argued in court today that the company had attempted a number of times to portray itself as profitable when it was not.

LEAD: Because Giuseppe Sinopoli is frequently mentioned as a possible successor to Zubin Mehta as music director of the New York Philharmonic, his guest appearances at the head of the orchestra excite more than routine curiosity. In some respects, the bushy-bearded Italian is a puzzle, a conductor who is fascinated by the largest and gaudiest pieces in the repertory but does not seem to have a natural affinity for such extravagance.
LEAD: East Germany's Communist Party met in an emergency congress this morning and debated its own survival, nominating a lawyer as its new chairman.

LEAD: Seeking to forestall internal challenges to its guaranteed leading role in Soviet society, the Communist Party leadership signaled today that the issue is not off limits for discussion but said that such a change would harm the country.

LEAD: The Chicago Bears have placed William (the Refrigerator) Perry, a defensive lineman, and Lemuel Stinson, a cornerback, on the National Football League's injured reserve list for the rest of the season. (AP)
LEAD: A 64-Billion-Ruble Question
LEAD: Rejecting the political changes sweeping through the Soviet bloc, President Fidel Castro said Cuba will embrace hard-line Communism to the end.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article and a headline yesterday about the Social Security Administration referred incorrectly in some editions to a Government assistance program from which people were suspended. It was the Supplemental Security Income Program, covering poor people who are aged, blind or disabled; the people were not suspended from the Social Security program.

LEAD: New computers have arrived at the United States Postal Service in time to speed some holiday lines. They are not everywhere yet, but the new devices handle virtually all of the manual transactions once performed by the clerk.

LEAD: The first step toward determining the 1989-90 College Champions was taken Nov. 21, when six teams in a field of 22 qualified for playoffs in Fort Worth, Tex. in March. Competing there will be, in qualifying order, Harvard, Virginia, Brown, Illinois, Caltech and Rice, who survived ''Instant Imp'' contests on their own campuses.

LEAD: N.B.A. Nuggets 103, Celtics 102: Michael Adams scored 18 of his 20 points in the second half as Denver overcame a 16-point deficit last night at Boston Garden. Trailing by 1 point, Boston got the ball with 23 seconds left when Larry Bird won a jump ball from Adams. But Kevin McHale missed a 12-foot jumper with 5 seconds left and the ball bounced off the rim and rolled to midcourt as time ran out.(AP)

LEAD: The militancy that has made workers' movements so conspicuous in the struggle for human rights in Eastern Europe, China and Latin America shows incipient signs of resurgence in the U.S. trade unions for the first time since Ronald Reagan fired 11,500 striking Federal air traffic controllers and smashed their union in 1981.
LEAD: Victor A. Kovner met David N. Dinkins when they were both Democratic district leaders in the 1960's, establishing a lasting friendship and political alliance.
LEAD: The Bush Administration today confirmed Iraq's statement that the Baghdad Government has launched a rocket capable of putting a satellite in orbit.
LEAD: It has been an awful two weeks for Phil Simms, the Giants' quarterback.

LEAD: Czechoslovakia's acting Prime Minister, in his second day in office, said tonight that he wanted half his cabinet to be made up of people outside political parties. Such a cabinet would put the Communists in a minority and go a long way toward meeting opposition demands.
LEAD: Of the Nets' five victories this season, tonight's was the most unexpected and the most satisfying.

LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to exchange agricultural experts in the next two years. The agreement calls for the exchange of teams in forestry, agricultural economics, agricultural science and food processing, the United States Undersecretary of Agriculture, Richard T. Crowder, said.

LEAD: Nothing is more unfashionable than yesterday's victims. This is the fate of more than 50,000 Vietnamese boat people now threatened with forced repatriation from refugee camps in Hong Kong. No longer ''victims of Communist tyranny,'' they are merely ''illegal immigrants,'' in the words of Prime Minister Thatcher of Britain.

LEAD: Five hours after beginning deliberations, a Circuit Court jury in Pontiac, Mich., yesterday found Reggie Rogers, a former Detroit Lions defensive end, guilty on three reduced counts of negligent homicide in the deaths of three teen-agers on Oct. 20, 1988, in a car accident involving Rogers. Circuit Judge Gene Schnelz scheduled sentencing for Jan.

LEAD: A tiny portion of the children who are vaccinated against whooping cough, a sometimes fatal childhood illness, suffer severe side effects that leave them brain-damaged or dead. Using a newly patented gene, researchers are now developing a vaccine without the dangers of the original one.

LEAD: In her first public appearance since the Philippine Government was nearly toppled, an angry President Corazon C. Aquino today named three men - the country's Vice President, its chief opposition leader and her own cousin - as the leading suspects in the abortive rebellion.

LEAD: Joe Reekie, the Islander defenseman who has been an important part of the team's four-game string of victories, broke two bones in his left hand in a car accident in Huntington, L.I., early yesterday and could miss four weeks of play.

LEAD: Robert W. Schleck, a former foreign service officer, teacher and research analyst who conducted studies on economic issues in New York City, died of cardiac arrest on Nov. 29 at Leland Memorial Hospital in Riverdale, Md. He was 64 years old and lived in Mount Rainier, Md.. After graduating from
LEAD: Dr. Esther Greenbaum, a psychiatrist and educator, died of cancer Wednesday at Bronx Calvary Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

LEAD: ''The mayor of New York City is the second most important political figure in the country when it comes to setting the tone of public discourse,'' Albert Scardino said yesterday. ''To be able to help shape that tone is a truly remarkable opportunity for someone interested in public policy, which I am.

LEAD: There were tears and laughter, public praise and personal anecdote as some 4,500 people commemorated Alvin Ailey yesterday in ''The Celebration of Alvin Ailey Jr., Going Home,'' a memorial and funeral service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The modern-dance choreographer and founder and director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater died of a blood disorder on Dec.
LEAD: May Garelick McClintock, an author and editor of children's books, died of cancer Wednesday at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.

LEAD: To Stephen and Maritza French, the Japanese businessman boarding in their home for six weeks seemed a polite guest who worked at improving his English and even volunteered to help wash the family car.

LEAD: For the last four and a half years, Tomasz Starzewski, a 28-year-old Londoner, has designed evening wear that has been sold in stores like Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's. But until this fall, almost no one outside a coterie of affluent clients had heard of him.
LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a law today banning the sale of assault weapons in Boston and said he would like to see more gun control across Massachusetts and the nation.
LEAD: Because of incorrect information supplied by Lenz Riecker Publishers, the Q & A column on Nov. 5 misstated the number to use when ordering a copy of the New York State Rent Stabilization Code.

LEAD: When Tom and Julia Berry decided to build a house two years ago, they didn't think too long or hard before deciding to have to it built of logs. After all, they had been married in a log cabin in Maine's northern woods.

LEAD: According to the New York Times stylebook, the eight-day Jewish Feast of Lights that celebrates the victory of the Maccabees and begins at nightfall of Dec. 22 this year, is spelled Hanukkah. Two k's.

LEAD: YOUNG people in the county in need of help with a wide variety of problems ranging from drug and alcohol abuse to how to get a driver's license and prepare for college entrance examinations can now turn to an 82-page countywide directory.

LEAD: That brilliant though eccentric theoretician Aron Nimzovich more than a half-century ago advised that the player should take a stand, espouse a cause, set himself to prove a thesis rather than look at strategy dispassionately. There is a lot to be said for that partisan approach because it mobilizes energy and enthusiasm.

LEAD: IN September a submarine-sandwich shop opened here on Sussex Street. Every day since, the small restaurant and takeout business has attracted lunch crowds of St. Michael's Hospital employees and students from the New Jersey Institute of Technology and Rutgers University across the street.

LEAD: Simply mention Sunday dinner in the presence of a bona fide French gastronome and his wide-eyed, sentimental expression will tell all. With his descriptions, you can almost taste the glistening poulet doti, hear the quiet simmering of the pot-au-feu, smell the faint sweetness of a quatre-quarts aux poires warm from the oven.
LEAD: THE HARVEY GIRLS Women Who Opened the West. By Lesley Poling-Kempes. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: Paragon House. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Knicks should play Jackson and Strickland together. When they play together, there is increased player and ball movement with an open man often in position to make an easy basket. RICHARD J. KITTRELL New York

LEAD: INCORPORATED in 1670 on the same 39.6 square miles of the Quinnipiac River Valley that it occupies today, Wallingford is one of Connecticut's oldest towns and one of the most stable. The scent of its early agricultural economy still drifts downwind from the handful of remaining dairy farms where cows graze, withered cornstalks rustle in the wind and pumpkins dot the wintry fields.

LEAD: The National Hockey League announced yesterday that it planned to expand from 21 teams to 28 teams in the next decade. The expansion would be the biggest since the N.H.L. doubled in size in 1967, from 6 to 12 teams.

LEAD: WITNESS TO HISTORY: A Refugee from the Third Reich Remembers. By Joachim von Elbe. (Max Kade Institute for German-American Studies/University of Wisconsin, $18.95.) Through the eyes of Joachim von Elbe one sees the agonizing history of various Germanies: the Imperial Germany of the Kaisers, the turbulent Weimar Republic, the despotic Third Reich, then the Federal Republic, whose fundamental laws the author helped codify.
LEAD: Two men, both immigrant workers from El Salvador, and a woman in her 60's died yesterday in two hit-and-run auto accidents, one on Long Island and the other in the Bronx, the authorities said.

LEAD: Waving banners and chanting ''Inocente!'' supporters today rallied to the defense of William Lozano, the Colombian-born policeman who was convicted of manslaughter in the deaths of two black men.

LEAD: GONE WITH THE WIND The Definitive Illustrated History of the Book, the Movie, and the Legend. By Herb Bridges and Terryl C. Boodman. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: Fireside/Simon & Schuster. Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $14.95. GONE WITH THE WIND The Screenplay. By Sidney Howard. Based on the novel by Margaret Mitchell.
LEAD: CALIFORNIANS are begining to learn what Texans did five years ago and New Yorkers more recently: that what goes up in real estate may also come down.

LEAD: As Zimbabwe approaches its celebration of a decade of independence, people here are increasingly apprehensive that their country, which in the view of some has been relatively democratic, is following the political pattern of many other African nations.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about seasonal TV programming for younger viewers omitted the date for the initial WNET broadcast of ''The Adventures of Alice in Wonderland.'' The program will be shown at 6 P.M. on Sunday, Dec. 24.

LEAD: Igor Stravinsky's opera ''The Rake's Progress'' (1951) is a monument to artifice. Determinedly awash in what the composer called ''the early cliches I have tried to re-establish,'' the libretto of W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman echoes almost every device of 18th-century opera, and the score revels in the results of Stravinsky's three-year immersion in Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte.

LEAD: New Yorkers who revel in the historic details of the neighborhoods they know and love will soon have 15 new plaques to read that mark famous places in the Times Square area. The Municipal Art Society, which is placing the markers in a continuing project entitled ''The Sidewalks of New York,'' is to unveil two on Thursday at 3:30 P.M.
LEAD: An answer in the Q.&A. column on Nov. 26 misstated the registration fee for the Global Home Exchange and Travel Service. It is $35.

LEAD: The farming community of Taylor, N.Y., is sharply divided over the prospect of a nuclear waste dump being located in the area: it's Arthur Allen versus everybody else. Mr. Allen, who says he can no longer make a living from his 730-acre dairy farm in upstate New York, is the only person in New York State who has said he is willing to sell his land for use as a low-level nuclear waste dump.

LEAD: Neil Reynolds Cronin of East Dennis, Mass., has made known the engagement of his daughter Maura Ann Cronin to Matthew Powers Connolly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Connolly of Weston, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe, predictable world a man has built for himself and his family. 2 2 6 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King.

LEAD: Alvin Ailey was at the peak of his creative power when he died, on Dec. 1, at the age of 58. Yet he, more than most of his generation in dance, had accomplished what he set out to do. And those accomplishments had a resounding impact on modern dance.

LEAD: Close to 2,000 guests climbed the Fifth Avenue steps of the Metropolitan Museum Monday night to pay homage to ''The Age of Napoleon,'' the new Costume Institute exhibit. About 700 guests, the women in couture dresses, dined and were joined later by 1,200 others in eclectic dress for dancing and drinks.
LEAD: An article last Sunday by a Polish journalist on European security needs misspelled the author's name.
LEAD: No Caddies Need Apply
LEAD: Saving a Colorful Past
LEAD: American households have shrunk to their smallest ever, but they are not shrinking as fast as they were a few years ago, Census Bureau officials say.

LEAD: The engagement of Jennifer Sherburne Kuhn to Charles Parson Irwin 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin 3d of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. John F. Raynolds 3d of Stamford, Conn., and Ascutney, Vt., and Jay C. Kuhn of Belvedere, Calif. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: I was surprised to read that Wolfgang Puck said he does not like to eat in bed (Food: ''Crumbs in the Covers,'' by Linda Wells, Nov. 12). When Wolf and his wife, Barbara, visited us for a few days, I took a picture of them eating a breakfast in bed of hot chocolate souffle with whipped cream and raspberries.

LEAD: COMPARED with some of the orgiastic, rum-drenched singles resorts that have flourished in the Caribbean in recent years, Sandals, a couples-only club in Ocho Rios, seems like a religious seaside retreat. That's not to say that there aren't a lot of bibulous fraternity-bash shenanigans at night, but the difference is that at Sandals the mirthmakers return to the dorm under their own power, and with their wives or steady girl friends.
LEAD: Who was Jackie Robinson, and why is it that so many know so little about him?

LEAD: ''Rod Stewart: Storyteller/The Complete Anthology: 1964-1990'' (Warner Bros. 25987, four CD's only) is an attempt to do for Mr. Stewart what ''Decade'' did for Neil Young and, not that he really needed it, ''Biograph'' did for Bob Dylan. In other words, it aims to tie a diverse career together and make a serious case for its subject.

LEAD: THE BLUE VALLEYS. By Robert Morgan. (Peachtree, $15.95.) The strong, pungent stories in ''The Blue Valleys,'' a first collection by the poet Robert Morgan, are set in the Blue Ridge Mountains of North Carolina, whose hills and valleys are a sturdy home for his characters, mostly working people at the mercy of circumstance.

LEAD: Who was climbing onto Jim Mora's back? The Saints' coach was rapt in the football game, peering from the sidelines, as his team was routing the Tampa Bay Buccaneers with two minutes remaining. Suddenly, someone leaped onto Mora and gave him a bear hug.

LEAD: Along the sidelines at Alumni Hall last night in the first half of the St. John's-Hofstra game, Lou Carnesecca winced repeatedly, paced nervously and, watching his players falter on defense, shouted, ''Don't lose him, don't lose him.''

LEAD: Bryan Dameworth, a senior from Calabasas, Calif., and Melody Fairchild, a junior from Boulder, Colo., won national titles today in the Kinney High School cross-country championships. Dameworth completed an unbeaten season by outkicking Andrew Maris of Buckley, Wash., with 250 yards left to triumph by 11 seconds in 14 minutes 49.9 seconds for 5,000 meters.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Gretchen Anne Maier and Timothy Alba Teran were married in New York yesterday in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral by Kenneth Clancy, a Roman Catholic deacon. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Maier of Norristown, Pa. Mr. Teran is a son of Eric Alba Teran D'Antin of New York and the late Patricia

LEAD: The quarterback, Dan Sharley, scored on two short runs today, leading Dayton to a 17-7 victory over Union in the Amos Alonzo Stagg Bowl and the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III football championship.
LEAD: To the Editor: ''Confessions of a Seat Strategist'' by K. C. Cole (Travel, Oct. 22) was more whimpering than strategy.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev rebuffed growing demands for early action to end the Communist Party's monopoly on political power, warning against an ''emotional'' rush to alter the Soviet Constitution. Page 30.

LEAD: By all accounts, the International Business Machines Corporation is in trouble. Drastic measures are now in order if it is to keep its dominance in computers. Some would even argue that the time has finally arrived for it to drop its stubborn preoccupation with the mainframe, maybe even spin off its minicomputers.

LEAD: FOUR months ago, Congress swallowed hard and approved the largest Federal bailout on record, the rescue plan for the savings and loan industry that will spend $159 billion over the next decade. But already financial experts are warning that lawmakers are not finished with the problems of the industry.
LEAD: More than anyone else, Jan Carnogursky, a slight, diffident Slovak lawyer and civil-rights campaigner, personifies the rapid dismantling of one-party Communist rule in Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is weighing whether to file criminal charges against Eastern Airlines on the basis of allegations that the company failed to insure that planes were being properly maintained at Kennedy International Airport, company officials said yesterday.

LEAD: His intent as a photographer is clear. ''I like to take something that everybody sees in a pejorative way and make a diamond out of it,'' said Simon Bocanegra, a 40-year-old French photographer who is having his first show in the United States.

LEAD: The marriage of Fran Melanie Farber, the daughter of Rosalind Farber of North Woodmere, L.I., and the late Sydney Farber, to Dr. Paul Mitchell Glat, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jay Glat of New York and White Plains, took place last evening at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere. Rabbi Paul Siegel officiated.
LEAD: Doug Scovil, the quarterbacks coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, died of a heart attack yesterday. An obituary appears on page 60 of Section 1.

LEAD: IT APPEARS THAT I WILL NOT HAVE A CHILD. I AM 41 years old, and even I have to admit that the possibility, now, is remote. Still, I cannot quite bring myself to say, ''I will not have a child.'' And so I hedge: It appears that. . . .

LEAD: MIDWAY through our 30's, my husband and I have managed to acquire an advantage that's rare in our generation: we have a low overhead. Each month, the mortgage we pay is a relatively small portion of our total income.

LEAD: IF the Communists thought at the outset that they could survive in power by chucking a few corrupt old officials out the palace window to placate the baying mob, this past week showed how wrong they were.
LEAD: JULIAN'S HOUSE By Judith Hawkes. 354 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $18.95.

LEAD: The Armenian Philharmonic's appearance at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night was as much an expression of need as of accomplishment. The stated purpose of the orchestra's three-city visit to this country is to raise money for rebuilding after the vicious earthquake of exactly a year ago. Usually the visits of such Eastern-bloc ensembles have been carefully orchestrated expressions of national pride.

LEAD: ON THE EDGE: The Life and Times of Francis Coppola. By Michael Goodwin and Naomi Wise. (Morrow, $22.95.) The film director Francis Ford Coppola has grappled with the conflict between art and commerce throughout his career, according to Michael Goodwin, a film journalist, and Naomi Wise, the film critic for San Francisco Focus, in ''On the Edge.

LEAD: Q. I installed some insulation under the floor over my crawl space. This insulation has a vapor barrier on one side, and so I removed the plastic vapor barrier sheets that originally covered the earth floor in the crawl space. Umberto has now written ''Foucault's Pendulum,'' a novel that is seducing the American literary establishment but was at the center of a heated, yearlong critical debate in Italy.

She is the office coordinator at Jenks & Partners, producers of television commercials in New York.

LEAD: TALENT and perseverance will out, as the chef Patrick Benrezkellan and the co-owner and maitre d'hotel Patrick Ravanello, both formerly with Guy Savoy in Greenwich, have demonstrated so ably in transforming a good South Norwalk storefront delicatessen and bistro called Cafe Parfait into La Provence, an excellent

LEAD: It's true that we should be grateful for everything given us. It's true, to a certain degree at least, that it's the thought that counts. But once these truisms are out of the way, it's time to get down to the nitty-gritty. And that is when it comes to gift-giving, there are people, lots of them, who give something they themselves would like to own.
LEAD: My eye caught the headline ''Many Issues Neglected in Race for Governor'' (Oct. 22), and the thought occurred to me that the word ''issue'' has undergone change in current usage.

LEAD: IT is only one small building, but the transformation in progress at a vacant and rundown five-story walk-up at 460 Convent Avenue, at the corner of 150th Street in central Harlem, has something to say about the way gut-rehabilitated housing can be produced for low-income working people and the homeless in New York
LEAD: NEAR THE MAGICIAN A Memoir of My Father, Edmund Wilson. By Rosalind Baker Wilson. Illustrated. 287 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $18.95.
LEAD: Timothy Donohue realized that many of his classmates think of World War II as something in ancient history, not something that began for the United States only 48 years ago.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I enjoyed Patrick Cooke's article on changing American dialects (''Are Accents Out? Hey Dude, Like NEH-oh Way!'' Nov. 19). It brought back fond memories of my childhood summers on a beach in southern Maine. The perfect icebreaker for renewing old friendships and making new ones was to acknowledge - and often poke fun at - one another's regional accents.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In the last six weeks, two Houston police officers have shot and killed motorists after traffic stops. Two other officers were found guilty in rape cases. One more was arrested for heroin possession, one was charged with coercing sex from a prostitute, one was reassigned amid charges of police harassment and two officers' houses were searched as part of a drug investigation.

LEAD: CLASSICAL Mozart: Piano Sonatas (K. 309, 457), Fantasies (K. 396, 397, 475) Cyprien Katsaris, piano. Teldec CD 244 191; CD only. This is not your usual Mozart. Mr. Katsaris makes no attempt to imitate a fortepiano or play a ''Classic'' Mozart. He feels the music Romantically and uses plenty of pedal (without any blurring) and large washes of color.
LEAD: MOST parents expect their eating habits to change with the arrival of offspring, but few are prepared for exactly how dramatic that change will be.

LEAD: When the United States returns to World Cup soccer action in June after an absence of 40 years, it will play in the same group as Italy, which is the host team and one of the world's soccer powers.

LEAD: The Harlem end of Central Park would get a new restaurant, cafeteria and catering hall - with room for nearly 400 people - under a proposal that has been approved by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.
LEAD: There are some sports that Ralph Lauren doesn't have a lock on yet. In bowling it's Ralph Kramden who sets a style that is newly popular with many young people.

LEAD: The Government has refused to grant residency to a former Salvadoran policeman who has been living in the United States for eight years and is currently on a hunger strike to protest American military aid to his native country.

LEAD: The engagement of Pamela Chapman Borthwick to Shannon Melvin Bass, a son of Patricia Bass of Whidbey Island, Wash., and Stanley Bass of Del Mar, Calif., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Borthwick of Pinehurst, N.C. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Louisiana Superdome in November of last year was the site of a deep soul-searching session by the Denver Broncos. They had just been destroyed by the New Orleans Saints, 42-0, and had fallen to 6-6. And what the Broncos would not say about the debacle, the Saints' quarterback, Bobby Hebert, would.

LEAD: THE progression is predictable. Someone strolls down Greenwich Avenue in Greenwich and notices activity in the window of the Complete Kitchen. He stops to observe a man presiding over a machine, making chocolate truffles. Another man, wielding a silver tray of the delectables, smiles and waves from inside.
LEAD: France and Spain are tracking down a pro-Iranian Lebanese terrorist network that had planned a series of attacks in this country over the holidays, French security officials say.
LEAD: Singapore's Tough Stance On Smoking

LEAD: Government mints around the world are making a nice profit honoring everything from the panda to sporting events. Buried within this marketing morass are several small groups that are marketing medals as e art first and commemorative pieces second.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In 1960 THE ARCHITECTURAL PHO-tographer Julius Shulman took a picture of a glass house perched high in the Hollywood Hills that will always be, for me, one of those singular images that sums up an entire city at a moment in time. The house is sleek and white, and its glass walls are cantilevered out over the hills; two elegantly dressed women lounge inside as the lights of the vast sprawl of the Los Angeles basin twinkle below.

LEAD: After years of writing bizarre criminal tales set in modern-day Hong Kong and Manila, William Marshall has discovered another teeming city and another tumultuous era to suit his flamboyant style - New York in the late 19th century. THE NEW YORK DETECTIVE (Mysterious Press, $17.95) introduces Detective Virgil J.

LEAD: IN Connecticut, it can sometimes be a challenge not only to get from here to there, but also even to know where there is, or when you've actually arrived there. When I first came to live in central Connecticut in 1977, the number of localities with similar sounding names complicated my becoming familiar with the lay of the land.
LEAD: Eastern Europe's shifting political map has left Turkey wondering from the sidelines whether it will end up a diplomatic loser when the dust settles.

LEAD: L. William Seidman, who manages the special regulatory agency created to liquidate and find buyers for the troubled properties held by failed savings institutions, said today that about 40,000 properties were being prepared for sale in 1990. About half, he said, are in Texas and Oklahoma.

LEAD: Perhaps the only major chemical company that remains very vulnerable to the commodity-chemical cycle is the Union Carbide Corporation. As part of a restructuring aimed at warding off a 1984 takeover attempt by the GAF Corporation, Carbide sold its consumer products businesses, its agricultural businesses and most of its European operations.

LEAD: Q. I installed some insulation under the floor over my crawl space. This insulation has a vapor barrier on one side, and so I removed the plastic vapor barrier sheets that originally covered the earth floor in the crawl space. I would now like to cover the earth floor with something else so that I can store things there.

LEAD: The engagement of Linda Mary Longo to Richard Bryan Hirsch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto J. Hirsch of Florissant, Mo., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James A. Longo of Franklin Lakes, N.J. An October wedding is planned. Miss Longo, 23 years old, is an editor at McCall's magazine in New York.

LEAD: A PHOTOGRAPH of a tree is included in the Hudson River Museum of Westchester's current exhibition here: ''Field to Factory: Afro-American Migration 1915-1940.'' The picture seems quite ordinary until one reads the caption: ''Hanging Tree, New Madrid, Missouri.''

LEAD: ''Why not? My mother lives in Vienna,'' is how Peter Sellars answered Ernst Neuspiel, production chief of Austrian Television, during an intermission last year at the Pepsico Summerfare festival in Purchase, N. Y., when Mr. Neuspiel invited the prolific 31-year-old stage director to Vienna to videotape his iconoclastic productions of three Mozart operas.

LEAD: Stacey Elaine Athans, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Athans of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday in Hempstead, L.I., to Leonidas George Demas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Demas of Holiday, Fla. The Rev. Nicholas J. Magoulias officiated at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Paul.
LEAD: The trade mart never had a chance. Its cousin, the free-agent market, overwhelmed everything and everyone in its relentless path.
LEAD: PETE ROSE My Story. By Pete Rose and Roger Kahn. Illustrated. 300 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.

LEAD: In the heartland of Brazil's German descendants, an uproar has erupted in recent weeks over a new publishing house that specializes in Portuguese-language books denying the Nazi genocide of World War II.

LEAD: FOUR communities will ring in the new year with town-wide festivities that are heavy on the performing arts and music but light on alcohol. The New Year's Eve festivities, which are modeled after the First Night celebration in Boston, will be held in Danbury, Hartford, New Haven and Stamford.

LEAD: The United States Postal Service is completing a month-long market test of a 25-cent self-stick stamp that does not have to be licked. Avoiding this nuisance costs a little under 3 cents a stamp. The test sites are Atlanta; Chicago; Cleveland; Columbus, Ohio; Dallas; Denver; Houston; Indianapolis; Kansas City, Mo.; Los Angeles; Miami; Milwaukee; Minneapolis; Phoenix and St.

LEAD: The engagement of Catherine Ann Grunewald and Brian John Collins has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John D. Grunewald of Chatham Township and Spring Lake, N.J. Mr. Collins is a son of Prof. John Collins and Titia Collins, both of Cazenovia, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

LEAD: Doug Scovil, the coach credited with developing Randall Cunningham into the starting quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles, died of a heart attack today at Veterans Stadium. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: SINCE the 15th century, when their navigators discovered how to steer ships by the stars, the Portuguese have been world travelers. Their voyages have left a legacy of Portuguese language and culture in romantic places like Macao, Goa, Mozambique and Farmingville.

LEAD: The City University of New York is entering a period of transition as it searches for a new chancellor, tries to replace many of its aging college presidents and prepares for a turnover of almost 2,000 faculty members in the next few years.
LEAD: ''If I knew then what I know now,'' M. Danny Wall, the chief savings and loan regulator, lamented shortly before his resignation last week as director of the Office of Thrift Supervision.

LEAD: Three hospitals and a drug-treatment center in New York City have been sued for refusing to provide drug and alcohol treatment to pregnant women. The case, brought by the Women's Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union and the New York Civil Liberties Union in a class-action suit, is thought to be the first in the nation to challenge exclusion of pregnant women from drug programs, a widespread practice.
LEAD: IRA Penalty
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has approved the state-by-state spending allotments that the National Guard will use for its expanded role in the national war against drugs.

LEAD: The Philadelphia Phillies have signed the right-hander Ken Howell to a one-year contract worth $615,000 after he posted a 12-12 record last season, tying Jeff Parrett for the team's leadership in victories. Howell was not a free agent, but could have taken the club to salary arbitration. Last season, his first with the Phillies after being acquired in the off season from Baltimore, the 29-year-old Howell made $225,000.

LEAD: ANTHONY M. MOSCA, the County Police Commissioner who was recently rebuked by a state commission for his intervention in a drug arrest involving a family friend, was acting in a police undercover operation that the District Attorney's office said last week had serious weaknesses.

LEAD: THE debate about the ''end of history'' has not come to an end. Francis Fukuyama, the State Department official who declared the end of the ideological struggle between East and West in an article last summer in The National Interest, has responded to his critics, and taken the argument a step further.

LEAD: DO you sometimes wonder why television and print media remind us again and again about the needs of gifted or handicapped children with scarcely a mention about the needs of most children: our average children?
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the statement today by the leaders of the European Community:
LEAD: Dear Editor:

LEAD: HALF a dozen lawyers from around the state gathered at the Attorney General's Office in Hartford last month to open the book on a series of narrow legal questions that will reverberate in Connecticut through 1990 and perhaps beyond: How many people might have had their telephone conversations improperly recorded by the state police over the last 15 years?

LEAD: ''WHAT is radio theater, and isn't it supposed to be dead anyway?'' David Ossman, whose resume lists his talents as ''radio producer, director and trainer; narrations, voice-overs and characters,'' was asked just that question during a recent performing and teaching gig, as he called it.

LEAD: After nearly a century of broad strides in irrigation, the world is now facing mounting problems of water scarcity accompanied by rising costs for new projects and widespread environmental damage that irrigation can cause, a new study concludes.
LEAD: ''THE KING AND I'' has left Connecticut, but in our home the memories and the music linger on. Peter, age 7, is consumed with the theater. He is totally stage-struck.

LEAD: SOMETIME between its headline-snaring decisions about flag burning and about abortion limits, the United States Supreme Court handed down a decision affirming the right of New York City to limit the volume of rock concerts in Central Park's open-air bandshell. With luck, the precedent will ripple out to communities everywhere, eventually reducing some of the torment imposed on captive audiences by mega-decibel noise.

LEAD: In a slack market for initial public offerings in technology, many analysts are toasting this month's coming debut of MIPS Computer Systems Inc. Investors might find that it is best to join the party now, buying during the offering but maybe selling before others take a sober look at MIPS's long-term prospects.

LEAD: Clifford T. Honicker's chilling account of Louis Slotin's, S. Allan Kline's et al encounter with the Nuclear Age is as horrific as it is emblematic of the lengths to which many will go to protect the nuclear industry (in which many of the Fortune 500 are involved) and the ideology of maintaining a strong and nuclear-based national defense at any cost.

LEAD: Less than two weeks have passed since Vladimir Horowitz's death, and Shura Cherkassky - the 78-year-old Russian-born, London-based pianist who is playing a recital at Avery Fisher Hall today at 3 - finds himself described with increasing frequency by concert reviewers as the last representative of the Romantic school of pianism.
LEAD: Speeches by leaders of two black groups have prompted a march on the president's office at Trinity College and the first complaint filed under the college's new racial-harassment policy.

LEAD: Three cribs, a twin bed, a specially constructed wheelchair, a bassinet and a small, brightly decorated Christmas tree all compete for a space in the living room of Rosa and Anthony C.'s fifth-floor walk-up.

LEAD: Dr. Laurie P. Salitan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark A. Salitan of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening at the Regency in New York to Marc Alan Kushner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour W. Kushner of Wellesley, Mass. Rabbi Melissa F. Crespy officiated.

LEAD: In the mid-1860's, officers at the United States Naval Academy were disturbed by reports of drinking and carousing by midshipmen. The brass concluded that healthier diversions were needed for the future officers and gentlemen, and football was introduced in 1869. The sport's popularity grew, and in the fall of 1890 Annapolis challenged the United States Military Academy to a game.

LEAD: NOW that ''The Least of These'' has been unveiled by the American Stage Company, it's best not to dwell on it, but hope that the worst of the season is behind us, and that we can get on with our lives.

LEAD: To the Editor: It is unrealistic of Ms. Cole to expect to meet the same sort of charming, tactful, polite and silent people she is undoubtedly used to admitting to her circle of friends, when she is traveling on public transport.
LEAD: Under Stu Jackson, Strickland is dishing for easy baskets, taking better shots, committing fewer turnovers and playing tighter defense.

LEAD: AS the Commissioner of the Department of Motor Vehicles, Lawrence F. DelPonte is charged with implementing Connecticut's new drunken driving law, which will take effect on Jan. 1. It will allow the suspension of a license for as long as two years if a driver refuses to submit to a blood alcohol test or if test results show the driver is intoxicated.

LEAD: An outlaw image clings to popular music regardless of how many benefits it puts on, how often it parades high-minded sentiments, no matter how much it accommodates itself to movies, television and advertising.

LEAD: REPORTS of a Federal inquiry into a stock transaction by Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins passed like a dark cloud through City Hall last week, breaking the rhythm of the transition, provoking surly confrontations with reporters and stirring fears of disorganization and drift.

LEAD: N.B.A. Bullets 103, Lakers 101: Mark Alarie hit a driving layup for Washington with 22 seconds left for Washington last night in a game played in Landover, Md. With Washington down by 101-100, Alarie was unable to get off a 10-foot shot, but drove into the lane and scored with a layup over two Los Angeles defenders.(AP)

LEAD: Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, analyzing the reasons leading to the defeat of his Congress Party in general elections last month, has begun wide-ranging changes in the organization by dismissing top party officials.

LEAD: The recent article on the Great Swamp struck a special chord of memory from my youth. I visited the Great Swamp several times as a teen-ager in the late 20's. Although I lived in New York, I had an aunt and uncle who belonged to a semirural community called Chatham Colony, about a mile south of the Lackawanna Railroad, which brought us to

LEAD: Lillian Elizabeth Clarke, a daughter of Mrs. Manuel Rafael Giberga of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Alan T. Clarke of Clarkesville, Md., was married yesterday to Theodore P. Donahue Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donahue of New York, Litchfield, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Richard Peard officiated at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Upperville,
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: It would be inaccurate to say that when I made a fateful decision to defect on Jan. 10, 1985, the circumstances mirrored those of my countrymen now leaving East Germany for the West.

LEAD: A SUBWAY musician's folk tunes were echoing off the walls at the 72d Street IRT subway station the other day. Was the music entertaining or distracting? That burly fellow with the extended hand at the Brooklyn Bridge stop was just asking for help. Or was he hinting that if he did not get a few coins there might be trouble?

LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev is remaking history in the Soviet Union and Europe. With the end of the cold war, George Bush has the same opportunity in the United States - the first chance in 40 years to think seriously about diverting resources from old and rapidly receding threats to a new agenda of urgent needs.
LEAD: While lawyers tend to the legal battle over who should be awarded the America's Cup, a political brushfire in Japan is drawing the attention of potential contenders.

LEAD: I would like to express profound thanks for Clifford Honicker's article. I am one of the survivors of Operation Crossroads. I was on a rescue tug assigned to the salvage unit at Bikini Atoll, in the Marshall Islands. We were back in the lagoon within hours after each of the detonations, performing a variety of damage-control operations.

LEAD: Michael Pye misses the real point, which is that the entire content of a newspaper is virtually gossip (''Low Tales of the Highborn,'' Nov. 12). Take, as an example, the articles about the youths accused in the attack on the Central Park jogger. Anything beyond the fact that an attack took place and that one should attend to one's safety is gossip.

LEAD: IT WAS A SCENE SALVADORANS HAD HOPED THEY WOULD NEVER SEE again. On Nov. 16, while a full-scale battle raged between the Salvadoran Army and leftist rebels in the streets of the capital, the bodies of six Jesuit priests murdered in the night lay strewn across a university campus. A witness said the killers had been soldiers in uniform.

LEAD: SINCE the Tax Reform Act of 1986, equity loans on homes have become one of the few remaining ways to borrow a large sum of money on which interest charges are tax deductible. Thus it has become an increasingly desirable way to finance anything from a new car to college tuition.
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today rebuffed growing demands from inside and outside the Communist Party for early action to end the party's monopoly on the nation's political power.

LEAD: The Knicks are squandering the considerable talents of Mark Jackson. First, Stu Jackson started yanking him in the crucial last minutes of close games. Then the news media hopped on the Jackson-bashing bandwagon, and his confidence has suffered. Jackson has earned his role as playmaker.The Knicks should play Jackson and Strickland together regularly.

LEAD: Never mind that Nadia Comaneci's Rumanian accent makes it difficult for many people here to understand her. Miami's rock-music radio station WXDJ, which calls itself The Breeze FM, wants her to be co-host of its morning talk show.

LEAD: Amy Elizabeth Cherry and Pierre N. Abitbol, associates at the law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher in New York, were married there last evening at Temple Emanu-El by Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich. The bride is a daughter of Jay Leonard Cherry of Hartford and the late Carm Cherry. The bridegroom is a son of Mr.

LEAD: After a turbulent all-night meeting marked by bitterness over abuses of power and privilege by its former leaders, the East German Communist Party this morning elected Gregor Gysi, a 41-year-old lawyer, to the new post of chairman.

LEAD: The spectacular movement for democratization in Eastern Europe, with the highly symbolic collapse of the Berlin wall, will compel us as Europeans to seek a new order. German unification, a taboo subject until a few months ago, is becoming a realistic prospect. After Austria - a neutral country - it will soon be Hungary's turn to request associate status in the European

LEAD: Philip Springer, a veteran New York songwriter who wrote the music for 1950's hits like ''How Little We Know,'' ''Moonlight Gambler'' and ''Santa Baby,'' did not reach his creative peak until a decade ago, when he collaborated with E. Y. (Yip) Harburg on the lyricist's final songs.
LEAD: Five senators and other Washingtonians wish they'd never heard of Charles Keating or his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. So does John Keating of Encino, Calif.

LEAD: The bassist Fred Hopkins and the cellist Deidre Murray love music's lower depths. The quartet they assembled for a concert Wednesday at the Alternative Museum included the baritone Andy Bey and Brandon Ross on electric guitar, and their music rippled and churned in a register most groups use primarily for accompaniment.

LEAD: The Knicks are fortunate to have two young guards who can pass the ball, and it is much too early in the season to make a rash judgment and trade either player. CHRISTOPHER GEORGE MAROS New York

LEAD: In an effort to concentrate its resources on the North American automotive market, the Chrysler Corporation announced last week that it would sell Chrysler Technologies, which owns Gulfstream Aerospace and two military electronics companies. Chrysler's November car sales were down 17 percent from November 1988.

LEAD: On March 7, 1936, my great-great-uncle, Dr. Herman Fried, died at the age of 55. He was a well-known specialist in X-ray therapy. His life was cut short because, in those days, people were not as aware of the dangers of radiation as they are today.

LEAD: Robert Morse's last Broadway appearance was in ''So Long, 174th Street,'' the 1976 musical version of ''Enter Laughing.'' The show's exit was another matter. Not only did it close almost immediately, but the theater, the Harkness, was torn down as well. For months afterward, as he rode the bus up and down Broadway, the actor was assaulted with the sight of his name on a ghostly marquee above the gutted theater.

LEAD: SOME friends of mine have never allowed their children to buy them Christmas gifts. All presents must be homemade. So over the years they have received the most touching presents, many of which required hours of careful planning and hard work. Of course, there were the inevitable misshapen pieces of pottery and the peculiar bits of knitting that came unraveled almost at once.

LEAD: We're still in the sybaritic 1980's, but not for long. So indulge yourself while there is time; and if top-rank sound equipment figures in your notion of self-indulgence, the following may add to your temptations.
LEAD: Two brothers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison are feeling the wrath of the administration over a product bearing a likeness of the school's mascot.

LEAD: He had an off year, missed two games entirely and had the lowest rushing totals of his four-year career. But old habits die hard, so they made Johnny Bailey do what he's had to do most autumns since he started playing college footall in 1986. The Texas A. & I. running back had to go over to Sheffield, Ala., Friday night to pick up the Harlon Hill Trophy as the best player in Division

LEAD: The engagement of Ellen Lee Kennelly to John Nicholas Brown 3d has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Eve Williams Puloka of Nukualofa, Tonga, and Richard Bayard Kennelly of Claremont, Calif. Mr. Brown is a son of Capt. and Mrs. Nicholas Brown of Baltimore and Middleburg, Va. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: As the newest effort to resolve the Palestinian-Israeli conflict slides into familiar patterns of ambiguity, the Palestine Liberation Organization is balking at the role of invisible player assigned to it by Egypt, a principal Arab backer.
LEAD: A man watching a subway robbery early yesterday stabbed one of the muggers dead after telling him, ''We're not going to have any more of this,'' the police said.

LEAD: RUTH MORRISSEY keeps Down Under close by. She runs the Australia House in Mystic, where she sells Australian opals and aboriginal paintings, sculpture and didgeridoos. She also tells of the mining of opals and the making of didgeridoos, the traditional musical instrument of the aborigines.

LEAD: A 15-month-old girl was showing an ''outstanding'' response today after undergoing the nation's second living-donor liver transplant, but she faces a tough battle in the next few weeks, hospital officials said.
LEAD: Money has apparently reached such stratospheric heights in baseball that players can afford to leave a million or three on the table.

LEAD: He's been critical of his hometown's preparations for the 1992 Summer Games, but now Juan Antonio Samaranch, the head of the International Olympic Committee, says things are going just fine. Even so, Samaranch, a native of Barcelona, Spain, said he would personally supervise a scheduled meeting between the Barcelona organizers and the I.O.C.

LEAD: TOM TAYLOR DID NOT ENJOY HIS LUNCH that afternoon back in 1987. He was dining with a friend, Bill Holman, in a Chinese restaurant in Austin and discussing one of their favorite subjects - the old, rare documents of Texas history that Holman, a former librarian and printer, studies, and that Taylor, a printer and book merchant, dabbles in selling.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Constantine XII, King of the Hellenes until the military junta he tried to overthrow abolished the monarchy in June 1973, said in a rare interview in exile here that he would like to go back to Greece. He said he would return the way the people wanted him to, in ''whatever capacity that happened to be.

LEAD: Sheree Ilese Fabrikant and Wayne David Bloch, both associates at New York law firms, were married last evening at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbis William Greenburg and Eugene Wernick officiated.

LEAD: High school and college-age people who communicate in bisyllabic extensions do so for a number of reasons. For one thing, people don't listen to one another as closely as they once did. Hence, young people add syllables and redundant words and phrases to get the message across. They pad their sentences with such expressions as ''It was, like, a great sound, ya know?

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY recycles 800 to 900 tons of trash every day: newspapers, magazines and cardboard that the Sanitation Department picks up in Manhattan and Queens and glass that Staten Island residents are required to separate from the rest of their trash. Last week, the number of households taking part in the city recycling programs under a five-month-old law passed the one-million mark.

LEAD: YOU may not remember me, Fritz von Witzleben, but in the fall of 1979, I visited East Berlin. It was a sobering day, except for my visit with you at the Metropole Theater. You were the only one who spoke English when I asked to photograph the beautiful costumes in the window. You said: ''No, Madame, we do not permit photography.

LEAD: Three composers who combine electronics and performance got together Thursday night at Roulette, and the program they assembled offered a sharp disjunction in mood between the first piece and all that followed.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William J. McDonough of Chicago have announced May wedding plans for Mrs. McDonough's daughter Victoria Stafford Falk and O. Peter Tead Michaelis, a son of Michael Michaelis of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Diana Tead Michaelis. Miss Falk is also a daughter of Ralph Falk 2d of Lake Forest,

LEAD: The marriage of Suzanne Gertrude Coleman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Coleman of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Frederic Moore Bancroft, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Woodward Bancroft of Old Brookville, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

LEAD: Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the president of Rutgers University since 1971, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Nassau, the Bahamas, where he was attending a business meeting. Dr. Bloustein lived in the president's house on the school's New Brunswick-Piscataway campus. He was 64 years old.

LEAD: It's been said many times that Dustin Hoffman, who will open here Dec. 19 in ''The Merchant of Venice,'' is a wholly unlikely star, an actor with multiple handicaps: he's too short, his nose is too big, his voice has been described, charitably in the opinion of his detractors, as nasal, lacking in resonance and range.
LEAD: THE time for ''Boesman and Lena'' is now.

LEAD: More than a thousand people filled the John F. Kennedy Plaza at the University of Dayton on Friday shouting, ''Five, four, three, two, one'' as they waited for President Raymond L. Fitz to light the 40-foot Christmas tree and officially begin Christmas on Campus.

LEAD: ONE of the oddest commodities in my mother's kitchen was an institutional-size tin of grated nutmeg that always gave me a funny feeling. Other mothers bought their spices by the ounce. Mine invested by the pound. Going to Grenada finally put that tin in perspective. As I walked through the nutmeg processing station in the coastal town of Gouyave, peering into spice-filled bins nearly the size of my bedroom and listening to literally tons of whole nutmegs rattling down chutes to be sorted, my mother's tin shrank in my memory to less than the size of a single grated speck of the spice.

LEAD: WHEN Tom and Julia Berry decided to build a house two years ago, they didn't think too long or hard before deciding to have to it built of logs. After all, they had been married in a log cabin in Maine's northern woods.

LEAD: The collapse of two old copper mine shafts in backyards here on Nov. 30 has left a 75-house neighborhood nervous about possible cave-ins of 40 other shafts and raised questions about paying for future property damage and for plugging of the 279-year-old mine.

LEAD: Most chemical companies are in fighting shape to enter a down cycle. Throughout the 1980's they have been shutting inefficient plants, trimming back personnel, investing in modern equipment and divesting money-losing operations. Today, most have their fixed costs under control.
LEAD: FEVER Twelve Stories. By John Edgar Wideman. 161 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $16.95.

LEAD: Auto sales were weak in November, with the Big Three American makers showing steep declines. General Motors decline for the month was 22.6 percent, while Ford was down 15 percent and Chrysler off 17 percent. There were sales gains for cars made at Japanese auto plants in the United States. Honda, for example, now has 9.6 percent of the American market and is approaching

LEAD: REBEL WITHOUT A CLUE. By Holly Uyemoto. (Crown, $17.95.) In this deceptive novel, adult concerns like power, fame, intimacy and mortality are tackled expertly, as is realistic dialogue laced with the macho accents of two male adolescents. But the writer is neither an experienced author nor a man.

LEAD: I was appalled by the facts disclosed in your article, not only for what had been hidden so long by the Atomic Energy Commission - though some of us have long known about similar cover-ups by the A.E.C. - but for what was revealed by your author about a man who clearly made every effort to have his story and identity protected.

LEAD: In the last few years I haven't had a client who hasn't asked me to design a wildflower meadow for him, thinking it would be maintenance-free, effortlessly and constantly beautiful - and somehow morally superior because it's natural. I've had a difficult time persuading them that without considerable maintenance they'd end up with the ''weed-filled-empty-lot'' look and that a wildflower meadow isn't at all natural in a 20-by-50-foot city backyard.

LEAD: Stopped in lines in another morning rush hour at the George Washington Bridge, motorists used terms like ''crazy'' and ''rip-off'' to describe a proposed dollar increase, to $4, in tolls on interstate bridges and tunnels.

LEAD: Your article about eating in bed evoked the most pleasant of childhood memories.

LEAD: Honolulu is an easy place to know and love if you give it half a chance. Some promoters call it a paradise, but it isn't. It is a city - commercial, expensive, noisy and tacky. It has traffic, drugs and street people. It also has abundant natural and manmade beauty, exceptional weather, exotic foods, friendly people, low unemployment, virtually no heavy industry.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 19 about shopping in London misstated the source of cashmere. It comes from goats, not sheep.

LEAD: In a what appeared to be a major effort to improve the image of his Government, President Alfredo Cristiani today offered to renew peace talks with guerrillas this month and posted a $250,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of the killers of six Jesuit priests.

LEAD: Men have always understood the mystique of the raincoat. More important, though, is that such coats are considered ''proper,'' yet at the same time offer some swashbuckling dash.

LEAD: European Community leaders endorsed the idea of a single German state today, but they attached a series of conditions aimed at insuring that moves toward German unity do not bring instability to Europe.

LEAD: After nearly 75 years, one of the most grisly relics of the Mexican Revolution has finally been laid to rest. LEAD: A music review on Sunday about ''The Phil Springer Songbook - Second Edition,'' a revue that plays weekly at Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street, misstated the performance day. It is Tuesday, not Wednesday.
LEAD: Robert E. Peary's polar expedition reached the North Pole in 1909 just as the explorer said, according to a study made public today that used new scientific methods to re-examine the evidence.

LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in remarks aimed at Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, said today that German reunification was not just a German issue but one to be decided in consultation with Bonn's NATO allies, its neighbors and the Soviet Union.

LEAD: The British Government yesterday awarded licenses to build three wireless networks for telephone and information services to international consortiums that include the Pacific Telesis Group, U S West Inc. and Cable and Wireless P.L.C.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission and its Dutch counterpart announced an agreement today to cooperate in trying to stem a broad range of cross-border violations of securities laws.

LEAD: The United States Army, facing major cuts in its forces stationed in Europe and a declining budget, has proposed reshaping itself largely into a fast-reaction force based in the continental United States, senior Army officials say.
LEAD: Engineers at the University of Rochester have developed a new process for sharpening blurred images in photographs.

LEAD: A complete Beethoven sonata cycle, offered chronologically, is a steep climb for a pianist, even at the comparatively leisurely pace that the Irish pianist John O'Conor has taken. Mr. O'Conor began making his way through the 32 sonatas in February, when he gave the first of eight concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art devoted to the works.

LEAD: William Carl Woodward, a former executive with the Aluminum Company of America, died of respiratory arrest following surgery yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 76 years old and lived in Pittsburgh and Washington.

LEAD: MANY people who are mildly depressed can improve with minimal treatment in which they get regular support from a professional but receive no drugs or formal psychotherapy, researchers have found.

LEAD: Tempers ran short as the House rushed to wind up its business for the year. During one of several late nights, those present on the floor began baying ''Gephardt! Gephardt!'' to encourage the majority leader to excuse them. Representative Marty Russo, who was trying to talk about Lithuania at the time, was not amused.

LEAD: An Argentine man charged with laundering $250 million in cocaine proceeds through storefronts in Los Angeles and New York pleaded not guilty today in Federal court here, Judge William Keller ordered the man, Raul Silvio Vivas, held without bail on the argument by prosecutors that he is the mastermind of an international network.
LEAD: Ben Barton, a music publisher who supplied songs to Frank Sinatra and others, died in his sleep Friday at the Actors' Fund Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: Robin Higgins, the wife of Col. William Higgins, accused the United Nations today of making its forces ''sitting ducks'' by failing to insure their safety. Colonel Higgins, a member of a United Nations observer force, was kidnapped and reported to have been executed in Lebanon.

LEAD: Many teen-age mothers on welfare who lack adequate child care may refuse to sign up for new job and education programs mandated by the landmark 1988 welfare law, state welfare and education officials say.

LEAD: In a decision that leaves patent rights to a valuable new genetically engineered drug still in hot dispute, a Federal magistrate in Boston ruled yesterday that two competing biotechnology companies have valid patents.

LEAD: The patient having her Fallopian tubes tied on the operating table had been pulled from a trap near the South Platte River that morning. Poking out from under the surgical cloth was her flat paddle of a tail.
LEAD: Fighting chronic fatigue caused by thin air and deadly cold, scientists here are assembling a new type of telescope that may reveal the mysterious origin of cosmic rays.

LEAD: Bus safety and drinking were the focus of testimony today as the defense began its case in the trial of Larry Mahoney on charges of drunken driving and murder.

LEAD: Judging from the way a good many women have been turned out at the big galas this season, the neatly swept-back hairdo that leaves the face, ears and neck in graceful relief is the coif of the moment. LEAD: Joseph L. Ferraro, a retired lawyer and former president of the Board of Education in Paterson, N.J., died of complications of heart surgery on Sunday at the St. Joseph's Medical Center in Paterson. He was 67 years old and lived in Oakhurst, N.J.

LEAD: WITH hearts, kidneys, livers and pancreases being transplanted almost routinely, surgeons are now forging ahead to give combinations of organs - as many as five at a time - to treat a wide variety of conditions ranging from birth defects to diabetes and cancer.

LEAD: West Germany's Social Democratic Party intensified the national political debate today by taking credit for the ideas advanced by Chancellor Helmut Kohl in his vision of German unification just as he was softening aspects of the proposal.

LEAD: Twelve policemen and an army officer were acquitted of murder today in the first such private prosecution brought in South Africa.

Manny Baisa, the girl's grandfather, said the girl, who fell about 30 feet, underwent surgery for a broken hip Sunday, after having surgery earlier for her head and internal bleeding.

LEAD: It is not often that the middle of December brings us an exhibition as remarkable as ''20th-Century Modern Masters: The Jacques and Natasha Gelman Collection,'' which opens today at the Metropolitan Museum. It is a show to which every informed student of modern art has long looked forward.

LEAD: Stock prices slipped yesterday, with the downturn sharpest in the technology sector. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.20 points, to 2,728.24.

LEAD: Dr. Aaron J. Gissen, a former professor of anesthesiology at Harvard Medical School, died of rheumatic heart disease Sunday at his home in Concord, Mass. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: A New Yorker returning to the city after a long absence finds himself confused by the subway system but comforted by the conductors. He is grateful to them for telling him at every stop where he is, where he is going next and what his travel options are. The simple announcement ''14th Street - change for the L'' leaves him wondering if he will ever go to Canarsie, which is where the L train goes.

LEAD: Direct measurements of atmospheric heat and water vapor have confirmed for the first time a fundamental feature of the theory that is central to predictions of future global warming, scientists at the University of Chicago report in today's issue of the British journal Nature.

LEAD: Defending its economic stewardship, the Government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev shifted the emphasis of economic planning from heavy industry to consumer goods today. But skeptics in the country's legislature questioned whether a workable recovery plan was even in place yet.

LEAD: Contributing more glum news to the retail industry, R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that its losses had worsened in the quarter ending Oct. 28 and that it would cut back its new-store openings sharply over the next two years.
LEAD: While jostling furiously for a visible place on the reunification bandwagon, West German politicians have begun urging more caution and less haste in plotting German unity.

LEAD: A 20-year-old landscaper was arrested today and charged with the murder of 14-year-old Jessica Manners, whose body was found last March on a rocky embankment of Setauket Harbor near her home in Stony Brook.

LEAD: After more than two decades as one of America's most successful college football coaches, Glenn Edward (Bo) Schembechler of Michigan announced today that he would leave his job following the Jan. 1 Rose Bowl game against Southern Cal.
LEAD: Frederick J. Ludwig, a law professor who had been a police officer and an acting district attorney in Queens, died Monday at his home in the Bronx. He was 71 years old.
LEAD: The owner of Hialeah Park, who had wanted to close the race track, agreed today to keep it open Saturdays, Sundays, and Mondays.

LEAD: COMPANIES Campeau has run into its biggest cash squeeze yet, forcing its two American retail subsidiaries to say for the first time that they had to consider the possibility of filing for bankruptcy protection. The cash problem stems from payments and interest on $5.04 billion in debt and an inability to obtain additional loans.

LEAD: All over this country there are officials who try to deal with the drug menace - policemen, Federal agents, prosecutors, judges - and know that our policy does not work. They see that the criminal law does not reduce drug supplies or stop the rot in our society. But fearful of being called ''soft,'' few say anything in public.

LEAD: Dr. Gunhild Avitabile, the Far East curator at the Museum of Applied Arts in Frankfurt, has been named director of the Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street. Dr. Avitabile is to assume her job next month.

LEAD: Workers at the Nevada Test Site, the desert proving ground for American nuclear weapons, were repeatedly exposed to dangerous levels of radiation from underground and atmospheric atomic blasts over three decades, according to Government records made public in a court case here.

LEAD: Dr. John Slawson, executive vice president emeritus of the American Jewish Committee, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old. Dr. Slawson retired in 1967 after 24 years as leader of the organization, which was founded in 1906 to combat bigotry and to protect the civil and religious rights of Jews here and abroad.

LEAD: This plains city of 300,000, which once boomed as a railhead for Texas cattle, runs these days on airplane production. But unlike the time of the Chisholm Trail, Wichita is far from a one-industry town, and its albeit bumpy ride in the 1980's illustrates a mix of forces that operate in today's diversified economy to blunt both boom and bust.

LEAD: Mistletoe has been banned at Moorhead State University after a psychology instructor, Margaret Potter, filed a grievance saying she believed it encouraged sexual harassment.

LEAD: The days of steeply climbing house prices are over, and the 1990's could begin with prices dropping by as much as 12 percent, according to a report released today by Rutgers University based on three million house sales in New Jersey.

LEAD: JEROME L. SINGER remembers talking to an imaginary companion as he traveled to junior high school in the morning. His friend was an ancient Roman.

But adding some specialized tools broadens the range of projects possible and makes some jobs easier.

LEAD: The trustees of WNET, the major public television station in New York, yesterday elected Henry R. Kravis as the chairman. Mr. Kravis, a founding partner in Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, a merchant banking firm, will replace William M. Ellinghaus on May 1.
LEAD: Sweeping anti-smog proposals introduced today call for drastic reductions in automobile emissions in California by the year 2000, a goal some manufacturers call impossible.

Each year, work by the previous year's three resident artists is shown at the museum.

Deng Xiaoping, who has his own brand of realism, bets that the visit of senior U.S. envoys to China reinforces his domestic and international position at minimal cost.

LEAD: Is Raul Ruiz a genius or the overrated remnant of a faded avant-garde? Like his enigmatic films, this Chilean director's controversial reputation admits no easy answer. LEAD: Libya has suspended air, sea and communications links with France over the last week in a dispute over the French Government's decision to withhold the delivery of three Mirage fighter planes and other weapons already purchased by Libya, French officials said today.

LEAD: As campaigning in Brazil's presidential race ended today with the two candidates tied in opinion polls, attention swiveled to the traditional arbiter of Brazilian politics, the military.

LEAD: THERE must be someone, somewhere, who still thinks of Christmas as a holiday that lasts a single day - or, counting Christmas Eve, a day and a half. But as early as the seventh century, a day was added to Christmas celebrations in several countries to commemorate the Feast of St. Stephen, the first Christian martyr, on Dec.
LEAD: The offense is lifeless, the power play clueless, the lineup once again helpless in the face of nonstop injuries. For the Rangers, it's a long, ugly list of liabilities.
LEAD: * Air Canada, Toronto, said that over the next year it would add another two to three percentage points to its share of the Canadian air passenger market, currently just over 50 percent.
