LEAD: Neil Perlman is switching from publishing magazines to running trade shows, and he sees similarities between the endeavors. Mr. Perlman, now with Cahners Publishing, has been named the president of Cahners Exposition Group, which produces large trade shows.

LEAD: As foreign governments and international relief agencies condemn Hong Kong's forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people, Hong Kong residents are expressing their approval of the radical measure, and even at times suggesting that harsher measures are needed.
LEAD: A karate instructor who taught rape defense in this Westchester suburb has been charged with raping and sexually abusing three teen-age girls who were his students, the police said today.

LEAD: In early adolescence, when I was too ignorant to know that a roguish Fred Astaire could be more seductive than an overwrought Richard Burton, Vincente Minnelli's ''Sandpiper'' seemed the ultimate screen romance. Years later, I was amazed to realize that this crass 1965 Burton-Taylor melodrama about adultery in scenic Big Sur was one of the last gasps from the director of such graceful, classic musicals as ''Meet Me in St.
LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and the American Express Company announced a plan yesterday to raise badly needed cash for the brokerage firm by selling assets and issuing new stock and debt.

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was investigating a report that the generic version of a cancer treatment drug had been linked to a higher-than-normal incidence of toxic effects on the nervous system.
LEAD: The Redoubt Volcano erupted today, shooting volcanic ash seven miles into the air at its site in Cook Inet and prompting the evacuation of seven oil workers.

LEAD: The Pentagon plans to halt the round-the-clock flights of an airborne command post that for three decades has been a grim symbol of America's preparation to wage nuclear war even if the President and other political leaders were killed in a surprise attack, Pentagon officials said today.

LEAD: A grand jury report on the choking death of a black man at the hands of a white, off-duty Middletown policeman recommended today that police agencies implement stricter policy standards regarding neck-restraint holds.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased $336.3 million, to $366.81 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of 144 institutional funds decreased $387.4 million, to $88.20 billion. The assets of 228 general-purpose funds were up $148.8 million, to $119.68 billion.
LEAD: The new leader of the East German Communist Party asked for help today from the United States to keep his country from being absorbed by its powerful West German neighbor.

LEAD: Parisians woke up this morning to find all major stores, airports, subways and train stations heavily guarded by paramilitary police forces as France went on a nationwide alert to guard against what Minister of Interior Pierre Joxe described as a distinct possibility of terrorist attacks and bombings over the holiday season.

LEAD: South Florida's water managers responded to the worst dry spell in 27 years today with restrictions on washing cars and watering lawns and golf courses in this region of more than four million people.

LEAD: With more potential sellers in the ''junk bond'' market than buyers, some institutions with large junk portfolios are using a version of financial magic to turn their holdings into marketable securities with investment-grade ratings.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: An almost entirely new cast has taken over from the original singers in Offenbach's ''Contes d'Hoffmann'' at the Metropolitan Opera. Of the principals, only Jose van Dam remains, and his palpably evil portrayals of Lindorf, Coppelius, Dappertutto and Dr. Miracle - the four villainous manifestations of Hoffmann's psyche - remain among the unquestionable joys of this year's staging.

LEAD: A Federal district judge has taken the unusual step of ordering a company whose legal costs are paid by the Energy Department to post an $85.4 million bond to cover the settlement of a suit brought by neighbors of a nuclear weapons plant in Ohio.
LEAD: A 26-year-old high school dropout who became a millionaire by running a Queens cocaine ring was sentenced yesterday to 35 years in prison and fined $1 million.

LEAD: In yet another indication that the cold war is drawing to a close, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union will make a visit to NATO headquarters next week, NATO announced today.

LEAD: President Bush has barred a planned reduction in the Social Security Administration's staff in the face of mounting complaints of curtailed services to beneficiaries, Bush Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Lawyers for John M. Poindexter charged today that President Bush and former President Ronald Reagan had adopted a strategy calculated to avoid the perception that they ''are still attempting to hide the true facts regarding their involvement in the so-called Iran-contra affair.''

LEAD: Historic Hudson Valley, an organization that administers a half-dozen historic properties in upstate New York, yesterday named John H. Dobkin as its president. Mr. Dobkin, the director of the National Academy of Design since 1978, will become president on Jan. 1.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Amsterdam's Bar and Rotisserie * (March 3, 1989), 428 Amsterdam Avenue, at 80th Street (874-1377) -Amsterdam's strategy for success combines a menu of simple rotisserie dishes, down-to-earth prices and an informal setting.

LEAD: In its first special session since 1966, the New Hampshire House of Representatives voted today to authorize Northeast Utilities' takeover of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the first public utility to go bankrupt since the Depression.
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: Props From Hollywood
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration has proposed limiting the health claims that appear on food packages, saying they are too broad and in some cases fraudulent.

LEAD: Robert R. Kiley, chairman of New York State's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, warned Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut yesterday that he would press for sharp cuts in commuter rail service on the New Haven Line unless Mr. O'Neill drops his opposition to $7.7 million in higher fares -or its equivalent in subsidies.
LEAD: Washington law firms know that representing foreign Governments can be risky. When the Minneapolis City Council meets Friday, one law firm will find out just how risky it can be.

LEAD: Dow Jones & Company expects earnings for all of 1989 to increase by about 40 percent above 1988 levels, Warren H. Phillips, the publishing company's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday.

LEAD: ''The Wizard'' is a blatant kiddie knockoff of ''Rain Man,'' with 13-year-old Fred Savage, the winsome and very natural star of television's ''Wonder Years,'' as a boy who spirits his strangely uncommunicative younger half-brother away from a hospital and travels across the country with him, discovering along the way that little Jimmy (Luke Edwards) is a real prodigy when it comes to video games.

LEAD: Upscale Brasserie New York could surely use some authentic French brasseries, those bright, bustling, drop-in restaurants that serve traditional fare at economical prices. La Cite, the dazzling new rococo extravaganza on West 51st Street, is a bit highfalutin to be called a brasserie. A better term might be brassaurant, Manhattan style, where prices can escalate fast.
LEAD: Although the Devils will play the 32d game of their season Friday night, they feel as if training camp had just ended this week.

LEAD: Gov. Thomas H. Kean today nominated his predecessor, former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne of Princeton, to a four-year term as a member of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. Mr. Byrne will replace William Taggart, whose term expires on Jan. 11.
LEAD: Armed men riding in a van fired two rifle grenades into a United States Government compound here today, the local police and the American Ambassador reported.

LEAD: When the veteran saxophonist Spike Robinson was prevented by illness from joining the Dutch pianist Jack Van Poll as a duo on Tuesday night at J's, on Broadway at 97th Street, he was replaced by the bassist Brian Torff, a change that created a different kind of duo.

LEAD: Andrei Dmitriyevich Sakharov was one of those rare figures who appear at turning points in history, a man whose courage in fighting for intellectual and political freedom impressed much of the world but put him in long and dangerous conflict with his own country.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Weighing in at 3.9 pounds and rising more than one and a quarter inches off the coffee table, the February/ March 1990 issue of Bride's magazine is claiming the record as the largest consumer magazine ever published. Totaling 1,040 pages, including the cover, the Conde Nast publication will include 798 pages of ads.

LEAD: Amid warnings of impending New York City deficits, a senior city union leader yesterday staked out an unusually early position in upcoming labor negotiations and called for moderate wage increases equal to the rate of inflation at the least.

LEAD: If you can believe that Sean Connery and a Sicilian wife could be parents to Dustin Hoffman, and that this same Dustin Hoffman and a Jewish wife could be parents to Matthew Broderick, then you should read no further than the next paragraph.

LEAD: The card has the look and the greeting of a Christmastime corporate freebie. ''Charge Yourself a Lovely Holiday Gift . . . It's on Us!'' declares the cheery red script on thick, glossy white paper. Below is a facsimile of an American Express card, embossed with an account number, an expiration date and Dan Rather's name.

LEAD: Andrei D. Sakharov, the indomitable human-rights campaigner who prevailed in official exile to become a relentless prod to the Soviet Union's new congress, died apparently of a heart attack late Thursday after a long and wearying legislative day. He was 68 years old and lived in Moscow.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 An East German call for U.S. help was made by the country's new Communist Party leader. He asked for help in keeping his country from being absorbed by its powerful West German neighbor. Page A1

LEAD: N.B.A. Bullets 105, Hornets 101: Mark Alarie sank an 18-foot jumper with 15 seconds left to snap a 101-101 tie for Washington. After Rex Chapman brought visiting Charlotte even at 101-101 with a steal and a layup with 28 seconds to play, Alarie hit a jumper from the top of the key. Washington's Jeff Malone added two free throws in the final second.(AP) Spurs 104, Rockets 100: Willie Anderson sparked a fourth-quarter burst with 10 of his 19 points and San Antonio outscored visiting Houston, 19-9, in the final 7:24 to win.
LEAD: The Jets are looking for a general manager. About time. For well over a decade, this football team has been a floundering example of a franchise without a single vision, without a plan.
LEAD: The Lamar University board of regents today voted to discontinue the school's football program, citing projected losses of half a million dollars over the next three seasons.

LEAD: For more than a decade, in an effort to prevent international embarrassment, East German athletes were tested for drug use before they were allowed to compete outside the country, Dr. Claus Clausnitzer, the chief of East Germany's only drug-testing laboratory, said today that from 1978 until last month, his staff tested all athletes selected by officials to compete outside the country, where they might be tested again.
LEAD: A $167.5 million bond issue by Lakeland, Fla., is offering a maximum yield of 7.10 percent for an issue due 2008 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
LEAD: Joe Walton, the coach of the Jets, this week described the game Sunday against the Los Angeles Rams as ''a good test for all our young guys.''

LEAD: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation rejected an acquisition proposal by Pacificorp, the Portland, Ore., utility company. Pacificorp, which had made an earlier cash bid for Pinnacle's Arizona Public Services unit, had offered to exchange 0.18 share of its common stock for each share of Pinnacle.

LEAD: In one of the first signs that events in Eastern Europe may complicate the European Community's integration process, West Germany postponed signing an agreement today to create a border-free region with four of its Western European neighbors.

LEAD: Swissair and Singapore Airlines signed a cooperation agreement and said they plan to work out details to exchange 5 percent of each other's shares by the end of 1990. The agreement established the third link in a global alliance of airlines. Swissair, Switzerland's national flag carrier, and Singapore Airlines signed bilateral agreements with Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines earlier in the year.

LEAD: Former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger once declared that when it came to courtroom skills, all lawyers were not created equal. LEAD: The Bureau of International Expositions in Paris announced yesterday that the 1995 World's Fair would be held jointly in Vienna and Budapest, with the Governments of Austria and Hungary acting as sponsors.

LEAD: The Walt Disney Company, which is stepping up its publishing activities, has hired Charles P. Wickham from Field Publications, known for its Weekly Reader. He will supervise all Disney publishing operations in the United States and Canada.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission and its French counterpart signed a cooperative agreement on securities investigations today.

LEAD: A Senate Ethics Committee inquiry into Senator Dave Durenberger has issued subpoenas to dozens of organizations that paid a Minneapolis publisher in lieu of direct speaking fees to Mr. Durenberger, the Senator's spokeswoman confirmed today.
LEAD: This was going to be a column devoted to criticizing the drug legalizers. Then I read a new study about crack babies.

LEAD: In an innovative move to help measure and confine the AIDS epidemic, New York City will begin testing for the virus in all 8,000 autopsies that the Chief Medical Examiner's office performs each year, and then use the results to find out who else might be infected.

LEAD: A CBS executive said yesterday that the network's plan to name Jeff Sagansky president of the entertainment division had been delayed only by minor complications related to Mr. Sagansky's departure as president of Tri-Star Pictures.

LEAD: Louisiana's Pardon Board today recommended to Gov. Buddy Roemer a reduced sentence that could mean freedom in five years for Gary Tyler, a black whose contention that he was framed in a murder case 15 years ago has won international support.

LEAD: Judith Rothenberg Tishman, a photographers' representative in Manhattan for many years, died of complications from a brain tumor yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

LEAD: Prices for near-term deliveries of hogs surged more than a penny a pound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as frigid weather in the Midwest slowed marketing and reduced slaughter rates.
LEAD: Mike Gottfried, who had four winning seasons as the University of Pittsburgh's football coach, was dismissed today, according to athletic department sources.

LEAD: After six years of sustained growth, New Jersey's economy slowed so sharply this year that the state stands a greater risk than the nation of sliding into a recession next year, a panel of economic advisers to the Governor warned today.

LEAD: The United Nations General Assembly gave unanimous backing today to a declaration setting political guidelines for the peaceful dismantling of apartheid and the creation of a democratic South Africa.

PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Waived Jay Vincent, forward. SAN JOSE (CBA) - Traded Monroe Douglass, guard, to the Tulsa Fast Breakers for a sixth-round choice in next year's college draft.

LEAD: Offering Gov. Mario M. Cuomo the kind of advice that he seems to be hoping for, the Governor's committee of economic advisers will recommend that the next phase of the state's income tax cut be delayed, committee members said today.

LEAD: The American woman deported from El Salvador after being freed from charges of hiding arms and ammunition for leftist rebels arrived in New York yesterday and harshly criticized the Bush Administration for not presuming her innocence.

LEAD: Guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization mounted an attack today against a Syrian Army garrison in southern Lebanon. The police said 6 people were killed and 20 wounded. The attack was believed to be the first Palestinian frontal attack on a Syrian position in 13 years.

LEAD: Defying calls to disperse from both Communist officials and their own opposition leaders, about 20,000 jeering Bulgarians ringed the Parliament building today to demand an immediate end to the Communist Party's monopoly on power.
LEAD: For many donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the generosity or selflessness of a relative, friend or colleague prompts the gift.

LEAD: In New York, and around the country, new living arrangements provoke new rules. Some recently proposed by the New York State Housing Division would grant officials a strange new power - to turn pairs of unrelated adults into families.

LEAD: A report in the Q&A column of Science Times on Tuesday about a possible 10th planet referred incorrectly to the orbit of Chiron, a rocky object in the outer solar system. It lies between Saturn and Uranus, not beyond Pluto.

LEAD: When the curtain rises on the bloated, jowly bubble of flesh that is the title character of ''Tru,'' Jay Presson Allen's monodrama about Truman Capote, a sentimental theatergoer is not so much startled by the resurrection of Capote, who died in 1984, as shocked by the obliteration of Robert Morse, last seen on Broadway in the mid-1970's.
LEAD: Like Alvin Ailey, Donald McKayle choreographed a superb work early in his career that became a signature piece.
LEAD: The consultant Thomas E. Muldoon was convicted today of charges that he helped a military contractor funnel bribes to a Marine Corps contracting official for help in getting Pentagon contracts.

LEAD: SOME people lament a theater that chases after lavish visual effects, but not I. Would ''The Phantom of the Opera'' retain half its mystery without dry ice and the sensuous, slow progress of thick curtains sweeping across the stage, promising to reveal something magnificent?

LEAD: Whether by chance or design, the two main exhibitions at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo play off each other in unexpected ways, forming a whole greater than the sum of its parts. These shows say a lot about the present moment in art, especially the quest for new meanings in old materials and images.

LEAD: The Radio Advertising Bureau has said that when 1989 is finished, radio advertising revenues will total $8.49 billion, up 7.5 percent from 1988. Network radio advertising rose 12 percent, national spot advertising 9.5 percent and local advertising 6.8 percent. Smaller increases are projected for 1990, when the bureau forecasts an increase of 5 to 7 percent.
LEAD: Offering Gov. Mario M. Cuomo the advice he seems to want, the Governor's economic advisers will recommend a delay in the next phase of New York's income tax cut. Page B1.

LEAD: The ramshackle tent city of the homeless in Tompkins Square Park was torn down yesterday as scores of city and park police officers mounted a long planned, long announced operation of nearly military complexity.

LEAD: James J. Blanchard was a high school sophomore in 1957, when highway engineers began talking about the new superhighway that might someday slice across this small suburb.

Raul Ruiz's ''City of Pirates'' was shown as part of the 1985 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 6, 1985. The film (in French with English subtitles) opens today with Mr. Ruiz's ''Three Sad Tigers'' at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. The Chilean-born fabulist Raul Ruiz makes surrealist films that are entirely self-contained; for ''intriguingly enigmatic,'' as the New York Film Festival literature describes Mr. Ruiz's ''City of Pirates,'' you might just as well read impenetrable. However, this film, like Mr. Ruiz's ''Three Crowns of the Sailor'' (which was shown at the 1984 festival), has the strong imagery and confident, if solipsistic, visual style that make Mr. Ruiz's work notable.

LEAD: The four distinctive rings that Voyager 2 discovered around Neptune, especially the lumpy outer one, have scientists shaking their heads and confessing that all their previous theories to explain planetary rings must be scrapped or drastically revised.

LEAD: The Rev. Bruce Ritter, the founding head of Covenant House, yesterday emphatically denied allegations by a 20-year-old former male prostitute that the priest had misused Covenent House funds and offered the youth special financial benefits in return for sex.

LEAD: A Somers State Prison inmate who called himself ''an animal'' and said he would have committed violent crimes if his escape attempt had been successful was sentenced Wednesday to an additional 10 years in prison. Judge Michael A. Mack sentenced Donald L. Williamson, who is already serving a 20- to 40-year sentence for kidnapping and rape, to an additional 10 years because he has shown no remorse.
LEAD: The stock market closed moderately lower yesterday after recouping more than half of its earlier decline.

Mr. McKinney resumed his jobs with the paper in 1987 after a nine-year legal battle with Gannett over his employment contract.

LEAD: A warehouse fire in Piscataway, N.J., burned for several hours last night, spread to several nearby small workshops and a house and forced the evacuation of about 100 people, the police said.

LEAD: The new Foreign Minister said today that the agreement under which Soviet troops are stationed in Czechoslovakia was invalid because it was concluded under duress.

LEAD: The holidays mean toasts, and toasts mean champagne. Champagnes are bottled in a greater variety of sizes than are other wines and that means you can generally buy what you need and no more. Most French Champagne is sold in half-bottles, bottles and magnums. Splits and jeroboams are also fairly common, and a few producers bottle nonvintage champagnes in sizes even bigger than the jeroboam.

LEAD: International 3-12 The East German exodus to the West has continued unabated. While 10 million East Germans have visited West Germany and returned home, each day about 2,000 have chosen to settle. 1 Warsaw's relations with East Berlin and Bonn have come under economic and political strain from the side effects of the revolution that has swept East Germany since October.

LEAD: Olive Booth, the last of the surviving granddaughters of Gen. William Booth, founder of the Salvation Army, died on Wednesday. She was 98 years old.

LEAD: A man under Federal protection whose testimony against a major crack ring made him a hero to some people in New York City returned to Spokane today and pleaded guilty to a charge of resisting arrest. He also apologized.

LEAD: Bulgarians are discovering that if democracy ever does arrive, as their Communist leaders pledge, it can be a boisterous, unpredictable, exhilarating and at times tedious process.

LEAD: Frederick E. Nolting Jr., who was United States Ambassador to South Vietnam from 1961 to 1963, died on Thursday at the University of Virginia Medical Center in Charlottesville, Va., a spokesman for the center said.
LEAD: Drug Treatment Chief Out

LEAD: A neighboring borough that sends its students to this Bergen County community's high school has refused to pay its tuition bill since the beginning of the school year. As a result, the Ridgefield Park Board of Education contends it may have to borrow money to meet its payroll next week.

LEAD: Zubin Mehta has always had a soft spot for crossover experimentation. This fall a New York Philharmonic subscription program included a world premiere of a piece for tuba and orchestra by Roger Kellaway. Now it's the turn of Gerry Mulligan, the mellow master of the cool-jazz baritone saxophone, who is the featured performer (along with his accompanying trio) at the current Philharmonic subscription concerts at Avery Fisher Hall.
LEAD: Pardo Frederick DelliQuadri, who was the dean of several schools of social work, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 74 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: One of the few groups in this society that has remained calm and quiet in the last 10 weeks of political uproar has been the country's farmers.

LEAD: A brief article in Business Day on Thursday about a proposed takeover statute in Pennsylvania referred incorrectly to the handling of profits made by investors who seek control of a Pennsylvania company - either though a proxy fight or by purchasing more than 20 percent of the stock -and sell shares within two years of seeking control.

LEAD: The jazz that developed in South Africa in the 1950's and 60's blended church music, South African ethnic influences and American jazz into a distinct style that overflows with optimism. It is sunny music that has kept a sense of dance, both in its group rhythms and in its solos. On Thursday night, Hugh Masekela, an expatriate South African who is one of the best known of all musicians to come out of South Africa, brought a fine band of African and American musicians to S.O.B.

LEAD: N.B.A. Bucks 103, Pacers 98: Visiting Milwaukee overcame a 16-point halftime deficit to win. Fred Roberts's free throw with about a minute to play tied the score at 95-95. A 6-point run by Milwaukee, with Jack Sikma scoring the go-ahead layup, gave the Bucks a 101-95 lead with eight seconds to go.(AP)

LEAD: Michael Mann, retired regional director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O for New York and New Jersey, died of heart disease on Dec. 9 at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 86 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Soviet Government, which once exiled Andrei D. Sakharov for being a human rights champion, today embraced him in death. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev mourned the national loss of ''a man of conviction and sincerity.''

LEAD: A sustained, deafening noise from the sellout crowd filled Byrne Meadowlands Arena for several minutes late in the game tonight as the Devils rallied from a two-goal deficit for a 7-5 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings.

LEAD: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 10.50 10.50 10.50 DISCOUNT RATE 7.00 7.00 6.50 FEDERAL FUNDS 8.56 8.50 8.90 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 7.66 7.63 8.16 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 7.41 7.40 8.21 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 7.79 7.79 9.20 30-YR.

LEAD: Dr. Grant Sanger, a surgeon who was an associate professor of clinical surgery at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center for 27 years, died of a heart attack on Thursday while dining at the Harvard Club in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

LEAD: Tony Meola, the starting goaltender on the United States national team and the college player of the year, said yesterday that he would give up his last two years of eligibility at the University of Virginia and turn pro.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: East Germany's hope that the exodus of its people would drop drastically once travel restrictions were removed has not been fulfilled in the month since the travel curbs were lifted, and West Germany continues to receive a steady stream of immigrants.
LEAD: The Video Appeals Committee of the British Board of Film Classification has upheld a ban on ''Visions of Ecstasy,'' the first film ever to be banned for blasphemy in Britain.

LEAD: A young advertising executive who was killed earlier this month leaving a Christmas party in the East Village was set upon by different robbers in two attacks within a few minutes, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Just as it did 50 years ago, this city gave a brazen and bosomy hug this week to the 50th anniversary of the premiere of ''Gone With the Wind,'' a weeklong promotional frenzy that included a costume ball, a parade, tours of antebellum homes, star-gazing and memorabilia-hawking.

LEAD: You don't have to mount an antenna on the roof to get decent FM radio reception. Many indoor antennas cost much less than a directional roof antenna with a rotator, and provide much better reception than the antennas that come with most FM sets.
LEAD: The wife of a senior partner in a large accounting firm was acquitted yesterday of murder and manslaughter in the stabbing death of her estranged husband.
LEAD: Boris Becker overpowered Stefan Edberg, 6-2, 6-2, 6-4, tonight as West Germany, the defending champion, and Sweden split the opening two singles matches in the Davis Cup final.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: George Marion Fanelli, a retired New York State Supreme Court Justice and a former District Attorney of Westchester County, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at a nursing home in Lansdale, Pa. He was 92 years old and had lived in Lansdale for the last year after growing up and living in New

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about the Bulgarian leader, Petar T. Mladenov, and a chart on Monday about political changes in Eastern Europe gave an incorrect date for his appointment.
LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: In his last opportunity to shape the city's judiciary, Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday named five people to the bench and announced that public hearings on the nominations would be held on Dec. 27.

LEAD: The Legal Services Corporation, an ideological battleground for eight years, voted today to keep its conservative president, who has worked to narrow programs designed to provide legal aid to poor people.

LEAD: The European Community fined the West German chemical producer Bayer A.G. $590,000 for violating competition rules in the marketing of an additive for animal feed. The fine stems from Bayer's insistence that West German customers buy the additive, which promotes growth in animals, only for themselves.
LEAD: Phoebe Mills is ready to compete. She takes a deep breath and begins her approach. The slender but strong 17-year-old builds speed, hits her takeoff mark and is suddenly airborne.

LEAD: There is a sense of urgency about many of the letters addressed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, a sense that people everywhere, no matter what their personal circumstances, must pitch in to stem the tide of poverty or despair.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is studying a plan that would create a new type of long-term savings account in which interest would be wholly exempted from taxes and depositors would be allowed access to their money before retirement, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: The Communist Party will give up its monopoly on power and allow independent parties to compete in free elections next year, according to a draft declaration published today.

LEAD: In a development that came as little surprise to the financial community, the Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would reduce its fourth-quarter earnings by $273 million, or 85 cents a share, because of write-offs of assets in discontinued businesses and payments to employees who are losing their jobs.
LEAD: Connecticut and Massachusetts have joined Vermont's fight to force the retirement of a 70-year-old Vermont Supreme Court Justice.

LEAD: ''The Crucible'' is Arthur Miller's most produced play, for reasons that are chillingly apparent in Arvin Brown's revival at the Long Wharf Theater. The play combines a clear dramatic line with a pronounced moral fervor that has not lessened in the 36 years since it was first presented.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Federal district judge has sentenced a former president of the West Virginia State Senate to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine for extorting $5,000 from a company that sought to promote the legalization of casino gambling in this state.
LEAD: The Soviet Union said today that it would oppose an American effort to repeal a General Assembly resolution that equates Zionism with racism.

LEAD: In its quest to clean up polluted air over Los Angeles and other major cities, California is putting unparalleled pressure on automobile makers and fuel companies to cooperate in designing the low-polluting vehicles of the future.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury today indicted the New Orleans District Attorney, Harry Connick, on charges that he illegally helped a well-known Louisiana bookmaker and his gambling business.

LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, whose adherence to the forms of public courtesy is as steady as the New York City press corps's is uneven, hopes his future contests with reporters will be played out with decorum, his new press secretary allowed yesterday.

LEAD: Froma Joselow, a reporter for The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin, and David C. Harrop, a writer in New York, were married yesterday at the White Horse Tavern in Newport, R.I., by John H. McGann, a justice of the peace.

LEAD: President Bush today rejected a recommendation by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to halt the round-the-clock flights of an airborne command post that could be used to wage a nuclear war, Administration officials said.
LEAD: Divers found the fuselage of a commuter plane in the 100-foot-deep waters of Block Island Sound today, but there was no sign of the eight people who were on board.

LEAD: The Bank of New England Corportion announced yesterday that its problems in real estate lending were far more severe than previously estimated and would result in a substantial loss for the year.

LEAD: Leda Anchutina Eglevsky, who danced in George Balanchine's first American ballet companies and founded the Eglevsky Ballet with her husband, Andre Eglevsky, was found dead yesterday morning in bed at her home in Massapequa, L.I. The cause of death was not immediately determined. Always reluctant to give her age, Miss

LEAD: Industrial production rose by a lackluster one-tenth of 1 percent in November despite rebounding from a major strike and the devastating California earthquake, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
LEAD: A CARDIOLOGIST at the Stanford University School of Medicine and his father obtained a patent this week on what amounts to a Roto Rooter system for clearing clogged arteries.

LEAD: As the countries of Eastern Europe rush to strengthen their economic ties with the West, Comecon, the trade organization that has been a pillar of the Soviet bloc, is rapidly disintegrating, many Eastern European officials and economists say.

LEAD: Seven choreographers presented works on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater as part of Dance Theater Workshop's Fresh Tracks series of programs by new talent. The offerings varied greatly in style. Yet all concerned people in crises, and one of the things that made the evening stimulating was seeing how the characters in these pieces managed to cope with their problems.
LEAD: One of the most violent figures in the world of cocaine smuggling was killed in a shootout this afternoon with Colombian security forces.
LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo tonight signed a bill that would allow Staten Island to secede from New York City, but only after steps that would take at least three and a half years.
LEAD: Sammy Lerner, a Hollywood songwriter who wrote the theme song for the cartoon character Popeye in 1932, died of cancer on Wednesday in a Los Angeles nursing home. He was 86 years old.
LEAD: Andrei Sakharov was a good and great man who dared to say the world was round when his masters insisted it was flat.

LEAD: In the midst of the hectic preholiday season, there is an oasis of civilized and joyous song and dance uptown at the Theater of the Riverside Church, where the Charles Moore Dance Theater is performing through tomorrow. The company of dancers and musicians, founded in 1974 by Charles Moore and Ella Thompson Moore, his wife, specializes in dance from Africa, the Caribbean and South America, with an emphasis on revealing the

LEAD: Almost all the characters in Janet Noble's likable comedy-drama ''Away Alone'' are illegal Irish immigrants in their 20's who have settled in an area of the Bronx that has been nicknamed the Irish mile.

LEAD: In a stunning psychological victory for the anti-apartheid movement, South Africa's highest court today reversed the convictions of five blacks who were found guilty of treason or terrorism last year after the longest political trial here in recent memory.

LEAD: First there was the ''Doonesbury'' comic strip. Then the skit on ''Saturday Night Live.'' But the most damning comments about a purchase of crack in front of the White House orchestrated by Federal officials came this week from the bench.s is like a Keystone Kops thing,'' said a bemused Judge Stanley Sporkin of the United States District Court as he heard the case of 18-year-old Keith Jackson, a local high school student charged with selling the bag of crack that President Bush used Sept.

LEAD: Gerald Busby, a pianist and composer, will direct a program of his works at Weill Recital Hall at 8:30 tonight. Among the works to be performed are ''Bullet-Proof Bikini,'' for piano; ''Get it Out!,'' for two sopranos, mezzo-soprano, contralto, piano and electric pencil sharpener, and ''Trip to the Valley,'' for piano, tape and spare tire.
LEAD: For real excitement you can't beat a snow forecast in what the television people infesting my parlor call ''the Washington viewing area.''

LEAD: For his failure to allow reporters into his team's locker room after a 24-17 loss to the Seattle Seahawks on Sunday, Coach Sam Wyche of the Cincinnati Bengals was hit with what the National Football League termed a substantial fine yesterday. The size of the fine was not disclosed.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In India, that ancient land of cults, a new belief system has sprouted in recent years. Adherents, called Redmondians, follow the teachings of the one they call the Cosmic Puppeteer.

LEAD: * American Steel and Wire Corp., Cuyahoga Heights, Ohio, a maker of shelving and other storage products, said its board had rejected as inadequate the increased acquisition offer of $9.50 a share by Chicago West Pullman Corp., Cincinnati, a railroad and steel company.

LEAD: Hong Kong's hopes to establish a democratic government after it reverts to Beijing's authority were diminished today when China declared that only one-third of the post-1997 legislature would be directly elected.
LEAD: Czechoslovakia's Defense Minister proposed today that the nation begin dismantling fortifications along all of its 150-mile border with West Germany.
LEAD: Normally, Gerald and Dominique Wilkins are not matched against each other when the Knicks face the Hawks. But tonight, circumstances dictated otherwise.

LEAD: Relations between Poland and the two Germanys are being strained by the side effects of the peaceful revolution that has swept East Germany since October, diplomats and Government officials in several European capitals say.
LEAD: A Chinese jumbo jet bound for New York was hijacked today and forced to land in western Japan, Japanese authorities said.

LEAD: Helen Robinson, a world-class angler who held several competitive fishing titles, died here Monday of complications from a fall. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Robinson set women's world records, among them the 1961 capture of a 796-pound black marlin and a 584-pound black marlin in 1962, both at Pinas Bay,

LEAD: Fernando Valenzuela, who had been on the verge of signing with another team, decided yesterday to return to the Los Angeles Dodgers for one year at a guaranteed $2 million. The left-hander could earn an additional $500,000 in bonuses if he pitches 240 innings.

LEAD: Top executives of some of the nation's largest newspaper companies predicted this week that 1990 would be another tough year for advertising sales, but most said they thought a recession was unlikely.

LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d expressed some disappointment today with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new five-year plan for the Soviet economy, saying it failed to include the kind of structural changes that would begin to re-orient the Soviet Union to a more productive free-market system.
LEAD: All four engines of a KLM Boeing 747 temporarily shut down yesterday when the jumbo jet flew through a cloud of ash from the erupting Redoubt Volcano in Alaska, Government officials reported.

LEAD: A United States Marine Corps reconnaissance team, which has been quietly patrolling the Southwest border since Thanksgiving, exchanged fire with drug smugglers for the first time late Wednesday night along the Arizona border, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Frank Belatti was named president and chief operating officer of Arby's Inc. in a move hailed by a group of dissident franchisees as a step toward ending their feud with the fast-food chain's parent. Mr. Belatti was the chain's executive vice president for marketing and has in the past been critical of Victor Posner, who controls the DWG Corporation, the Miami Beach, Fla., parent of

LEAD: After a coy decadelong flirtation that blossomed into a full-scale romance over the last few months, the Big Ten has finally popped the question and Penn State has said yes. The school has agreed to give up its independence and join the venerable athletic conference.

LEAD: A nuclear bomb plant in Washington State that was shut last December because of safety problems has had an unexplained chemical reaction in a pipe that ruptured a gasket and sprayed acid into an area sometimes occupied by workers.
LEAD: The holiday and vacation traveler, as well as the business traveler, has a wider choice of luggage this season than ever before.

LEAD: Clouds, even the ones formed by pollution, can have a silver lining. Regulators who have been trying to keep the chemicals that form harmful ozone from getting into the air have found that the same equipment that controls those chemicals can help control benzene, a toxic component of gasoline.
LEAD: The Jets' final days of the 1980's have taken on strange overtones. Neither coaches, players nor front-office officials know what 1990 will bring.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were largely unchanged yesterday after strong opening gains were erased later in the session.

LEAD: Players come from many parts of the world to take part in American National Championships. At the Fall Nationals in Lancaster, Pa., last month there was at least one Australian. Richard Kahn of Cheltenham, Victoria, namesake of an American star of yesteryear, successfully completed his requirements to be an American life master, a rarity Down Under.
LEAD: The nation's trade deficit widened sharply in October to the highest level in 10 months and imports soared to a record level, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: Tom Landry, the coach at Dallas for 29 years until he was dismissed in February, will attend the Giants-Cowboys game today as a guest of Wellington Mara, the Giants' co-owner and a longtime friend.

LEAD: Nearly a year after a bomb destroyed a Pan Am jumbo jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people, Scottish investigators said today that ''hard evidence'' implicates several people in the attack.

LEAD: James Franklin Beard, a professor of English and a leading authority on the American author James Fenimore Cooper, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester, Mass. He was 70 years old and lived in Worcester.

LEAD: The field was reversed yesterday for Anthony Thompson of Indiana, the record-breaking running back who was second to Andre Ware of Houston in the Heisman Trophy balloting. This time Thompson was voted the 53d Maxwell Award by the Maxwell Club in Philadelphia as the outstanding college player and Ware was second.

LEAD: Manhattan Lawyer magazine, the snappy, irreverent journal on the New York legal scene, will cease publication as a weekly next week, and reappear as a monthly next spring, its president announced yesterday.

LEAD: The head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service is considering whether to ban some people seeking political asylum in the United States from working in cities that already have large immigrant populations.

LEAD: People give a book of the month and even cakes and cookies of the month, so why not music of the month, or at least every other month? Now there is the Lincoln Center Video-of-the-Month, featuring videocassette tapes of six of the most popular programs from the Emmy Award-winning series ''Live From Lincoln Center.
LEAD: Some stood silently, in tears. Some talked quietly with friends, while others gazed into the candle flames flickering beneath the portrait of the man they had come to mourn.

LEAD: The Talking Deals column in Business Day on Nov. 30 and its headline, about an investment fund created by the leveraged buyout firm of Forstmann, Little & Company, referred incorrectly to deals in which the firm has previously invested. They have been only friendly transactions to buy companies - deals in which management of the acquired company has cooperated.

LEAD: On an October day in 1975, Andrei D. Sakharov opened the door of his apartment on Chkalova Street in Moscow, greeted the small group of correspondents warmly and invited us in. Somehow, his greatness seemed accentuated by the simplicity of his surroundings. He wore a tattered sweater and old slippers; his flat was filled with worn furniture.

LEAD: Increases were approved yesterday for subway, bus and commuter train fares effective Jan. 1 NEW YORK CITY TRANSIT AUTHORITY Subways and buses . . . $1.15 Elderly and handicapped Buses . . . $.55 Subways . . . $1.15 round trip LON ISLAND RAIL ROAD AND METRO NORTH

LEAD: Stocks closed moderately lower yesterday, after recovering from earlier sharp losses, as investors reacted to the ''triple witching hour,'' the quarterly time when stock options, stock-index futures and stock-index options all expire.
LEAD: Leland H. Watson, a lighting designer for many years, died of leukemia on Dec. 8 at his home in Lafayette, Ind. He was 63 years old.
LEAD: The Army said today that there was ''incontestable evidence'' that a Jewish World War II veteran did not perform the heroic actions that he had claimed in seeking the Medal of Honor.

LEAD: Katarina Witt, East Germany's most famous athlete, said yesterday that she planned to appear on East German television tomorrow to discuss recent events regarding possible changes in the country's elite sports system. In an interview that appeared on NBC's ''Today'' show yesterday, Witt defended the system.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: The City Council voted today to dismiss a law firm because it lobbies for President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador, a day after four partners and an associate lawyer resigned from the firm for the same reason.
LEAD: Without Consent or Contract The Rise and Fall of American Slavery By Robert William Fogel 539 pages. W. W. Norton. $22.50.
LEAD: A sharp drop in the cost of gasoline helped to push producer prices lower in November, the Government said today.
LEAD: ''He is plunging a dagger into the city's heart.'' - Mayor Edward I. Koch on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's approval of a measure that could allow Staten Island to secede from New York City. [ 1:3. ]

LEAD: There is nothing in ''Chelsea's Bells,'' a new duet by Barry Martin for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, that you won't see on MTV. But even music videos usually give you more than an image of a young man consistently expressing a stirring in his loins for a woman in prostitute's gear who kicks him around.

LEAD: President Bush's planned visit to New York yesterday, which was to have begun with his helicopter landing on Central Park's Great Lawn, was canceled because snow was predicted and Mr. Bush had laryngitis.

LEAD: In July and August 1973, Patricio Aylwin moved with urgency and secrecy around Chile's troubled political scene - among church and military leaders, ministers of the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens and leaders of his own Christian Democratic Party.

LEAD: Kai Astir Bloom and Valentin Eduardo Hernandez were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York by the Rev. Salvatore B. Matarazzo. The bride is the daughter of Susan Frisch Sagor of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Roger F. Bloom of new York. Her husband is the son of Mrs.

LEAD: Stravinsky's ''Histoire du Soldat,'' the Brahms Clarinet Trio in A minor (Op. 114) and Schubert's Piano Trio in B flat (Op. 99) will be performed at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, 85 South Oxford Street, in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, at 3:30 P.M. tomorrow.
LEAD: By his own admission, Radek Halden, a cross-country ski instructor from Norway, was not much of an expert on Christmas trees when he arrived in New York City two weeks ago.

LEAD: The delinquency rate for home mortgages jumped sharply in the July-September quarter to the highest level in more than two years, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said Thursday. In the quarter, 5 percent of mortgage payments for one-family to four-family residences were 30 or more days late, up from a second-quarter rate of 4.52 percent, a 10-year low.

LEAD: The Giants will play the Dallas Cowboys at Giants Stadium at 12:30 P.M. Saturday in what could be a runaway. Against a defense that ranks fourth from the bottom in the National Football League, the Giants seem capable of rushing for 150 to 175 yards, even in the cold and wind.

LEAD: WITH life expectancies increasing, many people who stop working at age 65 can expect a 20- or 25-year retirement. That makes it vital to accumulate an investment portfolio that will provide returns that outpace inflation. And those who accept a lump-sum pension distribution and roll it over into an individual retirement account will need to manage it with long-term needs in mind.

LEAD: Wall Street awoke to a gigantic bull on its doorstep yesterday - a 3 1/2-ton 16-foot-long bronze sculpture by an artist from SoHo who deposited it outside the New York Stock Exchange and declared it a Yuletide symbol of the ''strength and power of the American people.''

LEAD: New York State's top drug-treatment official resigned today, one day after the release of a blistering state report that said he had directed more than $2 million to drug-abuse programs that were run by his friends and that failed to treat anybody.
LEAD: Two-year-old Israel Mastov, with a pacifier tied around his neck, runs about his parents' apartment in Rego Park, Queens, chattering: ''Zdrast! Hi! Shalom!''
LEAD: In a long expected move, China said tonight that it would devalue its currency by 21.2 percent against the dollar, effective Saturday. It is China's first devaluation since 1986.

LEAD: A letter of intent for the Adolph Coors Company to buy the Stroh Brewery Company's domestic beer-making operations for $425 million expired today with no sale, freeing Stroh to seek other buyers, the companies said. Chris Sortwell, Stroh vice president for corporate planning and development, said the companies had agreed not to discuss details.

LEAD: Peter M. Horn, a retired judge who served in the courts of New York City for 30 years, died on Tuesday at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass., after a long illness. He was 91 years old and lived in Pittsfield.

LEAD: Reflecting France's traditional distrust of NATO, President Francois Mitterrand is expected to emphasize the European Community's claim to a predominant role in reshaping Europe when he meets President Bush on the Caribbean island of St. Martin on Saturday.
LEAD: Ernest N. (Dutch) Morial has announced that contrary to widespread expectations here, he will not seek to regain the mayoralty, an office he held for eight years.

LEAD: Bush Administration officials are divided over whether the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and his aides signaled at the Malta summit talks that they were ready for a political settlement in Afghanistan that could exclude President Najibullah.

LEAD: The Mayor of Pisa signed an order today that will close the Tower of Pisa to the public from Jan. 7 to April 7 for safety reasons. Mayor Giacomino Granchi said officials would at least consider adopting safety measures that would allow a limited reopening of the tower. Shifting ground under the 180-foot tower left it tilting almost from the time that Bonnano Pisano started building it in 1173.

LEAD: The early 17th century was a time of great soul-searching in Europe. Aftershocks from the Reformation and Counter-Reformation still shuddered through cathedrals and palaces, calling into question political alliances, religious convictions and personal beliefs. This introspection inspired a library of dramatic literature that is all too infrequently performed.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To great fanfare, the Ethics Reform Act of 1989 increased Federal pay and reduced honorariums. It also attacked the revolving door phenomenon that has long plagued government. The act clarifies and strengthens existing law requiring former high executive branch officials, all members of Congress and top staff members to wait one year before returning to lobby their old haunts.

LEAD: The composer Andrzej Panufnik will conduct the New York Chamber Symphony in the world premiere of his ''Harmony'' and the New York premiere of his Violin Concerto at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, at 8 o'clock tonight. Elmar Oliveira will be the soloist in the concerto.
LEAD: A headline yesterday about an attack by Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas on a Syrian Army garrison misstated the site. It was in southern Lebanon, not Beirut.

LEAD: A man was arrested yesterday and charged in the killing of a New Jersey man who was stabbed to death in August as he stood at the entrance to his daughter's apartment building on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation surprised the auto industry today by announcing it would buy half of Saab-Scania A.B.'s troubled car-making operations. The move enlarges G.M.'s European presence and plugs a hole in the company's product line, which needs models that can compete with imports like BMW and Mercedes-Benz.
LEAD: ''No way Mark Davis would have fit in in New York,'' George Steinbrenner said. ''Some guys don't want the challenge of New York.''
LEAD: In an effort to attract more customers to its dealerships, the Chrysler Corporation has significantly broadened the scope of its rebates and its low-interest financing programs.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DRIVING THE SIDEWINDING ROADS OF THE Kentucky knobs, even the casual observer notices islands of prosperity among the jagged limestone cliffs and river valleys. Many of the peeling clapboard farmhouses of my childhood have been torn down and replaced with brick ranch-style homes. A new truck or car sits in the driveway - at times of day you'd expect the owner to be away at work.

LEAD: FANS! They're the solution. Not screaming, frenzied rock-star fans, not electric fans, but hand-held semicircles of ribbed paper, lace and silk. Fans held delicately in front of one's face, calling attention to flirtatious eyes. Fans snapping shut for emphasis. Fans gracefully fluttered to advertise allure.

LEAD: Leslie Hope Derene studied historic preservation at Boston University and spent eight years working in the fashion industry before finding her true calling. She now takes photographs and mounts them on gift and note cards, holiday ornaments and portfolios.

LEAD: When a construction crane fell more than 16 stories into the heart of San Francisco's financial district last month, killing five people, it was one of the worst such accidents on record. But it was no fluke.
LEAD: Vanessa Teixeira said what she really wanted for Christmas was a tea set and chair cushions.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Roni Miller, to Andrew Lawrence Porter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Porter. Both families live in Jericho, L.I. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: INSIDE the locker room, a stuffed Bugs Bunny has so many obscene messages about this week's foe sketched on it that one wonders if a wrong turn was made into a bawdy saloon. Out on the practice field on this warm, bright day, a touchdown toss clicks, and whoops and hollers reach a fever pitch as one player lovingly locks another in a headlock.
LEAD: WITH English plum puddings, Jamaican rum cakes and Mexican ornaments, Laine Dyer and Nicole Shirley are hoping to promote peace.

LEAD: RUNNING WILD. By J. G. Ballard. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95.) Over the last 25 years, the British writer J. G. Ballard has touched a great many stylistic bases, ranging from straight science fiction (''The Drowned World'') to abrasive experimentalism (''Crash'') to autobiographical realism (''Empire of the Sun'').
LEAD: To the Editor: We found ourselves in the same situation as the person who wrote (Q & A, Travel, Oct. 8) about what to do in London during the Christmas holiday.

LEAD: SUSAN HALL sits on a wooden bench in S. R. Kelly and Sons, an eel and pie shop in London's East End and, with shining blue eyes, surveys the plate before her. An oblong meat pie with a flaky and ''ever-so-luverly'' brown crust dominates one half of the plate. Next to it lies a huge dollop of mashed potatoes, swimming in a green-flecked sea of parsley sauce, or ''liquor.

LEAD: When Councilman James T. Herl of Prince George's County attended the University of Maryland, he fought for students' rights against landlords who he said were more concerned about profit margins than respectable and affordable housing.

LEAD: To cash in on the consumer craze for high-priced crystal as gifts and collectibles, several manufacturers have moved into the upscale market or broadened their line of prestige products that sell for $500 and up. And to appeal to collectors, they are offering many of these products, from clocks to figurines, on an exclusive basis either by limiting the quantity or the time in which they are available for sale.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Some months ago, NBC ran a full-page advertisement that asked if it mattered whether the anchor of a nightly news program was this fellow or that. The ad's unastonishing answer was that it mattered a lot and that NBC's own man Tom Brokaw was the anchor of choice. Unfortunately for NBC, that does not seem to be the opinion of most viewers.

LEAD: A LAWSUIT filed by major league baseball against a tavern here seeks to have it stop the unauthorized showing of satellite broadcasts of games to patrons, but the tavern's owner says he is only doing what other bars in the area have done for years.
LEAD: CLOTH AND HUMAN EXPERIENCE Edited by Annette B. Weiner and Jane Schneider. Illustrated. 431 pp. Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press. $39.95.

LEAD: Alban Berg's ''Wozzeck'' was the first atonal opera to get anywhere near standard repertory status, and it is still the only one. (Berg's second opera, ''Lulu,'' is the only other remote contender.) It was first heard in 1925 and had almost 30 productions by the early 30's. After a hiatus while Nazi disapproval halted its progress before German-speaking audiences, it resumed its place at home and spread to all the world's operatic capitals.

LEAD: President Bush said today that he had ''no second thoughts at all'' about sending envoys to China last week. But he added that he did not believe that it was time for the United States or other countries to remove sanctions against China, imposed after the killings of students protesting for democracy in
LEAD: ''THE only child gets whatever he or she wants.'' Of all the stereotypical statements attached to the label only child, this one is probably the furthest from the truth.
LEAD: A high-ranking Ohio teamster official denied Friday that he took part in his own union's attempt to thwart the Government's disciplinary action against him.

LEAD: The following is from a letter my father wrote to me in 1981: ''In 1956, I went to Nevada to a field test of an atomic shot. It was a 28-kiloton shot and we were in the trenches at three miles from ground zero. . . . The ground rolled like the waves in the ocean, and the flash was so bright that, with my eyes closed and with my head cradled in my arm and my arm resting on my leg, I could see every bone in my arm and legs like you see in an X-ray picture.

LEAD: Los Alamos, N.M., is 25 miles from the Pueblo Indian Reservation communities of Santa Clara and San Ildefonso. I was raised at Santa Clara during the 1950's, and my grandfather, grandmother, father and mother all worked at Los Alamos. Scores of Indians were employed there during (and after) the time it was a ''closed atomic city,'' although Mr.

LEAD: Lee Van Cleef, the film actor whose steely eyes and rugged features led to a long career portraying Western arch-villains, died, apparently of a heart attack, early today at St. John's Regional Medical Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Oxnard.

LEAD: HEIDEGGER AND NAZISM By Victor Farias. Edited by Joseph Margolis and Tom Rockmore. Translated by Paul Burrell (French) and Gabriel R. Ricci (German). 349 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $29.95.

LEAD: Sneaky and improper dumping is a source of controversy and outrage for bridge players as well as for environmentalists and urban planners. Can it ever be proper to play badly by intention, dumping points to opponents who have not earned them and damaging other players in the process? It is easy to answer this question with a flat negative, and many, but not all, authorities do so.

LEAD: WITH ITS UNCATALOGUED FLORA and fauna - literally millions of species and genera - the tropical rain forest canopy is the natural world's richest frontier, a world unto itself, really. And the latest best hope for scientists eager to explore it is, fittingly, a little on the otherworldly side.

LEAD: Zarin Mehta, the managing director of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, has been named executive director and chief operating officer of the Ravinia Music Festival, the summer home of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, in Highland Park, Ill.

LEAD: As it prepares for a critical gubernatorial election, the New York State Republican Party is better financed and better staffed than it has been since the Rockefeller era. But it still lacks an experienced and well-known candidate to challenge Gov. Mario M. Cuomo if he seeks a third term and to end a 16-year Republican absence from the

LEAD: By the waters of Boksburg Lake, members of the self-anointed guardian of white supremacy, the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, sat down today to decry the betrayal of their tribe by President F. W. de Klerk.

LEAD: Catherine Ann Chesebrough and Hynek Pesta Kalkus were married yesterday at the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour in Manhasset, L.I., by the Rev. Thomas E. Hammond. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Chesebrough of Manhasset and Naples, Fla. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kalkus of Arlington, Va., and Newport, R
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The history books show a certain Col. James Montgomery, who commanded a black Civil War regiment in the vicinity of Charleston, talking about his soldiers in a particularly instructive way.

LEAD: When India's ninth democratically elected Parliament is called into session on Monday, Prime Minister V. P. Singh will bring with him a Cabinet that by most accounts has been constructed with imagination and skill.
LEAD: IF that Christmas stocking feels a bit thin and spindly this year, it may be because the world's largest supplier of windshield wipers has had its way with Santa.

LEAD: Lawrence Taylor. He redefined linebacker, forced offenses to redesign blocking patters, turned sacks into an art form and carried a team on his back all the way to the championship. GREG KIERNAN Stamford, Conn.

LEAD: Man-bites-dog it is not, but these days it qualifies as news when an early-music specialist of international standing comes to New York to perform anything earlier than Haydn or Mozart. Most early-musicians are tripping over each other on their self-appointed march through music history, some already feverishly polishing off Beethoven so they can move on to Schumann, Brahms and even

LEAD: SOMEWHERE along Interstate 195 in western Monmouth County, on the stretch of highway between Trenton and Freehold, two huge wooden structures display graphic messages to passing motorists. Residents of this rural, undeveloped, horse-breeding region are, to say the least, unhappy with a proposal to site a hazardous-waste incinerator on one of the state's few remaining pieces of virgin land.
LEAD: Canada's New Cross-Country Express Train
LEAD: Its a pity Eva Stychova didn't live to see it, though I can imagine the cracks she would make, accompanied by her knowing smile.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: My brother's name was Doug, the partner he left behind is Skip (Hers: ''A Brother's Death,'' by Barbara Lazear Ascher, Nov. 19). Doug's ashes rest in the sea off the coast of Maine, and he has been gone two years. In every other respect (that he was 31 when he died of AIDS, that he was the brother of two sisters and that his parents were unashamed of the cause of his death) the circumstances of Doug and Bobby are the same.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

LEAD: FAULTY GROUND. By Gabrielle Donnelly. (Victor Gollancz/David & Charles, $19.95.) When a University of London professor named Susan Barnes decides to visit her cousin Joanna in Los Angeles, she brings along the notes for her half-finished introduction to a new edition of ''Emma'' and a complete set of prejudices regarding the vapidity of the Hollywood film industry, the California beach culture and the United States in general.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Franklin P. Darmory, president of the Alcide Corporation of Norwalk, Conn., died of a heart attack on Dec. 7 while in London on a business trip. He was 46 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

LEAD: Treasured memorabilia from the career of Walt Disney, including early original drawings by the cartoonist and animator, were destroyed in a house fire here Friday. The house, in the Toluca Lake area, about 20 miles northwest of downtown, is owned by William Cottrell, an 83-year-old relative of Mr.
LEAD: LEGISLATION designed to provide equal treatment and broad changes for disabled people in the United States, estimated to number at least 43 million, is expected to be enacted early next year.
LEAD: AWAKENING from a creative coma, the National Hockey League plans to be born again in the South. Praise the Lord, y'all, and pass the tardy puck.
LEAD: The police said on Friday that they were looking for a man who sexually assaulted three boys in separate incidents in the last month in two Brooklyn parks.

LEAD: The engagement of Cynthia Terry Lawrence to Alan Read Ziegler Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ziegler of Rochester, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Thomas A. Farr of Beaufort, S.C., and Alfred N. Lawrence Jr. of Lawrence, L.I. A February wedding is planned.
LEAD: A caption on page 15 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the film ''Roger and Me'' misidentifies the film maker. He is Michael Moore.
LEAD: 'COOKIES AND CAROLS'

LEAD: Within the next two weeks, there will be be millions of ''I'm going to be a better person'' resolutions made. Thousands of them will be either ''this year I am going to start a diary'' or ''this year I'm going to keep up the diary I did start.''
LEAD: A wave of euphoria swept across Colombia today in the aftermath of the killing by security forces of a powerful drug trafficker accused of directing a four-month terror campaign.
LEAD: A three-way tie: Dutch Reagan, who spent eight years ducking media beanballs, Wayne Gretzky, and Martina Navratilova. JEROME AGEL New York

LEAD: IT didn't work out for Pam Postema. She came as close as any woman has ever come to being an umpire in the major leagues, but last week they let her go. There is no next step for her.

LEAD: Set, costumes and lighting blended with motion to magical effect in an evening of dance by Douglas Dunn, seen on Dec. 9 at Mr. Dunn's SoHo loft. Mimi Gross's vivid set and Carol Mullins's painterly lighting were so right that the dance often looked designed to animate that imaginative landscape. Given Mr.

LEAD: A man identified as a dissident in China was arrested and hospitalized in Japan on Saturday after a Chinese jetliner bound for New York with 223 people aboard was hijacked and forced to land in the southern Japanese city of Fukuoka.

LEAD: The U.S. merchandise trade deficit widened sharply to $10.2 billion in October, the biggest imbalance in 10 months, as imports reached a record level. The Government also reported that inventories climbed four-tenths of a percent in October, to a seasonally adjusted $793.9 billion. In November, wholesale prices edged down a tenth of a percent and capacity utilization also was down a tenth of a point, to 82.7 percent.

LEAD: In ''Sorceress,'' one of the more intense pieces in LadyGourd SanGoma's ''Look Above the Clouds,'' the quartet of African-American female singers, dancers and instrumentalists dons silver masks to act out a ritual of transformation. Twirling tubular instruments that make an eerie cry, the women dance and sing a chant that a program note describes as ''dedicated to all women of color, who against all odds managed to turn glass into diamonds.

LEAD: The engagement of Elizabeth Hayes Kirkland to John Tobin Cahill, a son of Mrs. Joseph F. Cahill of Charleston, S.C., and the late Mr. Cahill, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Kirkland Jr., also of Charleston. A February wedding is planned.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 19 about donating unwanted books gave the hours of the Bryn Mawr Book Shop in New York City incorrectly. The shop is open Thursday through Saturday from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., and on Sunday from 12:30 P.M. to 4:30 P.M.

LEAD: FOR four decades, the Pentagon has based its budgets, its strategy and its public relations largely on one premise: the Russians are coming. But now the Russians are going, and the Pentagon is experiencing the painful process of adjusting to the new military reality.
LEAD: Like many Communist parties that have relied heavily on the support of Eastern European governments, Greece's Communist Party is battling for survival.

LEAD: Cristina Perotti from Italy and an American, Laurence Lynn Dutt, form a piano duo specializing in music for four hands at one piano. Their program at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday night had none of the expected music - no Schubert or Mozart, no Ravel.

LEAD: February wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Roger Tolins of Roslyn, L.I., for their daughter, Fran Susan Tolins, and Joshua Alan Weingast, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Weingast of Pomona, N.Y.

LEAD: Rickey Henderson. His major league-leading totals on offense were: stolen bases, 838; walks, 962; runs, 1,122. Ty Cobb's comparable totals in his best decade (1910-1919) were: stolen bases, 577; walks, 602; runs, 1,050. THOMAS ASSICURATO The Bronx
LEAD: SOME FREAKS By David Mamet. 180 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

LEAD: At the Harvard University Memorial Chapel in Cambridge, Mass., Marina Jolanta Ivashenko, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Serge Ivashenko of Rutherford, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregory Winston Slayton, a son of Walter Slayton of Virginia Beach, Va., and Susan North Childs Slayton of Norfolk, Va.

LEAD: You ordered the burger, the fries and the Coke, but you certainly didn't order the Flounder. There he is anyway: a three-inch blue-and-yellow rubber replica of a character from ''The Little Mermaid'' right there in your McDonald's Happy Meal, in a box adorned with jokes and puzzles that test your knowledge of Little Mermaid lore.
LEAD: Theodore Roosevelt's home on Long Island, like the hyperactive President, is neither pretentious nor subtle.

LEAD: I HAVE always told friends I would know the revolution had come when they put diaper-changing tables in men's rooms. This year I moved to New Jersey and found that it had happened without me. The tables are already in place at the Princeton MarketFair - and it was built two whole years ago.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I cried when I saw the first pictures of Hugo's devastation, and cried again when I read Blanche McCrary Boyd's essay about her visit to Charleston after the hurricane. To those of us who were born and reared there, Charleston will always be home.
LEAD: LIKE many organizations that depend on volunteers, the Connecticut Braille Association is finding fewer people who are willing to work as volunteers, to transcribe books into Braille.

LEAD: To see the two collaboratively choreographed works that Sara Pearson and Patrik Widrig presented Friday night at Performance Space 122 was to watch two talented artists dance their way into a rut. Both pieces, to taped collages, concerned lovers' difficulties in getting along. But these choreographic variations on a theme lacked variety.

LEAD: IN many ways, the geographic heart of Mexico is also its spiritual and cultural heart. Dotted with elegant colonial cities and villages that still hew to traditional folkways and crafts, the area extending in an arc west and north of the capital is rich both in character and history. And unlike the Yucatan or the resorts of the Pacific Coast, the states of Michoacan, Guanajuato and Queretaro are readily accessible from Mexico

LEAD: THE HIDDEN ORDER: Tokyo Through the Twentieth Century. By Yoshinobu Ashihara. Translated by Lynne E. Riggs. (Kodansha International, $17.95). Japanese interiors may be the picture of stark and perfect order, but step out into a Japanese city and chaos takes over. Streets zigzag; buildings of all shapes and sizes are jumbled together like someone's closet full of toys.
LEAD: John M. Alden, an engineer and the founder of Alden Electronics, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Needham, Mass. He was 66 years old.
LEAD: A chart on Dec. 3 with an article about Tampa misstated the basis for calculating taxi fares. After the initial 95 cents, the fare is $1.50 for each mile, not kilometer.

LEAD: THE cobblestone streets of the medieval German city of Freiburg, near the French border in a valley protected by the lush slopes of the Black Forest, are lined by narrow canals filled with fresh, running water. They were built, some say, in an effort to help keep the streets cool in hot weather.
LEAD: Concert for Amnesty

LEAD: THE phone call was a surprise. I had spoken with my mother earlier in the day. Her doctor had indicated the chest pain was caused by pneumonia but the prescribed antibiotics were working, her fever was down and she felt better. Then my brother called to report she had increasing chest pain and was fearful of being alone.

LEAD: In a bid for a share of the upper tier of the crystal market, more and more manufacturers are forming collectors' clubs. Membership buys certain privileges - for instance, the ability to purchase exclusive pieces. But the real intention of these marketing ploys is to lock in collectors to a given brand, thereby increasing the sales of both retailers and manufacturers, which market the clubs together.

LEAD: I felt an all too familiar rumbling in the pit of my working-mommy belly as I read Janet Gibbs-Albanesius's article, ''That Old Question for a Candidate'' (Opinion page, Oct. 29). To respond to it, I must make a statement that they just don't ask men the same questions they ask women in any given situation.

LEAD: To the Editor In May 1968, I (age 12) watched my father collapse on a tennis court in Southampton, L.I. (''America's Radiation Victims: The Hidden Files,'' by Clifford T. Honicker, Nov. 19). That December, he was dead of acute leukemia at the age of 40.
LEAD: Fake furs. They're hot fashion. And why not? Made of synthetic pile cloth, they provide affordable, lightweight warmth, and look wild, too.
LEAD: THE Yale Center for British Art has never seemed more British than it does now, with ''The Desired Haven,'' a group of 89 photographs by Frederick H. Evans (1853-1943).

LEAD: Much has been written about the proper storage and care of pictures. Generally, photographs - whether prints or slides - should be kept cool, dry and in the dark. But what about cameras, lenses and other equipment?

LEAD: The phrase ''hot house'' may come to take on a new and radically different meaning as a result of a series of legal actions in Westchester County involving a large one-family home that was built from stolen materials. The property, at 10 Seth Canyon Drive in Mount Kisco, was seized two months ago by Westchester County after its owner, Wally
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Greg LeMond. His growth as an athlete during the 80's was capped by the most astonishing comeback on the final day of the 1989 Tour de France. RICHARD FERTELL New York
LEAD: SQUEAKY stairs are a comfort to some homeowners. Familiar noises on the stairs signal the return of family members, while unfamiliar noises may warn of an intruder.
LEAD: Vietnam opposes the forced return of boat people who sought refuge in Hong Kong and reserves the right to send them back to the British colony, the official Hanoi press agency said.

LEAD: Mrs. Charles E. Willis of Locust Valley, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Wendy Lee Willis, to David W. Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Smith of Manhasset, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: If Konstantine Kakanias had his way, most of the things that surround him in the world would be painted - and he would quickly volunteer for the job. The 28-year-old artist, who was born in Athens, lives in New York and is well on his way to putting his imprimatur on scenic backdrops for shop windows, glossy magazine pages and table tops.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Clawson of Rochester have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Martha L. Clawson and Bradford B. Bjorklund, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce C. Bjorklund of Mill Neck, L.I.
LEAD: I think we can tell ourselves that it's going to be all right now.

LEAD: It is difficult to know whether the newly finished headquarters of Creative Artists Agency at the intersection of Wilshire and Santa Monica Boulevards here is a throwback or an odd stroke of the avant-garde for this city of the forever new. For this building, the first Los Angeles-area work of I. M.

LEAD: The graying of New Jersey described in John Paul Marosy's article, ''When the Aged Need Care, Their Families Need a Hand'' (Opinion page, Oct. 15), coupled with the anticipated growth of the state's economy resulting in an increasing need for qualified workers, causes a new concern in the workplace.
LEAD: THE MAN WHO SHOT GARBO The Hollywood Photographs of Clarence Sinclair Bull. Text by Terence Pepper and John Kobal. Foreword by Katharine Hepburn. 256 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $40.
