LEAD: January wedding plans for Karen Ann Engelbourg and Donald Bruce Stewart have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Saul Engelbourg of Newton Centre, Mass.

LEAD: E. C. Dothard, the state trooper wounded in the 1972 assassination attempt on Gov. George C. Wallace, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound Friday night in a hospital where he was being treated for terminal cancer. He was 58 years old.

LEAD: Reflecting the dramatic improvement in East-West relations, the international agency that controls technological exports to the Eastern bloc is close to the most significant relaxation of rules in its 40-year history, Bush Administration officials said this week.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-35 Vaclav Havel may become President of Czechoslovakia until elections are held. The playwright appeared close to an agreement with former Prime Minister Alexander Dubcek to lead the opposition's fight for the vacant post. 1

From the first bars of the program's opening work - the Brahms Sonata No. 1 in F minor (Op. 120) -one gathered that Mr.

LEAD: A March wedding is planned by Lisa Kathleen Guglielmone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tito Walter Guglielmone of Oakdale, L.I., and Frederick Joseph Gillis, a son of Miriam R. Gillis of Detroit and the late Judge Joseph Augustus Gillis Jr. Ms. Guglielmone, 28 years old, graduated from Cornell University and received an M.B.A.

LEAD: Baseball: Nolan Ryan. Hockey: Wayne Gretzky. Football: Joe Montana. Tennis: Martina Navratilova. Basketball: Magic Johnson. Track and Field: Edwin Moses. My choice: Montana. THAYER SWALLEN Fairfield, Conn.

LEAD: The engagement of Marcia Harriet Perlstein to Dr. Lawrence Bradley Lusk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Lusk of White Plains, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Fred N. Perlstein of Oakland, Calif. A March wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Wendy Anne Charles, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Simpson Charles 3d of Short Hills, to Francis Patrick Maguire, a son of Mrs. Michael J. Fives of Hauppauge, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Kenyon J. Wildrick performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The engagement of Sydney Ann Solomon to Harry N. Neuhaus has been announced by their parents, Dr. and Mrs. Henry A. Solomon of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Peter Neuhaus of West Palm Beach, Fla. A February wedding is planned.

LEAD: Any listener whose interest in Western classical music extends beyond superficial ''music appreciation'' to a concern with origins, formal principles and stylistic evolution must sooner or later come to grips with the rich musical heritage of the Arab world.

LEAD: ''JASPER WHITE'S Cooking From New England'' (Harper & Row, $27.95) is a timely new addition to the cookbook shelf. The owner of Jasper's in Boston has assembled a collection of traditional and contemporary New England recipes, many of which make for mouth-watering holiday fare.

LEAD: The wife of an Israeli airman taken prisoner in 1986 by Shiite militiamen in southern Lebanon said today that her husband is now in the custody of the Iranian authorities. Asked about the woman's assertion, a senior Israeli military official in Jerusalem said tonight: ''It's true. I can confirm it, and we are calling on Iran to release him.

LEAD: DO not dismiss the Boston Post Road Stage Company on the evidence of the current cheerless production of ''The Mistress of the Inn.'' The dauntless little professional theater in Fairfield has considerable virtues but playing classic comedy is just not one of them.

LEAD: AT a time when co-op and condominium owners are struggling to maintain the market value of their homes, curb appeal - the first impression a buyer gets of a complex or building - is assuming new importance.

LEAD: Carolers, bell ringers and dancers waving giant paper snowflakes paraded through the marble halls of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue in a burst of holiday joy on Thursday night. An enormous Christmas tree glittering with simulated snow stood tall in Astor Hall.

LEAD: H.L. MENCKEN made the first entry in his diary on Nov. 5, 1930. The great journalist, critic and editor was 50 years old, just married for the first time and, as Charles A. Fecher, the editor of the diary, tells us, deeply, romantically in love with his wife, Sara. It's ironic that Mencken began his diary in the first year of a new decade.
LEAD: A Federal judge has ordered that retroactive disability benefits be paid to heart patients in New York State who were erroneously cut off the Social Security rolls by the Federal Government.
LEAD: An offer by Maurice Stans to donate his family home and a new museum to his hometown has been rejected because officials do not want to be responsible for the upkeep.

LEAD: FOR more than a year, clubs and agents have wrangled over lockout language in players' contracts. The clubs, at the urging of the Player Relations Committee, insisted that the players agree to provisions that said they would not be paid if the owners locked them out. No season was specified, but 1990 was the target because the two sides have to negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement for a period beginning next year.
LEAD: ICE SCULPTURE

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Egan of Malvern, Pa., and Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexis Marie Egan, to Paul Francis McCarthy, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William McCarthy of Hingham, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: THE day Patrick Lyden, a Pace University senior, opts for a job in the corporate sector may not be far off. For starters, the money will be better than he is earning now, not to mention the health-care benefits he will be entitled to, and perhaps a chance to have his graduate-school tuition reimbursed.
LEAD: Whenever the Los Angeles Lakers visit, there is excitement in the air, a large crowd is in the stands, and the opposing team's level of play usually rises.

LEAD: Crystal has always been a favorite gift for brides. But in the past two years, corporations have realized the value of giving a valuable gift like crystal to top clients and high-performing employees.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Fuchs of Tenafly, N.J., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Margot Lynn Fuchs, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at Yeshiva University and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and Marc Alan Schwartz, a third-year student at Columbia University Law School.
LEAD: The sports secrets that have given East Germany hundreds of Olympic medals are on the block.

LEAD: Remember sweet-and-sour pork? It is one of the first dishes most people over 40 ate at a Chinese restaurant. It was always a Cantonese restaurant; 40 years ago, Szechuan had yet to reach the United States. Actually, the dish was mainly sweet; the vast quantities of sugar and the canned pineapple in heavy syrup disguised whatever sour ingredients had been added.

LEAD: An autopsy today determined that a worker died of extreme heat when a boiler exploded at a tannery Friday night, the police said. Joseph Insogna, 62 years old, of Gloversville, was working alone in the Pan American Tannery when the boiler blew up about 7:30 P.M. or unknown reasons, said Patrolman Stan Stoller of the Gloversville police.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding ''Nocturne in St.-Tropez'' (Travel, Aug. 20), which recently came to my attention, I realize that the focus was on the beautiful people in what has become one of their special enclaves, but I would like to point out that between Colette's arriving there in 1926 and Brigitte Bardot's putting St.-Tropez on the world's movie screens in 1955, an event occurred that merits mention.

LEAD: THE head of the New York State Consumer Protection Board knows firsthand the escalating costs of cable television service on Long Island. ''I'm a Cablevision subscriber and I now pay $80.20 a month for my cable,'' said Richard Kessel, who has cable hooked up to several television sets in his Bellmore home so he can catch sports and ''News 12, Long Island.

LEAD: One of the works of art now on the market that this critic would most like to find in his Christmas stocking is the painting after Veronese by Eugene Delacroix that is now on view at the Salander-O'Reilly Gallery, 20 East 79th Street. The subject is a detail - two bearded heads - from the great ''Marriage at Cana'' by Veronese in the
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A January wedding is planned by Amy Sue Weber and David Lawrence Stern, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Weber of Westbury, L.I., have announced.

LEAD: THANKS largely to American university research, Toshiba Inc. is developing a new technology for recording images on disks, the Toyota Motor Company is devising new engineering stress sensors, and the Asahi Chemical Company is computerizing its manufacturing processes.

LEAD: THIS fall, Seattle voters narrowly approved, in a nonbinding referendum, a measure asking the school board to stop busing students for racial balance. The vote, which was not as clear as it might look, may symbolize the state of school desgregation these days.

LEAD: As China's leaders try to tug the nation toward greater central planning and more orthodox Communism, people here on the country's sun-drenched southern frontier are enthusiastically pulling in the other direction.

LEAD: The New World Symphony calls itself America's National Training Orchestra. But the ensemble, of which Michael Tilson Thomas is ''founding conductor and artistic adviser,'' now also counts as Miami's principal orchestra, with the demise several years back of the Florida Philharmonic.

LEAD: ''It was an incredible experience,'' Ron Kovic said of watching Tom Cruise portray him on the set of ''Born on the Fourth of July'' in Dallas last year. ''I was looking at myself live through the most difficult periods of my life. I was forced to deal with the reality of the hell that I had lived through in a way that I never dealt with it before.
LEAD: Well, either it was menopause at long last, or else I was pregnant. Terrific. No one's going to believe this. From a college professor? Try.

LEAD: Darynn Zimmer, a soprano, was presented in her New York debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening by Joy in Singing, an organization that offers vocal master classes and holds an annual competition. Ms. Zimmer has a lovely voice - compact but amply powered; generally sweet in tone, but dark and sensuous when the music and text require those qualities.
LEAD: Mrs. George Sousa of West Hartford, Conn., has announced May wedding plans for her daughter Diana Sousa and George Christian Jepsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Jepsen of Greenwich, Conn.
LEAD: Salt Lake City, home of the artificial heart, the Mormon Church and a persevering pioneer spirit, has in the last two decades, become a contemporary, cosmopolitan city.

LEAD: FEW people keep them under their pillows or massage them like good-luck charms. But the craving for high-priced objects and goblets of cut glass certainly rivals the craze for the fashionable ''new-age'' crystal rocks, especially during this gift-giving season, when 40 percent of all crystal is sold.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Balley of North Hills, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Jacqueline Sue Balley, and Lawrence Marc Glassheim, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Glassheim of Merrick, L.I.

LEAD: Students at Wellesley College have a new gift-giving option this holiday season. Condom jewelry was sold for $1 at the Student Center for two days last week by AIDS Alert, a student group dedicated to raising AIDS awareness. Each condom packet is decorated with glitter and paint and has hardware attached to make it either a pin or an earring.

LEAD: At the beginning of the decade, photography served the art world as a sign of cultural hyperabundance. It was held responsible for filling the world with images, for replacing primary experience, for substituting reproductions for unique art objects. It also helped usher in an era in which high culture seemed less vital and interesting a subject than the realm of television, magazines and movies.

LEAD: When Harry Met Sally . . . 1989. Nelson/Orion. $89.98. Laser disk. $24.95. 1 hour 36 minutes. Closed captioned. R. On and off for 11 years - beginning in college in the late 60's -Harry (Billy Crystal) and Sally (Meg Ryan) ostensibly debate whether men and women can be nonsexual friends.
LEAD: Elizabeth Vogel and John M. Schmidt were married yesterday at St. Vincent the Martyr Roman Catholic Church in Madison, N.J., by the Rev. James Reedy.
LEAD: RESIDENTS of this seaside town have weighed equity against history - and history has come up light.

LEAD: UTZ, by Bruce Chatwin. (Penguin, $7.95.) A petty aristocrat named Kaspar Joachim Utz becomes trapped in Czechoslovakia by the priceless collection of porcelain that he refuses to leave behind. The last novel of Bruce Chatwin, who died earlier this year, shows him ''at his most erudite and evocative,'' Robert Stone said here in January.

LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo and the three main opposition leaders have broken a deadlock over a range of issues lingering from the term of Mr. Roh's predecessor, politicians and diplomats said today. The dispute has bogged down Korean politics for two years.

LEAD: New York's City Council is a little like a lottery winner who has lived from hand to mouth for years and suddenly must learn to manage money, or make a profligate mess of things. What the Council must manage is power. The new City Charter gives it central authority over the city's most pressing duties.

LEAD: February wedding plans have been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Paul Ocken of Watchung, N.J., for their daughter Michele Ocken and Michael A. Wolfson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin E. Wolfson of Princeton, N.J.

LEAD: The Government of President Elias Hrawi, still reluctant to use force to oust Gen. Michel Aoun, the renegade Christian commander, is instead resorting to economic and political pressure to remove him.

LEAD: Semaphore Dance Theater of Boston offered two imagistic productions by its director, Janice Margolis, on Thursday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace. Both had texts by Thomas Frick and taped collages that blended original scores with sound effects and solemn and frivolous music by various composers.

LEAD: Julie Simone Brill, an assistant attorney general of Vermont, and Mark Edward Miller, an industrial designer, were married yesterday at the Mountain Top Inn in Chittenden, Vt. Tom Voity, a justice of the peace in Chittenden, officiated.

LEAD: FOR nearly 100 years, Mount Vernon Hospital has been an integral part of the small city for which it is named. A bit run-down by the most modern standards, the hospital is nevertheless viewed with pride -even affection - by many old-timers. It is, after all, the place where local children are born and where the sick and elderly have traditionally sought remedies for what ails them.

LEAD: Louise Bell Gilliam and Arthur Lee McGrady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lee McGrady of Charlottesville, Va., plan to be married in April. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Sara Brown Gilliam and George Harrison Gilliam, both of Charlottesville.

LEAD: If you're racing to complete your holiday shopping, it helps to have a few audio fans on your Christmas list. They are easy to shop for - even at the last minute. To find something in a hurry in a hi-fi shop to please music-minded friends, just check out all those little gadgets known collectively as audio accessories.

LEAD: A March wedding is planned by Colleen Marie Hoyt and Charles Richmond Dailey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Dailey of Newtown, Conn., the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Hoyt of Pennington, N.J., have announced.

LEAD: IN New York City, zoning change is always in the air. Ever since the basic change of 1961 there have been refinements and additions to the law, sometimes tending to encourage, sometimes to discourage, redevelopment. And at times the goal is to alter the style of new residential construction.
LEAD: MAINTAINING a remarkable immunity to slumps in the real estate market, the Merritt 7 Office Park in Norwalk has been fully rented since the first of four buildings opened 11 years ago.

LEAD: Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, remembers a time when the only blacks at major hotels were those serving ''white folks.''

LEAD: Five top staff aides of the New York City Council have received substantial pay increases to the $100,000-a-year level as the legislative body prepares to exercise expanded powers in the new year.

LEAD: Alison Poorvu, an assistant director of admissions at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, and Daniel G. Jaffe, a geologist, plan to marry in March. Their engagement was announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Poorvu of Cambridge, Mass.
LEAD: Confusion and insecurity reigned in East German politics today as the Communist Party struggled to redefine its role and new parties tried to take form.

LEAD: BY now, theatergoers who favor traditional holiday fare may have had their seasonal share of the Scrooge saga. As ever, it seems that a slew of ''Christmas Carols,'' or variations thereof, were already under way just after Thanksgiving weekend, in community and college theaters. Most have passed, although there is still time, through next Sunday, to attend the McCarter Theater's annual Dickens extravaganza in Princeton.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from a news conference by President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand of France today in St. Martin, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: Q. . . . I understand that one area of disagreement between the both of you was on the subject of export controls on highly sensitive goods shipped into Eastern Europe, the so-called Cocom regulations.

LEAD: WHEN the presidents of five Central American countries met in Honduras last August, they quickly gave up the idea that they could stretch a single broad framework of peace across their contrasting political conflicts. In two days of often bitter meetings, they settled for a narrower, less idealistic accord: ratification of an agreement to disband the American-supported

LEAD: Boo Harvey's new haircut, Malik Sealy's career-high scoring performance and some signs of life from the St. John's bench in the team's last four games were among the highlights last night at Alumni Hall as the Redmen easily defeated Manhattan College, 68-52.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: James L. Adler Jr. of Phoenix and Audrey R. Wolf of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie L. Adler to William S. Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harrison of Haddonfield, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Martina Navratilova. Her phenomenal ability elevated interest in women's tennis so it now has as much visibility as the men's game. And recently, she has made the transition from unbeatable dynamo to aging underdog with wit and grace. SARA DZIKIEWICZ Long Island City

LEAD: WHEN David Harrington lists his friends, he is quick to include Milo Sheff. And Milo puts David on his list. The 10-year-olds share an interest in drawing. And they have another bond. They are suing Connecticut.

LEAD: SINCE the late 40's, the popularity of pizza has spread so far that for some families it is now as American as apple pie. And just about everyone has a preference in pizza: Neapolitan. Sicilian. Chicago. Thick crust or thin. Recent years added a new dimension, the California-style pizza with toppings that can include anything from artichokes to zucchini.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Spy Inquiry Is Curtailed The F.B.I. has found no solid evidence in its intensive espionage investigation of a veteran diplomat, Felix S. Bloch, and it has significantly scaled back its inquiry, Federal officials say.

LEAD: AMERICAN POWER: The Rise and Decline of U.S. Globalism, 1918-1968. By John Taft. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) The ascension of the United States as a world power, according to John Taft, was largely due to the efforts of a Northeastern, Ivy League-educated, internationalist elite. This group, including George Kennan, Averell Harriman and Dean Acheson, believed that world order could be created through the Wilsonian ideals of free trade, democracy, anti-imperialism and world organizations.

LEAD: Joyce Rachel Ellman, an assistant general counsel for the New York City Transit Authority, and Marc Howard Fryburg, a lawyer in New York, plan to marry in April. Ms. Ellman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Ellman of New York, graduated cum laude from Barnard College and received a J.D. degree from Yeshiva University.
LEAD: FREEDOM BOUND A History of America's Civil Rights Movement. By Robert Weisbrot. Illustrated. 350 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $21.95.

LEAD: Alvin Ailey was a master of the choreographic suite. That was made clear when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented two of his finest works in the suite form last Sunday night at the City Center Theater as part of the company's series of programs called In the Black Tradition.

LEAD: March wedding plans for Roberta F. Zuckerman and Peter Hirsch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Hirsch of Harrison, N.Y., and Wayne, Me., have been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Zuckerman of New York and Margate, N.J.
LEAD: For the first time in the two centuries since human beings set foot on the continent, Antarctica is poised to become a world center for scientific research, scientists say.

LEAD: THE populations of two wildlife species - the bobcat in the northern part of New Jersey and the diamondback terrapin in the south -are plummeting, and each is being considered as a candidate for the state's list of threatened and endangered species, environmental officials and an independent researcher said.

LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa says his Government has cut off aid to the insurgents in Mozambique, but he acknowledges the possibility that private citizens in South Africa might be helping the rebels.

LEAD: Mona Lynn Kennedy was married yesterday to Brian Pfohl Kirby at the Doylestown (Pa.) United Methodist Church by the Rev. Brian Cloud, a Methodist minister, and the Rev. John Davids, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Kennedy Jr. of Holicong, Pa. Mr. Kirby is a son of Mr.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Brazilian voters will choose on Sunday between two presidential candidates offering radically different paths for Latin America's most populous nation: socialist or free market.

LEAD: WHETHER the father did a victory dance was not disclosed, but a spokesman said Mark Gastineau, the former Jets defensive end, got a son, Marcus, early Friday morning when the actress Brigitte Nielsen gave birth to a 7-pound boy in Scottsdale, Ariz. Gastineau, who is in the process of being divorced from his wife, Lisa, has a 7-year-old daughter.

LEAD: DO not dismiss the Boston Post Road Stage Company on the evidence of the current cheerless production of ''The Mistress of the Inn.'' The dauntless little professional theater in Fairfield has considerable virtues, but playing classic comedy just is not one of them.
LEAD: Vox, a 19-voice choir from Philadelphia, and the Saturday Brass Quintet, a New York ensemble, pooled their resources for a Christmas program at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening.

LEAD: THE idea of a ''peace dividend'' first surfaced in 1969. A Cabinet Coordination Committee was set up to report to President Lyndon B. Johnson on what the Federal Government should do with its savings when the War in Vietnam finally ended. The committee proposed that the Federal Government dedicate $39.7 billion a year from its savings - in 1969 dollars - for the upkeep of the infrastructure.

LEAD: ARE you wondering, ''Should I trade in the old clunker or should I endure it a while longer and save on those nagging monthly payments?'' If you have ever wondered what lies beyond 100,000 miles on a car, you can learn from my experience. I chose not to buy up and instead I am helping our trade imbalance by continuing to drive fine

LEAD: The wealth of the Americas flowed to Spain in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries. Each year, if wars permitted, two fleets would cruise the Caribbean, depositing Spanish trade goods and picking up gold doubloons, silver pesos, emeralds and pearls. Goods from the Orient, brought by the Manila fleet to Acapulco and by mule across Mexico to Vera Cruz, were loaded aboard.

LEAD: As Marie Antoinette made a mistake in mentioning cake, Leona Helmsley might have done well to talk less about taxes. No tumbrels rolled outside Federal Court in Manhattan as Mrs. Helmsley was sentenced for tax evasion last week, but her punishment was surprisingly stern: four years in prison and $7.1 million in fines.

LEAD: A RECENT proposal by the State Department of Corrections to make AIDS testing available to all state prisoners on a voluntary basis raises vexing medical, ethical and financial issues for prison and health care officials, experts say.

LEAD: Factual errors and flawed arguments pervade Thomas Belton's call for ''constructive debate'' on offshore oil and gas exploration off New Jersey's coast (''Oil vs. Fish? No, a Way to Have Both,'' Opinion page, Oct. 29).
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The British Broadcasting Corporation knows it is going to be in business at least thorugh 1996.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Robert D. Blue, a champion of the elderly who served two terms as Iowa's Governor in the 1940's, has died of complications from a stroke. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: The inauguration of a new president at Wabash College this month has given rise to renewed speculation that this all-men's liberal arts college - one of two of its kind in the nation - might some day join the ranks of coeducation.

LEAD: The American diver Greg Louganis. Since 1976, he has won four Olympic gold medals, 47 American titles, and 120 of 153 major events. Beyond that, in this decade of million-dollar earnings and cocaine and steroid abuse scandals, Louganis exemplifies the true spirit of competition and the beauty of sport.

LEAD: THE eighth-grade pupils in Shirley Singer's advisory group were paired by a draw of cards and directed to interview their partners, asking each other questions about their favorite activities, favorite music group and favorite pet at home. They then reassembled to share with their fellow pupils what they had learned about one another.

LEAD: Every technique used to make glass over 3,500 years is represented in ''The Art of Glass: Masterpieces From the Corning Museum,'' an exhibition on view at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, Madison Avenue at 56th Street. The 116 molded, blown, cut, engraved or painted works in these dazzling displays were made during the peak periods of this craft, from ancient Egypt onward, and include some of the finest examples extant.
LEAD: Three desert motorcycle races have been denied Federal operating permits. The denials marked a victory for environmentalists trying to save the desert tortoise.

LEAD: The engagement of Beth Anne Stevens and Steven Charles Rattner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rattner of Pittsburgh, has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Stevens of New York. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Twenty-five years ago Julio A. Martinez was battling to overcome heroin addiction. He won. Within three years he was helping establish Phoenix House, which grew into the largest private drug-treatment agency in the country. He set up a drug-free program for adolescents in jail on Rikers Island. And in 1979 he became the director of New York

LEAD: N.B.A. Bullets 112, Mavericks 108: Bernard King equaled his season high with 31 points and made two jump shots and two free throws in the final 1:36 for Washington in a home game. Rolando Blackman scored 21 points, including Dallas's last 13. Dallas ran off 12 consecutive points for a 57-51 lead with 2:57 left in the first half, led by as much as 11 and was ahead by 65-57 at halftime.
LEAD: Cornell University has punished two fraternities after a drunken fistfight on Oct. 5 that resulted in a student's death.

LEAD: The site of the old Nassau Farmers Market, a barnlike structure built in 1954 that was destroyed in a fire two years ago, is to be developed into a shopping center named Bethpage Marketsquare. Construction is expected to start on the $20 million, 147,000-square-foot retail project next spring, with completion scheduled for late next year.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Starting with ''The Ipcress File'' in 1962 and proceeding to such virtuoso pieces as ''Funeral in Berlin,'' Len Deighton has demonstrated again and again that he is a master of the British (is there any other?) espionage novel. His latest book, SPY LINE (Knopf, $18.95), will not disappoint his admirers.
LEAD: A little-noted issue in the last few days, but a highly delicate one as Bulgaria talks of dismantling old systems, is the fate of the country's large and long-victimized Muslim minority.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Colleges and universities, facing many of the same competitive pressures as big corporations, are trying to raise huge amounts of money to prepare for the 1990's, a decade that many educators think will bring expensive and potentially disruptive changes to their institutions.
LEAD: THE cultural needs of children are not being forgotten this holiday season, with more than a dozen attractions designed for younger listeners - and in some cases featuring them.

LEAD: The State Department of Environmental Conservation is jumping the gun, so to speak, when it proposes a new shotgun season for deer in Westchester County [ ''A Shotgun Season for Deer Is Proposed,'' Oct. 29 ] .

LEAD: The Selah Vocal Ensemble, a choir that specializes in Jewish sacred and secular music of all eras, turned its sights on sacred works by the late-Renaissance composer Salamone Rossi in a concert last Sunday afternoon at the Jewish Museum.
LEAD: THE Big Ten may be an athletic conference, but as its athletic directors may be discovering, it is not they but the university presidents who call the signals.

LEAD: The engagement of Helen Dow Matheson to David Shelburne Hilliard, a son of Mary Eichert Hilliard of New York and Landon Hilliard of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Tompkins Matheson of The Plains, Va. A January wedding is planned.
LEAD: Gretzky.
LEAD: John Kani wears a chip on his shoulder like a badge of honor. He has earned it, for his talents as South Africa's most prominent black actor have been forged against the anvil of apartheid.

LEAD: Betty R. is a diabetic and a mentally retarded 42-year-old mother of two who lives in the East New York section of Brooklyn. The first time an official of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service saw her apartment, ''It looked like a cave.''
LEAD: Three members of Congress have called for an investigation of whether federally supported medical researchers exclude women from clinical tests.

LEAD: WITH New York City's hospitals in a crisis of overcrowding, the idea of freeing beds by shifting those AIDS patients who are ready for other types of care makes perfect sense, health experts agree. Yet efforts to turn that concept into reality are encountering many obstacles and delays.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WAR is a dirty business. But for makers of guns, tanks and planes, it is a profitable one.

LEAD: DURING the last two years, a fortuitous combination of personal and professional circumstances has enabled me to spend considerable time in three of the world's great museums - the Louvre, the Hermitage and the Uffizi. Upon returning from these journeys to Paris, Leningrad and Florence, I sensed a certain loss of interest on the part of my hometown audience when I began talking about daily, near-idyllic forays into the halls of art.

LEAD: Gardeners ask questions. As they plant and grow different kinds of plants, they learn. Some are answered; others are not. Gathered here are the most frequently asked questions. But one answer is never final; what works for one may not work for another. The fun is in the learning.
LEAD: BIRTH POWER The Case for Surrogacy. By Carmel Shalev. 201 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.
LEAD: Arnold Moss, the popular classical actor, died of lung cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. George R. Minot of Santa Barbara, Calif., and North Haven, Me., have made known the engagement of Mr. Minot's daughter Caroline Mary Minot to Julian Edward Metcalfe, a son of David P. Metcalfe of London and the late Alexa Metcalfe. A March wedding is planned.
LEAD: From Ashes, Stained Glass

LEAD: AS the holiday season begins, I always become a victim of Christmas Card Anxiety, a tension that begins the day after Thanksgiving and continues right through Twelfth Night, when I figure the formal holiday season is over.

LEAD: It was a combination of charity and protest as 150 University of Connecticut students waited in line last weekend at Jonathan's, one of three fast-food restaurants here on the campus. The students were using the balance on their Vali-Dine cards to help feed the needy and homeless in nearby Willimantic.
LEAD: Boris Becker and Eric Jelen teamed today to lead West Germany, the defending champion, to a 2-1 lead in the Davis Cup final against Sweden.

LEAD: BEAUTIFUL MUTANTS. By Deborah Levy. (Viking, $17.95.) Although billed as a novel, Deborah Levy's rather thin little book, ''Beautiful Mutants,'' reads more like a short story. Episodic, concise and poetic, this unconventional tale about social misfits and secret desires feels dreamlike in its quick passage and sometimes indelible imagery.

LEAD: Texas has put 33 people to death since it resumed executions in December 1982. Clarence Lee Brandley twice came within days of being a 34th - even though the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals now says that his 1981 conviction for rape and murder was a ''subversion of justice.''
LEAD: Re: ''In the Natural State,'' Oct. 29:

LEAD: Ben Johnson's enormous individual talent was only exceeded by his talent for self-delusion. In that respect, his story transcended the boundaries of sport and helped define an era. MATT FARRAND Brooklyn

LEAD: Christoph Hein, a writer and intellectual prominent in East Berlin, has long been an outspoken critic of his nation's Government. A recent play of Hein's, ''The Knights of the Round Table,'' has been widely read as an allegory of the leadership crisis in East Germany; in recent months it played to packed houses in Dresden and has become a rallying point for the opposition.

LEAD: Q. Having read that it is always best to stain cedar shingles, rather than paint them, we contracted to have all the peeling paint sandblasted off our shingles. But now we have conflicting advice on where to go from there. Some people tell us it is best to let the sandblasted shingles weather for several months, while others say they should be stained immediately.

LEAD: I recently spent two weeks in Charleston, S.C., where I was a volunteer with the American Red Cross Hurricane Hugo relief effort (''The Way It Should Be Remembered,'' by Blanche McCrary Boyd, Nov. 19). Never having visited Charleston before, I had no memory of how things had been before the storm.

LEAD: Susan Edler and Leonard Jarvis Wyeth are planning an April wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Klaus W. Edler of Cornwall, Conn., have announced. Miss Edler, an architect at Centerbrook (Conn.) Architects, graduated from St. Margaret's School in Bushey, Hertford, England, and the Rhode Island School of Design.

LEAD: CHARLES DICKENS'S ''Christmas Carol'' is perfect holiday fare. The problem for most theaters is finding ways to present this venerable classic so that audiences will continue to come back season after season.
LEAD: Babette Pinsky says a woman's coat should make as much of a fashion statement as her dress, skirt or blouse do. It is, after all, the garment the outside world usually sees first.

LEAD: IN what must be one of the longest long counts on record, Dennis Milton has defeated Michael Olajide in a middleweight bout that began Dec. 1 at the Empire State Plaza Convention Center in Albany and ended two weeks later in the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission.

LEAD: Bobby Humphrey rushed for 128 yards today to become the first Denver rookie to reach the 1,000-yard mark as the Broncos limited Phoenix to 101 yards in a 37-0 victory, the first shutout of the Cardinals in four years.

LEAD: James Jeremiah Mahoney of Norwich, N.Y., has announced the engagement of his daughter Patricia Anne Mahoney to Richard Patrick Dempsey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Dempsey of Kennebunk, Me. A February wedding is planned.

LEAD: THE easy triumph of a coalition candidate in the presidential elections in Chile last Thursday reflects, on the surface anyway, the end of the longstanding animosity between the leftists who supported the late Salvador Allende Gossens and the centrists who opposed him 16 years ago.

LEAD: A festival of lessons and carols is being presented this afternoon at 4 in the South Congregational-First Baptist Church of New Britain. This fusing of Christmas music and Bible readings, born in medieval England, is now celebrated in many American towns.

LEAD: Six Congressmen back from a secret trip to Colombia say they are more convinced than ever that President Virgilio Barco Vargas deserves unwavering support in his country's battle with drug traffickers.
LEAD: This was to have been a week of celebration in this sliver of West Africa as workers removed the cover protecting a new bronze statue of Lenin.

LEAD: To the Editor: For 35 years I have been hustling around the globe and been the director of summer schools abroad. I am thus accustomed to the risks and thrills both of solo and group wandering. The following strike me as the four dominant myths about travel:

LEAD: A gang of 10 armed robbers invaded an apartment-house garage on the Upper West Side early yesterday, held up the attendant and made off with five late-model cars, the police said. The last car was cut off by police officers arriving at the garage and one of the occupants was seized.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bernd Brecher of Hartsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Alison Fay Brecher to Eric Scott Savitch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin R. Savitch of White Plains. A March wedding is planned.

LEAD: A recent spurt in corruption cases at the Drug Enforcement Administration has undermined morale and crippled many investigations at a time when the agency is all but overwhelmed by the illicit drug trade, agents say.

LEAD: WHEN a suspect is arrested in a drug case in Westchester, the police have five days to analyze the drugs seized or the suspect must be released and the charges dropped. Last year, drugs from 3,530 cases were sent to the crime lab and 88,705 tests were performed on the drugs. This year's cases are expected to total 3,800.

LEAD: IN his time as their coach, the Dallas Cowboys appeared in five Super Bowl games and won two. In seven other seasons, they advanced to the National Conference championship game before being eliminated. Over a span of 20 seasons from 1966 through 1985, only twice did the Cowboys fail to qualify for the playoffs.
LEAD: ''You will never be out of the sandhogs' thoughts.''

LEAD: OVER the next two weeks or so, 23 million Americans will board airplanes, 1.25 million will crowd onto trains and an additional 1.4 million will take a bus. It is the time of year when everyone in the country seems to be going somewhere else.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: NORWALK officials and residents are bracing for more bad news this week about the city's major tourist attraction, the Norwalk Maritime Center. The center is to present a financial report to the City Council on Wednesday and it is expected to show that the Maritime Center will need more money to survive.

LEAD: Are renters finding what they want when they go to the video store? In this the year of big-movie cassettes for sale (''Batman'' et al.), some in the trade are concerned that rentals, still the real right arm of video with about 70 percent of the revenue, aren't getting enough attention. ''What renters really want in a video store is breadth and scope of selection,'' says Nicholas Santrizos, the chairman of Trylon Video, a New York-based distributor.

LEAD: EVERY summer during the festival of the Morisma, the Christians and the Moors fight it out one more time on the hills outside Zacatecas. Charlemagne, John the Baptist and Mohammed come to life again in a medieval pageant in which roles are passed down from generation to generation. The outcome, of course, is always the same.

LEAD: ON a recent morning, Naomi Drew gathered her kindergarten and first-grade class at the Cambridge School around her on the floor to talk about how learning to solve problems with the children's peers could make the world a better place.

LEAD: For This Week: Carry on with the holiday projects such as shopping, decorating, wrapping, mailing, baking, etc, but do not neglect house plants that will need watering, debugging and leaf cleaning with a damp paper towel. Hold back on the use of fertilizer at this time of year as most indoor plants are in a dormant-rest period.

LEAD: One of those sticky questions that cling to Hollywood actors is why the undeniably popular Dennis Quaid - whose screen presence seems an unbeatable mix of boyish grin, effortless sex appeal and sudden bursts of passion - has never starred in a blockbuster movie. GREAT BALLS OF FIRE (1989, Orion, $89.98), appearing on video little more than five months after it bombed in theaters, won't do much to clear up the box-office mystery.

LEAD: ALL-AMERICA football players do not develop often on the Brookville, L.I., campus of C. W. Post. But there was one this season. John Lavelis, a senior defensive end, was named to the all-America first team for Division III chosen for Kodak by the American Football Coaches Association. Lavelis and Paul Cioffi, a defensive end from Montclair

LEAD: The engagement of Lorena Hathaway Crisfield to Richard Parker Callanan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Callanan of Auburndale and Plymouth, Mass., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Lucile Stafford Proctor of Princeton, N.J., and Cotuit, Mass., and James Pearce Crisfield of Youngstown, N.Y.

LEAD: FOR many Americans notions about long-distance train travel have more to do with mythology than memory. While few of us really knew the Santa Fe Super Chief or ever rode the 20th Century Limited, the mere whisper of such names evokes excitement and romance, in the same way we are still stirred by the sound of a faraway locomotive whistle.

LEAD: Long and arduous bankruptcy proceedings for Nelson Bunker Hunt have wound to a close in a crowded Dallas courtroom, ending one of the largest personal bankruptcy cases in American history and leaving Mr. Hunt with a fraction of his former worth.
LEAD: THE CHINCHILLA FARM By Judith Freeman. 308 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: Michelle Patricia Artiles and Jeffrey Howard Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey W. Cohen of Livingston, N.J., plan to be married in April. Their engagement was announced by Lucy Artiles of Miami, the prospective bride's mother.

LEAD: YOU have probably been spending your way into a corner this gift-buying season. So, how about a gift for yourself at no cost - something, say, in the $50-and-up category. Here's a shopping list of ways to save or earn some money - many of them obvious but often overlooked and all of them free for the asking.

LEAD: Dancegoers never know what they'll hear next at a performance. Usually it's music, but choreography can also be accompanied by the spoken word or even by sheer babbling. Often on such occasions movement can either intensify or contradict the import of the words, and in the process the text makes perfect sense.
LEAD: Georgetown scored the final 21 points of the first half today and went on to beat the University of the District of Columbia by 112-39, the third-largest margin of victory in school history.

LEAD: Colorful layered garments from the gusty deserts of India and Africa and the foothills of the Himalayas can protect wearers in city canyons, too. Urban nomads can find this warm and newly chic attire at some outposts in lower Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: ''The Politburocrats denounced the uprising of the people as a counterrevolution and wanted to repress it with violence, but in reality, they were the counterrevolutionaries.'' - Prof. Michael Schumann, a member of the East German Academy of Sciences, addressing a congress of the country's Communist Party.

LEAD: As a volley of guerrilla rockets pounded the airport in the Afghan capital on a bitterly cold December day, a conscript in the Government army standing sentry near the runway laid down his Kalashnikov rifle, spread a blanket on the ground, and prostrated himself in prayer.

LEAD: IT was the most evanescent of unofficial landmarks, a haphazard alignment of buildings spanning half a century along a mile-long stretch of Fifth Avenue. The view south toward the Empire State Building - actually a gradually rising succession of buildings - was long familiar to tourists and New Yorkers walking down the avenue along Central Park from as far north as the Cooper-Hewitt Museum at 91st

LEAD: In sending a high-level mission to the unrepentant rulers of China, President Bush acted on the premises of a particular world view. That is the one that Henry Kissinger brought to Washington as foreign-policy impresario for Presidents Nixon and Ford.
LEAD: THIRTY-FIVE years ago, with just one counselor on a budget of $26,000, Family Service of Westchester began helping families cope.

LEAD: In the mid-50's, when I was experiencing my first twinges of critical taste, I instituted our family's annual Christmas card contest. On Christmas afternoon, once all the presents had been opened, I would scoop the season's hundred-or-so cards off the mantelpiece and sort through them for nominees.

LEAD: The Knicks last night won their ninth successive home-court game since the beginning of the season, a franchise record for the fastest start. The 118-97 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics came so easily that it was enough to lull the Madison Square Garden capacity crowd of 18,212 to sleep.

LEAD: Now that elections are over for the 1989 season, it would make some sense for the State Legislature to take a closer look at how local boards of election operate. And to take corrective actions that will eliminate problems that have occurred in parts of the state.
LEAD: Composers have often taken up criticism, and the best composer-critics, from Berlioz and Schumann to Wagner to Thomson, count among history's most insightful commentators about music.

LEAD: What makes Richard Goode such a splendid chamber-music pianist, I think, is not an anonymous personality, but - to the contrary - the restrictions on his own personal passions imposed by those around him.
LEAD: The Government minister who has led Egypt's crackdown on Muslim militants escaped injury today when a truck bomb exploded just before he arrived at his sports club, security officials said.

LEAD: Kidnapped Words According to Thomas Mallon, plagiarism shocks us because it is the only case in which we can know where a writer's words actually came from. This is from ''Stolen Words'' (Ticknor & Fields).
LEAD: In an ambitious effort to combat child abuse, Hawaii has begun the nation's first effort to screen all parents for danger signs.
LEAD: *2*The Final Score Wayne Gretzky 30 Magic Johnson 8 Martina Navratilova 6 Greg LeMond 4 Joe Montana 4 Greg Louganis 2 Mike Schmidt 2 Lawrence Taylor 2 Mike Tyson 2 16 Others 1
LEAD: A front-page picture caption last Sunday about a visit by American officials to Beijing misstated Qian Qichen's title. He is China's Foreign Minister, not Prime Minister.

LEAD: Responding to public fears that the arrival of winter will push pollution to intolerable levels, the government of the Mexican capital has for the first time imposed restrictions on automobile use and begun putting in place a plan to improve air quality by reducing toxic emissions.
LEAD: LOVE AND WILL Twenty Stories. By Stephen Dixon. 193 pp. New York: Paris Review Editions/ British American Publishing. $17.95.

LEAD: Closings in the week ended Dec. 2 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $685,000 1 Fifth Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,150-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, windowed kitchen, wraparound terrace, parquet floors; maintenance $1,186, 39% tax-deductible (Broker: Ann Weintraub Realty/Kanelba & Robilotti)

LEAD: Q. Having read that it is always best to stain cedar shingles, rather than paint them, we contracted to have all the peeling paint sandblasted off our shingles. But now we have conflicting advice on where to go from there. Some people tell us it is best to let the sandblasted shingles weather for several months, while others say they should be stained immediately.

LEAD: In this holiday season the best-decorated house in New York has only a few simple wreaths in its windows, no Christmas tree and no garlands. What is on its walls is glorious beyond reckoning. True, the walls of the Frick Collection, at Fifth Avenue and 70th Street, are glorious all year round. But they're even more so right now, with 17 paintings on loan from Fort Worth's Kimbell Art

LEAD: A photograph last Sunday with an article about Japanese lobbyists in Washington was published in error. It showed William G. Walker, the American Ambassador to El Salvador, instead of William N. Walker, former deputy United States trade representative.

LEAD: ONCE the forgotten village in the forgotten borough, Tottenville, on the southwestern tip of Staten Island, is being pulled rapidly, if somewhat grudgingly, into the modern era. Stately homes and upscale condominiums are being built on every available lot in the 1,600-acre community, including what older residents remember as their ice skating ponds, ballfields and ski slopes.
LEAD: LIVES OF COURAGE Women for a New South Africa. By Diana E. H. Russell. Illustrated. 375 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.
LEAD: THE Elmsford Animal shelter is a very special place. It offers sanctuary, rather like a medieval alms house, for abandoned and mistreated animals.
LEAD: ASTROPHOBIA By Sasha Sokolov. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. 385 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $21.50.

LEAD: June wedding plans for Sasha Lonsdale Iglehart and Michael Elliot Richardson have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Corning Iglehart of Glyndon, Md. Mr. Richardson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot L. Richardson of McLean, Va.

LEAD: Ramon Ramos, a Portland Trail Blazer forward and former star at Seton Hall, was listed in extremely critical condition late today with brain damage suffered early this morning in a car accident. Ramos, a 22-year-old forward who was activated by the Trail Blazers 10 days ago after a knee injury, had not appeared in a National Basketball Association game.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has found no solid evidence in its intensive espionage investigation of Felix S. Bloch, a veteran diplomat, and the agency has significantly scaled back its inquiry in recent days, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Club, which moved into its building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and East 60th Street 95 years ago, is cleaning the exterior of the landmarked property, which was designed by Stanford White. More than $1 million is being spent to dissolve as many as five layers of paint on the marble exterior, and then slather it with a chemical poultice to remove stains caused by the reaction between air pollutants and impurities in the stone.
LEAD: Mike Dowis kicked a 20-yard field goal with 1:41 left today to lift top-ranked Georgia Southern to a 37-34 victory over Stephen F. Austin for the N.C.A.A. Division I-AA championship.

LEAD: SMALLNESS is currently the thing at City Without Walls. Not one of the 46 works in the gallery's ''Eighth Annual Metro Show'' is more than 12 inches in any dimension. It makes for easier transportation and distribution: Metro shows customarily go forth unto the people where they work, and the pit stops are not necessarily art galleries.

LEAD: Gold prices have risen sharply since September, from about $360 an ounce to $425 an ounce in early December before falling back to $408.25 at the close on Friday. Are we poised for another bull market in gold? Four precious metals analysts offer their views. Vahid Fathi Vice president, Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc., Cleveland.

LEAD: Lisa Marie Piscitello and Whitney Agnew Talcott were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn., by the Rev. David W. Good. The bride is a daughter of Mary L. Piscitello of New London, Conn., and the late Robert A. Piscitello. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Agnew Allen Talcott of Old Lyme and the late Mr.
LEAD: For a retarded and diabetic mother of two, and for others in need whose stories are told today, the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund offers dignity and support. Articles, page 99.

LEAD: IT'S not over 'til it's over, Yogi admonished. But with Muscovites salivating over the arrival of McDonald's and Hungary celebrating the embrace of General Electric, it is hard to deny that the long ideological war between capitalism and socialism has ended in a decisive win for the home team.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: For all their grief and insurgency, the congressional colleagues of Andrei D. Sakharov met today and decided that they were unable immediately to provide the political legacy he desired: the creation of a formal political opposition to challenge the Communist Party monopoly nationwide.
LEAD: THE last remains of New York harbor's century as a bustling port are being swept away, affording a clearer view of what the waterfront will be like in the next century.
LEAD: With the formal enthronement of Emperor Akihito nearly a year away, Japan has become entangled in a debate among scholars and political leaders about what sort of ceremony would be appropriate.
LEAD: ACROSS centuries of Turkish domination, decades of iron-fisted Communist rule and a few odd years of Nazi collaboration, Bulgaria's familiarity with democracy has been nodding at best.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bertram J. Diker of Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Helen Diker, to William Mark Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervyn M. Levine of Winnipeg, Canada. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: An article last Sunday about jigsaw puzzles with mystery themes misidentified a Bloomfield company marketing them. It is Be Puzzled, not DePuzzled.

LEAD: SINCE the early 1980's, corporate America has been wracked by endless takeover battles. Prices for companies soared, propelled by investors' seemingly insatiable appetite for debt. Those heady days are gone, however. And for the next year or so, takeover specialists predict that deals will be fewer, fetch lower prices and involve far less debt.

LEAD: AMERICAN businessmen must be smarting from the Japanese critique of our industrial and educational systems made as part of Japanese-American trade negotiations. I know that I am. If ever a challenge was issued to American educators and business people, this was it. Without subtlety, the Japanese told us that we are not likely to be competitive in the world economy of the future because we are failing to educate our youth.

LEAD: A TWO-YEAR dispute between a religious organization and a neighboring Pound Ridge homeowner was settled last week when a State Supreme Court judge upheld most of the neighbor's claims and awarded him a $45,000 settlement.

LEAD: In its journey across New York in search of site-specific locations, the nomadic En Garde Arts troupe sets new challenges for theatergoers. In the case of ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' the first question is how to find the temporary theater. The address is 1 Main Street, Brooklyn, a byway by the waterfront in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge.

LEAD: MY CULINARY CHAUVINISM DISAPPEARED WHEN I got my first chance to eat in England. Along with a whole bag of heavy sweaters for that mid-June jaunt, I had secretly packed a jar of pickled jalapeno peppers for my trip. If British food was truly going to be as dismal as I had always heard, I wanted to be able to give it a little heat, if not life.

LEAD: ''Hey - rock-and-roll!'' Sally Timms shouted as she and her fellow Mekons crammed themselves back onstage for encores at the Knitting Factory a few weeks ago. For most bands, the phrase is simply a sure-fire way to draw a yell from an audience. But for the Mekons, it is anything but unexamined; when they say rock-and-roll, they're simultaneously loving, wistful, suspicious, defiant and gleeful.

LEAD: America had a fair idea of what it was getting in George Bush: a competent, cautious steward with a slim agenda and no taste for what he called ''the vision thing.'' He would make changes at the margins of the Reagan Revolution without disturbing its core. The nation would be kinder and gentler. Taxes would stay low, defenses strong.

LEAD: Some of the most dangerous illusions on the chessboard stem from one of the greatest geniuses of the game, Wilhelm Steinitz, world champion from 1866 to 1894. This man, who was so adept at analyzing the structure of the game - embodied by the pawn formation - was cavalier about the factor of time and of rapidity of development and what it could do.

LEAD: Holly Hackett and John Vinson Kania were married yesterday in Locust Valley, L.I., by the Rev. Charles G. Newberry at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church. The bride, 29 years old, is the daughter of Lela Ottley Leslie of Locust Valley and Randall Winslow Hackett of New York. Her husband, 28, is a son of Mr.

LEAD: A former Bolivian Government official was taken prisoner last week in Washington's war on drugs. Col. Luis Arce Gomez, who was called the ''minister of cocaine'' when he served as Bolivia's Interior Minister in the early 1980's, was captured last weekend when Bolivian authorities raided his ranch.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THOUGH Christmas is in just a week, Carole Joy Creations is still receiving last-minute orders for greeting cards. Last year a retailer who had just heard of the company called as late as Dec. 22 to order cards, said Victor M. Gellineau Jr., who handles marketing.

LEAD: A group of students at Simon's Rock, part of Bard College, is fighting the parietal rules against nonresident students' staying overnight in single-sex freshmen dormitories. The administration is showing signs of retreat.

LEAD: LILY POND: Four Years With a Family of Beavers. By Hope Ryden. (Morrow, $17.95.) It is likely that ''Lily Pond'' will appeal to nature lovers. The startling thing, though, is how well Hope Ryden's study of a beaver family succeeds on other levels. Her observations of a pair of wild beavers in New York's Harriman State Park is eloquent and suspenseful, educational without being didactic, and includes a reasoned analysis of whether humans should further disrupt nature's balance.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WITH the passage of a powerful new disability rights law virtually certain, attention has shifted from its political prospects to its worldly consequences. A Senate supporter has vowed that it will emancipate millions of disabled people who spend their lives ''overcoming not what God wrought but what man imposed by custom and law.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH it is possible to put together a trip on the spur of the moment, most traveling anglers plan months ahead. This is particularly true if they wish to fish in a remote area where accommodations and guides are limited.

LEAD: A growing number of Americans, accustomed to taping everything from college lectures to television shows, now own answering machines or other devices that allow them to record conversations with their families, friends and business associates.

LEAD: CONTRAST and contradiction characterize North Bellmore's Smithville Cafe. Its rundown roadhouse exterior does not do justice to its warm, woody interior. This 19th-century landmark, which has served as a stagecoach stop, hotel, bordello, speak-easy and cowboy bar, became the Smithville Cafe in 1976.
LEAD: All it took was one look at the puffy eyes of P. J. Carlesimo to realize that this had not been an ordinary day for the Seton Hall coach.

LEAD: The number of new students enrolling in college and university nursing programs increased for the first time in five years, but the increase is too small to overcome an acute nursing shortage, a new survey shows.
LEAD: Llamas and boas, ferrets and parrots have led the exotic pet parade in years past. The latest status symbol is a miniature pig that stands 14 to 18 inches high and weighs about 40 pounds.
LEAD: Looking at a Co-op's Books
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Some have always been more equal than others in Marxist Europe. But with the new freedom in the East has come a tide of old resentments of the privileges accorded party officials and top athletes, among others. Katarina Witt, the Olympic figure-skating champion, thinks some of her complaining East German countrymen are being a bit ungrateful.
LEAD: A listing of resorts in the Caribbean on Dec. 10 misidentified a hotel on St. Barthelemy. It is Castelets.

LEAD: THE future of capitalism in Eastern Europe could be in Andzrej Bialous's chicken coop. Mr. Bialous, an energetic, raw-boned mechanical engineer, has moved several cutting and stitching machines into the former chicken house where four of his employees piece together flimsy plastic pocketbooks that are best sellers in the

LEAD: PLANS to reform our schools tend to overlook the fact that about half of our youngsters grow up in families that are not viable from an educational viewpoint. Frequent divorces, a bewildering rotation of boyfriends and parents who come home from work exhausted both physically and mentally, have left many homes with a tremendous parenting deficit.
LEAD: Milk prices in the New York metropolitan area rose to a record level for the fourth straight month in early December, state marketing officials said this week.

LEAD: A slight wind shift brought a haze of ash from Redoubt Volcano drifting down on Alaska's largest city today, prompting the authorities to issue a warning to people with lung ailments. The volcano, 115 miles southwest of Anchorage, began erupting Thursday and was belching ash skyward for the third day in a row, though in a somewhat reduced amount, said the United States Geological Survey.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Now that the excitement of New York City's election is over and a new mayor is in office, a critical task lies ahead. A new beginning is at hand with the awesome responsibility of bringing this city out of a myriad of complex economic and social problems that affect the poor and needy. But the responsibility for these changes does not lie with the mayor alone.

LEAD: Freehold $66,000 52 Manchester Court 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old condominium apartment; h/w floors, dining room; monthly maintenance $153, taxes $1,090. Howell $172,000 114 Pine Needle Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old contemporary; eat-in kitchen, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $1,900.

LEAD: AFTER a decade of service, Alex English has asked the Denver Nuggets to trade him, but the Nuggets are not inclined to do so. ''I want out; I want to be traded,'' English told The Denver Post. ''I hope it's done soon.''

LEAD: THE BIG FIX. Inside the S&L Scandal: How an Unholy Alliance of Politics and Money Destroyed America's Banking System. By James Ring Adams. (John Wiley & Sons, $19.95.) Finance - and financial fraud - can be dry and arcane. But in ''The Big Fix,'' James Ring Adams offers a front-row seat at a three-ring circus.

LEAD: At Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J., Nancy Jill Schwartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin P. Schwartz of South Orange, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Robert David Fechtner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Fechtner of Watchung, N.J. Rabbi Barry Greene performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Norman Summers.
LEAD: One athlete showed that he was the greatest at his position in the history of the sport. His name: Michael Jack Schmidt. ROBERT LIGANSKY Brooklyn

LEAD: The marriage of Laura M. Mestel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Mestel of Bayside, Queens, to Frederick E. Rubin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton R. Rubin of Woodmere, L.I., took place last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Jack Bemporad and Cantor David Benedict officiated.
LEAD: No other athlete is as synonymous with his sport as Mike Tyson. To talk boxing is to talk Tyson. ADAM BERLIN New York

But now we have conflicting advice on where to go from there. Some people tell us it is best to let the sandblasted shingles weather for several months, while others say they should be stained immediately.

Kristof, in fact, delivers a slanted and, at times, morally repugnant revision of the tragic end of the Beijing Spring (''China Update: How the Hardliners Won,'' Nov. 12).

LEAD: The news arrived by fax, as news so often does these days, but it echoed nostalgically from a past seemingly long gone. The Philadelphia Orchestra regretfully announced that ''Transfigured Notes'' by Milton Babbitt had been dropped from a subscription program beginning Dec. 7 and would be replaced by another Babbitt score, ''Composition for 12 Instruments.

LEAD: The recent New York State public-health law has indeed reduced the number of prescriptions written for the benzodiazepines by virtue of the triplicate prescription requirement. However, in addition to the triplicate form, the law requires that a prescription for benzodiazepine may supply a patient for not more than 30 days, and that a patient be examined by his doctor each time a renewal is needed.

LEAD: The Jets and Dick Steinberg were impressed enough with each other at their first meeting on Friday to schedule further talks tomorrow.

LEAD: THE New York City Campaign Finance Board is the rare government agency that didn't spend its budget. Taxpayers may exult at the budgetary success the brand-new office had in substituting taxpayers' money for big special-interest contributions in this year's city political campaigns - the first large municipal experiment of its kind in the country.

LEAD: Rusty Staub, the sports broadcaster, restaurant owner and former baseball star, was going to be there. So was Jackie Mason, the comedian and former star of the television show ''Chicken Soup.'' And so was Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, whom Mr. Mason had disparaged while campaigning for Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor of New York

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Loring of St. George, S.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Robyn Ann Loring and Leon Kotler Specthrie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jared Specthrie of Riverdale, the Bronx.

LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

LEAD: MOST of the people in the Spring Creek Gardens complex in the East New York section of Brooklyn earn considerably less than $20,000 a year, while those in the Belaire condo minium tower, on Manhattan's Upper East Side, make whatever is needed to buy half-million dollar condominium apartments and million-dollar penthouses.

LEAD: With warfare continuing inside Cambodia after the announced departure of Vietnamese troops, diplomatic activity to resolve the war is increasing again, with a senior Australian Foreign Ministry official arriving here on Sunday and a Soviet delegation expected next week.

LEAD: David Rubitsky, his hands trembling slightly as he read from a handwritten statement on lined notebook paper, today rebutted the Army's finding that he was simply an honorable old soldier with a foggy memory.

LEAD: On Wednesday, Dennis Russell Davies was named music director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and principal conductor of the Brooklyn Philharmonic, both effective in 1991. On Friday evening, he conducted the first in a three-concert series with the Philharmonic at the academy - the final installment is this afternoon at 2 - and a better advertisement for himself could hardly be imagined.
LEAD: Beatrice Hessen, an editor of her father's well-known philatelic journal, died of cancer on Thursday at her home in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 52 years old.

LEAD: COUNTY legislators grappling with a proposed $1 billion budget for 1990, Westchester's largest, face what may be a large and hostile crowd tomorrow night at the Board of Legislator's last public hearing. Final action on the spending plan is expected a few days later. Those likely to fill the lawmaker's eighth-floor chamber at 7:30 P.M.

LEAD: IN its wars on drugs, organized crime and white-collar racketeering, the Government means to seize ill-gotten gains wherever they are. Although prosecutors insist that they are using restraint, criminal defense lawyers say they have much to lose because of the Government's authority to freeze assets before trial and even to pursue legal fees that have already been paid.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Anatolia

LEAD: Most of the musicians who take part in the summer Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival were trained in New York, live in New York or appear often in New York. So it's not surprising that the city has not seen a group under the Santa Fe banner since 1981. On Wednesday, as part of a national tour, a quintet of musicians presented a program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LEAD: Human rights campaigners who think that the United Nations can discourage abuses are concerned by China's support for a proposal before the General Assembly to restrict the organization's right to criticize individual governments for violations.
LEAD: AFTER a 12-year hiatus, residential construction has resumed at a 52-acre former railroad yard on this city's near South Side.

LEAD: Susanna Marie Bellis and Michael Paul Gibbons, a son of Pamela Gibbons of Morristown, N.J., and William J. Gibbons of Orange, N.J., plan to marry in February, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George D. Bellis of St. Paul, have announced.

LEAD: I felt a grief similar to that of Ms. Ascher when I read her article. I am a 21-year-old man, attending college in New York, and I am also gay. With these circumstances in my life, the horror and despair caused by AIDS is a reality that I must face every day.

LEAD: THOUGH Christmas is in just a week, Carole Joy Creations in Danbury is still receiving last-minute orders for greeting cards. Last year a retailer who had just heard of the company called as late as Dec. 22 to order cards, said Victor M. Gellineau Jr., who handles marketing.

LEAD: To insure what it calls a more diverse experience in the freshman year, a committee named by Provost John Deutsch has recommended a plan to delay the selection of housing choices at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

LEAD: VETERAN shoppers here say that except for the bargain basement at Filene's and the blueberry muffins at Jordan Marsh, New England's two stylish department stores - neighborly rivals for 136 years - seem indistinguishable.

LEAD: BERNARD ARNAULT, THE 40-YEAR-OLD CHAIRMAN of LVMH, which combines some of France's oldest, most pretigious names, no longer has to apologize for the way his new Paris office looks. Arnault, a short, trim, somewhat awkward man, spent his first 10 months here with mud brown walls and a simple wooden desk - a far cry from the crystal chandeliers he left behind at the Christian Dior fashion house.
LEAD: A trend that can intimidate stamp collectors is the flood of gummed paper that some countries and non-countries put out to commemorate just about any topic you can think of.

LEAD: Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, led about 1,000 people today in marking the anniversary of the killing of scores of Baltic coast workers by security forces during food riots in December 1970.

LEAD: POLITICIANS here finally appear to be waking up to what economists have been telling them: The long binge of overspending and undersaving by government, business and consumers threatens to depress living standards and reduce the nation to a second-rate economic force during the next decade. Already, there are symptoms, among them lagging productivity, slow wage growth, the sale of major assets to foreign investors, stubbornly high interest rates and the huge trade and budget deficits.
LEAD: A SPECIAL provision written into the Federal budget bill will permit New Jersey to continue using a $465 million trust fund to pay for hospital care for the poor.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 5 about elections in Uruguay gave an incorrect party affiliation for the vice-presidential candidate of the Broad Front, a leftist coalition. The candidate, Danilo Astori, has since informed The Times that he is an independent, not a Communist Party member.

LEAD: PARIS is one of the cheapest places I know to have a glorious Christmas - or rather have a glorious time escaping from Christmas. Not a total escape; for that you'd have to go to Lhasa or Teheran. But if this year you can't face another magazine-ad-type American family Christmas with the father in Santa Claus costume and everybody sitting happily around the tree amid mountains of gaily wrapped laptop computers, Cabbage Patch dolls and electric trains, while through the snowy window can be seen the front end of the new car ''we gave to each other,'' Paris makes a blissful change.

LEAD: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. appears to be succeeding with an unusual experiment in ''circulation synergy.'' The communications company has announced that Episodes, its forthcoming subscription-only soap opera magazine that will cover only the ABC network's daytime dramas, has built its circulation to more than 500,000, in three weeks, using direct-response commercials on its soap operas to lure subscribers.

LEAD: By Geoffrey Beene, who as a designer has collected every known accolade in fashion, has embarked on a new career, as a retailer. Today, his first retail shop opens at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street in the Sherry Netherland Hotel. General Bramlett, 48 years old, will assume responsibility for the military training in the classroom and field for the academy's 4,400 cadets. A native of Galesburg, Ill., General Bramlett is a 1964 graduate of West Point.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Saying it is ''shocked,'' China today condemned the American military strike in Panama as a violation of international law and demanded the immediate withdrawal of American forces.

LEAD: Western creditors may lend Yugoslavia up to $4 billion in the next two years if it adopts Premier Ante Markovic's new market-oriented economic program, Yugoslav banking officials and news reports said today. The officials said the International Monetary Fund agreed to grant Yugoslavia an 18-month standby credit worth $600 million.
LEAD: A Rocker's Images

LEAD: Natan Sharansky, the former Soviet Jewish dissident now living in Israel, announced today that a private $20 million fund to provide housing for Soviet Jewish immigrants has been created with a single donation from an American businessman.

LEAD: The first four coffins holding bodies of Americans killed in Panama arrived at the United States Air Force base here on a bleak Thursday afternoon. Another 14 arrived in brutal sub-zero temperatures shortly after midnight today.
LEAD: The Federal Government is making a test case of this city's effort to turn itself into a nuclear-free zone.
LEAD: The nation's businesses plan to increase capital spending 4.9 percent in 1990, compared with an 8.5 percent increase this year, the Commerce Department said today.
LEAD: The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced yesterday that it will review its decision to finance a disputed housing project on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: Shoney's Inc., a restaurant chain based in Nashville, yesterday named as its chairman and chief executive Leonard H. Roberts, who left this fall as head of Arby's Inc. restaurants after a dispute.

LEAD: The Cowboys announced today that 10 Dallas players and 7 from the Philadelphia Eagles had been fined by the National Football League for fighting in a Thanksgiving Day game. The fight sparked accusations that Coach Buddy Ryan of the Eagles had put bounties on some Cowboy players.
LEAD: Here, for the first full day of winter, is a list of cold-comfort thoughts.

LEAD: The first of three transitional housing complexes intended to ease Westchester's problem of the homeless was dedicated here today by New York State and local officials, while in New Jersey families began moving into that state's first such project.

LEAD: The Israeli Army announced today that it would begin impounding property or sealing homes belonging to the parents of Palestinian children who throw rocks at soldiers in the occupied territories.

LEAD: ''It's bloody cold out here. I can't stand it. I'd rather not be out in this weather, but we all get that Christmas spirit, so here we all are, freezing in Rockefeller Center.'' - Simon Jones, a visitor from London. [ B4:1. ]

LEAD: The Investment Company Institute, a national association of investment companies, reported yesterday that unit investment trusts increased their deposits by $569.2 million in November to $8.96 billion in 1989.
LEAD: The Brideshead Generation Evelyn Waugh and His Friends By Humphrey Carpenter 523 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $27.95.

LEAD: Are British advertisements, which often entice consumers with entertainment and subtle humor, more effective than hard-sell American ones? Not to Americans, suggests a study of two Hellmann's mayonnaise print ads - one American, the other British.
