LEAD: Following up their three-player trade with the Mets, the Los Angeles Dodgers signed Hubie Brooks, a free agent, to a three-year, $6 million contract yesterday. The question is will the Mets follow up the deal by making another one for a center fielder?

LEAD: The SmithKline Beecham Corporation said today that it would sell Eminase, a new drug for heart attack victims, at a price of $1,700 a treatment. The drug will be shipped shortly after the first of the year.

LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy court judge here today formally approved a reorganization plan for William Herbert Hunt, whose fortune collapsed after a failed attempt to corner the silver market 10 years ago.

LEAD: The Corning Leader will become a morning newspaper and begin publication of a Sunday issue in March 1990, its publisher, Neil C. Hopp, said this week. The first morning issue is scheduled for March 5, followed by publication of the first Sunday paper on March 11. The Leader, owned by the California-based Howard Publications Group, has a circulation of 17,000.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: 'Oh, Kay!' Hits the Road

LEAD: UNADORNED homes are rare commodities around Christmastime in Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst and Canarsie. With thousands of plastic Santas and snowmen, armies of toy soldiers and multicolored megawatts of lights decorating block upon block of houses and apartment buildings, no one could accuse these Brooklyn neighborhoods of a lack of holiday cheer.

LEAD: Sylvester Stallone, a man in desperate need of career advice, had the good sense to subordinate his larger-than-life screen presence to the demands of a buddy film, and the bad judgment to pick this one. ''Tango and Cash,'' which finds Mr. Stallone wearing three-piece suits and glasses in an excessively ambitious attempt to make the break with Rambo, pairs him with Kurt Russell as a fellow Los Angeles narcotics officer.

LEAD: When Jewish families in half a dozen Soviet cities gather during the next few days to view a videotape of a popular animated film about Hanukkah, officials of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture will have won a 20-year gamble.

LEAD: YOU can't flip it. Nor is it packaged with a brittle stick of stale bubble gum. But the Topps Company is betting that American children will flock to it the way they have to the baseball cards the company has printed since 1951.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To see the 11 sculptures by Turku Trajan that are now at the Zabriskie Gallery is to be entranced and perplexed, for Trajan's legacy remains one of the genuine curiosities of 20th-century American art.

LEAD: The California Department of Insurance is examining the transfer of ''junk bonds'' by the First Executive Corporation to a series of affiliated companies. The transaction involving bonds worth more than $700 million took place in late 1988, but officials at the state regulator did not learn of it until mid-1989, they said.
LEAD: An undercover police officer was shot and robbed of $11,000 by two gunmen yesterday in Brooklyn in a ''buy and bust'' narcotics operation, the police said.
LEAD: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that its board had authorized spending up to $50 million to purchase shares of the company's class A common stock.
LEAD: Few areas in Panama City appeared totally secured by United States forces today as scattered fighting with paramilitary groups continued.
LEAD: Five people died in a house fire early today, and firefighters searched through debris for at least one more person, an East Orange fire official said.

LEAD: William M. Benkert, a retired Coast Guard rear admiral who was a specialist in marine environment and maritime safety, died of lung and liver cancer on Dec. 14 in McLean, Va., where he lived. He was 66 years old.
LEAD: Stock prices were slightly higher yesterday, as advances of blue chips helped to pull up smaller stocks.

LEAD: Ken O'Brien has decided to undergo exploratory surgery on his right shoulder on Friday, and will miss the Jets' final game Saturday against the Buffalo Bills.
LEAD: A Palestinian suspected in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 was convicted today along with three co-defendants in a series of attacks in northern Europe four years ago.

LEAD: Ever wonder what became of such former National Basketball Association players and coaches as Jim Chones, Jack Givens, Rich Kelley, Junior Bridgeman, Jan McGlocklin, Mike Glenn, Ron Boone, Hot Rod Hundley, Jim Barnett, Jim Spanarkel, Clark Kellogg, Johnny Kerr and Tom Nissalke?
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed new rules intended to give investors in mutual funds more and clearer information about the funds and their managers.

LEAD: The merger of The Kansas City Star and The Kansas City Times will take place on March 1, the editor of the newspapers said today. Plans to merge the morning Times and the afternoon Star were announced on Oct. 5. Joe McGuff, editor and vice president, said the decision came about because of sagging demand for afternoon papers and changing life styles.

LEAD: Two vacant, deteriorating houses of historic significance in Collis P. Huntington State Park in Redding, Conn., are facing demolition because the state sees no reason to preserve them, but they may yet get a reprieve.

LEAD: A Federal district judge declared a mistrial today after jurors failed to reach a verdict in the case of a teen-ager accused of selling the crack that President Bush used as a prop in a nationally televised address in September.
LEAD: A plane carrying four humanitarian workers from a southern Sudan town surrounded by rebels was shot down today shortly after takeoff, and all aboard were killed, a United Nations official said.

LEAD: Pentagon officials said today that Eduardo Herrera Hassan, a former colonel in the Panamanian army, was being flown to Panama by the United States at the request of Panama's new President, Guillermo Endara.
LEAD: Capitol Hill took a sober second look today at the United States attack on Panama.
LEAD: A former police official suspected in the disappearance of money from a secret $1.4 million Police Department fund was arrested on fraud charges today.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would place 1,600 workers on indefinite layoff in February at its plant in Linden, N.J., where it makes Chevrolet Corsicas and Berettas. G.M. said the second shift at the plant would be eliminated on Feb. 26. Corsica and Beretta cars also are made in Wilmington, Del.

LEAD: ''The life of the journalist is poor, nasty, brutish and short. So is his style. You, who are so adept at the lovely polishing of every grave and lucent phrase, will realise the magnitude of the task which confronted me when I found, after spending ten years as a journalist, learning to say exactly what I meant in short sentences, that I must learn, if I was to achieve literature and favourable reviews, to write as though I were not quite sure about what I meant but was jolly well going to say something all the same in sentences as long as possible.
LEAD: Dr. Joseph D. Bachelder, a public-opinion researcher, died yesterday at his home in Jamesburg, N.J. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: Marlo, a composer who goes by only one name, will give a concert of her recent piano works and chamber pieces at Up Front Muse, 190-A Duane Street, tomorrow evening at 8:30. The performers include members of two ensembles, Hot Kitty and Evolution. Tickets are $5. Information: 334-9847.
LEAD: The right to keep silent under the Fifth Amendment is being tested here in deportation hearings for a group of Latin American immigrants who were seized in a raid on a racetrack.

LEAD: * Cablevision Systems Corp., Woodbury, L.I., said it would buy Gateway Cable from Gilbert Media Associates L.P. for $102.5 million. Gateway serves Newark and South Orange, N.J., and is close to other Cablevision operations in New Jersey.

LEAD: Beacon International Ltd. of Toronto has agreed to buy the heating and air-conditioning division of the Coleman Company. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The transaction is scheduled to be completed in early 1990. Beacon International is a subsidiary of the Beacon Capital Corporation.

LEAD: Roy Bennett, an adviser to three Presidents on economics and foreign policy, died of a heart attack Wednesday at New York Hospital, where he was recovering from surgery. He was 77 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.
LEAD: East German sports authorities yesterday blocked the move of Rainer Ernst to a West German club, saying the soccer star was not playing well enough to deserve a transfer.

LEAD: Eileen Kingsbury-Smith and Thomas Leffingwell Pulling were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony. The bride, 48 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kingsbury-Smith of Washington. A graduate of the Hewitt School, she is a former vice president of Tiffany's.

LEAD: Many local telephone companies will no longer be able to earn a guaranteed profit beginning Jan. 1, 1991, the Federal Communications Commission said today.

LEAD: Two weeks of pounding rains in northern Brazil have killed 32 people and left thousands homeless, civil defense officials said today. Worst hit was the state of Bahia, where 24 people died and 25,000 were left homeless, according to Jornal do Brasil, a daily newspaper here.

LEAD: Penn State has been sent a letter by Atlantic 10 officials suggesting the school leave the conference by June 30, The Pittsburgh Press reported today.

LEAD: One of the lessons that 1980's pop culture has taught is that nothing really disappears. LEAD: Armitage Watkins, a literary agent who represented such authors as Pamela L. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

LEAD: U.S. Memories Inc., the cooperative venture to manufacture computer memory chips, has agreed to license the technology it needs for its first product from the International Business Machines Corporation, the two companies said yesterday. The agreement, which was expected, will give U.S. Memories the manufacturing process and design for a dynamic random access memory chip capable of storing four million bits of information, or four megabits.

LEAD: The United States appeared in serious difficulty today as it struggled to win international backing for its assault of Panama and for the newly installed Government of President Guillermo Endara against mounting third world and Soviet criticism of President Bush's action.

LEAD: The Government announced today that it would send two checks early next year to each of 27 million older Americans to offset continued deductions from their Social Security checks for a $5.30 monthly premium for extended Medicare coverage that was repealed last month.

LEAD: Susan Mulcahy has been named the editor in chief of Avenue magazine, replacing Joan Kron, who said she would resign last week. Ms. Mulcahy, a former columnist for The New York Post and for New York Newsday, will continue as editor in chief of On The Avenue, Avenue's sister publication. Ms. Mulcahy was featured in the recent advertisements for the Gap clothing stores.

LEAD: Ending a turbulent two-day meeting marked by bitterness over abuse of power by former leaders, the Czechoslovak Communist Party voted today to suspend the party memberships of 32 former leaders and expel a former party ideologist whom it accused of instigating the Soviet-led invasion of the country in 1968.

LEAD: The Pentagon has been releasing the names of servicemen killed in the Panamanian invasion as their next of kin are notified. Here are the names released so far: BROWN, Pfc. Roy Dennis Jr., an infantryman, of Buena Park, Calif. CONNORS, Lieut. (j.g.) John Patrick, a member of the Navy's special operations unit known as the SEALS, and a native of Arlington, Mass.

Mr. Nicholas, who starred with his brother, Fayard, as the Nicholas Brothers in nightclubs and movies in the 1930's, 40's and 50's, is an established singer and dancer in his own right.

The long Christmas weekend, which coincides with the beginning of Hanukkah this year (related article, page C34), may chiefly be a time for indoor family festivities.
LEAD: MANY people's anxieties these days focus on the political and military dangers of German unification. Memories of the Third Reich do not fade.

LEAD: Ronald D. Pacchiana, a construction executive in Westchester County, died last Friday in the crash of a twin-engine Piper Navajo near Cairo, N.Y. He was 56 years old and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

LEAD: The European Community said today that it would send medical aid to Poland as part of a medical aid program in place since 1982. The 1989 package worth $2.9 million will buy medication and small medical supplies. The aid brings total European Community medical aid to Poland since 1982 to $60.8 million.

LEAD: District Attorney Harry Connick, indicted Friday on charges that he conspired to help an arrested bookmaker continue a gambling operation, pleaded not guilty in a Federal court today.

LEAD: The State Department, citing ''changing conditions'' in the Soviet Union, is giving high priority to constructing a new United States Embassy in Moscow to replace the one to be razed after years of indecision.

LEAD: Ernest Ludwig Sisto, an award-winning photographer who worked for The New York Times for nearly 50 years, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Sierra Nevada Memorial Hospital in Grass Valley, Calif. He was 85 years old and had been living with a son Daniel in Rough and Ready, Calif., for 18 months.

LEAD: International 3-15 President Ceausescu of Rumania fled Bucharest, routed by crowds of pro-democracy demonstrators backed by army units. The state security police reportedly remained loyal to the President. Fierce fighting was reported. 1 News analysis: The armed rebellion in Rumania proves that no hard-line Communist government in Eastern Europe can evade the popular wrath sweeping the region.

LEAD: Wall Street had visions of its traditional holiday rally - covering the last five trading days of the old year and the first two of the new - as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 20.26 points yesterday, to 2,711.39, but activity was thin, as is usual before a holiday.

LEAD: George Harold Dennis, retired president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company in Madrid and former representative of Radio Liberty to the Spanish Government, died on Thursday at the White Plains Medical Center after a long illness. He was 91 years old and lived in White Plains.

LEAD: Apparently in part because of his ethics troubles, Senator Alan Cranston has announced that his plans to marry this Sunday have been called off. In a statement issued by his office here Thursday, the 75-year-old Senator suggested that local news organizations' attention to his wedding plans and the pressure of the Lincoln Savings and Loan affair were responsible for his decision.
LEAD: Maybe they love their MTV, their CNN, their HBO or their Cinemax. Maybe they hate it. But 110,000 cable television subscribers have something to say about cable service in Manhattan.

LEAD: Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter under suspension for his steroid-tainted past, may have a brighter future if promoters can parlay pay television and whatever curiosity the public may have in seeing him in a rematch against his rival Carl Lewis.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines, which just sold its Latin American routes, is also cutting back some domestic flights, including nonstop service from Miami to Boston, Philadelphia, Orlando and Tampa, Fla., and several Caribbean cities, the company said today.
LEAD: A tenant volunteer on watch in a Bronx apartment-house lobby was shot to death Thursday night with a stray bullet from a street dispute outside the building, the police said yesterday.
LEAD: The armed rebellion against Nicolae Ceausescu in Rumania demonstrates that no hard-line Communist regime in Eastern Europe can evade the popular wrath sweeping the region.

LEAD: Dr. Paul C. Agnew, a psychiatrist who headed the Dannemora and Matteawan correctional centers in upstate New York in the 1970's, died of pneumonia yesterday at the University of Vermont Hospital in Burlington. He was 66 years old and lived in Plattsburg, N.Y.

LEAD: For holiday shoppers, it has come down to that time when the gift they ordered absolutely, positively has to be there overnight. Not to worry, Federal Express told customers this week. The nation's largest overnight delivery company has teamed up with about 200 catalogue retailers, from L. L. Bean to the Sharper

LEAD: By ''decapitating'' Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's control of Panama's military, the United States has created a challenge that may prove to be as formidable as the capture of the general himself: the purging and restructuring of the 15,000-man army, police and customs force he commanded and bent to his own will.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Although the glasnost policies of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have taken much of the suspense out of the Victor Kamkin bookshop here, they have brought the largest Russian bookstore in the West a boom in business.
LEAD: The Security Council remained deadlocked today as it tried to decide the legitimate government of Panama in the aftermath of the United States military strike.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It stung the face and touched bare fingertips like a flame. It shattered plans and turned the most ordinary tasks to hardship. It meant danger and misery for some, poetry and adventure for others. But no one, it seemed, could ignore the cold.

LEAD: A brief article on Dec. 12 about the acquittal of a student accused of painting anti-Semitic slurs in the Jewish Student Union at the State University of New York at Binghamton gave an incorrect account of testimony about a can of spray paint found in a desk in the group's office.

LEAD: The Bush Administration said today that it was prepared to extend to Rumania the kind of assistance granted to Poland and Hungary if the government that emerges in Bucharest adopts similar political and economic reforms.
LEAD: IN a reversal of a 26-year decline, American inventors this year obtained a larger share of the patents issued in the United States than they did in 1988.
LEAD: Eleanor Shaler Dickson, a socially prominent actress and singer of the 1920's and 30's, died of pulmonary problems yesterday at her home in Gladwyne, Pa. She was 89 years old.
LEAD: Leaders of the two Germanys reopened the Brandenburg Gate today, breaching a barrier that more than any other had come to symbolize the division of the nation.
LEAD: New York's tough statewide anti-smoking law, scheduled to take effect on Jan. 1, will not be shelved during a new court challenge, a state judge said today.

LEAD: Giorgio Cavallon, a pioneer Abstract Expressionist who brought to American painting a Mediterranean feeling for color and light, died last night at New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: The Rev. Elizabeth Miller, an executive of the American Baptist Churches for more than 36 years, died Saturday at her home in King of Prussia, Pa., after a long illness. She was 67 years old.

LEAD: The Bank of New England Corporation said it would cancel an announced common stock dividend of 34 cents a share. A week earlier, the banking company, based in Boston, said that because losses in its real estate lending would result in a large loss for the year, it would consider rescinding the dividend.

LEAD: Even the most tennis-ignorant can recognize a Chris Evert or a John McEnroe. But ask someone as knowledgeable as the editor of Tennis magazine to identify the 732d-ranked player in the world, and unless there's a ranking list handy, the response will be a shrug and a blank expression.
LEAD: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law page yesterday referred incorrectly to the first Jews to have served on the United States Supreme Court. Benjamin N. Cardozo followed Louis

LEAD: The undefeated University of Colorado football team made its first trip here in 13 years today, landing amid 65-degree temperatures after taking off in readings of 15 below in Denver. The Buffaloes are preparing for a night game New Year's Day against Notre Dame in the Orange Bowl that could determine the national championship.
LEAD: The Government looked distinctly cheap when it offered $1 million for General Noriega. For that kind of money you can't even get a halfway decent baseball player anymore.
LEAD: The Notre Dame offensive coordinator, Jim Strong, was named head coach at Nevada-Las Vegas yesterday.

LEAD: William John Bailey, chemist, educator and former chairman of the board of the American Chemical Society, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Straub Hospital in Honolulu, where he was attending a professional meeting on polymers. He was 68 years old and lived in University Park, Md.

LEAD: ''Wozzeck'' is not exactly ''Hansel and Gretel.'' In other words, the opera that Alban Berg fashioned from Georg Buchner's harrowing play of proletarian military degradation is hardly cheery holiday fare. But the Metropolitan Opera's production, which dates back 30 years and which returned Thursday night, remains one of the company's finest achievements, and a healthy audience welcomed it warmly.
LEAD: A Maryland criminal court judge known for strong advocacy of gun control and harsh prison sentences was injured today when a package bomb exploded in his apartment in Hagerstown, Md.
LEAD: The European Community and 22 members of the Arab League decided today to resume a formal dialogue on political and economic issues, six years after talks between the two groups broke down.
LEAD: Two days after United States forces invaded the country, Panama appeared close to anarchy as bands of looters and roving gunmen took over and ravaged one neighborhood after another.
LEAD: Khmer Rouge guerrillas said today that they had captured the third district capital since Vietnamese troops withdrew from Cambodia three months ago, the guerrilla radio reported.

LEAD: SUMNER REDSTONE, the 66-year-old owner of Viacom Inc., has always lectured his children about the perils of dwelling on past mistakes. ''I tell them I don't want to hear any 'woulda, shoulda or coulda,' '' he said.

LEAD: EARLY last year, the distribution system at Alpo Petfoods Inc. was a major disappointment for top management. The company's 14 warehouses were located near its customers, but service nevertheless was wanting. In fact, in a survey of its 400 major customers, the company, based in Allentown, Pa., was rated below several of its rivals in service.

LEAD: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.
LEAD: As long as she can remember, Mimi Chapia has kept her eye peeled for great junk.
LEAD: Dear Ms. Klaus:

LEAD: ON Christmas Eve throughout the south of France a ritual takes place as it has for centuries. To insure good fortune in the coming year a platter is passed around the dining table. It holds the celebrated treize desserts, 13 of the region's delicacies. Although the selection may vary, it is likely to include walnuts and almonds, apricots and figs, almond-based calisson candies and nut-studded nougats and what some consider the star attraction, colorful candied fruits confits.

LEAD: If you're like me, you're probably having visions of mistletoe, eggnog and presents under the tree. It would be nice to think that all's well with the world, too. But there's trouble in Photo Land, I'm afraid.

LEAD: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has asked Gov. Bob Martinez to send in the National Guard here, saying it fears that black communities may be ignored by police officers loyal to a Hispanic officer who was convicted of killing two blacks.

LEAD: WHEN chunks of granite from a nearby quarry tumbled into his backyard last spring, Gus Dobes of Bethlehem Township complained to the state. Months earlier, when he and his neighbors noticed that their houses were shaking more than usual from the quarry's blasts, he signed a petition that was also sent to the state.

LEAD: The Rumanian Ambassador to the United States and the embassy's diplomatic staff today denounced the deposed dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu, joining about a dozen other Rumanian legations in declaring their loyalty to the rebels who toppled the Government this week.
LEAD: To the Editor:

Healy Jr. of Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in New York to William Redmond Cross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Cross Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., and Chilmark, Mass. The Rev. Brian Lathrop, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE toy train is making a comeback this season as one of the most popular holiday gift items. Good, old-fashioned fun, parents might think as they consider the purchase. Nostalgic, romantic, quaint. But hold on. Take it from a train widow. These contraptions can be dangerous.

LEAD: The Rumanian press has begun reporting events with a candor unthinkable before the ouster of Nicolae Ceausescu, Following are excerpts from the Rumanian press agency Agerpres and Rumanian, East German and Hungarian broadcasts as monitored and translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service.

Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

LEAD: A SUMMER WORLD The Attempt to Build a Jewish Eden in the Catskills, From the Days of the Ghetto to the Rise and Decline of the Borscht Belt. By Stefan Kanfer. Illustrated. 333 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

LEAD: In an unusual real estate deal, two Manhattan developers have gone into partnership with a Russian philanthropy to tack nine stories onto the philanthropy's Upper West Side town- house headquarters. The expanded building will contain ll luxury apartments and 3,200 square feet of doctors' offices, as well as new headquarters space for the philanthropy, the Russian Aid Society, which will share in revenues from the medical space.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Mark Valenti of Smithtown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gina Marie Valenti, to Robert Blake Sansone, the son of Robert Sansone of Marina Del Rey, Calif., and New York, and Marietta Sansone of Watchung, N.J. A November wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: TO THE EDITOR: Henry Spira's denouncement of the fur and leather industry is not substantiated by facts (''Pressuring Perdue,'' by Barnaby J. Feder, Nov. 26). One of the biggest problems today is pollution created by man, and one of the major causes of this pollution is the manufacture of synthetics.

LEAD: IN THE ANNUAL MEMORY SEARCH for the dying year's most important musical events, the hunter must be careful not to be lured off into neighboring cultural categories. The electronic information bank is invaluable in enforcing such discipline. In the absence of such help, one is too easily distracted by strange notes found lying about the desk at year's end.

LEAD: Each day's newspaper brings additional revelations of misconduct or criminal behavior on the part of elected or appointed officials. What is particularly saddening is the fact that the public does not respond in outrage. The attitude seems to be, ''What do you expect of politicians and public servants?

LEAD: Stephan Van Dam's career as a map publisher and design entrepreneur began with origami. Such was his fascination with the Japanese art of paper folding that the Swiss-born designer, 30 years old, came up with ''The World Unfolds,'' an award-winning series of maps that presented the lay of the land in major cities in the United

LEAD: ''The People Who Could Fly,'' a work that combines international dance, theater and storytelling, will be presented this week at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The performances by the Warp and Woof Theater Company are Tuesday through Friday at 11 A.M. and 2 P.M., with an 8 P.M. performance added on Friday.
LEAD: DOWN TO THE WIRE UPI's Fight for Survival. By Gregory Gordon and Ronald E. Cohen. Illustrated. 429 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. $19.95.
LEAD: In the Bronx, glasnost translates into Michael Kirsanov biting into his first hamburger and Nadya Barabanov watching soap operas like ''Days of Our Lives'' and ''Santa Barbara.''
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: TO escape the commercial and familial hoopla of the holidays, my husband and I like to take our children to faraway places for a different kind of celebration - one that we create from the bits of experience and tradition we value most. Traveling at Christmas is part of our general inclination to set out against the seasonal tides.

LEAD: THE acceleration of Japanese purchases of American corporate icons like Rockefeller Center, Columbia Pictures and CBS Records should come as no surprise, given the huge advantage that the Japanese enjoy in capital costs. Recent studies have found that America's capital is between 2 1/2 and 4 times as expensive as Japan's.
LEAD: Tax on an Apartment Sale
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Years ago, if you watched Bill Cosby, Danny Kaye or Tim Conway, you could see humorous sketches about dentists. Today, things are totally different. Barbara Klaus, a person who wants to inflict pain on dentists to compensate for the fact that she is not funny, couldn't get into comedy school and obviously failed whatever writing courses she might have taken.
LEAD: Tracy Jill Margel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence N. Margel of Villanova, Pa., and Adam K. Bernstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Bernstein of Washington, are planning an April wedding.

LEAD: THE magic of Christmas is a fleeting gift of childhood. Once gone, it can almost never be recaptured. As the season approaches, a brief glimmer of a long ago Christmas will be recalled by a carol overheard, the sparkle of a decoration or the familiar scent of fresh pine. It comes and goes so quickly that sometimes we can scarcely identify what it is that brings on that feeling of excitement and anticipation we associate with a more innocent time in our lives.
LEAD: Heading into the final period, it had been anybody's game, anybody but a goaltender.
LEAD: DIAGHILEV'S BALLETS RUSSES By Lynn Garafola. Illustrated. 524 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

LEAD: To be Marvin Gaye, Prince, Otis Redding, Sam Cooke, Stevie Wonder, James Brown and Bob Dylan rolled into one is a tall order - and it comes as no surprise that Terence Trent D'Arby, who has taken the job upon himself, falls short.
LEAD: For the daily reviewer, special events are like oases in a desert of routine. Here is where this writer drank last year.

LEAD: Joan H. Gelb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce S. Gelb of New York and Washington, was married yesterday to Jacek Jarkowski, the son of Witold Jarkowski of Warsaw and the late Wanda Jarkowska. The Rev. Clarke Oler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the New York home of the bride's parents.
LEAD: The cold snap that has fastened onto the New York area since Thursday loosened its clutch just a bit yesterday.

LEAD: IN ANTIQUES AS IN ART, THEJU astounding prices paid at auction for certain rarities became the most discussed development of the last year - and the decade. The fallout from recent sales of pieces of furniture and decorative art for the seven-figure prices formerly reserved for Renoirs and Rembrandts is bound to be felt for years to come.

LEAD: The engagement of Melissa Danne Shaw to Gregory James Fleming, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil S. Fleming of Hopewell Junction, N.Y., has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Dillard Munford of Atlanta and Crawford Shaw of New York and Quogue, L.I. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: GUARDIANS OF THE ARSENAL The Politics of Nuclear Strategy. By Janne E. Nolan. 320 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/ Basic Books. $21.95.

LEAD: I really enjoyed ''Recycling as a Permanent Life Style'' (Dec. 3). In addition to conserving materials and protecting the environment, the author demonstrated prudence and wisdom in approaching packaging from more than one perspective.

LEAD: TO THE EDITOR: I am puzzled. What do Henry Spira's cats eat? A survey of the cat-food shelves at my local supermarket shows no cat food, canned or dry, that does not contain animal products. After sharpening their claws on Mr. Spira's politically correct Naugahyde furniture, do his cats hunt, kill and eat mice?

LEAD: ONE of the treasures of the kitchen is a recipe for hors d'oeuvres that can be whipped up at the last minute with ingredients that are always on hand. Such a failsafe is a godsend when unexpected guests drop in or when nothing beyond a bowl of salted nuts comes to mind to serve before a dinner party.

LEAD: In 1979, as a rookie, Ottis Anderson replaced Terry Metcalf as the St. Louis Cardinals' tailback. Today, Metcalf's son, Eric, is a rookie running back for the Cleveland Browns, and Anderson, now with the Giants, is at 32 the oldest starting running back in the National Football League.

LEAD: March wedding plans have been announced for Anne Southall Adler and John Weatherbee Tarbell Jr., the son of Mrs. Tarbell of Needham, Mass., and the late Mr. Tarbell, by the prospective bride's parents, Anne Freeman Adler and Julius Ochs Adler, both of New York.

LEAD: Most patients do appreciate the comfortable atmosphere and the pain control modalities dental offices provide. Most patients do appreciate that their children have no caries. Most patients do appreciate early diagnosis of periodontal disease and the simple preventive techniques which can help maintain their teeth.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Pearl of New York have announced March wedding plans for their daughter Suzanne L. Pearl and Kenneth S. Bakst, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin A. Bakst of Rancho Mirage, Calif., and Lake Tahoe, Nev.

LEAD: It seemed appropriate, in keeping with the spirit of the holidays, to root around in current mystery releases for some nice books. Nothing as pointedly seasonal as ''Corpus Christmas'' or 'Mistletoe Mysteries,'' among other titles we've seen of late; merely something of gentle sensibility. A story with a hint of culture, perhaps, or a sleuth with a bit of class.

LEAD: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.
LEAD: With a palm thatch roof and poles for hammocks, the Indian House health clinic stands at the end of a sandy road, beyond the end of the freshly laid pavement of this Amazonian gold rush town.

LEAD: It's a ''big old house,'' that white, wooden, four-bedroom house on the quiet street in St. Cloud, Minn., with a Christmas tree inside and other holiday decorations. It is a house that tomorrow, in the warmth against the frost outdoors, will be filled happily for Ann Eisenreich. It will be filled with her family -her husband and five children and three daughters-in-law and three grandchildren -and the aroma of, among other delights, the oatmeal cookies and the angel food cake she baked.

LEAD: Q. We have thermal windows in our country home, manufacturer unknown. On several windows, moisture is seeping in between the two panes of glass. Is there a way to clean out this moisture and reseal the windows?

LEAD: Since dentistry has made so much progress in the prevention of tooth and gum disease, it saddened me to read the article. As a psychotherapist and spouse of a dentist, it seems clear that dental phobia is much harder to cure and prevent than cavities.

LEAD: Sticking to the themes he developed in his election campaign last year, President Bush will emphasize in his budget message to Congress next month new proposals to encourage personal saving and modest spending increases for drug control, education, science, research and the environment, Administration officials said.
LEAD: THE gift of music is precious, but it cannot always be taken for granted. A case in point is an orchestra that music lovers in the county almost lost.

LEAD: Junior sophisticates and teen-agers celebrated the holidays last Sunday at the 33d annual Gold and Silver Ball. Seven hundred 15-to-18-year-olds, the girls in black off-the-shoulder dresses with short skirts, danced the night away at the benefit party of the Youth Counseling League. LEAD: A COLLECTION of 100 Tiffany lamps, windows and vases, from the largest collection of Tiffany art in the world, appears headed to a permanent home at the William Benton Museum of Art in Storrs.

LEAD: There are those who can't make up their minds until the last split second. Should they start the winter solstice basking in the sun or schussing down the slopes? Designer Calvin Klein and his wife, Kelly, are like that. Today will find them either on sunny St. Barts or in frosty Aspen. Wherever, they will not be wanting for fellow celebrants.

LEAD: THE AMERICAN MUSICOLOGIST H. C. Robbins Landon lives in France but commutes to the 18th century. His means of conveyance are many - including the computer, the telephone and the goodwill and vigilance of friends. He was in town the other day noting the uses of the present as a way of getting at the past.

LEAD: IT is Christmas Eve. I've shifted into overdrive, madly wrapping last-minute purchases to put under the tree, when I hear, Thump! Thump! Thump! above my head. It's too early for reindeer hooves to be prancing and pawing on the roof, or perhaps too late. I haven't heard that noise for many years - and then it was only a faint echo in my imagination as

LEAD: The Government is moving to help unclog bottlenecks that have created shortages of heating oil and propane in the current spell of extremely cold weather, the Energy Department's top emergency planner said today.

LEAD: Katharine Ceremsak, an owner of Voila Designs, a textile design concern in Boston, and Leonard Andres, a doctoral candidate in respiratory biology at Harvard University, are planning a May wedding. Miss Ceremsak, 25 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Ceremsak of Evergreen, Colo. She graduated from the University of Colorado.
LEAD: HOW SOFT A LANDING?'' headlines the latest newsletter of economic commentary from the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, apparently not referring to military aid, said today that he would confer with Warsaw Pact members on rendering assistance to the Rumanian people in their ''just cause'' of opposing force fighting to restore Nicolae Ceausescu to power.

LEAD: DOOMSAYERS, CULTURE AND capitalism seem to conspire these days, both in Europe and America, despite all evidence to the contrary. With classical recordings, beyond larger complaints about a decline in artistry among our composers and performers, one hears laments about the foreign ownership of formerly
LEAD: Brains of the Mutants

LEAD: In its first major action, Panama's new civilian Government - installed by the United States military - announced this afternoon that it had dissolved the Panamanian Army and would replace the 15,000-member military institution that has ruled this country for more than 20 years with a more modest public security organ under new leadership.

LEAD: The removal this month of a student editor of a Duke University humor magazine has touched off a heated debate about the application of the First Amendment to university publications and about race relations on campus. The action was a response to the magazine's publication of satirical articles construed by some community members as racist.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Linsenmeyer of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Linsenmeyer, to Thomas Patrick Malone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Thomas Malone of Street, Md. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: A month after being dismissed as head coach of the Phoenix Cardinals of the National Football League, Gene Stallings has been interviewed for the head coaching job at Navy, The Phoenix Gazette reported yesterday.

LEAD: DURING the past five years, Texaco Inc. has earned some dubious distinctions. It became the victim of the largest damage award in history when a court ordered it to pay the Pennzoil Company $11 billion for illegally elbowing it aside to acquire the Getty Oil Company in 1984. It also became the largest company to file for protection from creditors under the bankruptcy law and the biggest target ever stalked by Carl I.

LEAD: FOOTBALL, which Bo Jackson will play at Giants Stadium today, is a contact sport. So is baseball, which Jackson also plays. While Jackson has shown improvement in avoiding contact in football this year, he has displayed improvement in making contact in baseball.
LEAD: AT two of the commencement exercises at Rutgers University I attended, there were a small number of handicapped students who received diplomas.

LEAD: Where is the world headed? The Week in Review asked a number of people to hazard some predictions about life in the 1990's. Some stuck their necks out farther than others, but, if experience is any guide, all of us are in for surprises. Economic Warfare

LEAD: AT parties, William A. Taylor Jr. keeps his eyes on the noses. As a professional caricaturist, he finds that parties and other gatherings are good places to work, and that he works best when he concentrates on a subject's nose.

LEAD: International 3-17 Nicolae Ceausescu was captured by insurgent Army troops, which continued to battle against the deposed Rumanian dictator's powerful state security police in several cities. 1 More atrocities by the security forces are being reported by frightened and angry Rumanians.

LEAD: In a recent article appearing in the Long Island Weekly, certain facts concerning my successful re-election campaign were incorrectly stated. The article read, ''Mr. Dillon, a Roman Catholic, said during the campaign that his opposition to abortion derives from his religious beliefs.'' I never said that and, to the contrary, I have always said that my position is based on the scientific evidence that human life begins at conception, and the ethical principle that it is always wrong to unjustifiably kill innocent human life.

LEAD: AS THE 1980'S AND THE REAGAN era came to a close, much of television's arts and entertainment programming, like the nation, seemed exhausted. The optimism bubble that characterized the decade and its yuppie cheerleaders suddenly burst, exposing a series of long-festering crises: the homeless, AIDS, environmental pollution, political scandals, multibillion-dollar bailouts of financial institutions, mountains of governmental, corporate and private debt.

LEAD: One of Alvin Ailey's most inspired ideas was ''The Magic of Katherine Dunham,'' a program devoted to the black heritage in dance as popularized and introduced to a wide public by the foremost pioneer in the field.

LEAD: John E. Parker, an investment banker and business executive who was chairman of the Bunker-Ramo Corporation and other companies in the electronic and computer data programming fields, died of colon cancer yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: UP on the scoreboard, the final seconds were flashing as the Buffalo Bills held a 37-0 lead. After having defied a wind-chill factor that was 11 degrees below zero at the kickoff, most of the scattered 21,148 customers had deserted Giants Stadium, but a record 55,743 customers had never appeared. Above the tunnel leading to the Jets' locker room, a few vultures in parkas and woolen caps were rehearsing their ''Joe Must Go'' chant.

LEAD: Doctors report that heavy crack smoking appears to be causing a growing number of addicts to become critically ill with symptoms similar to those of pneumonia. They say the condition is not easily detected unless the patients reveal their crack habits, but if it is not treated properly it can lead to death.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having spent a pleasant few days at La Residence du Bois in Paris at the end of May, I agree wholeheartedly with Warren Obr's description of the facilities (''Paris: Comfort and Good Coffee,'' Travel, Oct. 8). However, I do not agree with his description of the prices. I paid 1,350 francs, which made the price of a double room approximately $212.

Siegel, a son of Howard Siegel of Emerson, N.J., and Phyllis Burstein of Springfield, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Alan D. Fuchs at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia.

Dr. Kroop, 26 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Kroop of Teaneck, N.J. Dr. Martin, 28, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Martin of Hamden, Conn.

LEAD: STRUNG ALONG THE 46 CHROMOSOMES of every human cell are some 100,000 genes. Among them, in each one of us, are a few that can be deadly. Every person has a unique set of these seven or eight lethal genes. They are usually hidden, but in the wrong environment or in combination with certain other genes they can express themselves in dangerous ways.
LEAD: Armed skirmishes between Government troops and the security police swirled today across this city that had led the revolution against the deposed Rumanian leader, Nicolae Ceausescu.

LEAD: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

LEAD: Eight months after he sealed Michigan's national championship victory over Seton Hall with a pair of overtime free throws, Rumeal Robinson was at it again. This time, though, it was just another game.

LEAD: As troops and protesters clashed in Bethlehem, Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu of South Africa began a Christmas pilgrimage to the Holy Land today, offering support for the creation of a Palestinian state and for Israel's ''independence and territorial integrity.''
LEAD: THE RUBY SLIPPERS OF OZ By Rhys Thomas. Illustrated. 232 pp. Los Angeles: Tale Weaver Publishing. Paper, $14.95.

LEAD: A new ''call-up'' procedure takes effect in New York City Wednesday aimed at combatting the red tape that delays action on development proposals. Mandated by the city's revised Charter, the procedure allows a developer whose plans are under preliminary interagency review to appeal for a public review once 180 days have elapsed from the filing date.
LEAD: On behalf of the members of the Suffolk County Dental Society, I am writing to object to the scurrilous article on dentistry.

LEAD: THE day is still not over, but shadows and the temperature have begun to fall quickly as Dave Stewart drives slowly down Center Street, turns left onto 15th and then finally pulls to a stop at Cypress Avenue. There are old, tired houses to his right and to his left, a barricade of yellow police tape in front of him and then a strange wide expanse of leveled earth beyond that, as if a bulldozer had suddenly pushed everything aside.

LEAD: In some ways, the face of need has changed little since Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The New York Times, encountered a homeless beggar on Christmas Day 1911 and decided to start the Neediest Cases Fund drive. But to long-time experts in the social services it is markedly different.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ITALY, you might say, is a country where everyone likes football, but doesn't like one another. In terms of soccer towns (which means almost all of them) and soccer teams, it remains essentially a collection of city states, which have only in name been welded into a single nation. The longstanding notion in the north is that from Rome on down, it's no longer Italy, it's Africa.

LEAD: THE MOST DEARLY REMEMBERED Christmas present I ever received was given to me by my father when I was 12. It was a complete set of Beethoven's symphonies, the first ever to be recorded in its entirety.

LEAD: Disgrace was a main theme for the famous (Jim Bakker), along with wealth (Donald Trump) and tastelessness (Morton Downey Jr.). Not a few of the big names were big, and appear here, because they did something wrong.

LEAD: What must be considered the most remarkable bridge conspiracy occurred 40 years ago in the Philadelphia area. A special Christmas duplicate game was ruled with an iron fist in a velvet glove by the great Olive Petersen. It was played at the club she ran in her home in St. Davids Mrs. Petersen was one of the grande dames of the game, with a career as player, writer and teacher that spanned the evolution of auction bridge into contract.

LEAD: The worst flu epidemic in 14 years has strong-armed its way through Britain, claiming lives, forcing hospitals to postpone surgery and dominating conversation with worries over who has it, how to avoid it or how to get rid of it.

LEAD: Judith Ann Bertrand and John Lawrence Harrisingh, assistant corporation counsels for the city of New York, were married yesterday in the Harriet Packer Chapel at the Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Donald Roberts, a Presbyterian minister.

Olin Raymond Jackson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Villanova (Pa.) University
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: RETROSPECT often makes the most recent moments seem the most vivid. That is usually a trick that our minds play upon us, but surely not in the 1980's. The pictures of Berliners dancing upon, pouring through, chipping hunks out of their hated wall, symbolizing the end of 45 years of cold war, seem incredible now, and surely they and what they epitomize will still seem extraordinary in the next century.
LEAD: With bitter arctic cold sweeping across much of the nation, dozens of utilities and large industrial customers are scrambling to secure enough energy to avoid shortages and plant shutdowns.

LEAD: In a remarkable combination of will, foresight and happenstance, what began as a swampy island only 85 miles from the Equator has been transformed into the most modern, efficient and simply the cleanest city of Southeast Asia. The last is not a bad attribute in a part of the world where sanitation is more talked about than practiced.

LEAD: Although the past year produced more than the usual number of fine pop albums, none found the kind of critical and commercial consensus that ''Tracy Chapman,'' Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' and U2's ''Joshua Tree'' won in the three previous years. The following is a personal Top 10 in rough order of preference, plus an alphabetical listing of runners-up.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today lashed out at separatists seeking to secede from the Soviet Union, warning that any such move in the country's current difficult political and economic conditions would ''sow discord, bloodshed and death.''

LEAD: I was the deputy commander of the student demonstrations in Tiananmen Square. Last April, May and June, Chinese students nonviolently petitioned their Government to discuss human rights and put an end to corruption. Great expectation and hope filled the air. It was our spring. Now it is our winter.
LEAD: Of all of the labels known generically as cinderellas, Christmas seals have proved the most consistently attractive to collectors.

LEAD: The work of Arnold Schoenberg will be studied in six concerts of orchestral, chamber and solo works at the Juilliard School, from Jan. 26 to Feb. 2. More than 250 students of the music, dance and drama divisions will take part in the series, which is titled 'The World of Arnold Schoenberg' and which will include his own work and that of some of the composers who studied with him.

None of the communities or minority businesses we discussed were investment grade. Rather, they were completely unbankable, and most credit analyses by rating agencies would classify them as ''junk'' investments.

LEAD: I disagree with Benedict M. Kohl's letter to the New Jersey editor (Nov. 12) in his comparisons of New Jersey's drivers to those of Europe. Tailgating is an aggressive behavior that is unwarranted under any circumstance, is unsafe at any speed and is illegal for obvious reasons. It occurs in all lanes, not just behind ''slowpokes in the fast lane.

LEAD: THE Civic Center Synagogue at 47 White Street is just the kind of building planners warn against. LEAD: TO THE EDITOR: Congratulations to Prof. Robert Jahn of Princeton for having the courage to pursue his investigation of psychic phenomena (''Questions for the Cosmos,'' by Steve Fishman, Nov. 26). That is exciting. But as one who has participated in informal experiments testing such things as telepathy and psychometry (with startling results) and as someone who has read widely in the literature, I would ask: How many times do we have to prove that ESP exists?

LEAD: It was a poor year for foreign films, a fine one for talented American newcomers and a year that found a number of cinematic mainstays going strong. It was also a year that brought a bumper crop of sorry spinoffs. None of my top 10 films is a sequel. ''BORN ON THE FOURTH OF JULY.'' Like all of Oliver Stone's films, this one aims directly for the solar plexus.

LEAD: Joan Baron's account ''Rescue Mission: Saving a Swan'' (Opinion, Dec. 3) reminded me of the time, some years ago, when I foiled the kidnapping of a large goose at the pond located at Nassau Boulevard and Hempstead Avenue in West Hempstead.

LEAD: A new wind is blowing through America's remote outposts in Antarctica: a not entirely welcome impetus toward healthier bodies and tidier habits.
LEAD: President Bush offered no high-flown reflections and did no last-minute agonizing as he made the decision to invade Panama last Sunday, officials who were with him at the time say.

LEAD: New Year's Eve is a merry bonanza for many restaurants. It is the only night of the year when they get away with giving a couple a bottle of bubbly, an extra appetizer or two, a silly cardboard hat and maybe a lounge trio - and tripling their prices. If your New Year's resolution is to start 1990 with a whopping credit-card tab, Manhattan awaits you with open arms.

LEAD: THERE CAN HARDLY BE ANY doubt that the playwright who mattered most in 1989 was Vaclav Havel. In a year when the world was changing as fast as, if not faster than, at any other time in this century, Mr. Havel was one of the people who changed it - first as a dissident dramatist and now as a political leader shaping the future of Czechoslovakia.

The decision could signal a willingness by the United States to ease restrictions on high-tech exports. These exports are currently limited by the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, called Cocom, which includes 17 Western countries.

LEAD: Last week's statistics ran counter to the widely held view that the economy is slowing enough to threaten a recession. Durable goods orders surged by 5.1 percent in November, their largest monthly gain of the year. Aircraft orders accounted for nearly half of the increase, but there were gains in many categories.

LEAD: To the Editor: We were disappointed with a couple of points in the article ''Finding an Authentic Irish Harp'' (Travel, Oct. 8). My harps are played by classical and traditional players, and I make both gut- and nylon-strung harps. My lever system is not operated by rotating an off-center screw, it's adjusted by doing so.

LEAD: May wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Helle of New Canaan, Conn., for their daughter, Karen Elizabeth Helle, and David Stewart Nemiah, a son of Dr. John C. Nemiah of Hanover, N.H., and Mrs. William Geist of Rehoboth Beach, Del.
LEAD: A FIREPLACE that allows smoke to enter a room is less than cheery. The problem can be caused by a variety of conditions, some of which are simple to cure, some less so.

LEAD: East German athletes will continue to dominate in the world of sports because of their spirit of competition and their pride. They, along with the Soviets, will still rule the world of gymnastics, swimming and ice skating in the Olympics. Politics has no influence on sports. CLEMENTE LISI New
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Bartsch Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have made known the May wedding plans of their daughter Nancy Ellen Bartsch and David Shove Osborn, a son of James E. Osborn 2d of Greenwich, Conn., and Little Compton, R.I., and the late Nancy Brayton Osborn.

LEAD: Downtown - or experimentalist - dance had a varied and vibrant year, with inspired work not only from performers and choreographers but from designers of lighting, sets and costumes as well as composers.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Egypt and Syria appeared ready today to end a 12-year break in diplomatic relations within the next few weeks, senior Egyptian and Syrian officials said here today.

LEAD: Carolyn Patricia Tommins and William Arthur Whalen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Whalen of Bronxville, N.Y., plan to marry in the spring, the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Tommins of Rockville Centre, L.I., have announced.

LEAD: FOR A REFUGEE FROM A small town, Manhattan always feels like the luckiest place to be on New Year's Eve. It's the one night when my consort and I can walk out our front door and into the park at midnight to toast city life in an effervescence of fireworks and Champagne.

LEAD: ''It's the Securitate,'' yelled a burly man, leaning out of the open door of the small white car as it careened, horn honking and lights blazing, down a dark and empty boulevard. ''They're shooting again, the bastards.''
LEAD: THE setting of Tim Kelly's mystery play ''Murder Game,'' now at the Broadhollow Theater in Farmingdale, is an architectural oddity replete with cellar, attic and secret passageways.

LEAD: WILLIAM FINN thought he'd never get out of the soup kitchen where he'd been slaving for more than seven years on his new musical. Then along came the producer Joseph Papp to offer him not a way out of the kitchen but a new recipe for making soup. What they cooked up was a new version of ''Romance in Hard Times,'' a quirkily comic musical written and composed by Mr.

LEAD: THE artist Judy Chicago sent advice to a White Plains High School student, Susie Korn, and made drawings on the letter. Another artist, Jenny Holzer, sent a list of her ''Truisms'' - ''Lack of charisma can be fatal''; ''Loving animals is a substitute activity'' - to Amy Whittle, while the sculptor Mary Frank drew figures on the envelope of her letter to Esmeralda

LEAD: Christine Noel Gleichauf and Peter Metz, Cornell University graduates, plan to marry in October, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Gleichauf of Rochester, have announced. Mr. Metz, 25 years old, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Metz of Freeport, L.I. Ms. Gleichauf, 25, received a master's degree in nutritional sciences from Cornell.

LEAD: REPORTS of the death of the office Christmas party have been greatly exaggerated. In county business circles it appears that when it comes to cutbacks in the budget, the Christmas party is the last to go.

LEAD: Forget what will or won't be done in the year coming up. Think of the past 12 months and the things that were done that left a happy glow of satisfaction. And give a smaller thought to the things that were not done, and possibly regretted.

LEAD: NIXEVILLE-BLER COURT, France, appears on no map, or in any atlas readily available to Americans, but I have a favorite Christmas story -actually a 20-minute interlude during the course of one Christmas day -that took place there. I don't yearn nostalgically for that day of yore, but when I think about it I feel nurtured, as though I am slaking a tremendous thirst.
LEAD: A Maryland judge injured on Friday when a pipe bomb exploded at his Hagerstown apartment was reported to be in good condition today by a spokeswoman for Washington County Hospital.

LEAD: Dr. Theresa Felicita Pearse, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Pearse of New York, London and Lodz, Poland, and Kurt Alexander Eichenwald, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Heinz F. Eichenwald of Dallas, plan to marry in July.

LEAD: TO THE EDITOR: Has anyone replicated Robert Jahn's experiments in the area of psychokinesis? If they are as carefully designed as he claims, anyone should be able to set them up and get similar results. Has Professor Jahn allowed an outsider who is knowledgeable about computers, statistics and laboratory loopholes to observe his experiments?

LEAD: rrConsidering their small population, the East Germans have performed an athletic miracle through individual and organized effort, and that is to be lauded without cynicism. Yet, the same mind-set in their political system has caused all the discontent that has so rapidly risen to the surface this year.

LEAD: With the collapse of President Nicolae Ceausescu's regime in Rumania, Stalinism, the system of incorporating Communist power in a single, all-powerful leader, has crumbled in every Eastern European Communist country except Albania.

LEAD: The engagement of Regina Steuart Green, a daughter of Mrs. Frederick John Green Jr. of Baltimore and the late Mr. Green, to Richard Paul Rule, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Roderick Rule of Sarasota, Fla., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother. A February wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Rev. Kathleen Gail McCombe Rochester, the pastor of the First United Methodist Church in East Hampton, L.I., and David Paul Turnbole, a service-order writer for Parkview Auto Sales in Watertown, N.Y., plan to be married in June. The prospective bride is a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John H. McCombe of Stuart, Fla.

LEAD: The engagement of Ellen Zuckerman to Zachary Ben Mayo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Mayo of Manhasset and East Hampton, L.I., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Zuckerman of Englewood, N.J., and East Hampton. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: International yachting officials in London paved the way last month for professional sailors to compete in the 1992 Olympics. But the road to eligibility has changed in light of a new communique from the International Olympic Committee.

LEAD: The surgery on Ken O'Brien's right shoulder went as planned on Friday and the Jets' quarterback is expected to be ready for training camp next summer. In any event, he is not going to be permitted to throw in minicamp next April.

LEAD: FAR north of China's Great Wall, a city of crystalline sculptured ice emitting colored light transforms long frozen winters into a fantasyland. The annual Ice Lantern Festival in Harbin, capital of the northeastern border province of Heilungkiang and once a city of many Russians, celebrates the lunar new year like no other place in

LEAD: THEY were built around the turn of the century, to house the horse-drawn equipment that firefighters used to keep Connecticut's towns safe. Now, many vintage firehouses are gone, but a few scattered throughout Connecticut have been transformed into museums, restaurants and, in at least one case, a home.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: After beer brawls and 30 arrests at Stanford University's last football game of the season, the university is considering banning alcohol at all its sport events.
LEAD: KEVIN KEARNEY began his career as a lobbyist with efforts to preserve open space on Long Island, but lately he has been seeking to expand the range of a more conspicuous breed of nature buff.
LEAD: STAMFORD will ring in the new year and decade with a New Year's Eve celebration that will be the largest one-day performing arts festival ever held in the state.

LEAD: WHEN the Blue-Gray All-Star football game is played in Montgomery, Ala., tomorrow, Charlie Finley will be glowing like a Yuletide log. As owner of the Oakland Athletics, Finley gave baseball brightly colored uniforms and white shoes and the designated hitter and even lobbied for an orange baseball.

LEAD: IT WAS A YEAR OF POLITICAL UPHEAVAL overseas and natural disasters at home. Television brought close the drama of the worldwide impulse for freedom - the exhilarating days of protest in Beijing's Tiananmen Square that ended so painfully and the opening up of the hated Berlin Wall, along with the inspiring upsurges in Poland, Czechoslovakia, even Bulgaria.

LEAD: Scores of programs that provide clean needles or bleach to drug addicts to prevent transmission of the AIDS virus may fail because they overlook other routes of infection, according to new research and the observations of other experts.

LEAD: There are no decorations, no festivities in Bethlehem this Christmas. There will be church services for visitors, and six foreign choirs have come to sing in Nativity Square on Christmas Eve. But the people are staying silently in their homes. The holidays have been proclaimed a time of mourning and of protest.

LEAD: There is a long tradition of giving money, called Hanukkah gelt, to children during Hanukkah. Some believe the custom dates back to the original Hanukkah celebration when Judas Maccabaeus rededicated the Temple in Jerusalem. But most scholars feel these gifts of pocket change to children originated in Eastern Europe during the Middle Ages.

LEAD: To the Editor: Jake Barnes and Brett Ashley in ''The Sun Also Rises'' by Ernest Hemingway did not meet at the Deux Magots cafe in Paris, as Warren Obr said in his report on Paris hotels and restaurants. In Hemingway's novel, Barnes had been wounded in Italy in World War I and was invalided to a hospital in England.
LEAD: The deposed Rumanian Communist leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, included an estimated 40 members of his family in positions of power.

LEAD: April wedding plans for Catherine Ferrante di Ruffano and Ian Tapsall have been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Georgette D. Ferrante di Ruffano of Kingston, N.J. Miss Ferrante di Ruffano also is a daughter of Giovanni Ferrante di Ruffano of Bridgewater, N.J. Mr. Tapsall is a son of Mrs.

LEAD: TRYING to predict the future by looking back at the last year is very much like driving down a road while using the rear-view mirror to steer, as Allan Kay, a visionary at Apple Computer Inc. (his actual title is fellow), has noted. The task is all the harder in the computer industry, where the technology is always accelerating.

LEAD: Amy Sharon Isman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Isman of New City, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to David Aaron Appell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael N. Appell, also of New City. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Abraham P. Bloch, the bridegroom's great-uncle, and Rabbi Jackie Friedman, the bridegroom's cousin, at the Tammybrook Country Club in Cresskill, N
LEAD: Since Sunny Trefman [ ''Familiarity: Worth the Risk,'' Nov. 12 ] has bothered to comment on my essay, I would like to reply, partly because a correction is required.

LEAD: The American military commander here said today that his forces had begun to make significant progress in restoring order in Panama City and the countryside. But there was no indication that the American forces had made any progress toward one of their main goals, the capture of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the dictator who went into hiding when the Americans invaded this country four days ago.
LEAD: Congratulations to Barbara Klaus on her efforts to enhance the progress of good health for the general public.

LEAD: Top-ranked Ivan Lendl and John McEnroe head a field of 56 scheduled to play in the $1.5 million Skydome World Tennis event to be held Feb. 12-18. The tournament will mark the first time professional tennis is played at the Skydome and it is the first major event on the new Association of Tennis Professionals tour.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The editors' identification of Alfred Kazin on Dec. 10, with his review of Abraham Lincoln's writings, referred incorrectly to Mr. Kazin's book ''The Almighty Has His Own Purposes.'' It is in progress, not yet due for publication.
LEAD: The holly reds and pine greens of the holiday season are mirrored in one of the season's surprise fashion fads: Austrian loden garments and other Tyrolean wear.

LEAD: The modern dentist has many challenges in today's changing profession, not the least of which is overcoming patient fears. Deprecating sentiments set forth by unknowing and unappreciative individuals who themselves are beneficiaries of our care, skill and judgment only undermine the progress of the dental profession.

LEAD: An essay on Nov. 12 about writers and their sources of inspiration misattributed an account of the poet Hart Crane's boisterous behavior at parties. A reader has written to point out that the author of the account was Malcolm Cowley, not Malcolm Lowry.

LEAD: What happened? Morning in America, hole in the ozone, Oliver North, AIDS, terrorists, contras like Founding Fathers, $640 toilet seats, triumph of democracy, just say no. 1980 It's America vs. the Soviet Union, Khomeini, Castro, inflation and Jimmy Carter.
LEAD: Fearful of reviving its own domestic opposition, the Chinese leadership has kept much of the extraordinary change in Eastern Europe out of the press.

LEAD: THERE is something doubly affirming about the Forum Theater Group's staging of Stephen Sondheim's ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' which runs through next Sunday. It compels one to treasure Sondheim and to trust the Forum.

LEAD: IF Christmas is for children, then I am especially glad we are going to my brother's house in Trumbull to celebrate with his family, which includes two little boys. For this is the year of the empty nest, both of our offspring finally in college.

LEAD: Here's a sad statistic to remember on Christmas Eve: While about 20 percent of the nation's children are growing up in poverty, the figure in New York City is closer to 30 percent. Fifteen thousand of the city's youngsters are ''certified'' as homeless. Thousands still live under hazardous conditions in welfare hotels.
LEAD: ''Smile, Darn You, Smile'' is simply another unfunny attempt to degrade a profession which has unfairly taken more than its share of unthinking comedic criticism.

LEAD: VIRTUE, AS THE CHINESE SAYING goes, is not hereditary - and neither, to offer a paraphrase, is talent. Dynasties of the gifted might argue otherwise. But the explosion of exceptional dancing that marked 1989 had less to do with genes than with plain hard work - dedication and commitment from the performers.

LEAD: TEN correspondents of The New York Times, from countries as near as Mexico and as far away as Malaysia, were asked to select their favorite spots for a quick getaway on a winter weekend. Their choices include a beach where you can get some sun and a desert where it's best avoided, cozy inns and more rugged retreats, places to watch the water, watch the people, or be watched by tigers.

LEAD: A luxury rental apartment house is under construction on the site of a former A. & P. food market on the southwest corner of 79th Street and First Avenue in Manhattan. The project will have a base of 16 stories and a 28-story tower along the First Avenue side of the building, which will carry the address 350 East 79th
LEAD: San Francisco Feeling Pinch In Visitor Count
LEAD: FINAL WARNING Averting Disaster in the New Age of Terrorism. By Robert Kupperman and Jeff Kamen. 249 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

LEAD: Ion Iliescu, who announced the arrest of President Nicolae Ceausescu in Rumania today, is regarded by analysts and experts here as a rising leader who one day may become Rumania's head of state.

LEAD: Q. We have thermal windows in our country home, manufacturer unknown. On several windows, moisture is seeping in between the two panes of glass. Is there a way to clean out this moisture and reseal the windows?
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: I have been in practice for 31 years and am used to the dental profession being the brunt of jokes. Some material is even quite humorous.

LEAD: CHRISTMAS EVE is a night when many families drive around various Connecticut towns to view holiday displays, as they prepare to open presents tomorrow morning. But in Prospect, one family's display has attracted so many visitors and caused such a stir over traffic congestion that the Mayor put up ''no parking'' signs and added police patrols.

LEAD: Dr. Sidney S. Goldensohn, a psychoanalyst who was the director of mental health services for the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, H.I.P., before he retired earlier this year, died of complications from lymphoma on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old. Dr. Goldensohn, a native New Yorker, received his bachelor's and medical degrees from George Washington University and was a graduate of the William Alanson White Institute.
LEAD: The marriage of Martha Clara Vail and David Isaac Boonin took place last evening at Temple Beth David in Cheshire, Conn. Rabbis Steven Steinberg and Howard Kummer officiated.

LEAD: The United States used its radar-evading F-117 'Stealth fighter-bomber for the first time in the Panama invasion this week, the Defense Department said tonight.
LEAD: June wedding plans have been announced for Joanne Glaeberman and Jonathan Craig Hammond.

LEAD: A year after a four-pound plastic bomb blew Pan American World Airways Flight 103 out of Scotland's skies, a chain of luck, toil and sleuthing has led police officers to this university city, where a three-story apartment hides deep in a suburban cul-de-sac.
LEAD: THE following Christmas music events were omitted from an article that ran last week. All are free unless otherwise noted.

LEAD: For 20 years, Broward County ran its legal notices in The Broward Review, but after the newspaper published an article last year that was critical of the county sheriff, he canceled the advertising, taking his $35,000 a year in business elsewhere.

LEAD: Certainly dentistry, like any other field of endeavor is a fit subject for humor. This, I know, for I have had several dental humor articles published myself.

LEAD: IN ''Married to the Mob,'' Frank and Angela Demarco live in a modest but gaudily decorated Long Island home.
