LEAD: For aficionados of racing, winter is a time of discontent, of insignificant races and of memories of exactas that might have been. The Breeders' Cup, the last big event of the fall season, marks the edge of the racing doldrums, which extend until the trumpet sounds in Florida or California in February or

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Denys Raymond Carr of Normanton, Yorkshire, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Theresa Margaret Carr, to William Van Muran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Van V. Muran of Brookville and Southampton, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''JUAN DARIEN,'' THE PUPPET MUSICAL by Julie Taymor and Elliot Goldenthal, is an eloquent expression of the power of theatrical transformation, which in this case approaches transmutation. As the audience watches, objects and images shift and assume radically different, often metaphorical form. A jaguar cub is reborn as a boy (named Juan Darien), and, suffering at the hands of his fellow man, he is driven back to his beastly origins.

LEAD: The texture of a season is defined as much by the atmosphere around main events as by the events themselves, as much by the huge and ever-changing cast as by current art stars. Here are a few snapshots from a very personal album.

LEAD: HEIRESS: The Story of Christina Onassis. By Nigel Dempster. (Grove Weidenfeld, $17.95.) Pity Christina Onassis: all that money, but it couldn't buy her love. It was not for her lack of trying, however, and Nigel Dempster, a columnist for The London Daily Mail, tells all in ''Heiress.'' He divulges that a nearly 200-pound Onassis paid Luis Sosa Balsuado, an Argentine polo player, $1,000 a day for companionship and sex.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE Swatch watch doesn't tick; the picture on the Sony television is fuzzy; the mittens you sent your daughter from the mail-order house don't match. As the long-awaited unveiling of gifts gets under way this holiday season, a lot can - and often does - go wrong. What recourse do gift givers and recipients have?

LEAD: The College of Staten Island has unveiled its master plan for a $400 million campus designed by Edward Durell Stone Associates on the site of the old Willowbrook State School. The plan involves the construction of six new buildings and the renovation of 14 others at a 200-acre site near the center of the island off Victory

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Tomorrow is Christmas. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No collection, recycling, or street cleanings. Schools: Closed.

LEAD: The article ''Marrow Transplants More Available'' (Nov. 5) was an excellent report on important advances in cancer treatment in our state. It is heartening to know that there is new hope for patients with leukemia and lymphoma.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN 1984, CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG SAW SOMETHING IN HIS mind's eye. It was a train, standing still in a forest, puffing out steam into a silent, snowy night. Accustomed to being visited by such sights, Van Allsburg, an acclaimed children's book author and illustrator, calmly sat down at his drawing table and tugged at the edge of the image, seeking illumination.
LEAD: Mujur Stancu held a candle and wept yesterday as he sang and prayed in St. Dimitru's Church for the thousands of his countrymen who have been killed in Rumania this week.

LEAD: Anne Maree Lewin and Scott Alexander Frances were married yesterday at the Union League Club in New York by the Rev. Richard Davis Leonard of the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The bride is the daughter of John Charles Lewin of Townsville, North Queensland, Australia, and Wendy Maree Lewin of Brisbane, Queensland, Australia.

LEAD: THE National Basketball Association says it has no plans to reinstate Roy Tarpley. Tarpley, a Dallas Maverick forward, was suspended without pay by the league after he was arrested on Nov. 16 on charges of driving while intoxicated and resisting arrest.

LEAD: IT WAS THE YEAR OF PHOTOGRA-phy's sesquicentennial. A year that most museums spent celebrating the medium's past, while a courageous few tried to sort out its present. A year when the International Center of Photography launched a new, ambitious presence in midtown Manhattan and the Friends of Photography, in San Francisco, opened its long-awaited Ansel Adams Center.

LEAD: Experts on Rumania and international relations agree that the army will continue to play a crucial role as popular unrest propels the country toward change, but they give differing appraisals of the prospects for democracy and improvement in the economy.

LEAD: The United States, Britain and France used their vetoes as permanent members of the Security Council today to block a resolution criticizing the American invasion of Panama, although a majority of the Council's 15 members voted in favor.

LEAD: Prince Sihanouk, Cambodia's former chief of state, is a puzzlement. He says nothing wounds him more than the charge that he's an accomplice of Pol Pot, leader of the murderous Khmer Rouge. ''Pol Pot is like Hitler,'' he remarked in an interview with The Times's Steven Erlanger. ''Unless you kill him, you cannot oblige him to stop fighting and killing people.

LEAD: Arthur J. Brown, a retired business executive who was the first owner of the team now called the New Jersey Nets, died after suffering a heart attack Friday at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Fort Lee.

LEAD: Christine L. Frissora, a student at the Cornell University Medical College, and Dr. Scott A. Rodeo, a resident in orthopedic surgery at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York, are planning a June wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Frissora of Mount Sunapee, N.H., have announced.

LEAD: The day the tree came to stay the snow fell down with a hissing sound. The children saw each flake, for just a minute, sticking to the car windows, and then they melted and were gone. When the car climbed the big hill to the farm where they always found their Christmas tree, the wind whistled around them, and they felt warm behind the glass.

LEAD: WALK WITH THE SICKLE MOON. By Helen Norris. (Birch Lane/Carol Publishing, $15.95.) A misty coastal town in the north of France. A lonely but attractive American widow. An attractive but lonely local doctor. A quest. It's autumn in Montreuil, nine years after World War II has ended, and it seems that romance is as inevitable as rain.

LEAD: THE shrinking space requirements of tenants in nearly every office district in Manhattan are pushing increasing amounts of sublet space onto an already soft office market, real estate professionals say.

LEAD: THE 1970's were not all bad by any means. But by the time 1979 was entering its final weeks, feelings of gloom were so heavy that even some of President Carter's detractors had to admit he had a point: the country was suffering from a bad case of malaise. Sometimes it seemed that the decade would never end.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Howland Auchincloss Fowler of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanna Louise Fowler, to Eric Carl Jonsson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Rey Jonsson of Honolulu. An August wedding is planned. Miss Fowler graduated from the National Cathedral School for Girls and Princeton University and expects to receive an M.B.A.

LEAD: WHEN it was young, the great house commanded a panoramic view of what was once the northern East Meadow (now the Town of North Hempstead) between two arms of the Sound, an area from which farmers' produce was shipped out to 18th-century markets on the Island and in New York and New England.

LEAD: In the Kindergarten of the Heart Small boys sometimes have a finer perception of femininity than grown men. Here's an infant voluptuary from ''The Snows of Yesteryear: Portraits for an Autobiography'' by Gregor von Rezzori (Knopf).

LEAD: At the Dix Hills (N.Y.) Jewish Center, Lisa Sharon Brier, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin S. Brier of Plainview, L.I., was married last evening to Peter David Cole, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Cole of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Stanley Wernick officiated.

LEAD: DENISON HATCH is a junk mail connoisseur. Stacks of cheese log catalogues, record club offers and vacuum cleaner deals fill a basement office in his Stamford home from floor to ceiling. File cabinets spill over with solicitations for such collectibles as Princess Diana porcelain dolls, Lady Liberty wristwatches and Dr.

LEAD: There are as many versions of picadillo as there are regions of Mexico. Some call for picadillo, a mixture of ground meat, spices and some kind of fruit, to be made with beef or pork. Most call for raisins as the sweetening agent, but one calls for pineapple, and another is made with eggs. Some are spiced with hot chilies; some are not.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stanislas M. Yassukovich of London and Bibury, Gloucestershire, England, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Tatyana Alexandra Eugenie Yassukovich, to Charles Stewart Dubow, the son of Isabella Breckinridge Dubow of Washington and Arthur M. Dubow of East Hampton, L.I. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: PORTRAIT OF DAVID HOCKNEY By Peter Webb. Illustrated. 289 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $35.

LEAD: THE DIVERTED DREAM: Community Colleges and the Promise of Educational Opportunity in America, 1900-1985. By Steven Brint and Jerome Karabel. (Oxford University, $24.95.) The United States sends more of its young people to college than any other nation in the world. Approximately half of them are enrolled in community colleges, where they are channeled into low- and mid-level technical and vocational programs.

LEAD: IN ITS FORMER LIFE, SAN PATRICIO'S WAS A HIGH-SCHOOL band hall. Even now, a placard announcing Sunday Mass at noon and a white wooden cross over the front door are the only outward and visible signs that this mustard-colored square structure with its gray tar-paper roof is a church. A landscape of bare fields, punctuated by cattle, oil rigs, low, crawling cactus and mesquite stretches out from the church and the town of Throckmorton, Tex.

LEAD: IT is obvious that it is the king around here. Drive past its mammoth corporate headquarters a few miles south of downtown, and you spy the people filing in, day after day, to board the bus tour, thread through the brewery and meander around the stable to gawk at the famous Clydesdales. Many of the faithful then pay further obeisance by snapping up souvenir shirts and mugs at the tour center and then - why not?

LEAD: Melvin Emerson Dawley, who spent 36 years with Lord & Taylor, the last 13 of them as the retail chain's chief executive officer, died Thursday at his home in Mountain Lake, a residential community in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 84 years old and, until a few months ago, also had a home in Bronxville, N

LEAD: As the shopping days till Christmas dwindled down to a precious few, New Yorkers did what comes naturally to New Yorkers. They scurried about midtown in every direction, creating a sort of free-form street theater, with every stroller an actor, every block a stage.

LEAD: FOR the first 12 years of his marriage, Paul Maccio of New Haven worked 15 hours a day as a plumbing and heating mechanic. When he returned home, he expected to find a dinner prepared by his wife, Lisa, on the table, clean socks in his drawer and the evening newspaper next to his favorite chair. But those days are long gone.

LEAD: THIS is how a $150-a-night hotel room became an $85-a-night room: Last October, planning a trip to San Diego, I called the Sheraton Harbour Island Hotel for rate information. The reservations clerk said the standard room rate was $150. I plunged ahead:
LEAD: MY thumb was always in my mouth. My parents weren't mean about trying to break me of the habit, but they did use fear tactics.
LEAD: A June wedding is planned by Caroline Lovell McMullen and David Van Scoyoc Hemphill, the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. David Rule Pyott of Alexandria, Va., has announced.

LEAD: In the Nov. 26 article on the eruv in Atlantic Beach, the reader gets the false impression from Mr. Woolfe and Mrs. Leistner that the eruv is the cause for people walking ''four and five abreast'' in the streets.

LEAD: DEADLINE. By Tom Stacey. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) This very brief, sometimes annoying and often compelling adventure novel by a real Fleet Street foreign correspondent, which features a fictional Fleet Street correspondent, raises some essential questions about their profession. Is the foreign correspondent (or the local reporter, for that matter) a keen-eyed, sharp-minded observer of life, the public's representative at rebellions and earthquakes?

LEAD: FOR SOME CHILDREN, THE question is as innocent as the birds and the bees: ''What did you do in the war, Daddy?'' But for the American writer Joe Eszterhas, that question was never innocent. It was one of the central terrors of his childhood, of growing up in the shadow of the Holocaust.

LEAD: A WALK through South River is a stroll through New Jersey's past. Main Street still has a 5 & 10, a Chinese laundry and a barber shop with a barber pole out front.

LEAD: The new City Charter that the voters approved last month greatly increases the powers of the New York City Council. It also enlarges the need to scrutinize the Council's performance.

LEAD: A man tried in vain to save his family from a fire that destroyed their trailer home today, the police said. The man, Robert E. Thomas, 27 years old, had gotten up to go to the bathroom just as the fire started at 7:20 A.M., the police said. He ran outside and survived, but his wife, Heather, 27, and the couple's three sons, Robert Jr., 6; James, 5, and Christopher, 2, died, the state police said.

LEAD: This was in the summer of 1961, while Billy Martin was serving what would turn out to be the first of many sentences of exile from New York. He was finishing up as a player with the Minnesota Twins, wearing a gray road uniform in his old ball park, Yankee Stadium.

LEAD: Harold Ellis Klue, a principal at the Riverdale Country School for Boys for 29 years, died on Monday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

LEAD: The Bush Administration said today that it would ask several European countries to freeze more than $10 million in drug-related assets that the ousted Panamanian strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, is believed to have deposited in their banks.

LEAD: The sadness of Billy Martin, who died Monday on an icy road near his farm in upstate New York, is the sadness of a badly disconnected life. Inside a baseball stadium he came as close as he ever did to joy and self-control, even when he was railing against umpires and defeat. But outside lay another world that he never seemed to grasp and certainly couldn't control, a world in which his pugnacity, combined with alcohol, produced behavior as pathetic as it was predictable.

LEAD: Patrick Ewing scored a season low of 11 points tonight as the Knicks ran their winning streak to seven games by defeating the Miami Heat, 100-94. The Knick center also had his poorest shooting night from the field, making only 4 of 18 shots.

LEAD: Catherine M. Kelly, an executive secretary at The New York Times from 1953 to 1970, died of a stroke Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. She was 66 years old and lived in Cliffside Park, N.J.

LEAD: WHICH is more important, where a wine comes from, or the grape from which it is made? In California, it's the grape. A wine is a cabernet sauvignon or a zinfandel or a chardonnay. In France, it's the opposite. We know the place - Chateau Latour, for example - and care little about the grapes from which the wine is made.

LEAD: Certain rulers have the ability to drive Presidents right up the White House wall. These are unsavory rulers. Ayatollah Khomeini was an unsavory ruler. So was General Noriega. That's why President Bush sent an army to toss him out.

LEAD: The police stormed a cell block controlled by drug traffickers holding 18 hostages. Six traffickers were killed and five hostages wounded, officials said today. All hostages were released, and the situation at the La Picota jail in southern Bogota returned to normal, a Justice Department spokesman said.

LEAD: NEW YEAR'S EVE in my household has always been a time of great abundance but at the same time utmost simplicity. My memories of New Year's Eve in France focus on the grand roast fillet of beef with winter vegetables.

LEAD: Landmark Ventures Inc. said it would acquire 54 venture-capital partnerships from Cigna Venture Capital Inc. for more than $100 million. The partnerships have 1,200 investments in nearly 800 companies. Landmark, previously known as Technology Transitions Inc., manages about $60 million in 25 technology-based growth companies that include computer-based systems, software and support services and advanced electronics.

LEAD: SINCE she does not drive, Malvina Azzi cannot get to George's Bakery as often as she would like. But sometimes Mrs. Azzi, 78 years old, persuades one of her four sons to drive her the 30 miles down the Merrimac River to George's, in the gritty old mill town of Lawrence, Mass. There she buys the ingredients she needs to cook her favorite Lebanese dishes, rich and buttery, meat-filled celebration foods, aromatic with cinnamon, allspice and coriander.

McLucas, who has been with the commission for 12 years, as the agency's chief enforcement officer. Mr. Breeden also announced the formation of an enforcement unit to protect individual investors against fraud at banks and savings institutions.
LEAD: Doug Harvey, who won the Norris Trophy as the National Hockey League's top defenseman seven times from 1955-62, died today in a Montreal hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: A retired police officer who was facing major heart surgery fatally shot his ailing wife because he was afraid he could not take care of her and did not want her to suffer anymore, the authorities say.
LEAD: * Otis K. Henderson 2d has been named advertising director of Instructor magazine, published by Scholastic Inc.

LEAD: From drippingly fat bank accounts in Switzerland to meat scales made of gold, the reported plunder and greed of Nicolae Ceausescu and his family is starting to be laid before a shocked and disgusted Rumanian people.

LEAD: Ku Klux Klan groups say they have begun a campaign to rid Lakeland's streets of crack dealers. But the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the police say they are viewing the campaign with suspicion.

LEAD: Joel R. Jacobson, New Jersey's first energy commissioner and an outspoken public official, died early today at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston. He had been admitted Friday with severe chest pains. He was 71 years old and lived in South Orange.

LEAD: BEVERAGES, like foods, have intimate links with the seasons. Icy blends of rum and fruit juice, for example, are ideal for the dog days of summer. The coming of winter provides a long-awaited excuse to make special drinks usually reserved for the holidays: wassail, hot mulled wine and eggnog. The days don't seem quite so cold, or the nights quite so long, with a sustaining mug of holiday cheer.

LEAD: FOR children who give ''the fisheye'' to salmon en croute, the Inn at Essex offers a special buffet at Sunday brunch: a small table spread with chicken fingers, pizza, peanut butter cookies and other foods attractive to young palates. And one weekend each month, the young guests are invited to help prepare the brunch in the hotel's bakeshop.

LEAD: A New York City police officer was shot and slightly wounded last night in a foot chase that started with a report of shots fired at Lefrak City in Elmhurst, where a security guard also was wounded, the police said.

LEAD: AFTER-CHRISTMAS REMEMBERED

LEAD: ''The sentence was definitive and was carried out.'' So ended the announcement on Rumanian radio of the Christmas Day execution by firing squad of Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife. It is hard to feel pity for the Communist autocrat responsible for the wanton massacre of his ill-used people. Yet summary justice is a treacherous substitute for rule of law.
LEAD: THE last few months have been terrible times for bank stocks, as losses from real estate lending at some New England banks have raised fears of similar problems in other regions.

LEAD: Rumania's new Prime Minister, Petre Roman, rates in the Communist world as something of an aristocrat - his father, Valter Roman, was a prewar member of Rumania's then-tiny Communist Party who fought in the International Brigades in the Spanish Civil War.

LEAD: President Bush signed an executive order today carrying out legislation raising top Government salaries by up to 35 percent next year and giving all Federal workers a 3.6 percent cost-of-living pay increase. House salaries will rise from $89,500 to $96,600 in 1990, while Senate salaries climb from $89,500 to $98,400.

LEAD: New York City has begun to reverse a legacy of physical decline. Over the last decade, with money to spend and a new emphasis on rebuilding New York rather than adding to it, city officials have made major improvements in the physical environment.

LEAD: Dec. 15: Demonstrators ring a church in Timisoara, in western Rumania, to prevent security forces from arresting a clergyman who was active in promoting the rights of ethnic Hungarians. Dec. 16-17: Security forces open fire on thousands of demonstrators in Timisoara, who have expanded their protest to demand freedom and a better life.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has decided to go to Lithuania soon to consult with rank-and-file Communist Party members about the Lithuanian party's decision to break from Moscow, several people who attended an emergency party meeting here said today. The two-day meeting of the national party leadership ended without agreement on how to address the problem.

LEAD: A dispute between the chairman of the L. E. Myers Company and a primary shareholder may lead to a proxy fight for control of the electrical construction concern, based in Oak Brook, Ill. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing last week, Leonard Chavin, a Chicago real estate investor with 19 percent of Myers's outstanding shares, said he had nominated another representative to the company's board at Myers's 1990 annual meeting.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: Now starts the 21st century, argues the Israeli philosopher Yirmiyahu Yovel. The 20th century was not only brutish but short. It started in 1914, with the conflict President Woodrow Wilson called ''the war to end wars.'' It ends, Mr. Yovel claims with some intellectual justification, in 1989. This year, the most heavily armed parts of the world learned that force is not strength.

LEAD: The corruption scandal that marred Mayor Edward Koch's third term made it easy to forget that he brought to city government some of the finest public officials ever to serve New York. Those who worked tirelessly for the people of New York far outnumbered the losers. Here are a just a few who have earned the city's gratitude.

LEAD: The United States Government is giving the International Red Cross $500,000 to buy medical supplies for victims of the fighting in Rumania and is considering plans to send more aid, Bush Administration officials said today.

LEAD: The Jets' general manager, Dick Steinberg, officially cleaned house today. He dismissed Coach Joe Walton and his 10 assistants, accepted the resignation of Mike Hickey, whose college drafts had provided the bulk of the Jets' players, and reduced the role of Jim Royer, who evaluated and signed pro personnel.
LEAD: * ASEA A.B., Sweden, a heavy equpment maker, said it had sold its ABB Electric Inc. unit to Magnetek Inc., Los Angeles, which makes transformers, for $54 million.
LEAD: * Colt Industries, the New York-based industrial manufacturing company, promoted Paul R. Kuhn to president of its Menasco Aerosystems division.
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company announced a voluntary recall of more than 36,000 of Aerostar vans and Ranger trucks today, citing possible brake or throttle defects.

LEAD: By opening his door to Panama's fugitive strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Papal Nuncio in Panama served both a church mission and a practical need. But now the Bush Administration, in ''extraordinarily tough terms,'' pressures the Vatican to expel the general and further protests that it was ''totally inappropriate'' to have sheltered him at all.

LEAD: As the diplomatic impasse over the fate of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega continued, businesses and government offices opened here today and other normal activities resumed for the first time since an American invasion deposed the military leader a week ago.

LEAD: Earle Palmer Brown, a marketing communications agency based in Bethesda, Md., has established a Southeast division comprising its Atlanta, Tampa and Miami offices. The chairman of the division will be Alf Nucifora, formerly president of the Atlanta office. Don Hofmann, president of the Tampa office, was named president of the division.

LEAD: Public television's series ''The Metropolitan Opera Presents'' is opening its 1989-90 season tonight -on Channels 13 and 49 at 8 o'clock - with Verdi's ''Aida.'' This year-old Sonja Frisell production, conducted by James Levine, was taped at a Saturday matinee performance on Oct. 7. Once again the distinguished series, which started out as ''Live From the Met,'' meets its obligations quite grandly.
LEAD: Sir Lennox Berkeley, an eminent British composer perhaps best known for his Stabat Mater choral work, died on Tuesday. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: Israeli warplanes bombed and apparently destroyed a Lebanese Communist Party base south of Beirut today shortly after a ground attack by an elite paratroop unit on another Communist Party camp in southern Lebanon, the army said.

LEAD: Dr. George J. Becker, an author of books on writers and literary criticism and a retired chairman of the English department at Swarthmore College, died on Friday in a nursing home in Bellingham, Wash., after a long illness. He was 81 years old. Dr. Becker was on Swarthmore's faculty for 25 years, heading its English department from 1953 to 1970, when he transferred to Western Washington University.

LEAD: Cuba called today for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to hear its complaint that American forces in Panama have surrounded the ambassador's residence there and are harassing its diplomats.

LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh said today that India will bar all purchases from the Swedish arms manufacturer Bofors until the company reveals the names of Indians to whom it apparently paid kickbacks in a 1986 arms contract.
LEAD: Long a national leader in preserving open space, New York State is in danger of falling behind as it rapidly runs out of money to buy environmentally sensitive lands.

LEAD: EVEN at this time of year, when everyone is doing it, predicting the future is almost as dangerous as making resolutions: it is almost impossible to be successful at either. Year-end wrap-ups, on the other hand, hold no such uncertainty. They provide a sense of satisfaction for those who do the wrapping, and also for those who have posed the questions.

LEAD: Thomas B. Ross is leaving biNBC News, where he is a senior vice president, for Hill & Knowlton Inc., the public relations and public affairs subsidiary of the WPP Group, where he will be a senior vice president and global director of media relations. Mr. Ross began his career as a journalist, and from 1977 to 1981 he was Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors said today that they hoped that their drug-trafficking case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega would be strengthened after the jailing in Miami of a close associate of the deposed Panamanian strongman.

LEAD: Troubled by problem real estate loans and mounting losses, the Bank of New England Corporation announced yesterday that its chief executive would step down and that the bank would continue to seek some kind of reorganization, possibly including the sale of the bank.
LEAD: African officials say they are concerned that with attention focused on Eastern Europe, sub-Saharan Africa is likely to be relegated far down on the global agenda.

LEAD: Time Warner Inc. disclosed today that two class-action lawsuits had been filed in the last month by Warner Communications Inc. shareholders challenging the amount of money that they would receive in the second stage of Warner's $14 billion merger with Time Inc.

LEAD: Samuel Beckett, a towering figure in drama and fiction who altered the course of contemporary theater, died in Paris on Friday at the age of 83. He died of respiratory problems in a Paris hospital, where he had been moved from a nursing home. He was buried yesterday at the Montparnasse cemetery after a private funeral.
LEAD: With a final sales flurry, the 1989 Christmas season for retailers ended on an upbeat note, as expected.

LEAD: Benny Binion, owner of the Horseshoe Casino in Las Vegas whose flamboyant promotional efforts included an annual monthlong ''World Series of Poker'' for high-stakes players, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at Valley Hospital in Las Vegas, where he lived. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: A clandestine gunpowder factory exploded today in northeastern Brazil, killing four people, injuring more than 100 and destroying nearby homes. Fire-rescue workers dragged more than 100 people from the wreckage of their homes after the blast in the city of Feira de Santana, more than 900 miles northeast of Rio de Janeiro.
LEAD: ''DO you think,'' said the engineer, always a son but now a father himself, ''do you think you could find the little Brooks Brothers suit for our young man to wear to his cousin's wedding?''
LEAD: Joseph A. Livingston, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter whose column appeared in more than 50 newspapers nationwide, died Monday at the age of 84.
LEAD: A fire that killed 16 people in a high-rise retirement center started on the first floor, but investigators have not narrowed the cause, city fire officials said today.

LEAD: The United States military headquarters here, which has portrayed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as an erratic, cocaine-snorting dictator who prays to voodoo gods, announced today that the deposed leader wore red underwear and availed himself of prostitutes.

LEAD: With his trim haircut, scholarly eyeglasses and intent stare, Moses Pendleton looks like one of Chekhov's impoverished young intellectuals. But the choreographer is clearly a product of his time.

LEAD: JOAN and Lydia Wilen are headed toward the big time. Sales of their books, ''Chicken Soup and Other Folk Remedies'' (Fawcett, 1984) and ''More Chicken Soup and Other Folk Remedies'' (Fawcett, 1986), are soaring, and the sisters, who place their ages ''somewhere between Brooke Shields and Joan Collins,'' are the toast of the talk-show circuit.

LEAD: Bertha Czaczkes is 90 years old and lives alone in an apartment in Washington Heights. Her sister Serafine, the closest person to her in the world, passed away long ago. Yellowing pictures of the two of them are all about.

LEAD: The British Library has found a new weapon in the campaign to save crumbling books: gamma rays. Book preservationists around the world now use alkaline baths or sprays to save important old volumes damaged by the acid in paper and inks. But these methods can involve painstaking page-by-page applications and an average cost of up to $480 a book, said Marie Jackson, national preservation officer of the British Library, the largest in Britain.

LEAD: A group of men, apparently trying to show that a drug location was their territory, fired randomly as they drove down a Queens street Monday night, killing a teen-ager and mortally wounding a pregnant woman, the police said.

A towel was draped over his shoulders, ready to be flung off the moment the coach called for him to save the night, to be thrust into the thick of it.

LEAD: Within a few months the Energy Department plans to end its decades-old practice of paying all bills, including environmental fines and other penalties, incurred by the companies that run the nation's 17 nuclear weapons plants, department officials say.

LEAD: The Westchester County Executive said today that he would neither sign nor veto the county's 1990 budget, meaning that the budget, which mandates more than 600 layoffs, will take effect on Monday.
LEAD: George J. Couri, the chairman of Couristan Inc., an importer of floor coverings, died of lung cancer on Tuesday at his home in the Dyker Heights section of Brooklyn. He was 77 years old.

Manuel Antonio Noriega.

LEAD: The preseason scouting report on Seton Hall was that the Pirates were strong up front but woefully inexperienced in the backcourt with a freshman, Terry Dehere, and a junior-college transfer, Oliver Taylor, running the show.

LEAD: The famous Zen rock garden of Ryoanji temple is a model of austere, tranquil beauty. But many of the Japanese who come to view it these days arrive in BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes. The men often wear Armani suits, the women carry Chanel handbags and both may wear Tiffany jewelry. They are of a generation that seeks status rather than tranquillity, and this has transformed the place of the rock garden in Japan; owning one has become an important new status symbol.
LEAD: The chance to help the elderly who are frail and isolated and living with little income or companionship has motivated many people to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
LEAD: The Arab press has greeted the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu with an unusual outpouring of editorial warnings that the fate of Arab dictators may resemble that of the executed Rumanian tyrant.

LEAD: I AM trying to decide when it all went wrong in New York, when it was that one could no longer walk down a street without feeling guilty about having a destination. The people I see every day don't have a destination. ''See you around,'' they say to one another, and sure enough they do. They are like pigeons, rising suddenly to wheel in the air, then settling back on the same old perches.
